HEADLINE: The Call of the Lox and Due Process at Zabar's;
A Salmon Slicer Claims Discrimination; Her Employers See Only Mangled Fish

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
This is a tale of art and commerce, of sex discrimination and smoked fish, of due process and Zabar's.
On one side is a determined young woman seeking justice because her salmon-slicing skills, she believes, have been cruelly impugned. On the other is her employer, an exacting man who believes that anyone who mangles a nice piece of fish should not be paid the same as more seasoned counterparts -- regardless of whether they all happen to be men. 
 And making the determination last week whether Murray Klein dismissed Eleanor Wolper or whether she quit her job was Judge Dennis Aloysius Dooley, who is singularly qualified to know a fish story when he hears one.
To generations of slicers and buyers, an elegant sliver of fish is art on a waxed paper canvas. It's a stressful situation: in the demanding world of deli galleries, everyone's a critic. As Milton Bauman of Murray's Sturgeon Shop put it, "This particular store is very particular."
The artist, however, is almost never a woman. Murray Klein, 71, a co-owner of Zabar's, on Broadway and West 80th Street, acknowledged this situation, but said that he was not to blame. "Women are sensitive about the smell of fish," he said. "Men aren't. Women don't like the stink on their clothes."
Ms. Wolper, an earnest but easily flustered woman of 27, does not fit the image of a barrier breaker. Her peripatetic resume reflects both the volatility of the food-service industry and her restless search for the perfect job.
But she has the fever. Raised on the Lower East Side, she would often travel to Zabar's to watch the salmon slicers.
"I have an affinity for cutting salmon," she said wistfully as she waited last week for her case to be called. "I get chills thinking about it -- it's so beautiful to watch. And Zabar's was always the best." As she lifted her wrist to slice air salmon, she launched into the relative merits of Norwegian versus Scotch.
Last August Ms. Wolper passed Mr. Klein's do-or-die test -- a shift behind the counter on a typical wild-eyed Saturday. Soon she became something of a novelty herself at Zabar's. She was featured in several publications and developed her own coterie of regulars, some of whom, said one counterman, still ask about her, though she left in April. Sam Cohen, 79, the Dean of Slicers who has been behind the counter for 43 years, said Ms. Wolper worked out just fine.
Tourists would photograph her. One, noting that she was unusual for a slicer not only because she was a woman but because she was left-handed, described her technique as "French style."
Even Mr. Klein said that for a beginner, Ms. Wolper was pretty good. The customers benefited, he said, because "she wasn't as rude as the men."
But Mr. Klein and Ms. Wolper disagree about just how stylish a slicer she was. Once Mr. Klein scooped up a discarded salmon skin from a bucket, yelling at her because there was too much flesh left. She had been, in the vernacular, hacking up the fish.
"I said it wasn't my skin!" said Ms. Wolper, her cheeks flushing. "He told me to calm down."
Mr. Klein, a co-owner of Zabar's for more than 30 years, is so obsessed with the place that he cannot understand why Ms. Wolper would quit her exalted post. But quit, he said, is what she did.
Ms. Wolper has two actions against Zabar's. After, as she says, Mr. Klein dismissed her because she wasted too much fish and wanted too big a raise, she filed a claim of discrimination with the New York State Division of Human Rights. In it, she said she had been grossly underpaid: that even after she got a 50-cent raise to $8.50 an hour, her colleagues, all men, were earning up to $22 an hour. (A counterman says $22 includes overtime.) That investigation is pending.
After she left, she collected unemployment benefits. In June, the state Labor Department cut them off because Zabar's reported that she had left her job voluntarily. If she could not prove otherwise, she might have to return the $1,980 she had received. A hearing on that decision was held one afternoon last week at the department's Brooklyn office before Mr. Dooley, an administrative law judge.
Mr. Klein and his lawyer, Eugene G. Eisner, showed up to challenge her appeal.
A clerk yelled out: "Eleanor Wolper versus Zabras!"
Mr. Klein looked aghast. "He doesn't know from Zabar's?" he muttered to Mr. Eisner. "Oy! We're in bad shape."
In a hearing room so small it could barely accommodate the judge's desk and a table, Mr. Klein and Mr. Eisner sat across from Ms. Wolper, who could not afford a lawyer, but did bring her mother, Marjorie, a forceful woman who was very angry with Mr. Klein.
Ms. Wolper testified that last fall she asked for a $6 raise to $14 an hour -- "it was supposed to be a bargaining position," she whispered. By January, a manager promised he would intercede on her behalf. On Friday, April Fool's Day, the new rate finally came through: 50 cents more an hour. Her mother told her to march back into Zabar's and talk to Mr. Klein.
"I lose money on you," Ms. Wolper testified that Mr. Klein yelled. "You hack up the fish. Get out of my store."
Mr. Klein told a different story. He said the argument occurred on April 2, and so she must have quit, because he would never dismiss someone on a Saturday. "It's our busiest day," he testified. "I only fire people after the weekend." Ms. Wolper resigned in a rage over her salary, he said, leaving him perilously short-handed.
As these things go, the hearing was unusually probing. Mr. Eisner demanded the identity of the manager. Ms. Wolper refused, saying she feared he would be punished. He cross-examined her narrowly: about her past experience at Balducci's, about when she applied for and canceled her health insurance.
Mr. Eisner kept producing documents that he argued should be admitted into evidence because of their relevance to Ms. Wolper's state of mind and credibility. "I loved my job!" Ms. Wolper stammered, her eyes filling with tears.
Judge Dooley handed Ms. Wolper some napkins. Neatly trimming away the excess issues, the judge announced that the dispute came down to this: he said, she said.
Within the month he would issue his decision, he said, based on an evaluation of each party's demeanor and testimony. The disappointed party had the right to appeal.
Ms. Wolper and her mother, looking shellshocked, left quickly. Mr. Klein, looking equally perturbed, lingered.
"You haven't been to my store?" he said to the judge in a wheedling tone. "There is one God and one Zabar's!"
Mr. Eisner, alarmed, started tugging on his client's elbow.
Judge Dooley fixed Mr. Klein with a cool stare. "You can't fool me, Mr. Klein," he said. "When I was a boy I was a lox slicer at Pincus Appetizing in Long Beach, L.I. The owners used to say, 'He's one of the goyim and he knows how to cut salmon like that?' "
The legal slicer leaned across his desk. "I never hacked up a salmon in my life," he said.

HEADLINE: Louis H. Bean, 98, Analyst Best Known For 1948 Prediction

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Louis H. Bean, who was an Agriculture Department economist when he became nationally known for a book that predicted Harry S. Truman's surprise victory in the 1948 Presidential election, died on Friday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 98.
The cause was congestive heart failure, said his daughter, Elizabeth Fountain. 
 Mr. Bean, who had a master's degree in business administration from Harvard University, was an economic and political analyst over the years. He was a Government official from 1923 to 1953, mostly in the Agriculture Department. Later he was a private consultant for various clients until he was in his mid-80's. He also wrote on a variety of subjects.
He was an aide to the Secretary of Agriculture and did his political prognosticating in his spare time when his book "How to Predict Elections" came out in 1948. In that work, which is still in print, from Greenwood Press, he correctly forecast that voters would return Truman, who was generally seen as the underdog, to the White House. He also forecast the victory of the Democratic Party, which regained control of Congress at the same time.
Years later, no less an authority than Truman himself wrote, "Only Louis Bean, an economist of the Department of Agriculture, and a few others forecast any chance of a Democratic victory."
In 1948, Mr. Bean called his predicting technique the Bean Poll. It was described at the time as a complicated method of analyzing various sets of statistics, including characteristics of groups of voters and long-term voting trends. He kept on predicting election returns in the 1950's and 1960's, with a high degree of success.
Mr. Bean was born in Russia, came to the United States in 1906 and earned a bachelor's degree from the University of Rochester. He married Dorothy May Wile in 1923; she died in 1991.
In addition to his daughter, of Montross, Va., he is survived by a son, David, of London; a sister, Sarah Kizell of North Miami Beach, Fla.; six grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: A Life of Its Own

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Thirteen years ago, the plan to redevelop Times Square with four huge office towers was hatched as a grand design for urban renewal, something as ambitious as the United Nations or Lincoln Center, something that would bring civility and commerce to what had become a national icon of sleaziness and blight.
Since then, a building boom has gone bust, a torrent of lawsuits has derailed other large projects, and many of New York City's biggest development dreams have been scrapped. Mortimer B. Zuckerman's Columbus Circle project unraveled last month. And the 20-year-old effort to replace the West Side Highway was scaled back further last week to a plan for a riverfront boulevard. 
 But the Times Square project refuses to die. An agreement announced last week by the city, the state and Times Square developers makes it all the more likely that the four office towers will eventually be built on the same scale as was envisioned during the halcyon boom of the last decade.
Why the project survives as others have failed can be boiled down mainly to money. Too much has been invested to turn back.
 
The Risky Aspect
 Yet it also lives on courtesy of government sponsorship and tax breaks, and as such provides a case study of the risks a government takes when it commits its resources in a highly speculative real-estate market.
Even as the developers move ahead with the interim step of refurbishing the area's vacant storefronts, some New Yorkers, including people who supported the plan in the early 1980's, are questioning the need for office towers supported by huge tax breaks -- particularly on a block that seems to be springing to life on its own.
"There is a real renaissance, and shouldn't we be going with the flow?" said Michael T. Cohen, whose professional interests as president of the Williams Real Estate Company, a commercial brokerage in Manhattan, do not usually lead him to oppose new office buildings. "Times Square has already rediscovered itself as a mecca for tourism and entertainment."
Even William J. Stern, who a decade ago headed the state's Urban Development Corporation, the lead government agency in the project, has questions. "I don't think the government belongs in the business of developing office buildings," he said. "There may not be a way out of it, but we really ought to take another look at this project."
To be sure, such complaints are based on hindsight, looking back through a decade when New York City, and more particularly Times Square, were awash in economic changes that could not have been anticipated when the project was launched.
"You can't count the benefits to taxpayers," said Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project, an arm of the Urban Development Corporation.
Clear progress has been made toward two of the project's chief goals: reducing crime and shutting down pornography businesses that pervaded 42d Street. Pedestrians now confront a block that is decidedly less sinister, but eerily abandoned.
There are other signs of movement. The Walt Disney Company, for instance, has obtained an option to renovate the New Amsterdam Theater on 42d Street, and has joined a large New York City developer in a bid to build a new hotel at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue.
Officials say the improvements would not have been possible without the Times Square project, because it has provided money to condemn property.
"Does anybody think a private developer would have assembled 30 parcels on this site?" said Ms. Robertson, who reacted angrily to a recent report by the Municipal Art Society that the tax breaks pledged to George Klein and the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the developers, would amount to $1.5 billion to $4.2 billion after their towers are complete.
The tax breaks were intended to compensate the developers for the money it provided to the state to finance the condemnation process -- about $270 million so far.
The art society, which supported the Times Square plan in the 1980's, said the city and the state should now pay the developers back the money. If they still want to build their towers, the group said, no tax breaks should be offered.
But there appeared little chance last week that the city, the state or the Times Square developers would let their project unravel. After spending $270 million, Prudential and Mr. Klein will now be spending $22 million more as a result of last week's agreement.
That money will be used to fix up existing buildings, allowing stores and restaurants to move in.
It is the huge amount of money already invested that has given the project a life of its own. When the project was begun in 1981, city and state officials employed an urban renewal strategy that had been used in the construction of Lincoln Center, the United Nations and the World Trade Center. Because the buildings along 42d Street were owned by many landlords, and no private developer could be expected to buy them all out, the state would use its powers to condemn them.
But unlike other projects, where the city and the state raised the money for condemnation on their own, the Times Square project had a hitch that reflected the high finance of the 1980's. The money for condemnation would be paid by the developers, without any direct investment by the public, and the developers would be paid back through long-term tax breaks.
In 1981, that seemed to make sense, particularly because the price of condemnation was not expected to exceed $80 million. If the developers paid that much for the land, and built their towers swiftly, they could recoup their investment through tax reductions that would last no more than 20 years.
 
Times Change
 But the assumptions of the early 1980's changed radically by the end of the decade. Faced with dozens of lawsuits, the state's condemnation of property was delayed for years while Manhattan real-estate values soared, inflating the condemnation price and forcing the city and state to agree to tax breaks that would be far larger and extend far longer than anticipated. Now, no one knows how long they would last, because the benefits to the developers will depend in part on how much the value of the buildings and their rental income increases over decades. Some critics predict the tax breaks will last as long as 99 years.
By the end of the decade, the market for new offices had collapsed, leaving the developers with a plan to build four large buildings but few potential tenants to put in them.
On Tuesday, in announcing the interim agreement for the project, Mr. Klein said he expected that demand for new offices would continue to increase and that construction of the first of the four towers could begin in three to five years.
Mr. Cohen said that he also expected an improving market, and that some tenants, including entertainment companies and law firms, would find the proposed Times Square towers appealing. But he added that the neon lights and street activity that will return to 42d Street before any of the towers are built may prove a problem for Mr. Klein and the developers.
"There is no question the neon and glitter will limit the appeal of Times Square for corporate tenants," he said. "The tragedy here is that the developers have invested so much in a project that could be past the point of no return."

HEADLINE: Utility Gets New Rate Plan

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 7

 BODY:
The California Public Utilities Commission approved plans last week to make the San Diego Gas and Electric Company the nation's first energy utility to base rates on performance rather than costs.
The five-year plan allows rates to rise or fall annually with inflation, employee productivity and customer growth. It offers stockholders in the company greater profits if the company meets certain goals in safety, reliability, customer satisfaction and rate-cutting. 
 For the utility's 1.2 million customers in San Diego County and southern Orange County, the plan offers "the comfort level of knowing that the company now has an incentive to provide good service at reasonable costs and the most reliable service available," a spokesman for the utility, David Kusumoto, said.
But Michael Shames, executive director of the San Diego-based Utility Consumers' Action Network, said the company's rates were 36 percent above the national average and would not be lowered meaningfully by the new system.
Like commissions in most states, the Public Utility Commission has traditionally set gas and electricity rates so utilities can recover their reasonable operating and construction costs and a fixed profit.
As part of an overall effort to reduce regulatory controls, the commission has experimented with some performance-based rates.

HEADLINE: Notes Issue By Vietnam

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Aug. 7

 BODY:
Seeking huge injections of foreign capital for economic development, Vietnam will make its first foray into the international money markets late this year or early in 1995 with a $50 million issue of Euro floating-rate notes, a senior banker said on Friday.
The Bank for Foreign Trade, or Vietcombank, the country's largest state-owned commercial bank, will make the offering, the bank's deputy executive director, Vu Viet Ngoan, said. 
 The bank has selected the Standard Chartered Merchant Bank of Britain as broker for the issue and expects the notes will be issued on Asian and European markets and in New York, he said.
The issue, denominated in United States dollars, will be Vietnam's first attempt to raise money in international markets as part of a drive to attract $25 billion of international money -- mainly through direct investment and government aid -- by the year 2000. It intends to raise a similar sum domestically.
The Finance Ministry said a month ago that it was planning to issue Government bonds internationally and hoped to raise $2 billion to $3 billion by the turn of the century.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Clock Keeps Ticking and Two Sides Keep Staring

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Negotiators for baseball club owners and players expect to meet daily this week, but it will be a short workweek if they don't have anything new to talk about when they get to the critical topic: the game's economic system.
The players are set to walk out before Friday's games if the two sides don't work out a new collective bargaining agreement, and nothing has happened to suggest that either side has a new or different idea it will present to try to avert the strike. 
 There was a rumor during the weekend that the clubs were preparing a surprise proposal for Wednesday's session, the first one this week at which the owners' salary cap proposal is scheduled to be discussed. The rumored proposal involved some sort of payroll tax clubs would be charged depending on how much they spent on players' salaries.
But neither it nor any other new proposal will apparently find its way to the bargaining table Wednesday.
"I never heard of any such thing," Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief proposal maker, said yesterday when asked about the rumor. "I'm not preparing it. I never heard of it."
Bud Selig, the acting commissioner but also the owner of the low-revenue Milwaukee Brewers, said he was unaware of it, too. "The rumor is unfounded," he said by telephone from his office in Milwaukee.
Ravitch said he had nothing new planned for Wednesday. "I'm not negotiating with myself," he said.
The two sides will meet today to discuss elements of their expired agreement other than the issue that is at the heart of their dispute.
Ravitch and Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, made their fourth joint national television appearance yesterday, replying to the same questions with the same answers on "Meet the Press." They even rode to the airport together to return home, but that's about as close as they'll get this week.
"It seems to me," Fehr said after arriving home from Washington, "we're in a posture where they have predetermined dates when they'll be willing to negotiate, later this summer or next year. Until then, nothing we do matters -- unless we say we surrender. They're operating on a plan."
The owners, of course, deny that suggestion. What they do say repeatedly is they want the players to address their desire for cost certainty, which is the goal of their salary cap proposal.

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
More Like a Factory Than a National Trust

BYLINE: By Claire Smith 

 BODY:
IN the next four days you will read and hear the term "looming baseball players strike" a lot. You will also hear from a lot of grass-roots locales the term "fan boycott." And then there will be the obligatory calls for intervention by the President of the United States.
Only one of these notions should be given any credence at this point. And that is the players strike. For the players are scheduled to walk on Friday, and it appears that only intervention of the heavenly sort will stop that from happening. 
 The players have stood as one in opposition to the owners' salary cap proposal, the sort of unified defiance that caused owners to drop their ill-fated pay-for-performance proposal in favor of traditional solutions during the lockout of 1990. And the owners, still smarting from defeats like the one in 1990, are also boasting a heightened resolve, resulting in the current standoff.
With the two parties so thoroughly entrenched, it is left for others to look for solutions that, so far, resemble pipe dreams.
Oh, there are fan groups organizing boycotts. And if those boycotts are simply to show a general disgust, fine. But some boycott organizers are putting forth the proposition that they can and will affect the outcome of negotiations. The latter thinking is rooted in naivete over the role the public plays in these types of disputes. There is no role.
Yes, fans put down good money for tickets, just as they do for movies, concerts and video rentals. But fans are not buying into partnerships with these dollars. They are merely renting the right to be entertained by that particular entertainment business.
And that is what baseball is. A business. It is not a religion. It is not an inalienable right guaranteed by the Constitution or by your local cable television carrier. It is simply dollars and cents to those who try to finance it, the owners, and to those who take to the stage for pay, the players.
The money and time they invest is not considered discretionary or expendable, as is the contribution from the public. For owners and players, the game is their livelihood. As such, they have a right to take disputes involving their livelihood to the bargaining table. Just as do television writers, symphony orchestra musicians, actors, directors and movie technicians and their employers.
Fans will probably argue that there is a difference, that baseball is a national trust owned by the public. But it stopped being that the first time one man put a dollar in another man's hand to play baseball, then turned around and charged admission to recoup his costs.
Now, negotiators, staring at a pie worth billions of dollars, are merely fighting for things most Americans take for granted. Like the right to say what city they want to live in, work in or set up shop in. In other words, the right to make economic decisions that are best for their families, their businesses, their careers and themselves.
And, like it or not, owners and players have the right to pursue such goals, too, even if they do dance on a different economic plane and work in an industry others idealistically but unrealistically say they would participate in without pay.
Perhaps, deep down, fans who wouldn't countenance such outside interference in their affairs understand better than most these basic rights. Maybe that's why boycotts that accompanied strikes in 1981 and 1985 fizzled. Fans who said they would never buy another ticket invariably did. Despite the residual anger, the holes left in their hearts and the gaps in their summer schedules, they may have realized it still wasn't their fight.
Soon, the President of the United States will have to decide whether it is his fight. At least one owner, Ted Turner of the Braves, has called on President Clinton to intervene if the players strike.
Such requests are a hoot, in light of management's historic resistance to Federal interference as baseball continues to lobby for its antitrust exemption.
Despite the urgings of the players union, the Federal government, specifically Congress, has traditionally listened to the owners and protected the special dispensation granted baseball. Most recently, a Senate judiciary subcommittee defeated a modified rollback of the exemption, which would have applied to labor disputes. That defeat cost baseball players the legal recourse enjoyed by their peers in the National Basketball Association and the National Football League: the right to try to solve their labor disputes in courts.
Now an owner has the unrepentant moxie to woo the third branch of government to get involved where the judicial branch oft-times does not, because of the exemption, and where Congress will not, because of the lobbying successes of the owners.
President Clinton has not bitten, yet, keeping his Labor Department at a distance. Maybe he will intervene one day. But perhaps he has decided that this is Congress's mess and will remain so until those on Capitol Hill acknowledge what fans learned a long time ago the hard way: that baseball is a business and needs to be treated as such.

HEADLINE: A National Registry for Work

 BODY:
A Federal commission on immigration reform has urged President Clinton to establish a computerized national registry of all citizens and immigrants authorized to work in the United States. The goal, a worthy one, is to help employers check the eligibility of job applicants in order to screen out illegal aliens.
The proposal has been vigorously attacked as an invasion of privacy and a threat that will lead to government surveillance, a national identification card and new forms of discrimination. But such fears appear exaggerated. The registry can be protected so that it does not grow into an instrument of government oppression. The commission's chairwoman, Barbara Jordan, a former Democratic Congresswoman from Texas, a longtime civil rights advocate and leading black politician, said she would never support a proposal that increased discrimination or invaded privacy. 
 The registry is designed to tighten access to employment, the lure that brings most illegal immigrants across U.S. borders. The 1986 Immigration Reform and Control Act sought to shut off this economic magnet by penalizing employers who hired illegal aliens. Employers are required to ask all job applicants for documents to verify that they are either citizens or aliens authorized to work in the U.S. But phony documents can be readily obtained in many cities. Thus many illegal immigrants use false papers to obtain jobs, and many employers, seeking to avoid sanctions for illegal hiring, discriminate against any applicants who look foreign, whether they are entitled to work or not.
How to resolve this dilemma was one of many issues that the Commission on Immigration Reform was set up to examine. The commission will issue a final report next month, but Ms. Jordan previewed its recommendations before the Senate Judiciary Committee last week.
The most controversial proposal is the computerized registry of all eligible workers in the country, using data from the Social Security Administration and the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Employers would use the registry to check that the Social Security number provided by an applicant was valid and had been issued to someone authorized to work in the U.S.
The commission recommends a large pilot program in those states with the most illegal immigrants -- California, Texas, Florida, New York and Illinois -- to test the best way of determining the job applicant's identity and eligibility. That might be done through more secure documents, like counterfeit-resistant Social Security cards and driver's licenses, or other methods like a telephone verification system.
By making the same initial check of all potential employees, the new system would actually reduce the chances of discrimination. Employers would no longer have any reason to ask if an applicant was an immigrant or to reject all foreign-looking applicants out of hand. And American workers at the bottom of the economic ladder would benefit from more effective ways of discouraging the hiring of illegal immigrants.
Opponents of the proposal, like the American Civil Liberties Union, insist that it comes dangerously close to a national identity card. But the Social Security number is already a form of national identification system, used widely by government agencies and private companies. The computerized registry would enhance its reliability.
The commission recognizes the need for accuracy of the new registry and supports efforts by the Social Security Administration and the Immigration and Naturalization Service to improve and update their records. It also supports safeguards against use of the registry data for improper purposes. The task for Washington is to protect the integrity of any new data system as vigilantly as it would protect the workplace from illegal immigrants.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Clinton's Good Deed

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Five years ago, an inflammatory piece titled "Free the Baltics" appeared in this space. Its theme was that "a great struggle has begun" to dismember the Soviet empire, and I went to the Baltics a few months later to be able to put the message in a dateline redolent with pro-independence propaganda: "Riga, Soviet-occupied Latvia."
The three tiny Baltic republics -- Latvia, Estonia, Lithuania -- were the keys to the kingdom. The West had never recognized Stalin's deal with Hitler to swallow up the three states; for a half-century, U.S. Presidents of both parties kept the diplomatic faith with the peoples of these "captive nations" (a phrase derided by anti-anti-Communists here). 
 By emboldening independence movements in these disputed Soviet annexations, we subtly encouraged nationalists in Ukraine and in other republics where Kremlin sovereignty was recognized. Sure enough, as the Russian economy collapsed, Balts asserted their freedom, Ukrainians followed suit, and the Soviet Union came apart.
But there was a blot on the sovereignty of the Baltics: the ominous, continued presence of Russian troops.
Moscow gave such excuses as the protection of the human rights of Russians sent by Stalin to colonize the states, and the need to maintain an early-warning radar station. The practical reason was that no decent housing existed in Russia for the returning officers. The political reason was the rising resentment within Russia of the loss of superpower and the ensuing neo-imperialist pressure to dominate the "near abroad."
On Aug. 31, despite these pressures and to the surprise of many Russian, American and Baltic diplomats, all remaining Russian troops will be pulled out of the Baltics. Much of the credit for this unremarked foreign-policy stunner should go to the perseverance and persuasiveness of President Bill Clinton.
From the first summit with Boris Yeltsin in Vancouver to the recent meeting in Naples, Clinton pressed for the Baltic pullout. Yeltsin had criticized Gorbachev on this, but once in power was faced with the military's demands to stay. Aided by Swedish Prime Minister Carl Bildt, Clinton began chipping away at the reasons for delay, by phone and letter, making plain a personal interest.
The U.S. successfully mediated a radar phase-out that met Moscow's defense concerns. We made available $160 million for resettling Russian military, including $25,000 vouchers for officers to build new housing back home, more generous than our own old G.I. bill.
But Yeltsin balked at the impending deadline for withdrawal. Getting political heat from nationalists and resentment from his army, he complained of "brutal" repression of the Russian minority in Latvia and Estonia. Asked last month if he would meet the deadline, he publicly answered "nyet."
On July 6, Clinton was the first U.S. President to visit Latvia, affirming its Western ties, raising hard-liner hopes that he will abandon "partnership for peace" bomfog and expand NATO membership eastward while opportunity exists. But he quieted a cheering throng in Riga with a message many non-Russians did not want to hear: "to never deny others the justice and equality you fought for . . . for freedom without tolerance is freedom unfulfilled."
Nine days later, he wrote Yeltsin a private letter to assure him that the rights of Russians in the Baltics "is an issue of principle with me" but "we do not see in these countries a pattern of abuses . . ." He added: "Boris, it remains my firm view that we must not miss the chance to put Russian-Estonian relations on a new path by achieving agreement with President [Lennart] Meri. You should make every effort to withdraw your remaining troops from Estonia by August 31."
Russian diplomat Vitaly Churkin treated Meri rudely, expecting his Moscow meeting with Yeltsin to fail; Nick Burns, the Clinton national security aide highly regarded by the Balts, was pessimistic. But Bill's pen-pal Boris, repeatedly made aware of linkage, thundered "solve it!" to aides and ordered his troops out -- on the same day the last Russian soldiers are to leave Berlin.
Thus, Russian imperial interest seems directed more southward than westward, partly by virtue of Clinton diplomacy. That shows what can happen in the rare case when this President makes a clear-cut strategic decision, takes a personal interest in its success and quietly follows through.

HEADLINE: A Hutu Family Tries to Rebuild in Tutsi-Led Rwanda

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GISENYI, Rwanda, Aug. 8

 BODY:
In the six days that Laurent Ngwijabanzi and his wife, Constantine Nyiramahne, have been back in their mud-brick house on a hill high above banana plantations, it has been strangely silent.
Almost all their neighbors are still refugees across the border in Zaire. The schools are closed, the few public buses were stolen and the goats that used to roam the countryside disappeared with their owners. 
 "We feel alone," said Mrs. Nyiramahne.
Only three families out of the hundreds who lived on the hill have trekked the few miles home. The front door on the adjacent house remains padlocked; it is not known if the owner is alive. The neighboring village is empty.
But as tough as starting over is proving to be, Mr. Ngwijabanzi said he was pleased to be home. His initial fear of being harassed or harmed by the soldiers of the new Rwandan Government had subsided. His main problem, he said, was finding enough food, and generating enough money to pay for it in a shattered economy. A farmer who also runs a business building homes, he has no seeds to plant and no customers for the rows of mud bricks lined up in his yard.
The United Nations estimates about 90,000 Rwandans have returned from the squalid camps in Zaire, where tens of thousands have died of cholera and other diseases.
A vast majority of the refugees -- about 900,000 -- have chosen to stay in the disease-ridden camps out of fear of reprisals from soldiers of the new Tutsi-dominated Government. The Hutu soldiers and militia of the previous Government, who are being blamed for the massacres of up to 500,000 Tutsi in April and May and who ordered Hutu civilians to flee northwest Rwanda three weeks ago, are campaigning in the camps against repatriation.
 
Flow of Returnees Slows
 The number of Rwandans returning through the main border crossings has fallen as the propaganda in the camps has increased and as the political situation inside Rwanda remains unclear. There have been reports of attacks on returning refugees in the southwest.
The unease that many educated refugees feel was made clear tonight at a small gathering in Goma of Rwandans who had worked at the United States Embassy in Kigali.
A political assistant at the embassy, Habimana Diendonne, said his father had returned to his home in Rwerere, near Gisenyi, to have a look but was a week overdue in returning. "He went back to see if it was safe," Mr. Diendonne said. "Now we don't know anything."
Fear was a factor for Mr. Ngwijabanzi, too, but he decided to take the risk rather than stay in the camps. "The worst period in my life was in Zaire, when I saw what I'd never seen before," he said -- "roads full of bodies."
To make the return journey easier, he left five of his children with relatives in Goma and walked a mile to the border with his wife and Victor, 18, and Samuel, 10.
"When we crossed the border, we thought we'd be killed," he said, sitting on one of the five wooden chairs in the small living room decorated with faded black-and-white family photographs. "But the Rwandan Patriotic Front soldiers talked to us gently and we were no longer afraid."
 
A Military Escort
 At another checkpoint further inside Rwanda, where soldiers had placed plastic soft-drink crates as barriers, their luggage was searched for weapons. Then, with about 60 other refugees, they were assigned a Patriotic Front soldier as an escort for the three-hour walk home.
They arrived here to find their entire bean harvest stolen. The bananas had been stripped from the trees of his plantation. There were no more animals because the five goats Mr. Ngwijabanzi had taken with him were stolen by Zairian soldiers.
To survive, he said, he has been using his meager savings to buy food. His son Samuel was pounding cassava leaves in a wooden pot for the evening meal. There was a small dish of sweet potatoes.
But cooking was difficult because the community water pump was broken, probably looted by soldiers. The family now depends on polluted water from the river, he said.
Mr. Ngwijabanzi said he would have to depend on food from relief agencies. He hopes the food arrives soon so he can go back to Zaire and bring his five other children back.
But as long as he can feed his family, Mr. Ngwijabanzi, a Hutu, seems unconcerned about the new Government, which is predominantly Tutsi.
The Hutu Government had not treated him well. In mid-April his house was searched by 20 Government soldiers because he was suspected of hiding a soldier of the Rwandan Patriotic Front.
And the massacres are still emblazoned on his mind. "People were being killed like cutting bananas with a machete," he said
It was not only Tutsi who were being killed, he said. "Everybody was frightened because people could point and say you are a spy," he said. "Now there is no disturbance for those who come back, there is no more fighting. And when you are talking to the soldiers, they don't shout at you."

HEADLINE: Rabin Makes First Visit to Jordan by an Israeli Leader

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ARAVA CROSSING, Jordan, Aug. 8

 BODY:
Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, in the first official visit to Jordan by an Israeli leader, met King Hussein today in his seaside summer palace in Aqaba and opened a border crossing.
The meeting and ceremony, after years of secret contacts, come just two weeks after the Washington meeting between Mr. Rabin and the Jordanian King, which ended the state of war between the two neighbors. Phone links between Jordan and Israel were established on Sunday, and the King may visit Jerusalem as early as next week, according to Israeli officials. 
 The border crossing, which lies two miles north of the Red Sea port of Aqaba, will be open, for now, to foreign tourists and Israelis with foreign passports. Officials of both countries said they hoped that Israeli and Jordanian passport holders would not have to wait long to use it.
"We are literally seated at this time and this place, all of us, Israelis and Jordanians, on the remains of the past," Mr. Rabin said at the arid border crossing. "We are sitting on an old minefield which was cleared only three days ago. This is what divided Israel and Jordan for decades. This is the field in which death and destruction were sowed."
"We are sitting at this time and at this place, all of us, Israelis and Jordanians, before the future," he said. "To our right and to our left stand the new Israeli-Jordan border crossing terminals, which sprang up overnight."
 
Cleared of Land Mines
 The desert crossing was cleared of surrounding land mines in the last three days, and fresh coats of white paint marked the trailers and hastily built cement structures.
The King, who warmly welcomed Mr. Rabin at his palace, promised that this was just the start. He called his Israeli counterparts "friends and partners." And later in the day the Prime Minister told reporters that he had first met the King 20 years ago.
"Now that it has all been published, I will tell you," Mr. Rabin told reporters when asked how long he had known King Hussein, "that when we were all three at the White House, President Clinton, the King and myself, Clinton turned to us and asked us, 'Tell me the truth, how long have you known each other?'
"I looked at the King, and he didn't reply. I answered, 21 years. Then he corrected me and said: 'Twenty years,' and he was right."
 
The King's Comments
 The King said: "This is something I have never experienced over the many, many years that have passed. I hope it is something we will leave for all people, men, women and children, to live with and enjoy in the future."
Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who met with the two leaders and later traveled with them aboard the King's yacht, said, "The rhetoric of peacemaking is giving way and being translated into reality."
Mr. Christopher is in the Middle East to help broker a deal between Israel and Syria. Syria remains critical of the contacts between the Israelis and their Palestinian and Jordanian counterparts.
Syria and Israel are struggling to break a deadlock in the peace effort. Mr. Christopher, who met President Hafez al-Assad of Syria for five hours on Sunday in Damascus, said today that the two countries "have a great distance to go" to make peace.
 
Criticism of P.L.O. Delay
 Mr. Rabin criticized the Palestine Liberation Organization for delaying Palestinian elections and slowing up the agreement between the Israeli and Palestinian leadership. He said further agreements, including the status of the remainder of the West Bank, could not be decided until the P.L.O. went ahead with legislative elections, as called for in the self-rule agreement. The elections were scheduled for July.
The Prime Minister said he expected to meet Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, on Wednesday to discuss the delay.
The border ceremony, over which Crown Prince Hassan officiated for Jordan, was attended by Jordanian and Israeli veterans, as well as some of those who lost relatives in the four wars that have taken place between the two countries since the creation of Israel in 1948. The groups exchanged gifts and shook hands.
"The task of leadership is not to follow public opinion blindly," said former Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel, who shook hands with Jordanian veterans and went on to Aqaba with Mr. Rabin, "but to lead public opinion, and both Prime Minister Rabin and King Hussein are doing this."
 
Eban Praises Arafat
 Mr. Eban also paid tribute to the P.L.O. leader, noting that the agreement with Jordan was possible only because Mr. Arafat had broken the ice.
"We never would have reached the agreement with Jordan unless we had reached the agreement with the Palestinians," he said. "And we won't have peace with Syria unless we cherish the Palestinian and Jordanian agreements."
On Friday, President Clinton sent a letter to the leaders of Germany, Britain, France and 10 other industrialized nations to urge them to grant debt relief to Jordan, whose overall government-to-government debt totals $6 billion.
Mr. Clinton called debt relief for Jordan a "critical element" in demonstrating support for the peace effort.
"It is essential that the people of Jordan feel the benefits of peace in tangible ways," he said. "Jordan's debt overhang is a major impediment to economic growth."
Showing that the United States intended to lead the way, Mr. Clinton said in the letter, which was released today, that as a first installment he would seek to reduce Jordan's $702 million debt to the United States by about $220 million.
 
Yacht Tours Gulf of Aqaba
 King Hussein played host to Mr. Rabin and Mr. Christopher at his palace on the Red Sea immediately after the early-morning border opening. The three men met briefly with reporters in the garden of the palace before a tour of the Gulf of Aqaba in the King's yacht, Haya, piloted by the King.
Israeli boats, waving Jordanian and Israeli flags and unleashing horn blasts, greeted the Haya, which means life in Arabic, as it plowed through the placid waters. The yacht briefly crossed into Israel as it cruised along the coastal resort city of Eilat. Israeli gunboats escorted the vessel as Israeli and Jordanian helicopters hovered overhead.
"Friends say to us, 'The pace of events is too fast,' " Mr. Rabin said in the morning. " 'We cannot keep up. Wait a minute.' "
"Your Royal Highness, our friends in the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan, we have waited 46 years," he said. "We have gone through war, pain and suffering. To prevent further loss and so on, we cannot wait even one more day."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
WPP Group is having a good year after some shaky ones.

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
AFTER years in which its survival seem threatened by a bloated debt load and the pinch on marketing budgets caused by the recession, WPP Group P.L.C., the London-based advertising holding company that is an important force on Madison Avenue, has generated a steady stream of good news during the last 12 months.
Clients began spending more on advertising as economic recoveries took hold in the United States and Britain, aiding results at J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather, WPP's two biggest agencies. The company has shored up its balance sheet, in part through the sale late last year of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, another of its agencies, for $70 million. And in May, Ogilvy scored the biggest account gain in advertising history when I.B.M. consolidated its account, with billings estimated at $400 million to $500 million, there. 
 WPP's shares have reflected this, having surged on the London Stock Exchange from a low in 1992 of 22 pence a share, or about 33 cents, to 89 pence, or about $1.33, at the end of last year. The shares closed yesterday in London at 111 pence, up 3 pence. WPP's American depository receipts, which trade on Nasdaq and represent two shares each, closed yesterday at $3.50, up 25 cents.
Despite the progress, WPP's shares may have been restrained recently. A consortium of 28 banks, which financed WPP's acquisitions of J. Walter Thompson, Ogilvy and other companies in the mid-1980's, agreed in 1992 to trade $272 million worth of debt for equity. A big block of that stock -- 190.2 million shares, or 26.5 percent of shares outstanding following the conversion -- can be sold by the banks as of Sept. 1 under the terms of their agreement with WPP. The bank group includes J. P. Morgan, Bankers Trust, Barclays Bank and National Westminster Bank.
The banks indicated last week that they planned to sell the shares to institutional investors in Britain and on the Continent in an offering led by Bankers Trust, Morgan and S. G. Warburg Securities.
While investors have long known the sale was coming -- the banks were allowed to sell 60 million shares last year, and did so -- some analysts think a fear that WPP's shares are being diluted has kept buyers on the sidelines lately, blunting what might have been further gains.
"There hasn't been any evidence of short-selling or of the price being severely affected, but it's held back the share performance," said David Forster, an analyst at Smith New Court Securities in London.
The question now is how well the sale of the banks' shares will go next month and whether the shares will then resume their upward climb. WPP declined comment pending the release of its financial results for the first six months of the year, which is due tomorrow.
The company already had one lesson this year in equity market volatility: It had to cancel a $200 million offering of an equity stake in its market research business in June when it became clear that the market for new issues was close to sated.
But the general expectation among analysts is that the bank group will sell the WPP shares at a modest discount to the market price and that there is sufficient demand to avoid dragging down the market price significantly.
"If the placing is executed successfully we think the shares can move ahead from these levels," said Mr. Forster. He added that Smith New Court had rated the stock a hold for the last several months. "We're positive on the shares long term," he said. "We think there's reasonable value there."
Mr. Forster estimated that WPP would post pretax earnings for the first six months of the year of 37 million, or about $55.5 million. In the same period last year it earned 24.1 million, or about $36.15 million.
Average net debt for WPP, which peaked in 1992 at 395 million, or slightly less than $600 million at today's exchange rates, fell to 339 million last year, or $515 million, and should be less than 300 million, or about $456 million, for the first half of 1994. The advertising agencies have continued to gain new business, though the I.B.M. account probably will not show up on the bottom line until next year, when heavy start-up costs -- and offsetting losses of billings from I.B.M. rivals estimated as high as $200 million -- are out of the way.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 6.79 to End a Four-Day Decline

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average snapped a four-day slide yesterday, as the stock market was buoyed by expectations of strong corporate earnings. Stability in bonds and the dollar also helped stocks, traders said.
Friday's report of stronger-than-expected job growth in July "underlines the solid momentum of the current economy," said Gail Dudack, market strategist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "This is a good backdrop for earnings prospects for the second half of 1994." 
 Gains were capped by concern that this week's sale of $40.25 billion in new Treasury securities would glut the market and drive bond yields higher, creating competition for stocks, traders said. Concern about this week's inflation reports and next week's Federal Reserve policy meeting also limited the stock market's advance.
"Today's rebound doesn't have much 'oomph' behind it," said Christie McClellan, managing director at Robertson, Stephens & Company. "The pressures to buy or sell seem to be about equal at this point."
The Dow industrials climbed 6.79, to 3,753.81, after losing 51.15 points in the last four sessions. Gains for International Paper, I.B.M. and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing offset losses for Caterpillar, American Express and Union Carbide.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index closed up 0.80, at 457.89, after dropping 4.37 during the last two sessions. Computer systems, drugs and international oils were among the sectors with the biggest gains yesterday, while general retail stores, health care and chemicals were among the largest decliners.
The Nasdaq composite index, which shed 6.18 points in the last four days, rose 1.80, to 720.47. Cisco Systems, Microsoft and Nordstrom paced the rebound.
Nordstrom rallied 15/16 , to 439/16 . An analyst at Wertheim, Schroder & Company raised his earnings estimates a day before the apparel retailer is expected to post second-quarter earnings of between 65 and 70 cents a share, up from 52 cents a share in the corresponding period a year earlier.
Eleven stocks rose for every nine that fell on the New York Stock Exchange. About 217.7 million shares changed hands on the Big Board, below the daily average of 260 million shares in the last three months.
"We don't see long-term inflationary pressures and we're already beginning to see signs of a slowing in the economy," as evidenced by a drop in housing starts and auto sales, said James Engle, chief investment officer of Wood Struthers & Winthrop, the investment management subsidiary of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, which manages more than $2.2 billion.
The most active stocks on the United States composite list were Mesa Airlines, which plunged 37/16 , to 69/16 , after reporting a drop in third-quarter income; Telmex, down 1/4, to 62 3/4; Intel, down 1/8, to 58; RJR Nabisco Holdings, unchanged at 6 1/4, and Cisco Systems, up 3/4, to 21 5/8.
North American Mortgage soared 3, to 30 5/8, after it hired Morgan Stanley & Company to help it evaluate options, including a possible sale, to bolster shareholder value.

HEADLINE: If Welfare Mothers Must Go to Work In Clinton Plan, Will Children Gain?

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA 

 BODY:
Dorothy Carmona, a mother and relative newcomer to the world of work, thinks her children are better off now in day care than they were when she was on welfare. "I see many, many women who just get up in the morning and do nothing with their lives," she said. "My kids learn more at the day care center than when I was at home."
Gail Abney, a mother and no stranger to work, nonetheless calls it cruel to ask welfare mothers to work when their children are young. "A child's most important year is the first year," she said. "You build a bond with that child." 
 The two mothers, both welfare veterans from the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, reflect a larger divide about a major part of President Clinton's plan to overhaul welfare: for the first time forcing mothers of young children to leave those youngsters for work, school or training. Alternative welfare proposals in Congress make similar demands.
 
Echoing Broad Debate
 The unanswered, and so far unanswerable, question is just how the Clinton plan and other proposals would affect the women's children. Because no previous welfare-to-work program has required mothers of infants to seek work, there is little good research on children that age. But there is plenty of passion on both sides of a discussion that echoes broader debates about working mothers and the state of children.
For the Clinton Administration, the political calculus is clear: if the Family and Medical Leave Act grants just three months no-paid leave to working mothers generally, then welfare mothers can hardly expect more.
To disarm critics, the Administration would exempt welfare mothers until their first child is 1 year old, and give them three months off after the birth of any other children. After that, all welfare mothers who are 18 or older would have to prepare for work through job training or education, or would have to engage actively in a job search. After two years, welfare payments would end; if a woman did not have a job, she would be required to work at subsidized, Government-provided jobs at minimum wage for 15 to 35 hours a week.
"The philosophy is fairness," said Mary Jo Bane, the assistant secretary for children and families in the Department of Health and Human Services. "Our expectations for welfare mothers ought to be similar to the expectations of working people."
 
Child Care Guidelines
 Existing child care research suggests that children's responses to their mothers working depends on both whether their mothers want to work and whether their mothers' jobs are stressful and on the quality of the child care in which the children are placed. But these guidelines can be interpreted differently .
Ms. Bane and several other welfare experts argue, for example, that children might be better off if their mothers work because working could ease the women's social isolation, give them pride and self-confidence and combat the depression that disproportionately afflicts mothers on welfare. And, they maintain, children could be placed in child care that offers them more stimulation than they might receive at home.
"The issue isn't middle-class moms who, if at home, would spend all this time reading to their kids," said Douglas J. Besharov, a welfare expert with the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research organization. "That's why research on child care often shows that kids benefit, because compared to what they get at home, it is often more enriching."
Indeed, researchers at the Johns Hopkins University, in a recent study of 867 children nationwide, found that when children from the poorest and least intellectually stimulating homes were placed in child care (particularly in child care centers) before they were 1 year old, they performed better on math and reading tests than children who were not in day care.
A national study of 22,000 children conducted last year by the research organizations Westat Inc. and Child Trends Inc. found that welfare mothers -- and other poor mothers -- tended to read less to their children, allowed them to watch more television, showed less physical attention and spanked them more than mothers in the general population. Those children had more behavior problems and achieved less in school than other pupils, the study reported.
But other welfare experts argue that mothers forced into low-wage jobs that are unfulfilling might be resentful, overwhelmed by stress and unable to pay for quality child care. And poor children, they argue, are particularly in need of child care that offers an environment in which they are encouraged to learn.
 
Two-Generation Approach
 The scant evidence available from small-scale welfare-to-work projects suggests that children fare best when programs are designed both for parents and children. The National Center for Children in Poverty, based at Columbia University, recently studied about 200 children of teen-age mothers in Newark who had received further education and job training.
"If you're concerned about kids as well as parents, it's necessary but not sufficient to do welfare to work," said Lawrence Aber, the co-director of the center. "You have to combine employment training with parenting education and child-development activities for kids."
Other small-scale programs to require welfare mothers to seek work support that contention. So do the experiences of women like Ms. Carmona, who found her job as an administrative assistant with a nonprofit company through the help of Project Chance in Fort Greene, which offers counseling, parent education, employment training and free day care. Ms. Carmona said the combination of services helped her be a better mother.
The counseling and training improved her family's finances and her self-confidence. "When I was pregnant, on welfare and watching soap operas at home, one of the family educators said, 'This will make you depressed; you need to go out,' " she said. "I can't see myself at home all day long with them. I tell them, 'I have to work so you can get a better education.' "
The parenting classes improved Ms. Carmona's relationship with her children. "A lot of us come from abusive homes," she said, "and if you get upset with the child, instead of saying, 'Let's take a deep breath,' you say, 'Get the belt.' We learned we can't just take out our frustrations on the children."
The Clinton proposal, already pared because the President pledged not to raise taxes to pay for it, does not require a two-generation approach. But it would let states allow mothers to fulfill part of their required preparation for employment in parent education courses, as long as they spent most of their time looking for a job, Ms. Bane said.
But several child care experts fear that the plan, which was cut back because of costs and politics, did not allocate enough money to pay for quality child care when mothers were undergoing training and, more important, when they had to work. The cost of the proposal was reduced to $9.3 billion over five years from $19.5 billion.
Among other provisions, it does guarantee child care while mothers are on welfare and for one year after they find work. It also offers incentives to raise child care reimbursement rates; nearly doubles the amount of money available to help the working poor pay for child care, and expands the Head Start preschool program to include newborns to age 3. The program now serves 3 and 4 year olds.
 
Shortcomings Are Seen
 But Helen Blank, child care director of the Children's Defense Fund, said states would still be allowed to pay as little as $175 a month to reimburse child care expenses. With waiting lists for subsidized child care for working poor parents reaching 255,000 in California alone, Ms. Bank said the Clinton plan would fall far short of working parents' needs for affordable child care -- and risk pushing working poor parents back into welfare to get the scarce subsidized child care slots.
Jacqueline Bullock, a Fort Greene mother who left welfare to take a job as a transit clerk, said that without the free child care she found through Project Chance she could not afford to keep working. "I was lugging each child to a different place -- one to a center, one in family day care, one to my niece," she said. "If it weren't for the program here, keeping me ahead of the game, giving me free child care, I wouldn't work. With the income limits on day care, the system just throws you out."
Welfare mothers would also have to contend with a time limit if the Clinton proposal were adopted: They would have two years to find jobs, after which welfare benefits would end. Yet virtually every welfare-to-work program has shown that mothers struggling with particularly difficult emotional and family problems may need more time to prepare for work.
Mitzi Hack, for example, is a 30-year-old mother of four in Overland Park, Kan., and has been on welfare for five years, since she left an abusive husband. She says she wants to work but has no skills. She worries that within two years she cannot get training, find a job that pays enough to support four children and save enough money to buy a car, which is essential to commute to work.
Toby Herr, director of Project Match, which works with long-term welfare recipients at the Cabrini-Green housing project in Chicago, proposed that instead of requiring job training for every mother, participation in tenant patrols, Head Start programs, parent-teacher meetings and family support programs could count because these build work skills like reliability and promptness.
"I believe very strongly that everyone's expected to do something," Ms. Herr said. "But the expectations must be meaningful and realistic. If we push the mothers into things they aren't good at, it's bad for kids."

HEADLINE: Oil Prices May Be at a Turning Point

BYLINE: By KENNETH GILPIN 

 BODY:
The decline in oil prices that helped bring inflation in the United States down to an annual rate of 3 percent may be ending.
Many oil analysts and economists are suggesting that the sharp price increases this year, which have brought the price of oil up nearly $6, to about $20 a barrel, are going to hold. Some others contend that they see signs that point to rising oil prices for the rest of this decade. 
 "Using a very reasonable set of assumptions, I can foresee several years of price increases after 1995," said Vahan Zanoyan, senior director at the Petroleum Finance Company, a consulting firm in Washington.
"I personally think demand will be exploding because of a rapid coincidence of demand in the Far East, Europe and North America," he said. "And at current prevailing prices, I don't think the global oil industry is ready to accommodate a synchronized push in demand."
 
Demand Growth Increasing
 An executive at an oil trading company, who asked not to be identified, said the calculus looked like this:
"Total production is about 70 million barrels a day. Demand growth is increasing by 1.5 million to 2 million barrels a day, per annum, the equivalent of Kuwait's current annual production. The big supply sources over the past few years are coming to an end, and for the first time anyone can remember, OPEC has no substantial excess capacity."
Oil prices have been on a slow but steady rise since mid-February, when spot prices for a barrel of West Texas intermediate crude bottomed at $13.95 a barrel.
In the last few weeks, strikes by Nigerian oil workers have raised concerns about widespread and long-lived disruptions in the supply of high-quality Nigerian crude. Those worries have driven up spot oil prices by about $2 a barrel.
The price of light crude for September delivery closed at $19.42, up 11 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday. When its workers are not on strike, Nigeria produces about 1.9 million barrels a day.
But Nigeria is not the only big oil producer that is having political problems and could have production disruptions. Tensions are rising in Algeria, which produces slightly less than 800,000 barrels of oil a day, and in Venezuela, which pumps more than 2.4 million.
And with these problems on the production side, demand is rising.
"We are seeing an acceleration of demand for oil, at least as far as the United States is concerned," said Bernard J. Picchi, a managing director and oil analyst at Lehman Brothers.
"And the liberalization of economies in India, China and ultimately Russia will have an impact on demand," he added.
In a report issued nearly a month ago, analysts at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company said that by the end of September, "commercial stocks, relative to forward consumption," would be "well below" their levels a year ago.
But the Morgan analysis was done before a heat wave settled on Japan and Western Europe. During July alone, demand for electricity in Japan was so great that oil consumption was up 800,000 barrels a day, compared with July 1993. Until the country's heat and drought conditions abate, consumption will remain high, further taxing existing stocks.
In its most recent forecast, the Paris-based International Energy Agency in Paris said last week that petroleum demand would rise by 1.2 million barrels a day next year, after increasing by 800,000 barrels a day in 1994.
"The bulk of the price increase is due to a cyclical surge in demand," said John H. Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York. "If the Nigerian situation deteriorates, prices could go up another couple of dollars or more. But even if Nigeria comes back, prices are likely to be firm."
But even as these analysts predict that oil prices will rise, they maintain that compared with other commodities, oil will still be a bargain, if only because its price has stayed so low for so long.
In nominal terms, crude prices are about a third lower than they were in 1983, according to price data from Datastream. But after accounting for inflation, crude oil today is selling for less than half of its average 1983 price.
"I would argue that oil is still cheap, even if it goes up by another $3 a barrel," said Mr. Zanoyan of the Petroleum Finance Company. "Oil is not only cheap relative to its own price path, but also relative to the price path of other commodities."
But there are analysts who say they see a potentially more alarming scenario. To them, the emerging tableau of rising demand, tight inventories and instability in some key producing countries is disturbingly familiar.
"I have this eerie feeling we are about to repeat 1978-1979," said Philip K. Verleger, Jr., a Washington-based vice president at Charles River Associates, an economic consulting firm.
"We are probably going to have to deal with irregular production from Nigeria for the next six months to a year, demand is surging and there is not enough of a production overhang to deal with that sort of a situation," he said. "Towards the end of the fourth quarter we could have a terribly tight oil market. And at the moment, I am hard pressed to see many answers that could ease the situation."
Mr. Verleger said global inventories were currently at their lowest level in five years. Given current consumption patterns, by the end of the year inventories will have fallen to their lowest level since 1974, he said.
At the moment, Mr. Verleger's view is not widely shared. But even the merest suggestion that world petroleum markets could push up prices the way they did in the wake of the Iranian revolution should be cause for concern in the Clinton Administration, and at the Federal Reserve Board.
Oil prices soared after the 1973 Yom Kippur War, and then doubled during 1978, to $28 a barrel. The inflationary impact forced the Fed to push interest rates to record-high levels and played a big hand in Ronald Reagan's victory over President Jimmy Carter.
Those who reject the thesis that spot oil prices could skyrocket argue that there is enough excess capacity to cope with rising demand.
Mr. Lichtblau said that Saudi Arabia, the swing producer among the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, could pump as much as an extra two million barrels a day above its current production quota of 7.9 million, a cushion big enough to offset even a long-term disruption in Nigerian production.
Kuwait, currently pumping about 1.8 million barrels a day, has excess capacity of about 300,000 barrels a day. But other OPEC producers are operating at very close to full capacity.
OPEC oil ministers are not scheduled to meet again until November, when the group will discuss whether to increase production in 1995 above the current level of 25 million barrels a day. If conditions in Nigeria remain unsettled, Mr. Lichtblau said, the Saudis and Kuwaitis are likely to raise their output.
Aside from a desire to avoid another boom-bust cycle with oil prices, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are apt to go to extreme lengths to prevent prices from skyrocketing in order to keep the United Nations-sanctioned oil embargo against Iraq intact.

HEADLINE: 2 Companies Look to Leave Manhattan

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In a reflection of the growing strength -- and rising prices -- of the midtown Manhattan real estate market, two large companies said yesterday that they were considering leaving the city for offices in the suburbs.
The Equitable Life Assurance Society is considering several existing buildings in Westchester County, and the Swiss Bank Corporation said it might build on vacant land in downtown Stamford. 
 The two companies' search for new offices comes as offices in midtown Manhattan -- particularly the large, modern blocks of space preferred by financial services companies -- have grown increasingly scarce and expensive.
 
Vacancies in Suburbia
 At the same time, large numbers of suburban office buildings are vacant or only partly filled, the results of layoffs and corporate "downsizing." That has left asking rents in midtown more than a third higher than in suburban buildings, experts say, and the disparity may grow.
"It is very good news for the suburbs," said Michael H. Siegel, executive director of the Edward H. Gordon Company, a commercial realty company that handles property both in the city and suburbs. Because little new construction is expected any time soon in Manhattan, "large users are looking for alternatives."
The search by Equitable and Swiss Bank, which together have more than 4,000 employees in New York City, comes less than three weeks after another large Manhattan company, Mastercard, said it was looking for a suburban building for its headquarters and 540 employees. Although Mastercard has not said where it is looking, real estate executives say it is negotiating to take over a building vacated by the International Business Machines Corporation in the Westchester town of Purchase.
The Mastercard announcement raised some concern among city officials because it followed years of relative quiet in what as recently as the mid-1980's had been intense competition between New York and its suburbs for big businesses. To keep businesses, New York City was forced to offer increasingly generous incentives, like tax abatements.
Real estate executives attributed the slowdown in relocations to the region's real estate slump, beginning in 1988, which initially hurt midtown Manhattan as much as anywhere else in the region. With vacancy rates soaring, many midtown companies that might have considered relocating were able to negotiate new Manhattan leases at lower rents.
 
Differing Rental Rates
 Although experts say the expense of corporate relocation -- including the loss of employees who elect not to move -- involves far more complicated questions that a simple comparison of rental rates, those rates give a clear advantage to the suburbs.
According to Edward S. Gordon, the average asking rent in midtown Manhattan offices at the end of June was $31.60 a square foot. That compared with an average of $26.85 in lower Manhattan, $19.74 in Westchester and $19.25 in Fairfield County.
The possible moves by Swiss Bank and Equitable were first reported yesterday by Crain's New York Business, which also said that Avon Products and the Union Bank of Switzerland were considering moving from Manhattan to the suburbs.
Officials of Avon and Union Bank declined comment yesterday. Real estate executives, who asked that their names not be used, said both those companies had retained consultants to advise them on relocation, but they added that the use of such consultants had become routine for companies whose leases were expiring, and did not mean they would move.
The search for a new home appeared the most advanced at Swiss Bank, which has 1,500 Manhattan employees split between a United States headquarters at 10 East 50th Street and another building at Broadway and Park Row.
Matthias Beckman, a company spokesman, said yesterday that the company was considering building a new complex on a parcel just north of the Stamford train station.
"It would be a few years before we actually move," he said, "and it is far too early to tell how many employees would be affected." Nonetheless, Mr. Beckman added, the company is searching for a new location because it is expanding rapidly from its traditional banking business into stock trading and investment banking and needs more space for a trading floor, computers and offices.
One hurdle in Connecticut is that state law bars foreign-owned banks from locating there, and he said negotiations are under way in Hartford to have the law amended. Mr. Bergstrom said Swiss Bank could expect to obtain large tax breaks if it moved to Stamford because of a two-year-old state law that provides for long-term reductions in corporate income taxes to companies with more than 1,000 employees that either move into or expand in the state.
At Equitable, which opened its headquarters in 1985 in the Equitable Tower, at 787 Seventh Avenue, a company spokeswoman, Nancy Amiel, said other buildings were being considered across the New York region, including in Westchester County.
She said leases would begin to expire in 1996 at four other buildings Equitable occupies in Manhattan. Whatever decision is made, she said, the company will "maintain some space" in the Equitable Tower.
