HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
No Room For the Ruby Legs

BYLINE: BY IRA BERKOW 

 BODY:
I CLIMBED into a taxicab in Manhattan one day recently and told the driver, "Yankee Stadium."
He half-turned to me and in a foreign accent said, "Is that in New Jersey?" 
 "Not yet," I replied.
Then I gave him directions to the Bronx and, without even a thonx, he stepped on it.
One day, though, the Yankees may, as George Steinbrenner has indicated, wind up in a coveted spot in the New Jersey swamps.
If so, the New York Yankees will join such historic 19th-century major league baseball teams as the Providence Grays, the Troy (N.Y.) Haymakers, the Newark Peppers, the Worcester (Mass.) Ruby Legs, the Louisville Eclipse, the Keokuk Westerns, the Wilmington (Del.) Quick Steps and the Altoona Mountain City.
Not to mention the 20th-century Brooklyn Dodgers, the New York Giants, the Boston and Milwaukee Braves, the Philadelphia and Kansas City Athletics, the Washington Senators (two versions) and dozens of other teams. All of whom weighed their market places in the balance and found them wanting, and, like many businesses in similar situations in the American free-enterprise system, either moved away or went out of business.
The shuttling of teams is a harsh reality, but it is reality, something the baseball owners of today would rather not discuss.
The owners, on the verge of forcing the players into a strike, have demanded that the players accept a salary cap, which would negate many of the rights for which the players have fought successfully in recent years.
The owners contend they can't continue like this -- saying at first that 19 of the 28 teams are in the red, then changing that yesterday to 12 to 14 money-losing clubs -- but have been totally unconvincing to the players. This is unlike the National Basketball Association owners in 1984, who opened their books and proved to the satisfaction of the players' union that four franchises were about to fold, and the players thereby risked a loss of about 50 jobs.
Baseball owners, with frequent turnover, continue to sell their franchises at ever higher prices, and the sport continues to expand. While the owners say teams are losing money, especially the so-called small-market teams, Financial World Magazine, which tracks such goings-on, says this is fiction.
The San Diego Padres, for one, made a profit of $4.1 million in 1993, according to Financial World. And the Pittsburgh Pirates, who went on the sales block last week -- and immediately found at least two serious business groups expressing interest -- were reported to have made $4 million last year.
Nowhere is it decreed that a big league ball club must exist in a particular city. Instead, basic economics requires that one sets up shop at the busiest corner, a tradition baseball owners have followed religiously.
For many years, only 16 teams played in the major leagues. Of those 16, only 10 remain in the same city. The others moved on. Owners decided there was nothing inviolable about the national pastime. And the majors have ballooned to 28 teams.
Owners, some of whom say with a straight face that they are caretakers of a national trust, insist that it would be terrible to lose franchises in smaller markets because of the history of those teams, and that it would damage the continuity of the game. A continuity, in fact, that the owners themselves have often changed -- from franchise-hopping to the designated hitter to artificial playing surfaces.
If small markets are a grievous problem, then why don't the owners solve it among themselves with a greater degree of revenue-sharing -- and not tie it to a players' salary cap? They could give visiting teams 40 to 50 percent of the gate instead of 20 percent, as in the American League, and about the same in the National. And George Steinbrenner, for example, could share his $40 million-a-year local television deal with, say, Milwaukee, which gets only about $5 million for its locally televised games.
That's because the large-market owners are playing like profiteers, the game they're best at. Have always been best at. And if a shift in population and jobs in Pittsburgh, for example, no longer allows it to support a baseball team, then metropolitan areas on the rise like Orlando, Charlotte, Norfolk and Phoenix are ready and willing to try.
The Tampa-St. Petersburg area is so eager, in fact, that it built a domed stadium, and waits, like a maiden with trousseau at the ready. At last count, the Tampa Bay Baseball group had sold 32,079 season ticket reservations.
This is baseball business, also a national pastime. And apparently a thriving one, at that.

HEADLINE: Physicists Ponder Life After the Demise Of the Supercollider

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE 

DATELINE: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M.

 BODY:
PARTICLE physicists meeting here last week to ponder the uncertain future of their arcane science relished a host of new ideas for penetrating the secrets underlying universal existence. But their branch of science has fallen on economic hard times, and many physicists were mainly looking for new ways to make a living.
A cloud of gloom shrouded the meeting of the Division of Particles and Fields of the American Physical Society, the first meeting the group had held since Congress killed the superconducting supercollider accelerator last October. The supercollider, a $10 billion proton accelerator that was under construction in Texas, would have been the most powerful such machine ever built. With its demise, thousands of scientists and engineers have lost jobs or suffered professionally in other ways. 
 Particle physics, which is also called high-energy physics, depends on the enormous energies needed to accelerate nuclear or subnuclear particles to speeds close to that of light. The head-on collisions of particles like protons and electrons (or their antimatter partners, antiprotons and positrons) produce microscopic fireballs comparable in temperature to that of the universe a few trillionths of a second after it was created in the explosion called the Big Bang.
The energy in these fireballs quickly converts itself into many different types of particles, some of them familiar components of matter and radiation, others so exotic that they exist today only as the ephemeral products of gigantic accelerators.
 
Dwindling Financial Support
 The United States is still a leader in high-energy physics, and Dr. Melvyn Shochet of the University of Chicago proudly enumerated achievements at Fermilab's Tevatron accelerator in Batavia, Ill., in the last year, including the probable discovery of the "top" quark -- the last of the six types of quarks that theory had predicted. But high-energy physics is being starved of energy, in both the literal and figurative senses.
The pessimistic mood apparent at the meeting stems partly from a shortage of financial support for high-energy physics throughout the world, and partly from the isolation many physicists say they increasingly feel. Some speakers also spoke of a need for new theoretical and experimental breakthroughs to impart new momentum to a languishing field.
"We speak a different language from that of people outside our field -- a language that must be articulated by mathematics," said Dr. Julia Thompson of the University of Pittsburgh, an organizer of "outreach" groups of physicists who seek to reduce this alienation from the public.
The spartan salaries of most physicists (and particle physicists in particular) was also a sore point often raised in conversations here.
"It's bad enough that my children keep asking me why we haven't been able to afford a vacation in the last five years," said a particle physicist who has worked on several accelerator projects. "But even my wife doesn't really understand. She can't see why we have to live in near poverty after my having spent eight expensive years earning a doctorate."
 
Communications Gulf
 More serious for particle physics, some said, is the communications gulf between scientists and the politicians who control Federal money.
Among the speakers who addressed this subject was Dr. Murray Gell-Mann, the author of the quark theory of matter, which radically changed the course of science 30 years ago and won Dr. Gell-Mann the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1969.
"I talked to a senator from one of the Southern states who said he was really interested in particle physics, because it has to do with antimatter," Dr. Gell-Mann said. "It turned out that he thought antimatter had something to do with biological antibodies."
But the interaction between Congress and science is no laughing matter, he added.
"If we had built the supercollider, we would have had an exciting chance to find the higher-mass super particles that theories of supersymmetry predict to exist. But the supercollider, which might have had enough energy to demonstrate the existence of these and other fundamental particles, was killed by the House of Representatives -- a conspicuous setback for human civilization," Dr. Gell-Mann said.
 
Search for 'Sparticles'
 The discovery of supersymmetric particles, one of the main goals of high-energy physics, could prove the underlying identity of two basic families of particles -- fermions and bosons. Fermions include such entities as quarks, the building blocks of protons and neutrons, which in turn are the building blocks of atomic nuclei. Bosons, which are the carriers of force, include the photon particles that propagate the electromagnetic force in the form of light, radio and other types of radiation.
Among the supersymmetric particles (dubbed "sparticles") hypothesized by supersymmetry theory is the "gravitino," a partner of the graviton. The graviton is a fundamental (but as yet undetected) particle believed to be the carrier of the force of gravity, corresponding to the bosons that carry the other forces. If theorists are correct, gravitinos would have physical properties in common with those of some well-understood particles of matter, and could serve as a bridge to understanding the link between matter and gravity.
Reconciled to the probability that a decade from now the United States will have to take a back seat in experimental particle physics, some of the dispossessed Americans are seeking jobs at various European and Japanese laboratories, including CERN, the European Laboratory for Particle Physics at Geneva.
But Europe also has acute financing problems, and jobs for high-energy physicists are almost as scarce there as they are in the United States.
 
Wanted: New Careers
 One of the suggestions for underemployed physicists seeking retraining for new careers came from Dr. Fabio Sauli, an Italian physicist at CERN. Dr. Sauli said a type of particle detector being used at CERN and elsewhere has been adapted for use as a clinical X-ray device that exposes patients to only one-tenth the dose they would normally receive, while producing more detailed X-ray pictures.
"I know that many of you are looking for alternative career possibilities in view of the lamentable state of high-energy physics," Dr. Sauli told an audience. "I'm suggesting that medical applications could make use of some of the tremendous capital of manpower and knowledge that has suddenly become available since the death of the supercollider."
Although jobs in high-energy physics are harder to find than at any time since World War II, the intellectual allure of the field remains powerful. "I'm not working as a physicist," said a young woman who was recently awarded a doctoral degree in particle physics. "I guess I'm just another one of the physics groupies who keep coming to meetings like this to enjoy the ideas and problems. There's more to physics than making a living."

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Labor Secretary's Plea Is Hardly a Solution

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has enough trouble without blundering into baseball's labor dispute, but its labor representative has done just that.
Robert Reich, the Secretary of Labor, was at Fenway Park in Boston Sunday, watching a doubleheader but first speaking to players on both teams about the impending players' strike. He spoke to reporters, too, and used that opportunity to call on fans of all ages but especially young fans to write to him at the Labor Department asking players and owners to continue talking. 
 "I can assure you if every kid sends it to me, I will make sure it gets to both sides," he told reporters.
Reich said that the administration would not intervene in the dispute. But by calling for those letters to be written, he was doing exactly what he said he and Washington wouldn't do. He was intervening, or at the least, interfering.
Although the Secretary of Labor has spoken to the chief negotiators in the dispute, he apparently has missed a basic element of the position of each side. The players are poised to strike after Thursday's games because they believe, with good reason, that if no agreement is reached by the end of the post-season, the owners will declare an impasse and unilaterally implement their coveted salary cap.
The only weapon the players have to block that development is a pre-emptive strike while they still have leverage. Striking in November, when the cap would be implemented, the Secretary surely can understand, would do the players no good. That's Labor 101 in your college course book.
Using public pressure -- "Say the season's not gone, Don," the kiddies cry -- to induce both sides to continue talking means the players should put off their strike. The owners would love that; they would be willing to continue talking into the blizzards of winter.
The Secretary could argue that if the negotiators continued talking, they might reach an agreement without needing a strike. Yes, and George Steinbrenner will stop trying to tell his managers how to manage.
If the two sides had ideas that could avert a strike, they have had plenty of time to place them on the bargaining table. They certainly could have introduced them at their bargaining session yesterday, but yesterday they discussed provisions of the expired basic agreement having nothing to do with players' salaries.
They could raise their season-saving ideas today, too, but today they are scheduled to continue discussions in committees on such topics as a joint drug program and international play. They could bring them up tomorrow, when they have said they will confront the critical issue of cost certainty. But the players don't have anything to offer that the owners want to hear, and the owners don't plan to offer any new proposals.
"I'm not negotiating with myself," Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, said the other day.
If the Labor Secretary wants to do something constructive, without interfering, he could use his expertise to develop an economic idea that won't be as onerous as a salary cap to the players but that will go far enough toward the owners' stated need for cost certainty.
If such an animal exists in someone's fertile mind, don't write to the Labor Department; send it directly to Ravitch and Donald Fehr of the players' union. If it's good enough and gets there quickly enough, maybe the strike will last only for a couple of weeks instead of the rest of the year and then some.
Meanwhile, three days remain. They could be three of the most exhilarating days of any season because races, division and individual, abound, and they should be viewed as being definitive; that is, after Thursday, there very likely won't be any chance to alter the outcome.
The Yankees clinched first place in the American League East last Wednesday. Two National League races were decided Sunday. Montreal clinched first place in the East and Los Angeles in the West.
Entering last night's games, the leads in the other three divisions were one game (Cincinnati over Houston, Chicago over Cleveland) and one and a half games (Texas over Oakland). The three-game series between the White Sox and the Athletics that began last night could decide two races.
The two most interesting individual races involve Tony Gwynn of San Diego and Frank Thomas of the White Sox and Albert Belle of Cleveland. Gwynn's race is with no other hitter but with a figure -- .400. He will take a .392 batting average into the Padres' three-game series in Houston beginning tonight.
To reach .400 by the start of the strike, Gwynn would need to get 9 hits in 12 at-bats or 10 in 15, if he bats five times a game. But if he has a hot first two games and gets 7 hits in 9 at-bats, he would be at exactly .400 and should sit out the last game.
Thomas and Belle are vying for the Triple Crown, which no one has claimed since 1967. Thomas went into last night's games leading the American League in hitting with a .362 average to .361 for Paul O'Neill of the Yankees and .360 for Belle. He was tied with Ken Griffey Jr. of Seattle for the lead in home runs with 38, two ahead of Belle, and was tied with Belle and Joe Carter of Toronto with 101 runs batted in , three behind Kirby Puckett of Minnesota.
With so much on the line in the next few days, if the players did not strike or came back after striking, everything that happened afterward might be anticlimactic.

HEADLINE: South Korea's Self-Inflicted Wound

 BODY:
For more than a month, South Korea has been waging a fierce campaign against student radicals and labor militants with methods that have no legitimate place in a democratic society. Washington has muted its public criticism in deference to Seoul's anxieties over the North Korean nuclear program and the delicate succession to Kim Il Sung. But a month has elapsed since his death, and the repression shows no sign of abating, posing a far graver threat to democracy than any subversive scheme hatched in Pyongyang. South Korea's true friends need to speak up.
The crackdown began in June, amid a wave of labor unrest. In the first phase, riot police swept through factories making mass arrests. They also raided university campuses, arresting activist students for allegedly supporting North Korea. That charge falls under Seoul's fearsome National Security Law, which allows long sentences merely for expressing proscribed opinions. 
 Things got even worse after Kim Il Sung died on July 8. Radical students sought to travel north for the funeral and hold public memorial services in the South. These expressions of public sympathy for the man who started the Korean War outraged Southern conservatives and led to intensified campus repression.
Kim Il Sung is widely reviled in the South, where families mourn the relatives and homes they lost in the war. More recently, the North has sponsored acts of terrorism and compels Seoul to remain on constant defense alert. Meanwhile, South Korea's student radicals are notorious for their often simple-minded politics and sometimes violent protest. But suppressing speech and locking people up for their unpopular opinions will not fortify South Korea against external danger.
One reason the South has proved more successful than the North is that it has always been the more open society of the two. But even in Seoul, the word "open" has been qualified. For years, military regimes encouraged economic daring while maintaining tight control over political activities.
That dichotomy broke down under pressure from domestic dissidents and, at crucial moments, pressure from the United States. Since 1987 South Korea has moved toward full political democracy; since early last year it has been led by a former dissident leader, Kim Young Sam.
Mr. Kim should know better than to round up radicals under the National Security Law. The Clinton Administration earlier this year publicly expressed its concerns about the law as well as its hope that Seoul would repeal the statute as soon as possible.
More recently, however, Washington has lowered its voice on human rights issues in general and has seemed particularly reluctant to raise such issues with South Korea in the midst of the nuclear crisis. That reluctance has given Seoul exactly the wrong message. A fresh expression of American concern and hope is urgently needed.

HEADLINE: Farmers and Consumers Have Been Had

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your July 25 front-page article on the rebellion of Iowa farmers against subsidies: Farmers are not getting a good deal from the Government. Farmers reluctantly accepted that if we increased production at artificially low prices, a subsidy would replace the shortfall. That allows the political establishment to give an appearance of cheap food. 
 Both farmers and consumers have been had. Farm programs have artificially reduced farm income to such a level that we liquidate about 500 farms a week and have helped destroy rural America's infrastructure.
America's small towns are not prospering. Their physical decline and the aging of their populations are both the result of national policy.
Food is cheap only at the farm gate. Real food costs must include the cost to the taxpayers to maintain this "cheap-food" policy. Taxes and income will be consumed to pay the increasing national debt this policy in part creates.
If food is so cheap, why do 26 million Americans need food stamps?
Our economy's farm sector lacks the income to cover its costs even with the subsidy. It lacks the income to purchase other goods and services provided by the rest of the economy.
Debate on a new farm bill has been confined to more of the same. We can't let Congress avoid these issues.
The American farmer never wanted to become dependent on subsidies for income. But the choice was to take the subsidy or nothing. We want to do our job and to be paid fairly. We regard the food consumers of America as our greatest ally. Perhaps together we can extract sound policy from Washington.
 
TOM ASBRIDGE
Executive Director
American Agriculture Movement
Washington, July 28, 1994

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Are Mixed Ahead of U.S. Auctions

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of government securities were mixed yesterday ahead of this week's quarterly Treasury refunding. The market was also bracing for a fresh batch of economic reports that should show how fast the economy is growing, and thus provide a clue as to whether the Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates very soon.
Reports on July producer and consumer prices and retail sales could reinforce last Friday's stronger-than-expected employment report, which, analysts said, painted a picture of an economy growing at a brisk pace. 
 The 6 1/4 percent 30-year bond rose 2/32 to a price of 8431/32 for a yield of 7.53 percent, down from 7.54 percent on Friday. The two-year note was unchanged at 9927/32 for a yield of 6.21 percent, while the five-year note slipped 2/32 to 9924/32 for a yield of 6.94 percent and a 10-year dropped 3/32 to 9926/32 for a yield of 7.28 percent.
Matthew F. Alexy, a government trading strategist at CS First Boston, said the government securities market was preparing itself for a Fed action, and cited trading activity in the two-year note as an example.
 
A Spread Narrows
 Last Friday, he said, the yield spread between the 2-year note and 30-year bond narrowed to 134 basis points, the narrowest it has been since April 1991.
"Since the May 17 move by the Fed to a 4.25 percent Federal funds target rate, the two-year note has traded in a 55 basis point range -- between 5.71 percent to 6.26 percent," Mr. Alexy said. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
"We wouldn't be surprised to see rates inside five-years approach three-month highs by mid-August," Mr. Alexy said. "In such an environment the yield curve will flatten further," he added, meaning that the difference between the shorter maturities and longer maturities would narrow.
"The sooner the Federal Reserve reacts in a decisive manner, the closer the arrival of stability on the long end," he said, and he added "early indications are that economic activity will remain subdued over the next three months."
Mr. Alexy said, "If Mr. Greenspan properly manages expectations, inflation will remain in check, and the 30-year bond will not revisit 7.75 percent." With that in mind he suggests that investors should view this week's auctions as an opportunity to get into position for a flatter yield curve.
Traders pointed to rising steel scrap prices as one reason for the market to expect a near-term tightening by the Fed. Steel scrap prices, reportedly one of Mr. Greenspan's favorite inflation guages, are soaring. Prices, after tumbling more than 20 percent this spring, rebounded 12 percent in July and industry analysts predict that prices could return to their 1994 highs, as demand is far outstripping supply.
There is some concern that with the Fed now widely expected to tighten at next week's meeting of its policy making committee, the environment for this week's refunding could not be much worse. The issues will settle just one day before the meeting. Many expect to see no policy change at the meeting, while others predict the Fed will raise rates as much as half a percentage point.
Traders expect that the uncertainty will greatly limit any retail demand during the refunding, which begins with a $17 billion auction of new three-year notes today, followed by $12 billion of new 10-year notes tomorrow, and $11 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday.
In when-issued trading, the three-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.59 percent, the 10-year note, 7.27 percent, and the 30-year bond at a price to yield 7.42 percent.
At yesterday's auction of new three- and six-month Treasury bills the average rate at auction for a three-month maturity was 4.43 percent, up from 4.35 percent a week ago. The average for a six-month bill rose to 4.93 percent, from 4.75 percent last week. Both averages were the highest in nearly a month.
Following are the results of the weekly bill auction:

HEADLINE: Man With a Knife Hurts Seven in a New Haven Coffee Bar

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 8

 BODY:
A man sitting by himself in a coffee bar in New Haven's arts district pulled out a knife at closing time Sunday night and attacked the other patrons, stabbing or slashing seven people as they screamed and struggled to escape.
The man, identified by the police as Daniel Silva, 38, was caught shortly afterward, trying to pedal away from the bloody scene on a bicycle. Authorities said he cried, "Shoot me!" before he was tackled and subdued. 
 Five of the victims remained hospitalized today, one in serious condition, the others in good or fair condition.
In a city whose reputation has been battered by violent crimes in recent years, including the murder of a Yale student in a robbery attempt and a gang shooting on the courthouse steps, officials sought to assure residents that this attack, on one of New Haven's showcase blocks in one of its safest neighborhoods, had nothing to do with drugs, gangs or urban poverty.
"There is a definite mental-health aspect to the case," the Police Chief, Nicholas Pastore, said, saying that Mr. Silva had a history of personal problems and appeared to be distraught over the recent hospitalization of his mother.
Victims of the stabbings, who described a nightmarish scene of panic and terror inside Koffee, said that nothing seemed unusual there until the attacker pulled out a large knife and began attacking.
The man, wearing a ponytail and beard, seemed calm, "like someone you might see in a place like that," said Martin Bresnick, a composer and adjunct professor at the Yale School of Music, who was stabbed in the right thigh and left arm.
"He was sitting there quietly, just drinking his coffee," Mr. Bresnick said. "There was nothing in his demeanor that would make you think he would get up and start trying to kill people. Then suddenly, I heard someone screaming, 'He's got a knife! He's got a knife!' "
Mr. Bresnick said he was stabbed as he tried to back away from the assailant inside the cafe. His wife, Anna Bresnick, a sculptor who heads the art department at the Educational Center for the Arts further down the block, was caught in the crush of patrons trying to get outside.
 
Running for Help
 Ms. Bresnick said she was sitting in another part of the cafe when the screaming began. "I didn't even know what was happening at first, and then my friend, Ruth Shapiro, was trying to push me out the door," she said. "We were trying to crawl out the door and couldn't move because we had fallen onto the floor and gotten tangled up with each other. I thought I was going to be killed right then and there."
When she got out on the street, Ms. Bresnick said, she saw one woman bleeding heavily and her friend's husband, Bruce Shapiro, an editor for The Nation, lying near the curb. She said she ran several blocks for help, not realizing she had been stabbed in the side, before collapsing on the steps of a brownstone.
Candace Blasi, one of Koffee's owners, said 15 to 20 people were in the cafe when the attack occurred just before 10 P.M. One of the seven victims was an employee, Cristina Koning, 22.
The Bresnicks were fortunate enough to be able to go home after being treated for their injuries. Mr. Shapiro, 35, was reported in fair condition at Yale-New Haven Hospital, as was Richard Coleberg, 24. The hospital said that Emily Bernard, 27, was in serious condition, and that Ms. Koning, 22, was in good condition. Kerstin Braig, 29, was reported in fair condition at the Hospital of St. Raphael.
Mr. Silva was being held on $700,000 bond on seven counts of first-degree assault and one count of possession of a dangerous weapon. The police said he was unemployed, and they would not comment on whether he had been treated for psychological problems. He was not known to the patrons or employees of Koffee, which is frequented by Yale graduate students and faculty members who live and work in the area.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 24, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Aug. 9 about the stabbing of seven people in a New Haven coffee bar referred incorrectly to one of the people on the scene. He is Bruce Shapiro, a stabbing victim, not Ruth Shapiro. No one named Ruth Shapiro was involved in the incident. The article also said Mr. Shapiro was married, but he is not.

HEADLINE: Invasion That Never Comes Has Many Haitians Skeptical

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Haitians are asking foreigners here, especially Americans, many variations on a single question, now that the United Nations has authorized an American-led invasion of this country and economic sanctions are at last fully in place: What are you waiting for? When are you coming? Why aren't you already here?
The Haitian economy is in a shambles, with half the work force said to be unemployed. A lack of electricity and gasoline has severely circumscribed all aspects of daily life, leaving most people at home with nothing to do. Tempers are short and the anxiety level, already high, is rising as a result of the state of siege Haiti's military-dominated Government declared last week in response to the United Nations resolution. 
 In such an atmosphere, the invasion Washington has repeatedly threatened if Gen. Raoul Cedras and other military leaders do not step down has come to be seen by many Haitians as deliverance from privation and uncertainty.
"Waiting, waiting, waiting," a clerk at a transportation company here complained a few days ago. "We're tired. It's time to finish this."
Publicly, of course, no Haitian is willing to acknowledge support for an American invasion. A decree issued by the Justice Ministry after the Aug. 1 declaration of a state of siege makes it a crime to advocate any form of foreign military intervention.
But in private, many welcome the prospect of military intervention as the only certain way to end to the wild swings of emotion they have endured since the country's elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, was overthrown in a military coup three years ago next month.
"People aren't just fed up," one diplomat said. "They are mentally exhausted."
Acceptance of intervention is probably most widespread among the poor, who are accustomed to having their fates decided by others. But it can also be detected among the more well-to-do, including some who don't particularly like Father Aristide's populism but are eager for a resolution of the crisis.
"I want to get my business going again and my employees back to work," one American-educated executive said, looking forward to the eventual benefits of an invasion and lifting of sanctions against Haiti. "But you ought to do it soon, because the longer you wait, the more difficult it is going to be for us to rebuild."
Many here feel that the United States is toying with Haiti and its people. Those concerns are exacerbated, and nationalist suspicions awakened, any time a Congressman talks about establishing an American "protectorate" here or the suggestion is made that perhaps a United Nations trusteeship should be installed.
Viewing American policy, some people here detect evidence of a sinister conspiracy. Last month, for instance, five left-wing groups that support Father Aristide issued statements accusing the United States of seeking the failure of economic sanctions in order to weaken Haiti and prepare the way for an American takeover. "Don't be fooled," warned the Haitian Clerical Conference, one of the groups.
 
'The Magic Phone Call'
 Others subscribe to what is sometimes called "the magic phone call" theory. Citing American involvement in the overthrow of Jean-Claude Duvalier and two of the generals who succeeded him, Henri Namphy and Prosper Avril, they argue that all it would take to end the crisis is for the American Ambassador, William L. Swing, to make a single phone call to General Cedras, telling him it is time for him to go.
"That's how you Americans have always resolved these things in Haiti," one Haitian radio journalist argued. "What is keeping Swing from making the call? Is it the Pentagon?"
Given those doubts about American intentions, the latest round of statements out of Washington has baffled and perplexed people here. No sooner had the United Nations passed the July 31 resolution authorizing the use of "all necessary means" to remove General Cedras than the Defense Department began telling reporters that a decision on American military action here was weeks away.
 
Mixed Messages Perceived
 Almost simultaneously, Venezuela, a member with the United States of a five-country group that has been leading the effort to restore Father Aristide, announced a new diplomatic initiative that would entail one last round of negotiations with the military. That effort appears to have foundered, but it demonstrated the disarray within the pro-Aristide coalition and dismayed those here who had been hoping action was near.
American officials here say that they have tried to explain to Haitians that a multiplicity of voices is natural in a democracy like the United States. But they acknowledge that in a country with no democratic tradition, where power is wielded like a club and compromise seen as a sign of weakness, those explanations are largely unconvincing.
"Every time there is a sign of might, there is also what appears to be a sign of appeasement," one Latin American diplomat here said. The Haitian military interprets that as an invitation to stay on, he said, and the Haitian people are left "sitting on the edge of their seats, shaking their heads and waiting for this particular movie to end."

HEADLINE: Millionaire Nominated to Face Georgia Governor

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Georgia Republicans yesterday chose an Atlanta millionaire to face Gov. Zell Miller in the Nov. 8 general election.
The nominee, Guy Millner, founded Norrell Services, the nation's sixth-largest temporary services agency. He defeated John Knox, a former mayor of Waycross in southeast Georgia, in a runoff with 59 percent of the vote. The second election was needed when neither candidate got 50 percent of the vote in the July 19 primary. 
 In Colorado, another millionaire, an oilman named Bruce Benson, easily won the Republican nomination to challenge Gov. Roy Romer, who was unopposed in his bid for a third term. Republicans have not held the governor's office in two decades.
Elsewhere, South Carolina Republicans overwhelmingly favored keeping the Confederate battle flag flying over the Statehouse in primary voting there.
Despite the threat of a boycott by civil rights groups, Republican voters supported keeping the flag by a margin of 76 percent to 24 percent, with 87 percent of precincts reporting. Republicans put the nonbinding question about the flag on their ballot to increase interest in their primary for governor.
In that race, former State Representative David Beasley and Representative Arthur Ravenel Jr. were headed for an Aug. 23 runoff after neither got more than half the vote. The current Gov. Carroll A. Campbell, a Republican, is barred from seeking a third consecutive term.
South Carolina's Confederate battle flag has flown atop the Statehouse in Columbia since 1962, but civil rights groups threaten an economic boycott of the state unless the flag comes down by Labor Day.
South Carolina is the last state to fly the flag atop its capitol, though Georgia's and Mississippi's flags incorporate part of the rebel banner in their design.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE;
Excerpts From Opening Statements in Senate Health Care Debate

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the opening statements of the debate on health care bills in the Senate today. The statements by Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic majority leader, and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican minority leader, were provided by Reuters and the Federal Information Systems Corporation, a private transcription service. The texts of statements by Senators Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, were provided by their offices.
 
STATEMENT BY SENATOR MITCHELL

Madam President and members of the Senate, tonight we begin debate on health care reform legislation. We will undertake no more important task in this Congress. What we do will affect every American family. 
 In preparing this legislation, I was guided by one principle: the purpose of health care reform is the well-being of American families. The insurance industry and health professionals are important parts of the system -- but they're a means to an end. The end -- the real goal -- is the well-being and peace of mind that Americans should have with respect to their health care.
Health care reform is a matter of simple justice. Human beings are born unequal in ability and in strength. None of us chooses our family circumstance. None of us is immune to bad luck. We're all susceptible to accident and illness. We all grow old.
Health care takes 14 percent of our gross domestic product -- more than in any other developed nation. Americans pay the highest medical bills in the world. Thirteen years ago, the average family paid about $145 a month for health insurance. Today, that family pays over $430. If we don't control costs, in six year's time, that family will be paying more than $900 a month for health insurance.
All that expense might be worth it, if America led the world in adult lifespan or in low infant mortality. But it doesn't. . . .
 
Ruining Lives
 Some people can't get coverage for the health condition for which they need care. Some people stricken with serious illnesses find that so-called "lifetime insurance limits" are used up long before their condition improves. Some families, whose children have medical needs, find themselves red-lined out of insurance coverage. So, a sick child's healthy brothers and sisters are put at risk. Some families whose parents suffer disabilities as they age face years of providing in-home care or the bankrupting costs of long-term care because there is no affordable alternative.
Everyone engaged in the health care reform effort has heard, first-hand, the stories of people -- ordinary working people, middle class professionals, high school football stars -- whose health bills are ruining their lives and limiting their futures.
Senator Reid [Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada] told us of a man in Nevada who is able and is willing to pay for insurance for his college student daughter, but he can't because there isn't an insurance company in the country that will insure his daughter. She was born with a malfunctioning adrenal gland and is a victim of juvenile diabetes. She takes medication every day to control her symptoms and sometimes, she needs hospitalization. Her father wants to pay for insurance coverage. He can afford to pay for insurance coverage. But he can't find anyone willing to sell it to him.
He told Senator Reid, and I quote: "Neither Laura or I are looking for a government handout. We are willing to pay, even at a premium price. Isn't it ironic that we mandate automobile insurance companies to pool their assets and provide automobile insurance to high risk drivers, but we do not require the same for health insurance companies. Health is far more important than driving." So said a man from Nevada -- and he was right.
If the states can demand that auto insurers cover the risks resulting from bad driving behavior -- behavior that can be controlled and influenced and prevented, it is not beyond our ability to require health insurers to cover those whose conditions don't arise from behavior, but from circumstances and bad luck. My bill will do this. Insurers won't be able to reject a person because that person had the bad luck to be born with a malfunctioning gland, or to contract a disease in childhood, or to suffer an accident with long-term effects, or for any other cause.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
'Crisis of Affordability'
 High costs are driving ordinary Americans to choices that no civilized society should tolerate. Why is our society willing to allow people to experience the degradation, the humiliation of begging for care after a lifetime of hard work and personal responsibility? It's not fair. It should not continue. There are too many people forced into this kind of choice. There is a crisis in American health care. It is a crisis of affordability and price. It has to change.
I have proposed legislation which I believe will meet the need, which will make needed change with the least disruption to the parts of the system that work well for millions of Americans. The problem is that the money we all pay into our system doesn't deliver to those who need it the care they need when they need it at a price they can afford. People with secure, comprehensive insurance coverage -- members of Congress, Federal workers, state employees, or the employees of most large corporations -- are well served by our system.
But, for millions of other Americans, the situation is very different. For them, the difference between financial security and devastation can be as simple and dramatic as an auto accident or a weak heart valve. The difference between secure coverage and an unaffordable policy can be as heartbreaking as one sick child. That's not fair or right. That's why we need reform.
My approach is to build on the existing American health care system of private insurance and expand it to those not now included; Americans who can't afford insurance, people with an illness that insurers won't cover, and people between jobs. My plan would move most of the persons now covered under Medicaid into the same system of private insurance and care as the rest of us. Put another way, my plan would reduce one of the largest government programs -- Medicaid -- and encourage those in that system to buy private insurance policies.
My bill includes all of the insurance market reforms on which there is broad agreement. Insurance companies won't be allowed to reject applicants for pre-existing conditions. Insurance will travel with the person, so Americans won't be locked into jobs. Policy renewal will be guaranteed so people who become ill aren't cut off from coverage just when they need it the most. My bill creates incentives for cost controls through the competitive pressures of employers and consumers looking for the best-priced coverage.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Toward Universal Coverage
 My bill will create universal coverage through a voluntary approach. Based on discussions with the Congressional Budget Office, I am confident that its provisions will assure that 95 percent of all Americans will be covered by guaranteed, portable, renewable insurance over the course of the next six years.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Health insurance for all Americans is the key to reform. Without it, there will be continued cost shifting. We now have a system where some have coverage and some don't. Those who have health insurance are subsidizing those who don't. That's what cost shifting is.
Doctors, hospitals, clinics, and all other health care providers compensate for unpaid care by charging more to the people who have insurance. That added charge isn't paid by the insurance companies. They add it to the premiums that are paid by every insured family and individual. As a result, insured Americans pay as much as 30 percent more for their coverage to pay for cost shifting. The only way to stop cost shifting is to cover everyone.
To make insurance more affordable, my bill provides for the states to create voluntary regional or statewide health purchasing cooperatives. These co-ops won't be allowed to turn down qualified applicants, and they'll be required to offer a choice of plans to all buyers. Any American in a community-rated insurance pool will be able to enter the federal employee health benefits plan. It offers many different plans among which to choose. Many Americans believe they should have the same health care members of Congress get. My bill provides that opportunity.
 
'My Bill Will Expand Choice'
 My plan reaches the millions of Americans who are self-employed, the millions more who are out of work between jobs, and those now covered by Medicaid. It integrates all of these people into a national system of private insurance. With the end of acute care Medicaid, there will be less government involvement, not more.

 	 	 		. . .	 	A major strength in our system is the element of choice. My bill will expand choice, and will increase incentives to compete by price and quality to those offering insurance coverage. Today, most people's health care choices are limited to one plan that their employer offers. My bill requires every employer to offer at least three plans.

 	 	 		. . .	 	To sum up, let's help deal with the problems faced by small businesses who do provide health insurance to their employees, and encourage those who don't to do so.
 
STATEMENT BY SENATOR DOLE
 We all receive a lot of letters on health care and every other issue. And probably the most eloquent one I've seen so far on this issue was passed on to me by Senator Gregg [Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire] and it was written by Dr. John Schimmerhorn, a constituent of his, and I'd like to share a portion of that letter with you.
And I quote: "Recently my 10-year-old son was the victim of a near-drowning. Thanks to the intervention of people at the scene, he survived the initial incident and was transported to a nearby hospital where he received superb care and treatment, was stabilized and then sent to Children's Hospital in Boston, about an hour away from where we were. With God's help and the outstanding care and treatment that he received in the intensive care unit at Children's, my son is awake, alert and sitting up in his room, surviving with virtually all his physical and mental faculties intact.
"After the initial crisis had passed, I sat in quiet reflection over the entire episode, and it dawned on me with chilling clarity that had the Clinton health plan been in effect, the outcome could have been drastically different. In the scheme of things that the president proposed, we would not have been able to send our son to Boston. We would have been relegated to some other hospital, if any. And the penalty for going against the plan would be a $10,000 fine and possible jail sentence.
"I have no feelings of rancor; just fear that events could have been taken out of my control and put in the hands of some unseen, uncaring, bean-counting bureaucrat whose only concern was compliance to a government policy that only leads to mundane mediocrity."
And he concluded his letter by writing: "The choice comes down a simple question. If you were in my place, would you want the freedom to determine your child's care and outcome, or would you rather be forced to accept what the government will give you?" And I think that's what this debate is all about.
 
World's Best Health System
 America has the best health care delivery system in the world. America has the best health care delivery system in the world. America has the best health care delivery system in the world. And I repeat it three times because I'm concerned that actions we might take in this chamber in the next couple of weeks or so will mean those words are no longer true.

 	 	 		. . .	 	A lot of people have experienced miracles in health care in America, and I've been fortunate to be one of those. And had I returned from World War II to any other nation, I'm not certain what would have happened to me. But in America at the time, in my view, I had the best treatment possible. Now, I'm not here to talk about myself because it was large to me, but mine was just one small miracle among the millions that save and improve and prolong the lives of Americans every day, every week and every year.
And what makes those miracles possible is the American commitment to the freedom of individuals and the freedom of markets, and not the government. And there's something else I know from first-hand experience. The fact is, there's nothing worse than not being able to afford health care for yourself and your family. And I think that's very important that we understand that there's many people out there, as the distinguished majority leader has pointed out, who have that problem today.
And Republicans know very well there are people in need, and Republicans want to help. In fact, we've been working for a year and a half on a bipartisan plan under the aegis and leadership of the distinguished Senator from Rhode Island, Senator [John H.] Chafee, and probably even into the health care debate before President and Mrs. Clinton.
 
Affordability and Accessibility
 The plan sponsored by myself, Senator Packwood [Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon] and 38 other Republican senators that we introduced today will make our system more affordable and more accessible to millions of Americans. And it will be introduced today. It's 619 pages. . . . And if anybody will read it carefully, instead of passing judgment without reading it, they'll find it does a great deal.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Affordability and accessibility, in my view, are the important two words; if you forget all the others, affordability and accessibility. Everybody wants to help those who are blocked from getting insurance because of a pre-existing condition. We believe we can make health care more affordable and more accessible and we can take care of the pre-existing condition and portability and malpractice reform and pooling for small business and probably 25 other things that, if you had a vote in this chamber, it would be 99 to 1. There would probably be one who didn't get the message. But it'd be almost unanimous.
We believe we can do that without new taxes, without having the government tell you what will be included in your health insurance, and without, in many areas, putting Federal bureaucrats in charge of your health care system. And my colleague from Maine, the majority leader, talked about Social Security. It was 31 pages long. Medicare was 110. Senator Mitchell's bill is 1,410 pages. Ours is 619. So they weren't as complicated. Maybe times weren't as complicated.
And Mr. President, it seems to me this debate is just too important, as has already been stated by the majority leader, to degenerate into false accusations and partisan bickering. And it's too important to be completed in any rushed or haphazard manner. And there are a lot of questions that are going to be asked by members on both sides over the next week, several weeks.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
So Many Questions
 So we ask ourselves questions. Will we trade in a health care system based on individual freedom for one based on government control? That's a legitimate question. Will countless small businesses be forced to close their doors and countless more working Americans lose their jobs because of government mandates? That's a serious question. I don't care what you say about mandates; it's a serious question.

 	 	 		. . .	 	And what about new taxes or increased taxes? Some count 17 new; I only count 16. I don't count Part B Medicare as an increase in taxes, because I've long believed that if you could afford it, you ought to pay a little more. And how much is it going to cost?

 	 	 		. . .	 	We haven't learned anything. We appoint this commission and they tell us if we don't do something by the year -- what is it -- 2005 or 2010, we're going to double taxes, double our taxes. So we set out to say: "Well, that's a terrible problem. Let's create some more entitlement programs right now." And we create a new one in our bill, low-income subsidies. But we don't include prescription drugs or long-term care or early retirees or some of the other entitlement programs that have been talked about.
So somebody has to explain all this to us. Maybe we've overlooked something. We appoint one commission to say there are too many entitlement programs; we ought to do something about it. Then we trot out a bill that blithely creates three or four more big ones. These are big ones. Maybe 100 million or more Americans are going to be subsidized; 100 million or more, much bigger than Social Security and Medicare combined.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Now, my point is, there are hundreds of other questions. I may not even have the important ones. But all of these questions deserve lengthy debate, because I'm certain my colleague from Maine is going to say, "No, that's not quite right," or whatever. And he may want to ask us questions, which is certainly fair. So we're talking about all these questions and more and more and more.
 
Getting Public's Consent
 Mr. President, before a patient has surgery or is given some new experimental treatment, the doctor must explain in plain English the treatment's benefits, its risks, its costs and alternatives. This is called, and I quote, "informed consent." And it is crucial to the trust between the patient and the doctor.
Health care reform is an experimental treatment, too. If there's going to be any trust between our government and the public, then the public must have a chance to grant or not to grant their informed consent. And I think we can ask a very legitimate question. Maybe the public shouldn't have a right to know, but I think the public does have a right to know.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Once the American people had what we called informed consent on the President's bill, it went down and down and down, regardless of the efforts by many in the liberal media who bought into the program and tried to sell it every chance they had -- on the evening news, in the newspapers. But the American people weren't buying because they understand that there's a little tilt out there in the media sometimes. They're all good people, but they have a little different view.
And so the American people said, "Wait a minute." And it wasn't Harry and Louise. It wasn't the Republicans. They said, "Wait a minute. I don't understand the President's bill." And if you walk into a drug store or grocery store and you read the label on some product and you don't understand it, I'll bet you walk on. You don't pick it up. You don't buy it. And the American people didn't buy the Clinton health plan because it was too complicated, too bureaucratic, too many taxes, too many controls, too many mandates.
 
STATEMENT BY SENATOR KENNEDY
 On a personal level, this is a special moment for me. I introduced my first universal health care plan in 1970 and I have been working on this issue ever since. One of my strongest memories is a series of hearings we held around the country in 1978, where we learned of the health care tragedies affecting Americans all over the country.
I remember especially one family, the Corbetts. Their child had spina bifida. The Corbetts' insurance didn't cover the costs of therapy for their son, and their unpaid bills mounted rapidly. Hounded by bill collectors, Mrs. Corbett began to worry about the cost whenever her children needed care. Once, her daughter urgently needed hospitalization after a convulsion. She did what she had to do. But I'll never forget what she told me: "I put my child in the hospital, and I cried. I thought we were going to be wiped out for the rest of our lives."
Think of the pain suffered by the Corbett family almost two decades ago. Multiply it by all the American families who have faced similar crises since then. Hasn't there been enough fear and worry? Should we study the problem for another year, or another decade, so that more American families find themselves in the Corbetts' shoes?

 	 	 		. . .	 	As we discuss the Mitchell bill, it is important that we understand the two alternatives. The first is to do nothing -- and that is simply unacceptable. The second is to adopt the Republican proposal -- and that would be equally wrong.
Senator Dole's proposal has already been cosponsored by 39 of his Republican colleagues -- even though it is not a bill. It is only a 37-page outline. But this outline makes it clear that the Dole bill will not guarantee universal coverage. It will do little for the hard-working middle-class families who cannot afford to insure their families and who need help the most. It will not control costs. And it will cut Medicare while offering nothing to our senior citizens -- not long-term care not prescription drug coverage. It is another example of too little too late.
Medicare was a defining test for Congress a generation ago. Social Security was a defining test in the years of the Depression. This legislation is the defining test for Congress today.
 
STATEMENT BY SENATOR KASSEBAUM
 It is with deepening disappointment that I have watched the evolution of the reform debate in recent months. The leadership legislation now before us reflects an unfortunate accumulation of missed opportunities.
We had an opportunity to simplify the current administrative nightmare that is health insurance. Instead, the bill before us is a 1,400-page tangle of new bureaucracy, red tape and government regulation.
We had an opportunity to focus on the root of the public's concern -- namely rising costs. Instead, the majority leader's bill -- like the Clinton plan that preceded it -- has been constructed almost as if cost were no object. Far from "streamlining" the costly promises in the Clinton proposal, the Mitchell bill would create at least four new entitlements and cost taxpayers a projected $1.1 trillion over the next decade.
We had an opportunity to give Americans the security of a truly basic set of benefits guaranteed for everyone. Instead, the majority leader's bill promises an unreasonably lush package -- one that is more responsive to interest group pressure than it is to what average Americans can afford.
We had an opportunity to be honest about financing. Instead, all of us -- in both parties -- have chosen to pay for our desired new entitlements by chopping into existing ones, namely Medicare and Medicaid. We do this knowing full well that such "savings" are not really savings at all, but rather cost shifts to those who have private insurance.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We all want health insurance available to Americans. However, we need to move toward universal coverage through straightforward subsides based on income, not through an expensive and rickety structure of complex subsides and "triggered" mandates.
We all want to control health care costs. I contend we should do so through market disincentives against high-cost health plans -- not by using heavily regulatory limits on prices in the market.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Photos: "THE PLAYERS: The Senate's Face Off"
 
GEORGE J. MITCHELL
 Democrat of Maine. The majority leader of the Senate, he is retiring after his term expires in January. As he is the principal advocate of the Democratic side of the debate and the author of the bill before the Senate, passage of a measure would be a valedictory to his Senate career.
 
BOB DOLE
 Republican of Kansas. The minority leader and a potential Reprublican presidential candidate, he is a strong opponent of the Mitchell measure, which he says gives the Government too large a role in health care. As the Republican leader, his decision on how hard to work against the Mitchell bill, including whether to try to block it with a filibuster, will be pivotal in the debate.
 
EDWARD M. KENNEDY
 Democrat of Massachusetts. As chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, Senator Kennedy has been a leader of liberal legislative efforts. His panel passed a health care bill more generous than President Clinton's original proposal.
 
NANCY LANDON KASSEBAUM
 Republican of Kansas. Senator Kassebaum is the senior Republican on the Labor and Human Resources and once supported measures like limits on insurance premiums as a way to control health costs, but in recent months has been a loyal supporter of Senator Dole's.

HEADLINE: U.S. Lawmakers Agree On Bosnia Arms Measure

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Senate and House lawmakers have agreed on a measure instructing the Clinton Administration to seek the lifting of the arms embargo against the Muslim-led Bosnian Government before the end of October if the Bosnian Serbs do not agree to a peace settlement.
If by then the Serbs had not agreed to the peace plan and if the United Nations Security Council failed to approve an exemption to the arms embargo, American military forces would be barred from enforcing the arms ban under the Congressional plan. 
 The compromise measure, which was proposed by Senator Sam Nunn and is attached to a bill authorizing military spending, is intended to stave off calls for an immediate lifting of the arms embargo while setting a deadline for action.
 
Backed by Administration
 A senior Clinton Administration official said the White House supported the thrust of Senator Nunn's proposal as a way to gradually increase pressure on the Bosnian Serbs to go along with a peace settlement.
The Security Council imposed an arms embargo on the former Yugoslavia in 1991 in an unsuccessful effort to quell the fighting there. But since the Serbs acquired most of the artillery pieces, tanks and other weapons from the old Yugoslav Army, the ban locked in a Serbian advantage in heavy weapons.
While the Clinton Administration agrees that the arms ban has unfairly hampered the Muslims, it has resisted calls by some lawmakers to unilaterally lift the ban, asserting that such a move would undercut the force of other Security Council resolutions.
"The Nunn approach does reinforce our overall strategy to build up pressure on Bosnian Serbs with the lifting of the arms embargo as a last resort," a senior Clinton Administration official said. "At the same time, it provides leverage with our contact group partners," he said, referring to Britain, France, Germany and Russia.
 
Tightening of Sanctions
 American officials have been trying to work out a United Nations resolution to toughen economic sanctions, particularly controls on financial transactions by Serbian-controlled companies. But the American effort has been slowed by disputes with Britain and other allies about how strict the controls should be.
While supporters of Senator Nunn's proposal portray it as an astute compromise, critics assert that it is intended to buy time for an Administration that has come under growing Congressional pressure to lift the arms ban on Bosnian Government.
"Nunn is trying to save the Administration embarrassment and maintain the status quo," said Marshall Harris, executive director of Action Council for Peace in the Balkans, which supports the Bosnian Government.
Senator Nunn's compromise also falls short of Senator Bob Dole's proposal to unilaterally exempt the Bosnian Government from the embargo by mid-November if a peace settlement is not reached.
Senator Nunn's plan, which has been accepted by Senate and House conferees on legislation authorizing military spending, has a number of elements.
 
A Move at the U.N.
 If the Bosnian Serbs continue to resist a peace settlement, the Clinton Administration would introduce a resolution in the United Nations Security Council before the end of October exempting the Bosnian Government from the arms embargo and would actively work for adoption of the measure.
This element of Mr. Nunn's plan is not legally binding, but Congressional aides say President Clinton has promised to go along with it. If the United States was unable to muster support in the Security Council to lift the arms ban, Senator Nunn's plan would prohibit spending funds for American military units enforcing the arms ban. To prevent the Security Council debate from dragging on, the provision cutting off funds could go into effect by mid-November.
American officers attached to NATO command centers could be exempted from the ban on American enforcement if President Clinton thought such an exception was necessary. This provision was added so that the legislation would not have the effect of stripping American officers from important command positions in NATO.
 
Link to Attacks on 'Safe Areas'
 If the Serbs stepped up their attacks on the Muslim "safe areas," Senator Nunn's plan calls on President Clinton to immediately seek Security Council approval for the selective lifting of the arms embargo so that weapons could be delivered to the enclaves that were under attack.
While Administration officials expressed hope that Senator Nunn's move could strengthen their hand with the allies to build pressure on the Bosnian Serbs, Serbia's five-day-old announcement that it was cutting off trade with Bosnia's Serbs, except for food and medicine, has complicated Washington's efforts to tighten economic sanctions.
Generous logistical support from Serbia has been an important factor behind the Bosnian Serbs' ability to capture most of Bosnia, and a prolonged cut-off of supplies from Belgrade would hurt them. But President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia made a similar promise to cut off assistance to the Bosnian Serbs a year ago and never followed through.
Administration officials said that their basic plan was to propose tightened sanctions on trade with Belgrade. The sanctions against Serbia would be eased if Belgrade agreed to allow monitors on its border to verify that it was cutting off aid to the Bosnian Serbs.
"It will take some time to assess fully whether the closure of the border is effective," Secretary of State Warren Christopher told reporters en route from Israel. "It's a long border with a number of crossing points."
"All I can say is there are some encouraging early indications," he said. "But we will be very cautious before we express any final evaluation."

HEADLINE: Months After the Quake, Ghost Towns in the City of Angels

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3

 BODY:
In one abandoned apartment after another along Hubbard Street in Sylmar, wall calendars are open to January, when normal life came to a halt. Scavengers have picked through the rooms so thoroughly that there is almost no sign left of the lives that were lived here before the Jan. 17 earthquake.
Only a few mattresses and broken couches remain. Air-conditioners, refrigerators, even door handles and wall thermostats, have been stripped away. 
 In one littered apartment here in the northern San Fernando Valley, a Jan. 30 edition of The Los Angeles Daily News, evidently brought in by squatters, carries the headline: "The Northridge Earthquake: Some Hard Lessons in Survival."
Nearly seven months after the quake, Los Angeles is still plagued by single blocks or entire neighborhoods of these vacant, damaged buildings, populated by squatters, drug addicts and gangs, as they await demolition or repair.
 
123 Ghost Towns Identified
 The city has identified at least 12 "ghost towns," as they are known here, mostly in the San Fernando Valley, the epicenter of the earthquake, which measured 6.7 on the Richter scale. The areas include scores of low-rent apartments in the Sylmar section of the city as well as two clusters of a dozen or so condominiums and single-family homes in the comfortable Sherman Oaks area.
Though emergency repairs were rapid, and the city's freeways were reopened ahead of schedule, government regulations and bureaucratic procedures, insurance conflicts and a lack of money have slowed housing reconstruction, especially in apartment buildings.
While right after the quake there were 50,200 vacant housing units citywide, that number is now down to 19,400 vacant units, including apartments, condominiums and houses. City statistics show that 4,029 of those units are in the 12 ghost towns.
Many property owners did not have earthquake insurance. Applications for Federal assistance have set records, and the Government has pledged $11.2 billion in aid, more than for any previous disaster.
 
600 Applications a Day
 The Federal Emergency Management Agency, which received twice as many applications as for any previous natural disaster, is still receiving 500 to 600 new applications each day.
Applicants say paperwork and coordination of aid have been nightmarish, and it was only in late July that the city began fencing off and patrolling the filthy and vandalized ghost towns.
Last week, President Clinton announced that he was asking Congress to allocate an additional $225 million primarily "to solve this ghost town problem." The money, which would come from leftover Federal money for repairing freeways and schools, would provide interest-free loans.
Officials say that the ghost town problem can be partly traced to the defeat in June of a $2 billion statewide bond issue for earthquake recovery, which would have included $576 million to provide loans for building repairs. Even though the Federal Government is paying 90 percent of those repairs, that meant California could not pay its 10 percent of the disaster repair costs. Without state help, earthquake victims have besieged Federal agencies.
 
'Things Are Getting Worse'
 As the months have passed, the 12 urban black holes, each with a dozen or more buildings, have blighted their surrounding areas, residents and officials say. Nearby residents are fleeing the neighborhoods, and local retail businesses are collapsing and closing.
"Things are getting worse rather than better," said Richard Close, president of a homeowners association in the Sherman Oaks section. "In areas where 70 percent of residences are vacated we are finding that the remaining 30 percent of people are now moving out because they don't want to live in a ghost town."
"The cleaners, the shoemaker and the little retail establishments just don't have the population they need to survive," he continued. "So even if they physically survived the earthquake, now they are finding major economic problems."
Michael J. Ourieff, owner of Michael J.'s Italian Kitchen, which is on Ventura Boulevard near a ghost town in Sherman Oaks, estimates that the vacancy rate on his street is 40 to 50 percent. Though business was not so bad right after the quake, he said, many people have since moved. "We've been forgotten," he said. "Our business is way, way off."
One vacant store on Ventura Boulevard belonged to Leo Shahinian, who lost his men's clothing stop after business dropped 40 percent. "The damage from the earthquake was significant, but we were able to patch things up," he said. "Then people started moving away."
 
'Giving Up Everything'
 Barry Wegman, a lawyer, owned a $159,000 condominium in a 30-unit building in Studio City that was severely damaged in the earthquake. The building did not have insurance, and his owners association has voted to walk away from it.
"We're giving up everything," he said. "It now goes to the banks. I'm financially wiped out. My cash flow is next to nothing."
Mr. Wegman, who said he lost about $30,000 in equity, applied to the Small Business Administration for low-cost loans but has received no response. He did receive a check from the emergency agency for $3,400 for his moving expenses and is now living with his parents.
In the deserted neighborhoods, rats and cockroaches have proliferated. Stagnant swimming pools have become breeding grounds for mosquitoes, and city officials recently ordered them drained or stocked them with insect-eating fish.
On Hubbard Street in the Sylmar section, vandals shattered windows and sliding glass doors and threw a toilet out a window.
 
Prostitutes and Fires
 Before a recent sweep of the area, prostitutes used looted sofas outside on the curb to wait for customers.
"I come up here every day, three or four times a day, to kick somebody out of here," said Howard January, a security guard hired by the city to keep out squatters. "I had a guy come in last week shopping for clothes. 'Oh, I'm just here looking for clothes.' I said, 'Go ahead and look.' "
In one building, squatters started a fire that burned most of one apartment. Firefighters turned on the water supply to fight it, and since then, Mr. January said, homeless people have been coming by to take showers.
This summer, the city formed an Earthquake Ghost Town Task Force to direct efforts to board up buildings and remove graffiti and debris, and the City Council acted recently to step up that work.
At the end of July, the Federal Emergency Management Agency had received 606,643 applications for assistance, said Marty Zucker, a spokesman for the agency; that surpassed the 304,000 applications filed after Hurricane Hugo in 1989, the previous record. Mr. Zucker said the agency expected to pay out a total of $5.5 billion for the Northridge earthquake.
A spokeswoman for the Federal Small Business Administration said it was processing more applications for low-interest loans than in all disasters over the past five years combined.
"We have had, in the last five years, seven of what we refer to as major, major disasters," said the spokeswoman, Lisa Cookie, listing Hurricane Hugo, the Loma Prieta earthquake in San Francisco, the 1992 Los Angeles riots, Florida's Hurricane Andrew, Hurricane Iniki in Hawaii, Typhoon Omar on Guam and the 1993 Midwest floods. "We have received and processed more applications than we did in the combined total of all those others."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Howard January, left, and Jerome Goodrich are security guards hired by the City of Los Angeles to patrol the 12 ghost towns in areas severely damaged by the earthquake in January. Scavengers, vandals and graffiti scrawlers have added to the destruction. (Jan Sonnenmair for The New York Times)
