HEADLINE: German Court Criticized for Its Treatment of a Holocaust Skeptic

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BONN, Aug. 9

 BODY:
A German court has come under criticism for suspending the one-year sentence of a veteran far-right leader convicted of publicly inciting racial hatred against the Jews. The court said he probably would not do it again now that he knew it was against the law.
The far-right leader is Gunter A. Deckert, national chairman of the 5,000-member National Democratic Party. He was found guilty in 1992 after organizing a meeting in Weinheim where he translated and embellished a speech by an American skeptic, Fred A. Leuchter Jr., casting doubt on the historical fact of the Holocaust. 
 Earlier this year, Germany's highest court ordered Mr. Deckert retried on the ground that he could be convicted only if he had publicly expressed views that were clearly his own. Publicly denying the existence of the Holocaust is a crime under German law, and Mr. Leuchter, who lives in Massachusetts, was also charged, but he has not been tried.
 
Sentence Suspended
 Last June, the three-judge Mannheim court that had convicted him retried Mr. Deckert, 51, a former high school teacher. In its latest ruling, published this week, the court found no doubt that at the meeting, in November 1991, he had clearly violated German law by telling the audience that the Holocaust was a myth.
The court rejected his appeal for acquittal but suspended his sentence in the expectation that he would be more careful next time.
It also rejected the view that Mr. Deckert should have been given a harsher sentence because of the 5,000 far-right attacks against Jews, foreign asylum-seekers and Turkish families that have taken 24 lives in Germany since 1992.
Some leading German politicians have expressed dismay with parts of the ruling.
A leading legislator from Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union, Heiner Geissler, said: "The decision proves, unfortunately, that right-wing radical thinking has also penetrated the thinking of a few judges, and the heads of some people in German justice. You can practically read the decision as a legal guide to how to deny the Holocaust and make anti-Semitic statements without fear of punishment."
Germany's domestic security service, the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution, classified Mr. Deckert's party in its 1993 annual report as an extremist group that encouraged anti-Semitism and racism. The party is not a contender in national elections on Oct. 16.
The court did not respond to Mr. Geissler's criticism of its ruling on a German television program, "Report," on Monday night, but made the full 67-page decision available today.
The news magazine Der Spiegel this week also criticized the court's reasoning.
"The accused made a good impression at trial," the court's decision said. "He is a strong-willed, responsible personality with clear principles who defends his political views with great dedication and a considerable expenditure of time and energy.
"The court believes such a man when he professes obedience to the law, as he did expressly during the trial," the ruling said. "It is to be expected that the accused will stay on the right side of the law in future simply by virtue of his conviction."
Mr. Decker is unemployed and has long been under Government surveillance but had no earlier convictions.
The judges said Mr. Deckert was not an anti-Semite in the racist Nazi sense, but a nationalist who bitterly resented the financial, political and moral demands that Jews continued to make on Germany 50 years after World War II.
They said they were also under no illusion that Mr. Deckert would change his views about the Holocaust, but expected that he would be more careful in the future about expressing them. "We are also not unmindful of the difficult circumstances of the accused, who had to give up his much-loved profession as a teacher after a long and successful career," the judges said.
Though it found he had only his own conduct to blame, the court noted that he had been allowed to teach for years in the southern state of Baden-Wurttemberg by authorities who were aware of his connections with the National Democratic Party and only ordered him to sever them a decade ago.

Firebomb Destroys Mosque
 BOBLINGEN, Germany, Aug. 9 (AP) -- A firebomb destroyed a mosque early today in southern Germany, the latest of several attacks against Turkish-owned buildings.
No injuries were reported in the fire, in Sindelfingen, outside Stuttgart. Both right-wing radicals and Kurds came under suspicion.

HEADLINE: Bosnian Army Makes Gains On Key Fronts

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Though its advances are relatively modest and may not endure, Bosnia's outgunned army has for the first time in more than two years pressed forward along key battlefronts across this war-ravaged country.
United Nations officials announced today that forces of the Muslim-led Bosnian Government were on the verge of winning their most significant victory of the war after routing the main body of a pro-Serbian Muslim militia. 
 Under the command of Fikret Abdic, a businessman and underworld figure, the militia has held a northwestern Bosnian enclave named after its main town, Bihac.
A Bosnian Army thrust toward Mr. Abdic's last stronghold, the town of Velika Kladusa, has sent more than 7,000 rebel soldiers and their family members fleeing northward into a Serbian-held area of Croatia.
Bosnia's official news agency reported today that the Bosnian Army's V Corps had met almost no resistance in capturing 30 villages and 23 square miles of territory in the Bihac pocket. Army commanders told radio reporters that Velika Kladusa would fall within days with little effort.
The army suffered only three wounded in three days and took some 1,400 Abdic loyalists prisoner, a United Nations spokesman said.
"Bihac will now become one more area where the Bosnians will be able to turn their full attention toward the Serbs," another United Nations spokesman said. "Abdic was a thorn in their side, and his defeat will be a boost for the Bosnians' morale."
 
U.N. Fears Rise in Violence
 Surprising even their commanders, Bosnian Army forces have also advanced to within a few thousand yards of a critical Serbian supply line near the northern town of Brcko and routed Serbian forces southeast of the town of Vares.
Today, Sarajevo Radio also reported the capture of high ground that the Serbs had used for more than two years to bombard the town of Gracanica.
United Nations officials here are worried that the Bosnians' military advances -- combined with economic pressure on the Bosnian Serbs to accept a peace plan, and calls in Washington for the lifting of the arms embargo against the Bosnian Government and for more air strikes against the Serbs -- presage an intensification of violence that would force an end to the United Nations peacekeeping mission here.
"Many troop-contributing nations would say they've done enough trying to make peace in a war zone and it's time to turn our investment elsewhere," said the United Nations military commander in Bosnia, Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Rose.
The United States, Britain, France, Germany and Russia threaten to press the United Nations Security Council to stiffen economic sanctions against Serbia if the Bosnian Serbs continue to reject a plan that would require them to recognize Bosnia's sovereignty and hand back a third of the territory they control.
The Bosnian Serbs' main military and economic supporter, Serbia, stopped most commerce with Bosnia on Thursday, though border crossings reopened on Sunday to private cars. But the rebels have sworn to fight on to create a greater Serbian state.
 
Temptation for Bosnians
 United Nations commanders have said that if the embargo amounts to more than just another bluff, the rebel Serbs' huge weapons superiority in Bosnia will evaporate and tempt the mostly Muslim Bosnian Army to try for more territory.
"The evidence should start to emerge in two or three months," General Rose said. But he added that he did not expect the Bosnian Army to be able to assemble enough firepower, trained men and logistical savvy to mount a full-scale offensive for more than a year.
"Modern armies work on fuel," General Rose said, referring to the rebel Serbs' dependence on Serbia for oil. "Without fuel, you've just got lumps of metal."
Bosnian Serb leaders have closed gasoline stations to all but military vehicles, and have ordered the mobilization of the entire adult population into work brigades to free able-bodied men for military service.
The Bosnian Serbs are also reported to have intensified an "ethnic cleansing" campaign against minority Muslims in the Serbian-held town of Bijeljina.
 
Serbian Retaliation Possible
 General Rose said the Bosnian Army advances might spark a violent Serbian response against the most susceptible Government-controlled areas in Bosnia: Sarajevo and three Muslim enclaves in eastern Bosnia, Gorazde, Zepa and Srebrenica.
"It doesn't look very good at the moment," he said. "The Bosnian Army is not in the state to be able to defend the enclaves. I'm not saying Sarajevo would be overrun, but it would be pounded. It would be a catastrophe of enormous proportions."
General Rose was referring to a potential breakdown of the heavy-weapons exclusion zone around Sarajevo, which was imposed by a NATO ultimatum that ended the 22-month Serbian bombardment of Sarajevo six months ago.
General Rose officially says that no more than six rebel-Serb heavy weapons are inside the Sarajevo exclusion zone. But Bosnian radio reported today that the Serbs had used howitzers and mortars inside the zone to shell the towns of Visoko and Breza, from which the Bosnians have mounted recent infantry and artillery attacks.
And it is an open secret in Sarajevo that the Bosnian Army has smuggled mortars, antitank guns and other weapons into the city.

It had been suspended for most of the last 19 days after a series of episodes in which planes came under fire. A Canadian peacekeeper directed a British plane landing with supplies as a Canadian plane took off. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Chip Index Drops in July

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Aug. 9

 BODY:
The Semiconductor Industry Association's closely watched book-to-bill ratio fell to 1.04 in July, down from June's revised 1.07.
"That's basically what we were looking for," said Brett Hodess, an analyst with Montgomery Securities. "That means we saw slightly less than the usual seasonal decline in bookings." 
 Analysts had expected the ratio to fall to about 1.03, because of a seasonal summer slowdown.
The ratio is an indicator of future demand for semiconductors. A book-to-bill ratio of 1.04 indicates that for every $100 in chip shipments in the North American market, semiconductor companies took in $104 in new orders. A ratio of more than 1.0 implies that the market is expanding.
The June ratio was revised downward, from 1.08.
Billings for July, based on a three-month average, decreased 2.5 percent, to $2.65 billion from $2.78 billion in June. Shipments increased 29.6 percent from the July 1993 mark of $2.04 billion.
Actual billings in the month were $2.31 billion, up 26 percent from June's record billings of $3.11 billion, and 25 percent higher that the July 1993 number of $1.85 billion.

HEADLINE: Productivity Of Workers Down 1.2%

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
In a sign that the current business expansion is reaching a mature phase, the Labor Department reported yesterday that the productivity of American workers fell at an annual rate of 1.2 percent during the second quarter -- the first decline in more than a year.
And, in a report economists said could lead the Government to revise downward its estimate of second-quarter growth in coming months, the Commerce Department said stockpiles of unsold wholesale goods fell four-tenths of 1 percent during June. 
 The figure suggests that businesses were not stockpiling goods as rapidly as the Commerce Department estimated when it released preliminary figures for second-quarter economic growth last month.
 
The Inventory Debate
 The sharp gains in inventories reported then sparked a sharp debate in the stock and bond markets about their impact on the economy and on the possible timing of another short-term interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve.
Many analysts had said the rise in inventories, combined with a sharp slowdown in consumer spending, would lead to slower economic growth and a cutback in manufacturing and production in the months ahead. But others, including officials at the Federal Reserve, were worried that consumer spending could rebound and, therefore, the economy could actually grow faster.
Neither of yesterday's reports had much impact on financial markets, partly because a drop in productivity had been widely expected and partly because monthly inventory numbers are subject to constant revision.
The 1.2 percent drop in productivity during the second quarter followed gains of 4.1 percent and 4.9 percent in the third and fourth quarters of 1993 and a revised 2.9 percent rise in the first three months of 1994. Previously, the Labor Department had reported a 1.9 percent gain in productivity during the first quarter.
Analysts noted that the big gains during the second half of last year were consistent with an economy in an early phase of expansion, a period when businesses, in an effort to control costs, work employees longer and harder rather than add to payrolls.
But job growth has been strong since the start of the year -- just under two million jobs have been created in the last seven months. That sort of growth in employment means that productivity, which measures the time, effort and cost of producing goods, is bound to decline.
Reflecting the surge in employment, the Labor Department said the number of hours worked increased by 5.4 percent in the second quarter, more than double the increase reported for the January-March period. The gain in hours was the largest since a 6.1 percent rise in the second quarter of 1988.
"As the expansion continues to mature, the sharp productivity gains of the recent past will probably slow," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities Inc.
During the second quarter, manufacturing productivity, which has outpaced overall productivity in recent years, rose at a 3.8 percent annual rate, the Labor Department said, down from a 6.8 percent increase in the first quarter.
Meanwhile, total business productivity, including farming, fell by 1.4 percent, after rising 2.8 percent during the first quarter.
 
Wage Figures 'Well Behaved'
 Even with the sharp increase in payroll employment, labor costs remained largely in check. Unit labor costs for nonfarm businesses rose 2.0 percent in the second quarter, after a 3.1 percent advance in the first three months.
"The wage numbers were very well behaved," said Stuart G. Hoffman, senior vice president and senior economist at PNC Financial Corporation in Pittsburgh. "You worry about productivity dropping because it suggests you are adding to unit labor costs. But these figures were a bit of a silver lining" in the productivity report.
Mr. Hoffman and other analysts said they expect the productivity numbers to improve a bit in the second half of the year, in large part because they expect a slowdown in economic growth. A slowdown could lead businesses to add workers at a less rapid rate.
"We see employment growth slowing down a little bit, and think the Federal Reserve Board is cooling off the economy a little bit," said David A. Wyss, chief financial economist at Data Resources Inc., the economic forecasting firm.
 
Smaller Stockpiles
 In its inventory report, the Commerce Department said stocks at wholesalers fell by four-tenths of a percent in June, to $222.3 billion, after posting a 1.6 percent increase in May.
Inventories of durable goods like motor vehicles and machinery fell by one-tenth of a percent. Inventories of nondurable items like clothing and groceries fell by a similar amount.
The wholesale inventory number for June follows an earlier report from manufacturers which showed their inventories were virtually unchanged during that month.
Economists will get another piece of the inventory picture on Friday, when business inventory figures are scheduled to be released.
Based on the June numbers that have been reported, Mr. Hoffman said that "some of the inventories that were built up in April and May, particularly at the wholesale level, were partly worked off."
Mr. Fine said the drop in wholesale inventories for June "suggests there could be a downward revision in the inventory component of gross domestic product."
But that adjustment need not mean that the overall growth figure of 3.7 percent will change much, he added, "because that change says nothing about possible offsets that might be made in other areas" of subsequent revisions.

HEADLINE: Veneuela Announces Bank Rescue Package

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Venezuela announced a $294 million rescue package today for the nation's second largest bank and claimed a long-running crisis in the financial sector had reached its final chapter.
The financial rescue package for Banco de Venezuela, which has 2.5 million depositors, came a day after the Government seized the struggling institution.
It was the tenth bank officials have taken over since January in a liquidity crisis that has dogged President Rafael Caldera's six-month-old government and exacerbated Venezuela's already severe recession.
The Government also announced at least $253 million in emergency loans to four other banks with liquidity or solvency problems.
An unspecified number of other banks managed to rescue themselves without state aid after shareholders pledged fresh capital to keep them afloat, Norys Aguirre, president of the Government's deposit insurance agency Fogade, said.
Seven other banks avoided the same fate on Monday after shareholders pledged $765 million in fresh capital to keep them afloat.
Information Minister Guillermo Alvarez Bajares said these measures represented "the definitive solution to the problems that have been confronting the national financial system."
 
Normal Operations to Continue
 Mr. Bajares, the chief Government spokesman, insisted all the banks affected would continue operating normally.
"All the financial institutions will keep their doors open to attend the public," he said. "The measures only concern the administration of some banks and in no case affect depositors."
Other top officials, moving to reassure a skeptical and nervous public, said no more banks would be taken over and all deposits at Banco de Venezuela and the other seven banks were fully guaranteed by the state.
Despite such reassurances, analysts criticized the government for effectively nationalizing a large section of the bank industry and failing to tackle the roots of the liquidity crisis.
"Now we have a nationalized bank system, which was the only element lacking to complete the government's model of economic controls," Venezuelan economist Tobias Nobrega said. He was referring to price and currency controls introduced by Caldera June 27.
Jose Grasso, a banker and financial analyst, said the 10 banks taken over since the crisis began in January, together with the other seven that needed capital, represented more than half the financial sector's assets and deposits.
Other economists warned that more of Venezuela's 50 banks would face liquidity problems if the Government did not restore public confidence by guaranteeing all deposits, tightening regulation of the banking sector and quickly improving Venezuela's general economic panorama.
At a news conference today, Mr. Aguirre said authorities hoped to sell Banco de Venezuela to United States or European investors after restructuring and bolstering it with the new funds.
Mr. Bajares said the takeover of Banco Venezuela and the accords reached with the other seven banks were part of the Government's long-term economic stabilization program, which he said would be announced in two weeks.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Doubts Raised on Number of Internet Users

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
Has the Internet been overhyped?
Even as cyberspace is being touted as the hippest place to congregate since the original Woodstock, some experts now contend that estimates of the number of people actively using the Internet web of computer networks may be grossly exaggerated. 
 There is still widespread agreement that the growth of the Internet, and the number of people using it, is exponential; it is seen doubling in size every year. But some network experts say the most commonly cited numbers -- 20 million to 30 million users worldwide -- may be many times too high.
"Suppose there were really only two million or three million," said John S. Quarterman, a highly regarded Internet demographer in Austin, Tex.
In an assessment potentially chilling to all the businesses betting millions of dollars on the premise that they can sell advertising, information and products to the Internet masses, Mr. Quarterman believes that his lower numbers may be a more accurate count of people who are active and reachable on the computer network.
The latest comprehensive survey that tries to estimate the Internet's reach discovered more than 3.2 million "host" computers capable of communicating directly with other computers on the Internet. The data, released late last week by Mark K. Lottor of the consultants Network Wizards of Menlo Park, Calif., marked a stunning increasing of one million additional machines since the survey was last taken in January.
But while Mr. Quarterman and some other experts do not dispute this raw count of Internet computers, they take issue with the common assumption that each of those machines represents an Internet port of entry for perhaps 10 people working from desktop computers. Moreover, the skeptics suggest that as many as one million or more of those Internet ports, and the millions of people who use them, may be walled off to much of the potential incoming traffic on the Internet, as corporations erect electronic "fire walls" in response to mounting concern over computer security and intrusions by hackers.
If Mr. Quarterman's analysis is correct, then his calculations further blur the already vague notion that electronic culture and commerce is just around the corner. Certainly his assessment does much to debunk the myth of an interactive, information web that will eventually link everyone on the planet.
Estimates that there are more than 20 million users of the Internet have excited the imagination of businesses, politicians, social scientists, investors and journalists.
The Internet has been described as a prototype of the Clinton Administration's proposed information superhighways. Companies seeking to tap a vast new customer base are spending millions to stake out storefronts in cyberspace, and Internet-related businesses are popping up in every city of significant size. An Internet electronic mail address is considered de rigueur for business cards today, and even the White House is "on the Net."
The Internet is popular, all right. But is it a less dynamic force than we've all been led to believe?
To be sure, there are those who contend that even the estimates of 20 million to 30 million Internet users are too low, if one counts the users of smaller public and private computer networks, like America Online and Prodigy, that are linked to the Internet mainly to exchange electronic mail. But such links do not allow users to employ some of the most significant features of the Internet, including some of the most impressive ones for conducting electronic commerce on the network, transferring and publishing files, and initiating complex information searches.
"The important variable is what the usage is, rather than what the numbers are," said Gary Chapman, coordinator of the 21st Century Project, a science and technology policy study group at the L.B.J. School of Public Affairs in Austin. "If it's just E-mail, that would have some certain kinds of implications. You could surmise there were a large number of people who were exploring the Net and not getting their noses very far into the tent."
 
'Fire Walls' Disconcerting

 
 And for businesses and policy makers who are planning for a digital future where the Internet delivers tens of millions of interactive users freely sending and receiving all sorts of information over the Internet, the rise of "fire walls," or security barriers, is a significant impediment. Mike Schwartz, associate professor of computer science at the University of Colorado at Boulder, said a 1992 survey of the Internet found that an estimated 35 percent of all Internet computers were barricaded behind fire walls.
"If you start looking at Internet services that require interactivity, things like billing or accounting across the Net, there might be nicer ways to do it if you could directly connect to people," Mr. Schwartz said. But if more and more Internet users erect one-way barriers, he added, "the services you can use are more limited."
Also, Internet surveyors agree, there is no way to know how many computers are truly active on the Internet -- as opposed to ones that are out of service, are turned on only infrequently, or exist only as an address with no corresponding machine. When attempts are made to contact a sampling of computers on the network, typically fewer than 30 percent respond.
Despite his deflationary data, Mr. Quarterman still predicts that the Internet will eventually achieve and surpass the size now widely credited to it. But the future isn't here yet, he says.
 
Opportunity Knocking

 
 Some of the biggest investors in the Internet are unswayed by suggestions that the numbers are overblown.
"Whether it's 6 million or 60 million, it's still an opportunity, and the biggest opportunity is within the business community," said Gail Grant, who manages development of Internet services for the Digital Equipment Corporation in Palo Alto, Calif.
Digital, one of the world's largest computer makers, has an estimated 40,000 computers connected to the Internet for interacting with employees and customers around the world. And the company is spending millions of dollars to develop Internet-related services, like distributing the company's product information and allowing potential customers to test powerful Digital computers remotely over the network.
The latest census of the Internet, released last week by Mr. Lottor of Network Wizards, is part of the tally of Internet "host" computers undertaken several times a year. Host computers are the portals through which others can gain access to the Internet, and counting them is roughly analogous to counting the number of telephone numbers on the world's connected phone systems. Mr. Quarterman acknowledges the numbers as an historically reliable set of data.
Once the number of host computers on the Internet is determined, the next challenge is to estimate the number of people who use each host. The task might be equated to calculating the average number of people who can be reached at a given telephone number.
 
How Use Is Calculated

 
 The commonly accepted figure for computers has been 10 users per network node, a number that derived partly from a survey of corporations several years ago, and partly from the ease of multiplying big numbers by 10.
Based on 10 users per machine, Mr. Lottor's latest survey would yield 32 million Internet users worldwide, a number that was embraced quickly by businesses and organizations that champion the growth of the global Internet.
But the number of users per machine may be as small as one, which is often the case for someone who links his or her home computer to the Internet. Or it could be hundreds of thousands, as would be the case for a giant public network like America Online, which is forging Internet connections.
"I've got more I.P. addresses here than I have staff," said Brad Templeton, publisher of Clarinet Communications, an electronic publisher in San Jose, Calif., referring to Internet Protocol addresses, the defining characteristic in Mr. Lottor's survey. "I've got three machines at home with I.P. addresses. There are coke machines and toasters with I.P. addresses."
Mr. Lottor, in defense of his data, said he was more comfortable counting machines, not people. "I try not to get into the user count, because there isn't really any way to figure it out," he said. Pressed to make a guess, he said: "Five to ten users per machine sounds pretty reasonable."
Based on 3.2 million machines, the net population would then be 16 million to 32 million.
 
'Wrong Expectations'

 
 But Mr. Quarterman, who runs MIDS Inc. an Internet consulting company in Austin, said a more reasonable figure, based on the surge of Internet interest among individual personal computer users, is 3.5 users per machine, which would deflate the Internet population to 11.2 million, assuming all the network host machines are counted.
But Mr. Quarterman questioned even that number, based on his own surveys of Internet system operators. Mr. Quarterman sent detailed questionnaires to 5,000 Internet system operators in his most recent survey, in January 1994, and concluded from the responses that the number of active computers was about 741,000 machines. Using his estimate of 3.5 users per machine, the active Internet population would be about 3 million users, he said. Because only about half the users are in the United States, the Internet population domestically would be 1.5 million.
Mr. Templeton, whose company, Clarinet Communications, is in the business of distributing data over the Internet, was asked if it really makes a difference whether there are 3.2 million computers and 32 million users, as some contend, or perhaps as few as 1 million machines and 3.5 million "reachable" users, as Mr. Quarterman suggests. "It's bad if people get false impressions about how big things are," Mr. Templeton said. "It leads to wrong expectations."

HEADLINE: French Bind: Algerian Ties

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 9

 BODY:
For Algeria's besieged army-backed Government, France's arrest of 17 sympathizers of the Islamic Salvation Front after the killing of five French citizens in Algeria last week represented a rare expression of foreign support for its battle against Muslim fundamentalism.
But in clamping down on suspected Islamic militants operating among the large Muslim population here, France's conservative Government has assumed the risks of becoming drawn ever more deeply into a conflict over which it has little influence. 
 The Government felt it had no choice but to show firmness after the killing of its five citizens last week, but the military arm of the Islamic Salvation Front promptly denounced the arrests as "a declaration of war" and threatened reprisals if the 17 detainees were not soon freed.
 
Tightened Security
 The Government in turn responded by tightening security at airports and railroad stations, bringing police reinforcements to Paris and carrying out some 9,000 identity checks in the last three nights. Today, it also banned five Islamic publications that it said were inciting violence in France.
An immediate result has been to place Algeria at the center of French political concerns, with the Government arguing that it should do all it can to forestall a fundamentalist victory and with opposition voices on the left and the far right urging France not to take sides.
The conflict erupted in January 1992 after the Algiers Government canceled a second round of legislative elections that seemed likely to bring the Islamic Salvation Front, now outlawed, to power. Since then, political violence has taken the lives of some 4,000 Algerians and 56 foreigners.
For France, however, the key question is less what happens in Algeria than how France itself will be affected by events in its former North African colony. And for that reason, the simmering civil war in Algeria is increasingly viewed here as a domestic as well as a foreign policy issue.
While France fears the effect of a fundamentalist takeover in Algeria on the rest of North Africa, its main worry is that it would set off a flood of refugees into France.
Interior Minister Charles Pasqua has warned that an Algerian exodus would be a European as well as a French problem, an argument France has used to try to mobilize economic support for the Algerian Government. But the record shows that both immigrants and refugees from Algeria prefer to come to France.
 
Pasqua Criticizes U.S.
 France's sensitivity was apparent last week when Mr. Pasqua criticized the United States, Germany and Britain, accusing them of harboring members of the Islamic Salvation Front. In light of the killing of 15 French citizens by Algerian militants over the last 10 months, he said, this was an offense to France.
Closer to home, France is already alarmed that Islamic fundamentalists are trying to influence young Muslim immigrants -- or French-born children of older immigrants -- with their radical message.
So far, Mr. Pasqua's measures have produced ambivalent reactions among Algerians here. Many are opposed to the Salvation Front and support the Government's action.
"At least we are protected now," said Kheina Lakrenche, 59, who owns the Bar des Amis in the Belleville district of Paris. "But Pasqua should have acted sooner."
But many Algerians fear a backlash from the campaign against militants. Karim Azaiza, 19, who has both French and Algerian nationality, said he no longer carried his Algerian passport. "If I'm asked where I'm from and I say Algeria, people immediately think I'm a fundamentalist," he said.
 
Fear of a Witch Hunt
 Dalil Boubakeur, dean of the Paris Mosque, expressed similar concerns. He urged Islamic militants not to embark on a terror campaign in France, warning that it could set off "a witch hunt" here. But he also called on the French authorities not to use ethnic criteria in stopping people for identity checks.
On Monday, the Algerian Fraternity in France, which identifies with the Islamic Salvation Front, called for the release of the 17 detainees, but Mr. Pasqua has insisted that they will be held until a country willing to accept them is found. He said they would not be deported to Algeria since they would be at risk there.
Less clear is how France intends to pursue its policies toward the conflict in Algeria itself. The United States has urged the Algerian Government to open negotiations with "moderate" Islamic groups, but Mr. Pasqua has dismissed the suggestion, saying no moderate voice has emerged.
On Monday, Algeria's President, Liamine Zeroual, issued an invitation to eight small opposition parties to end their boycott of a Government-named Transitional National Council and to take part in a dialogue with a view to returning the country to democracy. But no invitation was sent to militant Islamic groups.

HEADLINE: Stocks Flat On Concern About Rates

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks ended mixed yesterday, as interest-rate jitters overwhelmed gains in chemical and technology stocks, and reports of a big hostile tender offer.
"It's a market in which there is a lack of great enthusiasm or continuity of movement," said Dick Stein of MKI Securities. "Nobody is making any real bets." 
 Analysts said the market was on edge because of an expected rise in interest rates next week. If the inflation data that are due later this week prove strong, it will increase the chance that the Federal Reserve will raise rates.
The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 issues closed up 1.95 points, to 3,755.76. In the broader market, losing stocks outpaced gainers, 1,145 to 974, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 0.03 point, to 457.92. The American Stock Exchange index rose 0.62 point, to 442.22.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.03 point, to 252.96. The average share was unchanged.
 
Fed Meeting Planned
 The Nasdaq index rose 2.14 points, to 722.61.
The producer prices and consumer prices reports due tomorrow and Friday come just a few days before next Tuesday's meeting of the Federal Reserve's Federal Open Market Committee, which sets policy and is widely expected to raise short-term interest rates for the fifth time this year.
"I think they are going to raise interest rates next week, but I think the marketplace has already discounted that," an analyst at A. G. Edwards, Alfred Goldman, said.
He said an increase in rates would help the bond market, though the bonds could fall temporarily.
Mr. Goldman said the producer prices and consumer prices this week may show that inflation is not as serious a problem as some people believe. He said the interest rate increases earlier this year had slowed the economy to a healthier, sustainable rate of growth.
Retail sales data for July is also due tomorrow, at the same time as the producer prices report. The consensus is that there will be no change from the previous month.
 
A Hostile Takeover Bid
 Among the news that influenced the market, American Home Products began a hostile $8.5 billion takeover bid for American Cyanamid, sending shares of American Cyanamid up 2 5/8, to 93 5/8, on the Big Board. American Home Products rose 1/4, to 56 1/4.
Traders said American Cyanamid would have difficulty finding a "white knight" after the aggressive move by American Home.
Chemical issues rose in response to recent positive comments by several Wall Street firms. Union Carbide gained 1 1/4, to 32 5/8, Lyondell rose 1 1/4, to 28 5/8, and Dow Chemical added 2, to 72 1/4.
Traders said the technology group was buoyed by an article in The Wall Street Journal that said Fidelity Investments' $35 billion Fidelity Magellan fund was bullish on the group.
Molten Metal Technology soared 4 1/2, to 22 3/4, in Nasdaq trading on news of an alliance with Martin Marietta to clean up pollution at United States Government sites, using Molten's technology. Martin Marietta gained 3/8, to 47.

HEADLINE: Clinton Is Expected to Strengthen the Diplomatic Status of Taiwan

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8

 BODY:
President Clinton is expected to approve a policy change in the next few weeks and raise the political standing of Taiwan, a step that is likely to anger Beijing.
Administration officials said the policy review is on the President's desk awaiting final choices on some options. But in its overall thrust, the new policy will recognize Taiwan's growing economic power in Asia and elevate the status of its diplomats and business representatives. 
 But it will leave Taiwan's legal position as an estranged province of "one China" unchanged, thus continuing two decades of normalization with the Communist Government in Beijing, which has claimed Taiwan's seat on the United Nations Security Council and has persuaded dozens of countries to switch their diplomatic allegiance to Beijing.
 
Recriminations Likely
 The leadership in Beijing has reacted angrily to earlier attempts to bolster Taiwan's diplomatic standing, and there have been sharp recriminations over continuing American military sales to Taiwan. Administration officials expressed hope that the new policy would draw only a mild rebuke.
This week's diplomatic breakthrough between Beijing and Taiwan on accords relating to fishing and the return of plane hijackers indicates that Beijing may have tried to pre-empt the Administration with a clear signal that Beijing's dispute with Taiwan is an internal Chinese affair.
One practical result of the policy change will be to make it easier for Taiwan Government officials and diplomats to meet in United States Government buildings to discuss trade, commerce, military assistance and other issues with American officials. It will also make it easier for officials from Taiwan to visit the United States and for American officials to visit Taiwan.
In an embarrassing episode in May, President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan was not allowed to leave his airplane or sleep overnight on United States soil during a refueling stop in Hawaii on his way to Central America. The incident infuriated members of Congress, who have since invited Mr. Lee to visit their districts.
Taiwan, an island of 20 million led by the Nationalist political party that fled the Communist takeover on the mainland in 1949, has become one of Asia's four "dragon" economies, along with Singapore, South Korea and Hong Kong. Taiwan imported $16 billion in United States goods last year, double the amount of American goods shipped to China.
In a "white paper" in July, Taiwan's leadership called on Beijing "to face up to the fact that China is a divided country under two separate governments." Beijing considers Taiwan a renegade province and has never renounced the use of force if Taiwan's burgeoning independence movement were to come to power and declare independence from Beijing.
Under President Lee, Taiwan's dominant Nationalist party has pursued a dialogue with the mainland while also seeking world recognition for Taiwan as a "political entity," short of nationhood.
"Prior to unification," the white paper states, "these two parts of China should have the right to participate alongside each other in the international community," including representation in the United Nations and regional organizations. "Only when we set aside the sovereignty dispute will we untangle the knots that have bound us for the past 40 years or more and progress smoothly toward unification."
One of the most visible aspects of the policy change will be a name change for Taiwan's offices in the United States; the current title, Coordination Council for North American Affairs, lacks any geographical reference to Taiwan. Taiwan officials in Washington expect President Clinton to select a new name, possibly Representative Office of Taiwan.
Under the new policy, the Pentagon will be free to continue aid to Taiwan's military without consultation with Beijing. It is not clear how this will be reconciled with an accord signed by Washington and Beijing in August 1982 that stipluates annual reductions in military assistance to Taiwan.
The greatest violation of the agreement on military sales occurred in 1992, when President George Bush agreed during his re-election campaign to sell 150 F-16 fighters to Taiwan for $5.9 billion.
A similiar sale by France of 60 Mirage 2000-5 fighters opened a rift in relations between China and France that was only repaired this year when France abandoned further military sales to Taipei.
One Administration official involved in the new policy said the White House expected Beijing to "go along with a twisting" of the 1982 communique, adding that China is "not likely to go to the mat over it."

HEADLINE: Senecas Ponder Novel Deal On Tax-Free Tobacco Sales

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CATTARAUGUS RESERVATION, N.Y.

 BODY:
Prodded by the United States Supreme Court, officials of New York State and the Seneca Indian Nation are discussing a novel solution to a costly bootlegging problem involving sales of tax-free cigarettes and gasoline at reservation stores.
The deal would establish the tribe as the only wholesaler allowed to supply a lucrative chain of reservation stores. In return, tribal officials would help the state for the first time by using their sovereignty to close down wildcat Indian dealers involved in bootlegging. 
 The two sides would share inventory information on the Indians' untaxed sales of cigarettes and gasoline and introduce a special Seneca Nation seal on cigarette packs to control the reservation cigarettes that Albany officials say are now bootlegged far and wide in northern New York, costing the state an estimated $100 million in revenues.
"This is an ambitious undertaking," said the State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, James W. Wetzler, who hopes to produce a model agreement for use with eight other tribes around the state.
Seneca leaders favor the deal because it would considerably bolster the budget and sovereignty of the 6,600-member tribe, which is singular lately in rejecting the boon of Indian casino gambling as too disruptive a cultural force.
"If you're going to cry sovereignty, you've got to step up to the plate," said Ross John, who is on the 16-member Seneca Council, the tribe's legislature.
 
A Reservation Economy
 There are 28 cigarette and gasoline retailers run by Senecas who operate tax free and thereby underprice off-reservation merchants by about 25 percent. The stores, opened over the last 15 years, have been the tribe's first success in building a reservation economy after two centuries of depression. A few Indians, in fact, have become millionaires but do not contribute to tribal coffers. That situation would be remedied under the new approach, which would generate $10 million in wholesale profits annually, doubling the Senecas' communal resources.
The talks began after a recent Supreme Court ruling upholding the state's right to begin taxing non-Indian wholesalers who supply the reservation stores. This put the reservation shops and their 500 jobs in jeopardy. Two years ago, there were arrests and injuries over this issue after a lower-court ruling sparked Seneca civil demonstrations that closed state roads here through the reservation.
With perhaps another month before officials must enforce the Supreme Court ruling, the Cuomo administration and Seneca leaders have been quick to pursue talks on a mutual accord to satisfy tribe and state needs and head off heightened confrontations and litigation. "If we have no agreement, we're looking at another five or six years of limbo and animosity on this issue," warned Patrick E. Brown, director of the State Office of Industry and Community Relations.
Sovereignty-minded Seneca leaders refuse to use the word "negotiations" and are wary of the long history of broken agreements with the state. They remember especially 16 separate attempts by Albany officials to break the tribe's treaty guarantee of 152 years ago to remain forever untaxed. But they say these talks seem to be a remarkable break with Albany's perfidious past.
 
'The Same Language'
 "What's different now is that we're speaking the same language, literally," said Robert B. Porter, the Senecas' first Attorney General, a Harvard Law School graduate. "Signing pieces of paper written in a foreign language by somebody else -- those days are gone," he said of the tribe's slow upturn in self-reliance since the days only a generation ago when a total of three Senecas held on-reservation jobs.
Tribal politics can be sharp-edged, and to critics of the current talks leaders are insisting that, far from informing on Seneca bootleggers to New York authorities, they would approach this as a matter of protecting the tribe's new economic self-interest within the reservation. "We'll take care of this ourselves," Mr. Porter said of Senecas who might try to deal around the wholesale restrictions.
"We need the state's information as much as the state needs ours," Mr. John, the Seneca Council member, added of the pact's basic goal to introduce an overall tracking of incoming wholesale and outgoing retail dealings.
 
Price Advantage
 For the state, the issue is particularly difficult because of pressure from the gas-station and convenience-store lobbies off the reservations to enforce the court ruling and eliminate the Indians' price advantage. Under the agreement being discussed, the Indians would raise their prices closer to those off reservation but maintain part of the current advantage of about $5 a carton and 10 cents a gallon.
Beyond the communal profits as wholesaler, the tribe would collect a surcharge for five years from the retailers of one cent a gallon and three cents a pack to raise money to build the first three tribal-run schoolhouses ever on the 4,500 acres of the Cattaraugus, Allegany and Oil Springs reservations. This would be a payback for the retailers' having given nothing directly to the tribe for the last 15 years.
This is only fair, said Mr. John, who is both a tribal councilor and successful owner of the Iroquois Smoke Shop and gas station. A 38-year-old former construction ironworker, the Senecas' traditional off-reservation job pursuit, Mr. John opened his shop eight years ago and became one of the tribe's pioneer entrepreneurs.
 
'Can Compete Now'
 He has been successful enough to diversify into a construction company, an electronics supplier, and a manufacturer of drug-testing products that he hopes will produce more reservation jobs. "I could never have competed straight off the iron," he said of his roots. "This shop is a training ground for the Senecas. I can compete now and could probably work in a management role for someone else."
As tricky as the three-cornered court issue is for Mr. Brown and the other state negotiators, the Senecas say they feel squeezed too by past wariness, present reality and future hope. Larry Ballagh, a tribal councilor, concedes that the alternative to cooperating with the state is for the Senecas to close their businesses in the face of the court ruling that would introduce taxation.
"But my problem is with the children and grandchildren down the road," he said.
"Here we have the prosperity of my people depending on New York State upholding a law -- I don't know," he said, surveying history with considerable uncertainty.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Anxiety on Fed Makes A Rally Short-Lived

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities declined yesterday, amid continued uncertainty about the economy and the direction of interest rates set by the Federal Reserve.
The Treasury's quarterly auction, which many analysts thought might go poorly because of the threat of another increase in short-term interest rates, began yesterday with a slightly-better-than-expected sale of three-year notes. Dealers and traders have worried that a rate increase during the quarterly refunding could leave them holding new notes and bonds that would be hard to sell. 
 While some analysts expected a rate increase before the Treasury auction, more seem to believe that the Fed would wait to take any action until the Aug. 16 meeting of its rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee.
Still, while the three-year note sale yesterday was a happy surprise, and did help Treasury prices rebound from losses early in the day, market attention quickly shifted to today's auction of new 10-year notes. This stalled the afternoon rally.
The Treasury's 30-year bond declined 9/32 to a price of 8420/32 to yield 7.57 percent, the highest since July 27, when it was 7.61 percent.
In the when-issued market, yields rose for the 10-year notes to be sold today and for the 30-year bonds to be auctioned on Thursday. The 10-year note was offered at a price to yield 7.29 percent, a couple of ticks higher than on Monday, while the yield on the new 30-year bond rose to 7.46 percent, about four basis point higher than Monday. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
At the three-year note auction, the average yield was 6.61 percent, up from 6.54 percent on May 10 and the highest since August 1991, when the yield was 6.92 percent. But the note rallied after the auction, with the yield in the when-issued market slipping to 6.59 percent. Prices and yields move in opposite directions.
Noncompetitive bidding at the three-year note auction, which is sometimes a good measure of retail interest, was the fourth highest in the last six years. Many investors have moved away from the longer maturities, which are riskier and more volatile, to less risky, shorter maturities, which are now offering yields higher than those on 30-year bonds at the beginning of the year.
Adding to the pressure on Treasury prices are the two important inflation indicators that are to be released at the end of the week. The July report for producer prices comes on Thursday, followed by the Consumer Price Index on Friday. The July retail sales data released on Thursday will also be watched closely.
Andrew J. Schnydrig, first vice president and head of domestic fixed-income trading for Bank Julius Baer in New York, said that in a quarterly Treasury auction, the first leg is the easiest. "From an investor standpoint, they would want to be short because of all uncertainty weighing on the market," he said.
Looking ahead, he did not expect the two remaining auctions to have aggressive bidding, particularly because of uncertainty about Fed policy and the economic data ahead.
The Treasury is selling selling $12 billion in 10-year notes today and $11 billion in 30-year bonds tomorrow.
Looking farther down the road, Mr. Schnydrig thinks that Japanese-American trade talks could have a positive effect on bond prices in this country. He believes that if the talks resume and an agreement is reached, this could cause a dollar rally and reverse an 18-month trend of Japanese gradually selling their United States Treasury securities.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Head of Mutual Fund Unit Replaced at Paine Webber

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Paine Webber Group Inc. replaced the head of its mutual fund division yesterday, the latest casualty of a costly and embarrassing bailout of a bond fund that dabbled in risky securities.
Paul Guenther, Paine Webber's president, took over Joyce Fensterstock's position as president of Mitchell Hutchens Asset Management, the mutual fund subsidiary, until a permanent replacement is found, a company spokeswoman said. 
 The move is the brokerage firm's latest attempt to contain the damage from its $268 million bailout of the ailing short-term government bond fund, which this year has lost 7.55 percent through the first week of August, according to Lipper Analytical Services Inc.
"I think it's normal to fire the coach when the team doesn't perform, whether or not the coach is directly responsible," said Michael Lipper, president of the mutual fund research company, which is based in Summit, N.J.
Three weeks ago, the brokerage firm propped up its Short-Term United States Government Income Fund by paying $180 million for its weakest securities -- nearly one-quarter of the fund's value. The rescue was in addition to a $33 million cash infusion and $55 million buyback in June.
The fund's troubles stem from surprising investments in mortgage-backed derivatives, which are securities based on, or derived from, homeowners' monthly mortgage payments.
With the Federal Reserve Board's decision to start pushing interest rates higher in February, the market for exotic mortgage securities dried up and hurt the Paine Webber fund's returns.
While other mutual funds also have been battered by this year's tumbling market for exotic securities, Paine Webber's troubles are particularly shocking.
Most short-term bond funds are considered extremely safe and able to retain their value even in times of market declines.
Ms. Fensterstock had a 16-year career at Paine Webber, and spent the last seven years with Mitchell Hutchins. The move to replace her comes after the resignations of Steve Brown, the fund's portfolio manager, and Ellen Griggs, a former manager.
The Paine Webber spokeswoman said Ms. Fensterstock was "exploring other opportunities" within Paine Webber and declined to say whether Ms. Fensterstock resigned or was fired. Ms. Fensterstock could not be reached for comment.

HEADLINE: Watchdog's Deal Raises Revenue and Eyebrows

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
They seem no different from the direct-mail solicitations that swamp the average householder, these circulars that have appeared in 600,000 New Jersey mailboxes from companies like Aristo Aluminum Siding of Lake Hopatcong, the East Coast Mortgage Company of Clark, King Oldsmobile of Verona and nearly 200 others in the state.
But these fliers arrived in Better Business Bureau of Northern New Jersey envelopes, accompanied by letters emblazoned with the bureau's trademarked "torch" logo. And the nonprofit watchdog group was paid by the advertisers for the mailings.
 
Expanded Services
 The New Jersey bureau, the first and so far the only one in the nation to engage in such a venture, is using the money to expand its services. But consumer advocates and some other Better Business Bureau executives say the experiment presents a conflict of interest, because it promotes the very companies the bureau monitors. 
 The New Jersey program, which is being studied by other bureaus, represents only one of the growing number of revenue-raising strategies used by Better Business Bureaus across the country. Others include 900-number systems and credit-card billing for information calls that traditionally have been free, and charges for mediation and arbitration services.
Also being studied are fee-based partnerships, with on-line services like Compuserve and Prodigy and with Yellow Pages directories.
The New Jersey tactic highlights a deepening internal debate in the 82-year-old Better Business Bureau, a national organization, whose mission is the self-regulation of the business community. Some of its members say they are concerned that the private group is compromising its integrity as it tries to become the nation's pre-eminent provider of information on business practices, and a main source of dispute-resolution services.
"I have a problem with a nonprofit corporation charging the public a fee for access to our basic services," Edward Smith, president of the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan Atlanta, said in an interview. "I don't think it's appropriate for us to say we're funded by the business community to provide free services -- and then start charging for them."
But Joel S. Wein, president of the Northern New Jersey bureau for the last seven years and the force behind the direct-mail advertising experiment, said the growing need for those services meant that the bureaus needed to be open to new ways of doing things.
"We are the victims of our own success," he said. "Many bureaus were hurt badly in the recession, and we've had to look for clever ways to generate revenues."
Critics with a long view say the risk of conflict is inherent in the concept of the self-policing organization, which was founded in 1912, in the era of patent medicines, snake-oil salesmen and emerging Government regulation. Without enforcement powers beyond the ability to stigmatize a business with an "unsatisfactory" rating, Better Business Bureaus have always relied on moral suasion in resolving disputes.
The bureaus are a repository for consumers' complaints about local companies, and offer volunteer mediators in disputes. Perhaps the greatest asset of each bureau is its data base of company ratings, derived from complaint records. The Northern New Jersey bureau, for example, has 50,000 companies in its computerized file, and six "information specialists" who field calls.
The largest of the three bureaus in the state, representing eight counties with a population of about four million, the Northern New Jersey bureau has been operating for 22 years, has a budget of $1.3 million and employs 25 people. It has 1,800 dues-paying members, businesses that pay annual fees that range from $350 a year for small companies to $10,000 a year for big corporations.
 
Modest Profits
 With 185,000 companies in its target area, the bureau received 12,000 complaints last year. Fees covered 35 percent of the bureau's expenses last year.
Profits from the advertising mailings have been promising but modest -- a bit less than $10,000, Mr. Wein said. The money raised will be used to upgrade the bureau's services, including its hot-line -- (201) 539-8222 -- which receives more than 500 calls each workday. "As it is now, too many people get busy signals," Mr. Wein said.
According to Jim Bast, president and chief executive of the Council of Better Business Bureaus, the national umbrella organization based in Arlington, Va., consumer inquiries and complaints to the nation's 163 Better Business Bureaus increased 29 percent last year, to 14.6 million. As a result of those inquiries, the council estimated, the bureaus influenced more than $40 billion of business transactions contemplated by consumers.
But in most bureaus, revenues from membership fees have hardly kept pace with consumers' demands.
Three years ago the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York, which covers New York City, Long Island and the mid-Hudson region, installed a 900-number system for telephone queries. It receives 200,000 of them a year, and now charges an average of $3.80 a call.
 
Testing in Other Cities
 For those unwilling or unable to charge 900-number fees to their phone bills, the bureau assesses a flat credit-card fee of $3.80 for inquiries. There is no charge for mail inquiries.
The 900-number concept is also being tested in Philadelphia, Miami, Buffalo and Los Angeles, Mr. Bast said.
The president of the Metropolitan New York bureau, Barbara Berger Opotowsky, said fees brought in about 10 percent of the New York bureau's budget of $2.8 million. And she said she saw virtues beyond the revenue effect. "It builds a support base among consumers," she said, "and shows we must be accountable to them."
But Mr. Smith of the metropolitan Atlanta bureau said he was concerned that 900-number fees would deter callers who were less well-off. "We don't have anywhere near an accurate accounting of the effects," he said.
Mr. Smith said he was not opposed to a bureau with aspirations to be forward thinking. "We automated our office eight years ago," he said, adding that consumer inquiries had increased to 45,000, from 22,000, since the bureau installed a computerized voice-response system two years ago, providing callers with information 24 hours a day.
The Atlanta bureau does not charge for its service. And while Mr. Smith said he sympathized with "the need to raise money," he acknowledged that the bureau had been blessed with a supportive business community.
So far, the Northern New Jersey bureau has done three mailings, totaling 600,000 pieces. A fourth, of 250,000 pieces, is scheduled for September. As the bureau's sales force of 10 criss-crosses the region signing up new members, it is also trying to sell its direct-mail services.
The six-paragraph letter accompanying each flier says that in the event of complaints, the advertisers have agreed to mediation by one of the bureau's 90 arbitrators and 25 volunteer mediators. The fifth paragraph carries a disclaimer: "The BBB does not guarantee, endorse, recommend, approve or disapprove of any product, service or company."
Advertisers pay 4 cents to 5 cents for each household served, about a penny more than commercial services charge. Gerald Damora, the owner of Morris Window and Siding, of Succasunna, N.J., and a member of the bureau, said that from a single, 10,000-household mailing, he had received 32 responses and made 8 sales, "a wonderful rate of return." A response rate of half a percent is considered good.
"It comes to the homeowner from the Better Business Bureau, and I guess it raises their curiosity," Mr. Damora said. "I'm a legitimate businessman, and they make the public aware of my company. They legitimize my legitimacy."
The New Jersey Department of Consumer Affairs has not received complaints about the mailings, said Nancy Erickson, director of communications for the department, and many of the state's leading consumer groups said they were not aware of the direct-mail program.
The response of Phyllis Salowe-Kaye, executive director of New Jersey Citizen Action, the state's largest consumer organization, with 10,000 members, was typical. "All nonprofits have to look to creative ways to stay alive," she said. "But if the letter states that they don't endorse the companies, then why are they mailing it out?"
Consumers have had a mixed reaction. "I would pay a fee for their arbitration services," said Karen Carrano-Miller, a financial analyst from Nazareth, Pa., who had a dispute about an automobile warranty with a company in Newark. The bureau, she said, interceded for her, and she received the $350 she had sought in the dispute.
"I'd assume the bureau would be endorsing the advertisers," she said. "But I'd only be upset if I had a problem and the bureau didn't follow through."
Another customer of the Better Business Bureau, Elizabeth Kesselring, a massage therapist who lives in Parsippany, N.J., said the bureau had persuaded a car dealer to replace a "lemon" she bought last year.
 
No Conflict Seen
 Miss Kesselring said she "welcomed" direct-mail advertising sent by the bureau, but was less happy with the idea of paying for information. "I don't know why they would have to charge $3 or $4 if they're just sitting at a console," she said.
Mr. Bast, the national council president, said the New Jersey bureau was operating under the council's guidelines, and the direct-mail venture was "definitely not a conflict of interest."
"If there were a conflict with what we stand for -- our integrity -- we wouldn't do it," Mr. Bast said.
Mr. Wein of the Northern New Jersey bureau insisted that his organization could shoulder its dual role as ombudsman and direct-mail peddler. "Our raison d'etre is integrity and the promotion of honest advertising," he said. "We represent the good guys."
Asked whether consumers would notice the disclaimer, he said, "I guess it's possible that some people will not realize that we aren't endorsing these products and suppliers."
"Look," he added, "it's always a balancing act."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Broad Retreat As Fears of Inflation Grow

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most leading currencies yesterday, hurt by falling bond prices and uncertainty over inflation.
The Treasury's auction of $17 billion of three-year notes met with lukewarm investor interest, which further restrained enthusiasm for the dollar. 
 "I'm sensing that the market is looking to the bond market for some direction," said David Gilmore, partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics.
Traders said the dollar remained vulnerable to further downward pressure as the Treasury auctions $12 billion in 10-year bonds today, the second leg of its quarterly debt refunding.
With the Government scheduled to release key inflation reports tomorrow and Friday, analysts said investors were cautious in purchasing dollar-denominated assets. Expectations are widespread that July figures for both producer and consumer prices will show an acceleration in inflation.
Economists see the Producer Price Index for July rising four-tenths of 1 percent, and consumer prices are expected to show a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent.
"The market is going to have trouble with the inflation numbers on Thursday and Friday," Mr. Gilmore said. "So between now and then, I suspect we'll see the dollar sell off along with bonds."
Although traders had recently detected a shift in sentiment for American investments by foreign investors, there was little evidence of strong foreign demand for the three-year note offering.
One additional hurdle, traders said, was Washington's future monetary policy. The Federal Reserve's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee will meet next Tuesday to discuss the economic and monetary conditions. Many expect that the central bank will choose to nudge interest rates higher at that meeting.
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 101.31 Japanese yen from 101.55 yen late Monday. In Tokyo, the dollar had closed at 100.44 yen, virtually unchanged from Monday. The dollar also slipped to 1.5825 German marks from 1.5835 marks late Monday. Earlier in London, the dollar closed at 1.5825 marks, little changed from Monday.
Gold prices rose 70 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, where the December contract closed at $383 an ounce. A late quote from Republic National Bank put spot gold at $378.30 an ounce.
The British pound slipped to $1.5390 in New York from $1.5396 Monday.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Insurance Sales Buoy Equitable's Net

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The Equitable Companies said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose solidly, as improved life insurance sales cushioned the company from the higher interest rates that have hurt its brokerage operations and other Wall Street firms.
Equitable, an insurance and investment banking company based in New York, said its net income rose 44 percent, to $68.5 million, or 34 cents a share, for the three months that ended on June 30, compared with 47.5 million, or 21 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago. 
 Total revenue fell to $1.5 billion, from $1.55 billion.
Analysts said a drop of 48 percent in earnings at Equitable's Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette brokerage unit was a worrisome sign. Rising interest rates have given Wall Street its worst quarter since 1990.
"A year ago, the company was getting most of its earnings from the brokerage business instead of insurance, and now it's the other way around," Ira Zuckerman, an analyst with SBS Financial Group in Westport, Conn., said. "This has been a volatile stock because it has a large brokerage, which belongs to an industry having a bad quarter."
Richard H. Jenrette, chairman and chief executive of Equitable, said a continued improvement in individual life insurance and annuities, which almost tripled its contribution to pretax profit, offset the results of the "harsh environment."
Total assets under management rose to $180 billion in the quarter, from $161 billion in the comparable period a year ago.
 
An Increase in Volatility
 At Equitable Life Assurance Society, the nation's seventh-largest life insurer, earnings, excluding gains from the sale of investments, rose to $62.6 million, from $29.2 million a year ago.
The company's investment business reported earnings of $30.4 million for the second quarter, down from $55.9 million a year ago. At Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, earnings dropped to $21 million, from $40.5 million.
"Increased market volatility, which diminished new underwriting activity and reduced the level of dealer and trading gains," more than offset growth in commissions, fees and other revenue, Mr. Jenrette said.
The quarter has been a difficult one for Wall Street, with Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc., the world's fourth-largest underwriter of stocks and bonds, reporting a decline of 79 percent in second-quarter profit. Earnings at Merrill Lynch & Company fell 27 percent.
The results for Wall Street firms have declined because the three-year rally in the bond market stopped abruptly in February, when the Federal Reserve began raising interest rates. The drop follows a year of record profits on Wall Street, with the industry posting pretax earnings of $8.6 billion for 1993, including $1.5 billion in the second quarter.
Third-party assets under management at investment subsidiaries rose 15 percent, to $129 billion.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Traders Are Proved Wrong By a Decline in Oil Supplies

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday on speculation that American oil supplies rose last week. Traders were caught off guard, however, when an industry report proved them wrong after the market closed.
On other markets, lumber rose its daily limit amid renewed strike threats in Canada, lifting the Commodity Research Bureau index 0.47 point, to 231.52. Copper fell as stockpiles rose. 
 In the American Petroleum Institute's weekly report on crude inventories, stockpiles were reported down 2.8 million barrels, or almost 1 percent. Imports plunged 15.5 percent, to their lowest since May 27.
"Imports are way down," said Tom Curtis, energy research director with Pegasus Econometric Group in New York. "That's a little surprising."
Before the weekly report was released he had predicted a "goodly increase in imports."
The United States normally imports about eight million barrels of crude a day, half of its total supply. Nigerian crude accounted for 10 percent of American imports before a strike by oil workers began early last month.
September crude fell 12 cents a barrel, to $19.30. Unleaded gasoline rose 0.78 cent, to 59.22 cents a gallon, and heating oil rose 0.32 cent, to 50.17 cents a gallon.
In "access" trading after the petroleum report was released, Nymex crude was down 10 cents at $19.20.
Lumber rose as much as rules permit in a single day, to a two-week high, as strike threats grew in British Columbia, which produces 18 percent of the United States wood supply.
"There is concern about the possibility of a strike" by the union that represents workers at nearly 95 percent of British Columbia sawmills, said Paul Court, a commodity broker in Vail, Colo., who specializes in forest products.
Lumber for September delivery rose the daily trading limit of $10 for 1,000 board feet, to $358.30, the highest level since July 25.
Copper fell as stockpiles rose, ending a 45 percent decline in supplies since the beginning of the year that had pushed prices to a two-year high. September copper fell 1.35 cents, to $1.0725 a pound, on the Commodity Exchange. Copper has fallen 8.2 percent since reaching a two-year high of $1.169 a pound on July 19.
Traders are concerned that the strong American demand for copper in the first half of the year may have slowed as inventories rose. Wholesale inventories rose 4.8 percent in June from a year earlier, according to the Commerce Department.

HEADLINE: Chrysler May Cancel Model

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 9

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation said today that it might cancel a new four-door sport-utility vehicle because of worries that it would fail to meet future fuel economy standards.
The vehicle, which is in the planning stages and is tentatively called the Dodge Adventurer, was intended to compete with Toyota's Land Cruiser and Land Rover's Range Rover in the fast-growing luxury sport-utility market. But concerns about future legislation regarding corporate average fuel economy standards for light trucks has prompted Chrysler to reconsider the $100 million project. 
 "What concerns us is we'd have the right project at the wrong time," a Chrysler spokesman, Alex Tsigdinos, said, confirming a report yesterday in The Detroit News. He said the addition of several new competitors in the full-sized sport-utility market was also a factor in Chrysler's decision to review the project.
Sport-utility vehicles are one of the fastest-growing segments in the auto industry today, but some experts fear a sharp rise in fuel prices could quickly cool the sector.
Under current fuel economy rules, each manufacturer's truck line must achieve an average of 20.5 miles a gallon. But the Government is considering increasing that by as much as 25 percent over the next 10 years.
