HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Cadigan Puts Jets on the Hold Button

BYLINE: By FRANK LITSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 9

 BODY:
An offensive guard named Dave will rejoin the Jets on Wednesday. No, not Dave Cadigan, a starter the last three seasons, but now unemployed.
Instead, it will be Dave Ware, a second-year pro who walked out of their training camp here Monday and seemed ready to quit pro football. Tonight, he concluded that he really wanted to keep playing. 
 Cadigan may be out of a job, but he told the Jets today that he was not ready to come back, certainly not for the money they had in mind. During the winter, he bought out the last year of his contract because he was unhappy with his 1994 salary of $825,000. He thought several other teams would be willing to pay more. But no one has.
Meanwhile, Roger Duffy, Cadigan's backup last year, had taken the starting job, with Ware as his backup. But when Ware left camp, the Jets called Cadigan at his home near San Diego. Cadigan agreed to come to camp today, take a physical examination and talk.

 
 
Waiting for Injuries

 
 The Jets did not know if they would offer him a job. And if they did, they warned that because of the National Football League's new salary cap, limiting teams to $34.6 million a year for player salaries and benefits, they could probably pay him $400,000 or less, not $825,000.
So Cadigan and his new agent, James Moran, changed their minds about having Cadigan come here, even just to talk. As Dick Steinberg, the Jets' general manager, explained it:
"Dave Cadigan and his agent decided it would be more advantageous for him to stay home and take more time to evaluate their chances around the league, maybe let a few more injuries occur. Because we didn't have a definite proposal for him, he didn't pick up his plane ticket and won't be in. And maybe they felt we could come up with more money."
Down the road, Cadigan could be a Jet again.
"We keep a list of so-called disaster players," Steinberg said, "and he's still on our list."

 
 
Ware Reassesses Future

 
 With Ware returning, the Jets can put aside that list for now. Ware spent more than an hour here this afternoon talking with Steinberg and other personnel officials. At night, Ware met with his agent, Alan Herman. Later, Herman reported that Ware said he was sure he wanted to play.
"He said he would go into the Jets' office and put his best foot forward," Herman said. "He said he had thought things over and concluded that football was important to him again.
"I think his problem was that he never left New York after last season. He stayed here, he worked out every day and spoke almost every day at schools. He never took a day off. He just put too much pressure on himself."
Coach Pete Carroll said he was looking forward to talking to Ware Wednesday.
"If he doesn't want to play football," the coach said, "he should move on. If he says 'I want to play football, but I don't like it,' maybe he won't come back. If he is certain it's what he wants to do, I'd like him back. But we don't want anybody on this team not sure if he wants to play."

 
 
Report Card on the Coach

 
 Thoughts on Pete Carroll's start as the Jets' head coach:
Quarterback Boomer Esiason: "He put up a basketball hoop and gets you to play with and against him. He holds a family picnic on Sunday afternoon. He gets guys to do things together, and anything a coach can do to bring guys together will pay off."
Outside linebacker Bobby Houston: "No situation can get him down. When the defense gets backed up, he'll clap his hands and say, 'Good, good. Don't you just love it? Let's go.' When the offense is in trouble, he's still upbeat. You can hear some guys saying, 'He's out of his mind.' But he takes adversity as a challenge."
Defensive end Jeff Lageman: "Sometimes I wonder how he gets up so early and at 8 A.M. he's so chipper and I wake up and feel lousy."

 
 
EXTRA POINTS
Cornerback JAMES HASTY (knee), fullback FRED LESTER (ankle) and center DAN SCHMIDT (ankle) have been declared out of Saturday night's preseason game against the Eagles in Philadelphia. Defensive tackle MARK GUNN (thumb) is doubtful and two others, wide receivers ORLANDO PARKER (hamstring) and STEVIE ANDERSON (hamstring), are questionable. . . . Coach PETE CARROLL said cornerback AARON GLENN, this year's first-round draft choice, would also return punts against the Eagles. Last year, playing for Texas A&M, Glenn had the best return average (19.9 yards) among collegians. . . . Every day, NICK LOWERY, starting his 16th N.F.L. season, and TONY MEOLA, starting his first, share field goals and kickoffs in practice. Carroll said he was pleased with the rapid improvement of Meola, the goalie for the United States World Cup soccer team. "He's powering the ball, elevating it quicker, just getting better," Carroll said. "We want to see him on kickoffs, and he'll do that Saturday night. Nick Lowery will be our field-goal kicker."

HEADLINE: Food Notes

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant 

 BODY:

Studying Chinese
A conference on "Chinese Cuisine and the American Palate" will be held Sept. 22 through 24 at Queens College in Flushing. It will explore some of the health aspects and lore of Chinese cuisine, regional Chinese cuisines, the evolution of Chinese restaurants in America, Chinese cooking in American homes and Chinese food as a business.
There will be cooking demonstrations and exhibits of food, equipment and cookbooks. The keynote speaker will be the cookbook author Ken Hom. A banquet will be held at 7 P.M. on Sept. 23. 
 The symposium is sponsored by the Institute for the Advancement of the Science and Art of Chinese Cuisine, an educational organization in Kings Park, L.I., and by the Asian-American Center and the department of home economics, both at the college.
The fee for attending for three days is $30, for one day, $25; for students the fee for the entire symposium is $5. Tickets to the banquet are $35. More information is available from the institute, Box 91, Kings Park, L.I. 11754; (718) 997-4153.
 
Cake Flour Anniversary

Swans Down Cake Flour is celebrating its 100th anniversary with a fine little baking booklet that has 18 classic recipes, 13 of them by Rose Levy Beranbaum, the cookbook author, and the others from the Swans Down company's test kitchens.
Cake flour is a relatively low-gluten, soft-wheat flour sifted to an extra-fine texture, which many bakers prefer for tender cakes. The booklet is $1 and can be ordered from Swans Down 100th Booklet, Reily Foods, Box 60296, New Orleans 70160.
 
Helping Children

During August, Desserts by David Glass is donating 10 percent of its profits to Save the Children, an international nonprofit organization. And fans of the company's chocolate mousse cakes, cheese cakes, carrot cakes and the like have a chance to win a free cake for each week of the year. Stores that sell the cakes have entry blanks for a drawing, which will be held on Sept. 12.
 
Taste of Woodstock
 The updated music of the Woodstock generation will echo through the Catskills this weekend. And for a taste of Woodstock, there is "Famous Woodstock Cooks," by Joanne Michaels and Mary Barile (JMB Publications, $14.95), which was published in 1987 and republished in June.
The contributors include Sylvia Miles, the actress; Paul Draper, the choreographer; Peter Schickele, the musician and conductor; Heywood Hale Broun, the columnist; Milton Glaser, the artist; Mary Orser, an astrologist; Alf Evers, a historian of the Catskill region and Susun Weed, a herbalist specializing in weeds.
Recipes, accompanied by local lore and profiles of the contributors, run from soybean stew and commune cutlets to Cajun shrimp and a gelatin mold with caviar. But the emphasis is on foods one might associate with the Age of Aquarius, like transcendental Tibetan tea, poor-woman's pasta and vegetarian lasagna.
The book is available by mail from JMB Publications, Box 425, Woodstock, N.Y. 12498. Add $2 for postage and 50 cents for each additional book mailed to the same address.
 
English Sugars
 People who use cookbooks published in England often encounter the term "caster sugar." This is a fine-grained sugar similar to extra-fine granulated sugar. Now, unrefined caster sugar from England, Billington's Golden Caster, is available at Balducci's, 424 Avenue of the Americas (Ninth Street). It is pale ivory with a clean flavor that is slightly richer than regular refined granulated sugar. The refining process is what makes sugar snow white.
Balducci's has other varieties of Billington's English sugars, including light and dark brown, both of which have a richer, spicier flavor than American brown sugars. The color is natural and does not come from the addition of molasses or caramel, as in most American brown sugar. The English sugars are somewhat more granular and less likely to harden.
Billington's Amber Crystal Sugar is a fairly coarse pale-brown granulated sugar with a mellow flavor, excellent as a topping, on cereal and in coffee.
The sugars, $2.99 a pound, are produced on plantations in Mauritius, an island in the Indian Ocean.
 
New Brews
 This summer, Zip City, 3 West 18th Street, began brewing some new beers. Weisse, a summer wheat beer, is golden amber with a refreshing fruity tartness. It is being served at the brew pub in a 20-ounce glass for $5 through September and is also sold in a two-liter bottle for $11 plus a $7 deposit.
Carrying home the seven-and-a-half-pound bottle is a serious undertaking. But you can take it back, empty, and then carry it home again, filled, for another $11.
The new rauchbier, made with a smoked malt that imparts a decidedly smoky flavor, is a deeper color and has a somewhat skimpy head. At the brewery a 16-ounce mug is $4. It is also available in the two-liter bottle for $11 plus $7 deposit.
Zip City also makes good, earthy root beer, $1.25 for a 12-ounce mug. It will be available in bottles later in the year.
Another hand-crafted root beer, this one from England, is Virgil's, a dark, spicy brew. Like the Zip City beers, it comes in an old-fashioned stoppered bottle secured with a wire spring. But it is a reasonable 15.2-ounce bottle.
It is sold for $2 to $3.50 a bottle at the Gourmet Garage, 453 Broome Street (at Mercer Street); Greenwich Liquors, 161 Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich, Conn., and Bagel Express, Sterling Plaza, Route 10, Randolph, N.J.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); CHINA (58%); 

STATE: XIZANG, CHINA (58%); APPALACHIAN MOUNTAINS (52%);

LENGTH: 485 words

HEADLINE: Census Justice for Cities

 BODY:
After 14 years of frustrating litigation, New York and other major cities have won a major judicial ruling that holds out hope for correcting the Census Bureau's habitual miscounting of the nation's population. The U.S. Court of Appeals in New York held on Monday that the Bush Administration had failed to justify its refusal to adjust the skewed undercounting of minorities and ethnic groups that cheats cities of the political representation and economic benefits their true numbers deserve.
Almost certainly the Supreme Court will have to review this decision, a profoundly merited intrusion into the Federal Government's discretion in running the census. If upheld, the ruling could shake up the decade's political maps for Congress and state legislatures and force state and Federal governments to rectify inequities in population-based distribution of benefits. 
 The court's opinion, by Judge Amalya Kearse, was joined by Judge Pierre Leval. Ordinarily, as a lower court observed, Federal bureaucrats are sustained unless they acted "beyond the pale of reason." But the appeals court, citing the census's constitutional purpose of fairly apportioning Congressional seats, said that when voting rights were concerned the bureaucrats had the burden of showing that their refusal to adjust the census furthered a legitimate government purpose.
For decades the population survey has missed millions of urban dwellers -- the very people whose crowded living conditions, apathy and suspicion of authority add to the social burdens and service needs that an accurate census can help relieve. The undercount ends up shortchanging cities in Federal and state allocations pegged to the census.
Over the years population experts have developed acceptable statistical techniques to measure the undercount and adjust the tally. But the Bush Administration, no political ally of urban interests, flatly refused to apply those methods.
Judge Kearse's opinion studiously avoids the partisan politics that permeates the dispute. She did not mention the demoralizing fact that former Secretary of Commerce Robert Mosbacher, who rejected census fairness, was between stints as chief fund-raiser for his friend George Bush.
Instead she simply recited years of high-level resistance to the statistical improvements worked out by the bureau's scientists and Mr. Mosbacher's unrealistic insistence on total precision for any alternative methods. All in all, she said, the Secretary plainly had not made a good-faith effort to achieve what the law required him to seek: accuracy, as nearly as practicable.
States that stand to lose numbers in the House of Representatives are certain to seek Supreme Court review even if the Clinton Administration does not. The current Court tends to favor the Federal Government in disputes like this, but the appeals court's reasoned opinion will be hard to reject.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Business Technology
Some experts say that far fewer people use the Internet web of computer networks than the 20 million to 30 million estimated. Indeed, that may be 10 times too high, even though cyberspace is touted as the hippest place since the original Woodstock. [Page D1.]
The F.C.C. ruled that companies awarded pioneer's licenses for new wireless telephone services will have to pay for them. The costs will run into the hundreds of millions of dollars for American Personal Communications, which is controlled by The Washington Post; Cox Enterprises, and Omnipoint Communications. [D2.] 
 Lotus and Intel agreed to develop and market software and hardware jointly for computers and video conferences. [D4.]
 
The Economy
The productivity of American workers fell for the first time in more than a year, indicating that business expansion is reaching a mature phase. And stockpiles of unsold wholesale goods fell in June, suggesting that second-quarter growth may have slowed. [D1.]
Critics charge that the Better Business Bureau of Northern New Jersey is opening itself to conflicts of interest by allowing companies it monitors to send out ads in bureau envelopes. The nonprofit watchdog group was paid by the advertisers for the mailings, and is using the money to expand its services. [D1.]
 
Companies
KPMG Peat Marwick agreed to pay $186.5 million to settle Federal charges that it failed to audit a number of failed and distressed banks and savings institutions properly. [D1.]
Akzo Nobel is likely to pose tough competition for U.S. and European rivals like DuPont, Bayer of Germany and ICI of Britain. The diversified chemicals company was formed by the merger of Akzo of the Netherlands and Nobel Industries of Sweden.[D2.]
Venezuela announced a $294 million rescue package for the nation's second largest bank.[D2.]
American Home Products pressed ahead with its $8.5 billion offer for American Cyanamid. Some analysts still expect a $10 billion to $11 billion bid, but none has occurred. [D3.]
Storage Technology and Network Systems agreed to merge in a stock swap valued at $307 million. [D3.]
Paine Webber replaced the head of its mutual fund business, Joyce Fensterstock, as the fallout continued from a record $268 million bailout of its premier government bond fund. [D3.]
Terra Industries agreed to acquire Agricultural Minerals and Chemicals for $400 million in cash. [D3.]
Equitable Companies' second-quarter profit rose 44 percent, to $68.5 million, because of improved life insurance sales. [D3.]
 
Markets
Stocks were mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.95 points, to 3,755.76, but losers outpaced gainers, 1,145 to 974. Some broader indexes were higher. [D6.]
Prices of Treasury securities declined, even though the Treasury's quarterly auction began with a slightly better than expected three-year note auction. [D5.]
Oil-futures prices fell, with September crude oil off 12 cents a barrel, to $19.30 on speculation that supplies rose last week. But an industry report after the market closed showed a drop. [D15.]
The dollar fell against most leading currencies, slipping to 101.25 Japanese yen and 1.5825 German marks. [D15.]

Carl C. Icahn is presenting a tough choice to investors in American Real Estate Partners, which he controls. An unusual rights offering seems intended to allow him to increase his stake. HEADLINE: White House Memo;
First Things (the Elections) Come First for Chief of Staff

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Leon E. Panetta holds the rank of White House chief of staff. As his very first change of staff suggests, even that grand title understates the job.
Mr. Panetta has yet to reveal a long-rumored reshuffling of the White House or even hire his own aides. But on Tuesday he reshuffled outside the White House, tapping a fellow Californian, former Representative Tony L. Coelho, to in effect run the Democratic Party through the November elections. In part, his move reflects an understanding that President Clinton's agenda is a dead letter if Democrats lose many seats in Congress, as a number of experts predict. 
 It also hints at the breadth and urgency of the political rescue operation Mr. Panetta is conducting. With the President sinking in the polls, his legislative goals imperiled and Whitewater rearing its head yet again, any dramatic White House administrative changes -- changes Mr. Panetta pledged six weeks ago to make "earlier rather than later," if needed -- await more-urgent political duties.
"There are some fundamental problems that need to be addressed now, the most important being the President's legislative agenda," one senior Administration official close to Mr. Panetta said today. Should Mr. Clinton lose the summer's battles on Capitol Hill, this official said, the damage to Democrats "would be considerable."
And so for now, the new chief of staff is also the new chief lobbyist, attending Democratic whip meetings on Capitol Hill to find votes for health-care, crime and trade bills. And he is the chief image-maker, summoning consultants and political friends for advice on how to focus the public's fuzzy view of just what Mr. Clinton stands for.
Perhaps most of all, he is trying to focus Mr. Clinton himself. He is reining in the many aides-without-portfolio who once had fingers and entire hands in almost every Oval Office decision, for example. And he is trying to get the President himself to stop talking so often, for so long, on so many topics.
That may be one of the hardest jobs of all.
Still, one would never know it by talking to the new chief of staff. When Mr. Panetta speaks of managing the most powerful office in the world, he does so in the blandest of bureaucratic language.
"What we're involved in here is the need to make the transition from a campaign organization to a governing organization," he said, "and that means greater discipline, greater lines of authority, greater focus on what needs to be done. Just the overall efficiency and effectiveness of the organization needs to be improved."
 
A Curb on Give-and-Take
 In an interview this week in his White House office, a capacious affair decorated with Ansel Adams landscapes, Mr. Panetta said one of his priorities when he took on his new job on June 28 was to draw clear lines of responsibility among Mr. Clinton's aides. "There has been a tendency to have a group of people trying to manage an issue who may not have been assigned that responsibility under their job description," he said drily.
On any issue of note, Mr. Panetta said, White House advisers must now submit "decision memos" to him, for review and forwarding to the President, rather than hash out policy in the kind of open-ended give-and-take for which this White House became famous.
A second priority, he said, is to insure that aides do not "bypass the process," going around bosses to lobby the President directly. Mr. Panetta has cut back aides' access to the Oval Office.
Mr. Panetta said he had not decided when, or even whether, to undertake a full-fledged reorganization of the White House, much less who should be moved, promoted or let go. The White House did confirm today that he and the President had decided to replace the acting counsel, Lloyd N. Cutler, with Abner J. Mikva, now chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. But Mr. Cutler's departure had been planned for weeks.
Still, there have already been some less-than-full-fledged changes. By Mr. Panetta's account, two of Mr. Clinton's closest advisers and Arkansas friends, Bruce R. Lindsey and Thomas F. McLarty 3d, have circumscribed duties. Mr. Lindsey, who has handled much of the political damage control stemming from Mr. Clinton's days as Arkansas Governor, is now becoming a more generic legal adviser; Mr. McLarty, Mr. Panetta's predecessor as chief of staff, now serves mostly as a liaison to the business world and to conservatives.
A third free-ranging aide with an office next to Mr. Clinton, George Stephanopoulos, now acts as a deputy to Mr. Panetta, focusing on Capitol Hill and the day's brush fires.
Moreover, Mr. Panetta is widely reported to be considering changes in the White House communications staff, which handles public relations and the press, and in the advance office, which plans and helps select Mr. Clinton's trips.
Virtually all these changes are rooted in a worry that the public, confused and worn out by Mr. Clinton's broad list of legislative goals and his varying explanations of personal and political conduct, is starting to write him off. The White House is especially concerned by polls suggesting that the public -- in particular the political independents who carried Mr. Clinton to victory in 1992 -- is increasingly unhappy with his leadership and gives him no credit for the healthy economy or for past victories in Congress.
Mr. Panetta's apparent solution, at least for now, is to plunge into both the White House's message machinery and its lobbying operation. He describes himself as one of the coordinators of the President's strategy for pushing health care legislation through Congress, and said he was lobbying lawmakers to approve Mr. Clinton's crime bill and a new world trade agreement that has unexpectedly met some Republican opposition.
Asked what role that left the White House legislative office and its chief lobbyist, Pat Griffin, Mr. Panetta chuckled and said: "He basically is picking up the rest of the legislative effort, and he works as a member of the team on these issues as well."
Mr. Panetta has also assumed command of an informal group of political and communications strategists who have already reshaped the way Mr. Clinton appears in public.
In recent weeks, the President has delivered more prepared statements and delivered fewer off-the-cuff remarks at photo opportunities. He has staged a nighttime press conference, a setting where advisers believe he looks especially Presidential and where he can appear to be taming the press corps. He has made a point, in virtually every public appearance, of reciting a list of legislative and political achievements of his first term.
Discipline in his public remarks is not easy for Mr. Clinton, who has been known to wax effusive about underwear and his pollen allergy as well as about details of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Indeed, he sometimes falls short: after agreeing last month with Mr. Panetta and the national security adviser, Anthony Lake, to read a statement on Rwanda without taking questions from reporters, he strode to the White House press room, read his statement -- and took questions.
In an interview last week, Mr. Coelho, the Democratic Party's new overseer, said of the President:
"He understands that there has to be discipline, that there has to be a structure, that if it's not there, it's the missing component. He's going to be in good shape.
"But he needs to let Leon be Leon."

GRAPHIC: Photo: If the Democrats lose many seats, the damage to the Administration could be lasting. So Leon E. Panetta's first reshuffling as White House chief of staff was outside the White House, in the party organization. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times) (pg. B10)

HEADLINE: Stocks Up Modestly as Dow Rises by 11

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The stock market posted modest gains yesterday, bolstered by takeover fever among drug stocks and renewed interest in semiconductor stocks.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 11 points at 3,766.76. 
 In the slow summer market, investors kept their eyes on special situations, like American Products' $8.5 billion bid for American Cyanamid. Its cash tender, begun Tuesday, excited investors about the drug sector.
Nasdaq stocks gained, with the index rising 5.59 points, to 728.20, as investors snapped up technology issues. Computer-chip stocks soared on a healthy orders report, and interest also grew in software company stocks.
Eugene Peroni, technical analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott, said the semiconductor book-to-bill ratio for July was in line with or better than forecasts. The industry reported the ratio at 1.04, meaning there were $104 in new orders for every $100 of semiconductors shipped.
"I think it's putting a more positive tone into the market because technology does have the sizzle that can get people excited," said Dennis Jarrett, analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Co.
Mr. Peroni said the gain in semiconductors gave a boost to the overall market. But he said there was still resistance around 3,780 to 3,800 on the Dow as traders fret about a possible hike in interest rates from the Federal Reserve.
 
Federal Open Market Meeting
The policymaking Federal Open Market Committee will meet on Aug. 16 to discuss monetary policy, and Mr. Peroni said Wall Street has already factored in a quarter-point rise in interest rates.
Robert Stovall of Stovall/Twenty-First Advisers said a rotation was taking place among the market's leading issues, with capital goods and heavy industry stocks taking a back seat while investors chase technology stocks and pharmaceuticals.
He noted semiconductors usually make a move up in the fall, and some investors apparently were trying to get an early start on the seasonal move.
In the semiconductor group, Micron Technology rose 3 1/4, to a new high of 42 1/4, Motorola gained 1/2, to 54 and Texas Instruments jumped 3 3/4, to 84.
Elsewhere in the technologies, Hewlett Packard added 2 1/2, to 82 1/4 and networking stock Cabletron Systems rose 2 1/4, to 101 7/8. And Lotus Development rose 4 5/8, to 40 1/4, while Dell Computer jumped 1 3/4, to 32 3/4.
In the drug group, Upjohn rose 1 3/4, to 35 1/2, Bristol-Myers Squibb gained 1 3/8, to 55 5/8 and Merck jumped 1 3/8, to 32 1/4. Also, Lilly jumped 1 7/8, to 50 5/8, while Pfizer gained 1 1/2, to 65 1/8.
American Cyanamid, the object of American Home Products's $95 per share offer, ended unchanged at 93 5/8.
The Standard & Poor's drug company index rose 3.8 percent.
New York State Electric and Gas was a big decliner, dropping 4 5/8, to 20 7/8. The company said it does not expect to earn its allowed return on common equity and the board will continue to review its common stock dividend.
Analyst Mark Luftig of Kemper Securities said the news was a surprise and the dividend could be cut by one-third.
Among other active issues, Dillard Department Stores fell 4 7/8, to 26 5/8. Late Tuesday, the retailer announced disappointing second-quarter earnings.
Lam Research rose 2 7/8, to 36 1/8. The company on Tuesday announced strong earnings, Smith Barney and Kidder Peabody upgraded the stock.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 279.5 million shares, up from 259 million on Tuesday. Advances beat declines 1,186 to 941 on the Big Board.
Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 2.38 points, to 460.30. The American Stock Exchange index rose 1.75, to 443.97.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite index rose 1.24 to 254.20.

HEADLINE: Does This Mean Abortion?;
Vatican and U.S. Battle Over Document for Population Talks

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ROME, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Less than a month before the countries of the world assemble in Cairo to discuss how the planet can avert catastrophic overpopulation, the United States and the Vatican have emerged as the poles of a bitter debate over one central theme: should abortion, in any form, by any name and for any purpose, be legitimized in the lexicon of international relations?
At issue is a document drawn up at a preparatory meeting held in New York in April under United Nations auspices. Yet the arguments of both sides might almost be drawn from different texts as the United States and the Vatican wage a diplomatic war of selective quotations from the same pages to support opposite views. 
 This week alone, the Vatican has produced a detailed critique to show that the Cairo document comes close to a call for abortion on demand. And the chief American negotiator, Timothy E. Wirth, the Under Secretary of State for Global Affairs, has insisted that "neither U.S. policy nor the Cairo document promotes abortion" and, indeed, that the idea is to reduce abortion rates.
 
'Loaded Language'
 So who's telling the truth? By their own definitions, both sides are.
"There are problems of ambiguous language," said a senior Vatican official closely involved in negotiations still under way to seek a consensus before the Cairo conference opens in September. "On each side, some phrases are looked on as loaded language."
Thus, in a debate that sometimes resembles the kind of textual dispute more familiar to theologians, the United States cites Chapter 8, Paragraph 25 of the draft document, which refers, clearly enough, to "proper counseling to reduce the rate of abortion" as an aim that should be pursued as countries seek better health care for women.
The Vatican counters with Chapter 7, Paragraph 1, which advocates the right of women to "safe, effective, affordable and acceptable methods of fertility regulation of their choice," while Chapter 7, Paragraph 4, speaks of services including "pregnancy termination" as part of the "reproductive health" services that should be available to women.
"If Timothy Wirth can say that that doesn't mean abortion, then let's get a wording that's absolutely clear," said the Vatican official, who insisted on anonymity.
Moreover, to support its arguments, the Vatican refers to American objections to Chapter 7, Paragraph 22. This restates the conclusions of a major population conference in Mexico in 1984, saying in part, "Governments should 'take appropriate steps to help women avoid abortion, which in no case should be promoted as a method of family planning.' "
Underlying the textual debate is a profound collision of visions between the United States, where the Cairo conference is seen as a potential harbinger of great change in the lot of women, and the Vatican, where Pope John Paul II sees the gathering as a harbinger of victory for what he terms "the culture of death."
 
'Biggest Battle' for the Pope
 Marco Politi, who covers the Vatican for the Rome newspaper La Repubblica, commented: "After the epic duel with Moscow and the Polish Communist Party to save Solidarity, this is the biggest battle for Pope John Paul II. The stake is the family and the aim is to subdue the United Nations, defeat Clinton and force the Cairo conference to rewrite its manifesto so as to eliminate any reference to abortion laws."
The Vatican argues that, on nine-tenths of the Cairo document, there is no dispute with Washington. And Katie McGinty , director of the White House environment office, said "the confluence of our interests with the Vatican's is so strong" on matters including women's and children's health and the role of the family.
Neither does it seem in dispute that the conference will confront a crucial issue: according to newly released World Bank figures, the world's population, estimated at 5.7 billion, could reach 8.5 billion in the next 35 years. The Cairo conference is aiming to stabilize it at 7.2 billion by the year 2050.
Yet the Vatican's campaign -- the most vociferous and global on a specific issue in years -- is based on a variety of perceptions that seem to preclude consensus in Cairo.
One is the belief that the American aim at the gathering is to enshrine the right to abortion for every woman in the conference's final declaration.
Vatican officials insist that they base this belief on a confidential American cable sent from Washington to United States embassies around the world that, they say, makes it a priority for American diplomats to work toward that aim.
While senior Vatican officials say they have seen a leaked version of this cable, they have not produced it to reporters.
Additionally, Roman Catholic doctrine that life is sacred from the moment of conception and that no artificial means of birth control should prevent the transmission of life dictates its own solution to the population crisis.
"One of the principal convictions of the church is that demographic growth is the child of poverty," said a Vatican reporter, Giancarlo Zizola. "And so it's necessary to work for world economic reform: rather than reduce the numbers at the world's table, you need to increase the courses and distribute them better."
 
A 'Type of Murder'
 In Italy itself, the Vatican has begun an effort to persuade the new, conservative Government to "harmonize" its position for the Cairo conference. The campaign already appears to have had some success. Despite legislation in Italy permitting abortion in some cases, the neo-Fascist Environment Minister, Altero Matteoli, told Vatican Radio on Tuesday that, as far as he was concerned, abortion was a "type of murder."
Some analysts believe the Vatican's campaign is advancing on a broader front.
"In fact, the Vatican has already won a first round," Mr. Politi wrote in La Repubblica. "Diplomatic observers are convinced that the preparatory document for the Cairo conference will be changed in part."
"One-zero for Wojtyla," he added, referring to the Pope by his Polish name.

SECTION: Section A; Page 21; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 3420 words

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE;
Excerpts From Senators' Speeches on the Mitchell Health Care Plan

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from statements made yesterday on the Senate floor in the second day of debate over the health care bill, as transcribed by The New York Times from a broadcast on C-Span.
 
STATEMENT
BY SENATOR ROCKEFELLER
We're all here to confront problems, not to pretend that they don't exist. We're all here to represent the people of our states as part of the same union, bound together as a nation. And now we have reached this moment when we confront a problem called health care in America. In our wake are years and years of speeches about the crisis of rising health care costs and diminishing health care coverage.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We've reached out in terms of making alliances not mandatory but voluntary; we've stretched out the time line. If there is ever to be a mandate, it will never happen until the next century, and only then under certain circumstances, only if the Congress doesn't follow the orders of the commission.
We have reached out. But . . . this does have to be a two-way process. We cannot constantly be reaching out and out and more and more, and then nothing comes back. So it's very hard to reach agreement that way.
So here we are with our years of speeches about this crisis. This debate begins after, as you go over the years, I would say virtually thousands of hearings here in Congress, certainly tens of thousands of hearings. There've been public meetings at our homes and visits that all of us have had with people of our states, hundreds of reports, hundreds of studies and commissions, mountains. They fill cabinets in everyone's offices and in distant chambers somewhere in this complex, telling us some of the grim facts about health care in America.
 
Emphasis on Realism
We have to be realistic. The Senator from Minnesota spoke about the fact that we let the market work. That's one of the compromises that Senator Mitchell has made in his bill, is to give more time for the market to work.
But I have to point out to my friends on the other side that the Department of Labor has recently indicated that workers who are insured, who have insurance through their jobs, that their number dropped from 66 percent to 61 percent over the last 10 years, and that the trend is downward under the voluntary system.
That means, Mr. President, that 5.5 million more working insured Americans are now uninsured. The market system works in different sectors in different ways. Does it work perfectly in health care? I'm afraid not.
At some point we have to draw on everything that we have learned from the experts, from our own constituents and from our own souls, and decide on the actual steps that will solve as much of the problem as we possibly can this year.
With the health care plan submitted by the majority leader, we now have that opportunity. This is a bill that tries to achieve the major goals of health care reform in ways that will work and that we can afford and that are fair.
The majority leader can only offer the rest of us the opportunity to act; he has no powers further than that. Then it's up to us.

 	 	 		. . .	 	If too many senators treat this debate upcoming as only a chance to score points one against the other, one party against the other, their win is the American people's loss. If too many senators also stay stuck on the idea that we should hold off one more time, until next month or next year or the next election, their delay dashes the hopes of millions of Americans, many in my state, that are now thinking maybe, just maybe, something will soon happen here to help them with their health care nightmares.
 
STATEMENT
BY SENATOR KERREY
The question before us is whether or not we have the capacity to bridge the differences between Republicans and Democrats and pass a bill that is urgently needed by the people, urgently needed.

 	 	 		. . .	 	There truly are people in America watching now, hoping that this debate gets interesting, and hoping that the debate, as a consequence of getting interesting, leads to a finished product, the enactment of legislation. The question before us is, Can we bridge the differences? . . .
It is true that we are dealing with a seventh of the U.S. economy. It is true that we are dealing with something that's life and death for the American people, and so we need to give it our full and serious consideration. We're prepared to do that.
 
Demand for Care
Many of us, indeed I would say most of us, have spent a great deal of time studying this issue, a great deal of time at home looking at the problems that are there. It is, as the President said, bankrupting this country. There will be a $38 billion increase from last year to this year just in Federal spending for health care -- $38 billion. . . .
It is a tremendous amount of money, and the President of the U.S., when he started this thing, said it's bankrupting America, and it is bankrupting businesses and, increasingly, it's bankrupting families.
Why? Well, in part we're demanding expensive health care. Not very many of us walk in and say, "Could you give me the cheapest thing you've got."

 	 	 		. . .	 	We've gone from a point in 1950 where 80 percent of the bills were paid with cash; today, 80 percent is either socialized through the Government or it's socialized through insurance. Eighty percent have our health care bills paid for by someone else. And it's a consequence that most of us don't even know what the price is. And most of us in this body need to be reminded that, for tens of millions of Americans, even having a baby can be a financial catastrophe.
Mr. President, it costs $12,000 to have a baby in this city. Imagine that, $12,000. That's two-day normal vaginal delivery. Now the insurance companies only pay for a day. Two-day normal delivery, $12,000.
Mr. President, my babies were born 19 and 17 years ago, and I paid cash. I didn't have to be insured 20 years ago. Why? Because having a baby wasn't a financial catastrophe if you weren't insured.
We have driven increased demand into the system. In order to provide coverage for individuals, in order to reach out and help individuals pay the bills, we've driven increased demand into the system. The price goes up, the requirement for increased subsidies occurs as a consequence.

 	 	 		. . .	 	There are tens of millions of Americans out there who do not have the capacity to pay the bills, who are forced to ingratiate themselves, to remain on welfare before they are told that they're eligible. All of us feel that there's a problem in America. We can see the gaps and differentials that separate Republicans and Democrats, and my sincere hope and prayer is that the momentum that seems to have stopped, that seems to have caused lots of us to say, "Well, I'm not sure we're going to get a bill" ----
I hope that we are able in a quiet moment to acquire the humility necessary to see that the American people are counting on us to set aside our differences and enact legislation this year. It is urgently needed. And we ought to do the best we can and get a bill to the President of the United States so that he can sign it on behalf of millions of Americans who are hoping and praying that we are able to get the job done.
 
STATEMENT
BY SENATOR DOMENICI
I want to talk a little bit about health care reform and the Federal budget.
Now, why would I do that? Because essentially, whether we like it or not, we are going to be voting on legislation that has a big effect on our children and grandchildren in terms of the budget of the United States, whether we are still in enormous deficit position, whether we are still unable to pay our bills as a nation.
And thus, in a very real sense, the effect on the Federal budget of this plan -- and any major plan -- is of extreme importance, and we ought to try our best up front to understand.
It not so easy because we are sending new things to those who make the estimates all the time. Evidence of that today when every section in this bill has been changed, and yet we had some estimated costs in here the day before yesterday. . . . So we must be careful not to saddle our young people and to burden future generations with today's health care costs.

 	 	 		. . .	 	There is no more compelling case for controlling health care costs than their current and projected impact on the Federal budget. Indeed, one of the most critical issues facing the country is continued growth of open-ended mandatory spending in the Federal budget. That is, you create a situation where a citizen is entitled as a matter of law to benefits and if you don't pay them, they can enforce it in a court of law. That's the definition of an entitlement. And this is led today by Medicare and Medicaid and the resulting growth in budget deficits. . . .
New Entitlements
These new entitlements will bring millions of Americans onto the Federal Government's subsidy program, and let me give you the best estimates I can there.
An estimated 100 million Americans will be eligible for Senator Mitchell's premium subsidies alone, not counting the long-term care, which is a new program with new beneficiaries, and other entitlements in this bill. I am not counting them; I am only counting the recipients of subsidies in whole or in part from insurance premiums.
And what's most alarming to me is the growth rate of these new entitlement programs. According to the Congressional Budget Office, the new premium subsidy program will grow over 10 percent a year even after it is phased in.
So if we thought we had things under control and we're getting them there with new health care reform admittedly, right up front the Congressional Budget Office warns us that these subsidy programs will grow at a rate of 10 percent a year even after they are phased in. The Medicare drug benefit, a brand new one, grows at 10.5 percent a year even after phased in. The long-term-care program grows 44 percent a year, according to the Congressional Budget Office once it's in full effect.
So I don't think there can be any mistake about it: The Mitchell-Clinton bill, under the guise of health care reform, will create several new open-ended, runaway entitlement programs.
 
STATEMENT
BY SENATOR CHAFEE
I want to say I'm delighted we're moving into this health reform legislation this week. It's very complicated, but I think it's time for us to do the best we can do struggle for constructive changes that are going to help our citizens lead healthier lives. . . .
No American's going to remain untouched. It's going to affect how we're born, how we live, how we die. And this is far-reaching.
I think I just saw in the paper a note of a little child born in Pawtucket, Diana Rebello, Pawtucket, R.I., born on Sunday night, Aug. 7, in Women and Infants Hospital in Providence. Think of her life and what it means.
And then I think of Theresa Nigrelli of Westerly -- 100 years old, still stringing pearls every day at Nigrelli Jewelers. And she doesn't even need glasses. So we think of her, too.
And the financial aspects of this are mind-boggling. They've been touched on before, but I'd like to repeat: one-seventh of our economy in the United States of America is devoted to health care, one-fifth of the Federal budget. Of the five biggest items in the Federal budget -- Social Security, defense, interest on the debt, Medicare and Medicaid -- it's the last two that are going right off the chart, Medicare and Medicaid. Defense, banging along, going down. Social Security, fairly stable. Interest on the debt going up but not such a substantial amount. But it's the last two that are causing us our principal problem.
Now, the 1,410-page bill before us was only released a couple of days ago, and as I understand -- I'm not sure it's accurate -- I understand that changes are still being made to it. So it's up to us during this debate to air thoroughly for the American people what's in this proposed legislation and to insure that our actions don't make the situation any worse. Clearly we don't want to go backwards.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Now we all know from study and vast experience and listening to witnesses much that's right and much that's wrong with our health care system. And we acknowledge that in many respects it's exemplary: in technology and innovation, the skill of our professionals and the range of choices.
But we also know there are several things that demand reform. And it seems to me very important to keep in mind, What are we trying to do? What's the endgame here?
 
Goal of Security
And I think our objectives are three:
First, we must give Americans health security. We want to insure to hard-working people like Christopher North of North Smithfield, R.I., that he doesn't live in fear of losing his coverage. He, his wife and two sons were covered by his wife's policy through her employer. She lost her job. They applied for a new policy. They were turned down. Why? Because their son had a pre-existing condition. Minor though it might have been, it was enough for the insurance company to turn him down and thus their family's insurance down. . . .
But what about job lock? In other words, staying in a job you want to leave but you can't because if you go to the new place you won't be able to get insurance. Donald Bolster, Bristol, R.I., 13 years with Blue Cross. His wife suffers now from Parkinson's. No other insurance people, plan, will take them on because of a pre-existing condition. They can't shop for insurance coverage. They can't get an alternative plan. They don't have portability. They can't move to another job. That's what's known as job lock.
 
Covering the Uninsured
The second objective: We must extend health insurance to those -- as many as we can -- who are not now covered. We want to make sure that the first group can keep their insurance; the second group we want to extend it to them. We know the statistics: 15 percent of Americans, 37 million Americans, at any one time without health insurance. In my state, it's 92,000 of our citizens -- 15,000 of them are, regrettably, children. Can't get, or don't have, health insurance.
Now who are these uninsured?
Many people have the impression that the uninsured are the poor or the elderly. That's no so. . . . The very poor have Medicaid; the elderly have Medicare.
Ironically, in our system, single-parent families are better-off in terms of health insurance than two-parent families. Single parent families are frequently on Medicaid. But two-family parents aren't. One of them's working and works for a company that doesn't provide it; the other, the wife, is at home or she's working in a firm where they don't provide the insurance likewise. Earn too much to qualify for Medicaid.
The vast majority of people without health insurance live in families in which the head of household is employed for at least some portion of the year. These aren't people who are the unemployed -- never getting a job. They're employed for at least some portion of the year.
In my state, 76 percent of the uninsured are in families in which the head of household works full time; 85 percent have incomes above the poverty level.
Now we all know it's very costly for society when individuals like these don't have health insurance. They're the ones that go into the emergency rooms of hospitals for treatments, for procedures that the hospital emergency room is not the right place. It's far too expensive for these individuals to be. Or else they don't go anywhere. And then the child or the individual, the parent, comes down with a devastating illness, that in the end costs our society far more.
 
Controlling Costs
Now the third objective is to do something about controlling costs. Cost containment is the buzzword that's used.
The cost of health care in our society is getting tremendously expensive for the individual, for the companies, for states -- particularly through Medicaid -- and for our Federal Government.
In the United States as a whole we spend 14 percent of our gross domestic product on health care, more than any other industrial nation. The Federal Government spends 19 percent of its budget, nearly 20 percent, nearly one-fifth of all our expenditures on health care. And that's projected to go up to 25 percent by the end of the century. And local and state governments, particularly through the cost of Medicaid for state government, spend about 15 percent.
Now the country just cannot sustain these costs. You talk about what it's doing to businesses. The statistic is well known that there's a greater cost for health care involved in every automobile that's built by Chrysler and Ford, General Motors, more for health care than there is for the steel in the automobile. Twice as much we spend for health care in the United States per automobile worker per car than is spent in Japan.

 	 	 		. . .	 	There should be a minimal level of Government intervention. Let's not replicate Medicare, which has been fine for the beneficiaries but a disaster in terms of cost containment. That's the ultimate of the micromanagement program. It's cumbersome; it's top-heavy with regulation. It produces a 12 percent annual growth in costs, which is more than double what the private sector's going up in.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Now it seems to be we can begin to debate in earnest, taking up the bill produced by the distinguished majority leader, Senator Mitchell. He's worked hard to fuse the two bills in the Finance Committee and the Labor and Human Resources, which is a herculean effort. And I think we're indebted to Senator Mitchell for the effort he's made.
 
Seeking a Consensus
Now there are a number of provisions in this that cause me great concern. And the Senator from Massachusetts says, Well, Dick, list them. But just don't attack the measure. Tell us specifically what you're talking about. . . .
Maybe I'm misunderstanding. Maybe I don't read the legislation right. Maybe it's changed in the subsequent rewrite. I don't know. But the President and Senator Mitchell and others have indicated they're willing to give voluntary market solutions a try before imposing Government controls. In this bill in many areas in my judgment, that voluntary market solution effort has not been given the chance it deserves.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The Mitchell bill, but for the employer mandate, appears to reflect few of the principles that those of us in the mainstream have: those of us erring on the side of less government intervention, more marketplace competition and effective cost containment. . . .
Does it mean we can't unite?
I believe we can unite.
Does it make sense for us to try for a bipartisan measure that keeps in mind the two objectives we all say we're for?
I think if you ask people out here what are they for, they'd all say two things: We want to increase the number of Americans who have health insurance with our goal of eventually covering everyone. Everybody would agree with that, I think, very few not.
And secondly, our objective is to get costs lower for individuals for companies for state governments and for the Federal Government. Cost containment.
Nearly all of us pay tribute to the effectiveness of the marketplace. We all seem to subscribe to the notion of competition. There'd be very few people get up on the floor of this Senate and say, "I don't believe in competition. I don't believe in the effectiveness of the marketplace."
We subscribe to the notion of competition, those of us in the mainstream. We're for the most part extremely skeptical of government intervention. So why can't we unite behind a bill that incorporates those beliefs? . . .
 
'What an Opportunity'
I and all the other members of the mainstream group want to see good health care reform enacted this year. We'll do all we can to be helpful. We believe it's extremely important to have a bill with broad support.
What am I talking about? 75 or 80 votes in favor. That's not an impossibility. Rather than a measure that sneaks through, 51 or 52.
Time is getting short, but there still remains time to produce a product that will be of great benefit to millions of Americans.
What an opportunity! What a wonderful opportunity!
So let's not let it slip through our grasp.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Says the Fed Uses Anecdotal Guides

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
The head of the nation's central bank told a Congressional panel today that changes in the American economy had made it impossible for the Federal Reserve to follow any one computer model or economic indicator in setting short-term interest rates.
As a result, the Fed tries to gauge the economy's strength and forecast inflation by relying on a broad range of models and statistics and by paying attention to anecdotal evidence from trade groups and advisory councils of prominent business executives, said Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. 
 "Such detailed readings of firm behavior are important, for example, in indicating when inflation pressures are beginning to mount," he told the House Government Operations Committee's panel on commerce, consumer and monetary affairs.
Mr. Greenspan's testimony was further evidence that top Federal Reserve officials look for anecdotal clues about future inflation even though broad price indexes remain stable. Although the Fed's approach to setting interest rates has always been somewhat intuitive, it has grown more so in the last several years as traditional indicators, such as growth in bank certificates of deposit, have tended to show less and less correlation with economic growth.
 
Interest Rate Increase Expected
 Marc W. Wanshel, an economist at J. P. Morgan in New York, said that today's testimony indicated again that the Federal Reserve was soon likely to raise interest rates once more regardless of whether Government price indexes later this week showed higher inflation.
"He reiterated, in a way, that you can't wait for inflation to appear in the broad indexes," Mr. Wanshel said.
The Government is scheduled to announce on Thursday morning how much producer prices rose in July; July's consumer price figures will be released on Friday. The Commerce Department is also scheduled to announce on Thursday the level of retail sales in July.
Mr. Greenspan particularly criticized the quality of consumer price data, saying that he and many other economists felt that the Government had overstated inflation, driving up the cost of Federal programs linked to the consumer price index. But even the true, lower rate of inflation could be a long-term problem, he said.
Many Wall Street analysts expect that the Federal Reserve's interest-rate policy committee will raise rates soon, possibly at its meeting next Tuesday. They point to signs that the economy is growing significantly faster than its long-term average and that shortages of materials and skilled workers may soon rise as a result, sending prices up.
 
Inventory Buildup a Concern
 Seven members of the policy committee expressed some of these worries in separate interviews over the last week, although they were also slightly concerned about a large buildup in inventories during the second quarter that could take a while to sell.
Under a prior agreement with the House panel, Mr. Greenspan's testimony today did not include any discussion of current interest rate policy or the current health of the American economy. Instead, he delivered a lengthy tutorial on the flaws in Government statistics and the shortcomings of computer modeling.
Technological changes in particular, such as the spread of computers, have made it hard for the Government to measure accurately the economy's health, Mr. Greenspan said. Past measurements of the tonnage of aluminum production or manufactured goods output were much easier, and probably more reliable, than measurements of the nation's output of computer programs, which vary greatly in quality.
At the same time, computer models of the economy have proved unreliable because they wrongly assume that past economic relationships will stay the same.
 
Skepticism Needed
 "History teaches us that the underlying structure of the economy is in a continuing state of flux," Mr. Greenspan said. "Current estimates of key parameters describing the basic relationships are based on past experience and need to be viewed skeptically when making policy for the future."
He added that the Federal Reserve had tried to get around this problem by calculating many different forecasts and assigning them different probabilities.
While many corporate forecasters of the economy continue to rely on large computer models, and while the Federal Reserve staff continues to maintain one, models have gone out of fashion in academic circles. Laurence M. Ball, an economics professor at Johns Hopkins University, said, "I was at a conference recently where someone presented results based on a large econometric model and the general reaction was that this was antiquated, something that belonged in the 60's," he said.
Mr. Greenspan called today for the Treasury to begin issuing bonds with regular interest payments that would vary with the level of inflation. Government bonds currently make fixed payments. The prices people were willing to pay for inflation-indexed bonds would show how fearful they were of inflation, he said.
 
Measure of Fear Sought
 Because inflation fears tend to be self-fulfilling, the Federal Reserve now goes to great lengths trying to measure these fears to determine when interest rates need to be raised. Currently traded bonds vary somewhat with inflation but are an imperfect indicator of inflation fears.
But a senior Treasury official said this afternoon that while the agency had been intermittently studying the possibility of inflation-linked bonds for 15 years, no decision was likely soon. The Treasury made a big shift in the spring of last year when it decided to issue more short-term securities and fewer long-term bonds, and is unlikely to make another shift quickly, said the official, who insisted on anonymity.
The sharp shrinkage in the Federal budget deficit has also reduced the need to find new ways to finance the shortfall, the official added.

HEADLINE: Inland Region of Brazil Grows Like Few Others

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BETIM, Brazil

 BODY:
Inside a factory complex that sprawls over nearly a square mile here, assembly lines are running three shifts a day, propelling Fiat Automoveis S.A. past Ford and General Motors to rank as Brazil's second-largest car maker.
Smaller only than Volkswagen, Fiat presents the flashy face of a lesser-known region of Brazil that is quietly enjoying the highest industrial growth rate in South America. 
 Here, along a 300-mile inland corridor linking the state capitals of Minas Gerais and Sao Paulo, industrial activity is expanding at 10 percent a year, a pace of expansion seldom seen today outside coastal China.
 
Fiat's Big Commitment
 "This will be the main plant for producing Fiat's new world car," Pacifico Paoli, chief executive of the subsidiary, said one recent evening here in Betim, about 20 miles west of Belo Horizonte, as assembly lines worked full tilt.
Fiat of Brazil, already the Italian auto maker's largest subsidiary, is investing $1 billion in expanding the plant here -- four times the parent company's total investment planned at all other Fiat plants around the world.
This industrial surge has driven Minas Gerais past Rio de Janeiro, to become Brazil's second-biggest state economy, after that of Sao Paulo.
Minas Gerais may be little known outside South America, yet its $40 billion economy, and its 16 million people are comparable to the economy and population of Chile.
United States investment here has lagged behind that of Europeans. Even so, the score of American corporations already operating in Minas Gerais include Alcoa, Cargill, General Electric, TRW Automotive and Union Carbide. Citibank and the Bank of Boston have offices in the state capital, Belo Horizonte. And state officials are wooing General Motors, which plans to build an automobile plant in Brazil next year. With such interest, American Airlines will inaugurate daily service between Miami and Belo Horizonte in December.
Responding to Minas Gerais's economic growth, the United States Commerce Department plans to open an office in Belo Horizonte later this year. "It's a state the size of France, with an expanding economy," said Geoffrey H. Walser, a Commerce Department officer in Sao Paulo. "More and more Americans that come here say they also want to visit Belo."
Underlying the state's growth is its longtime status as Brazil's mining and steel center. Minas Gerais, which means General Mines in Portuguese, produces 77 percent of the nation's iron ore. And its nine privately run steel plants produce 41 percent of the nation's steel.
Brazil's two largest mining companies are planning to spend about $1.5 billion to expand iron-ore operations here. Gold-mining companies in the state are undergoing multimillion-dollar expansions.
The latest transformation dates back to 1976, when Fiat began turning steel into cars. Since then, manufacturing has expanded from a quarter of the state's exports to half of them.
 
Magnet for Secondary Industries
 With its rapid growth, Fiat has drawn 53 car-parts manufacturers to the region. It now employs 18,000 people here, and a similar number work in nearby auto-parts factories. The company is in the process of raising the Minas Gerais-originated content of its cars, from 25 percent in 1989 to 60 percent in 1996.
Cheap land, relatively low-cost labor, and abundant steel and electricity are cited as factors in Fiat's expansion. So, apparently, is worker satisfaction. While strikes close auto plants around Sao Paulo perhaps once a year, Fiat has not had a strike here in a decade.
"We have been running three shifts for a long time," said Mr. Paoli, who has watched Fiat's market share in Brazil jump in the last year from 21 percent to 27 percent.
Undoubtedly influenced by Fiat's track record, General Motors and Autolatina, a Ford-Volkswagen consortium, are reportedly leaning toward choosing Minas Gerais for factories they plan to build in Brazil next year.
In March, a French-Brazilian group started to assemble JPX four-wheel-drive vehicles in Pouso Alegre, a city in this booming industrial corridor. The vehicle, which Peugeot sells in France, is produced here with a Brazilian body and an imported Peugeot engine and transmission. Following the same formula, the joint venture intends next year to make pickup trucks and station wagons.
The industrial corridor's growth is expected to continue unchecked, straining a main transport artery, the largely two-lane road that links Belo Horizonte with Sao Paulo.
The bottlenecks are so bad that companies allot 24 hours for a tractor-trailer to go the 281 miles between the two cities. This resulted in intense business pressure on the state governments, and six months ago ground was broken on a $750 million project to expand the road to a four-lane divided highway, The improvement could result in as much as $10 billion of new investments along the corridor, officials calculate.
 
Balanced Budgets, Outside Help
 In recent years the national Government, short of funds, has littered the landscape with unfinished big construction projects. But contractors think this highway expansion will be completed on time, at the end of 1996. The project is being financed by the Inter-American Development Bank and the state governments of Minas Gerais and Sao Paulo.
In a nation that until recently suffered from double-digit monthly inflation, business people appreciate the sober financial habits of Minas Gerais's state government, which has balanced its budget for the last three years. The state raised $400 million this year through the sale of Eurobonds, backed by shares in the state electricity company.
"It was the first of any kind of international bonds floated by the federal Government or by a Brazilian state since the debt crisis of 1992," said Antonio Claudio Sochaczewski, Brazil's representative at the Inter-American Development Bank. Brazil rescheduled its foreign commercial debts with creditor banks in March.
With Rio de Janeiro suffering from street crime and kidnappings and Sao Paulo beset by pollution and traffic congestion, Belo Horizonte looks increasingly attractive to businesses.
 
Livable, but Also Dull
 Built 100 years ago as a planned city full of parks, this state capital of two million was recently rated Latin America's most livable major city by the Population Crisis Committee, a private group based in Washington.
But with a new international airport as yet offering only three international flights a week, foreign business people complain that life in Belo Horizonte can be stultifying.
"Professionally, Belo is very challenging," said Edward M. Mason, who has built his distributorship of Cummins diesel engines here into the United States company's largest outlet in Brazil. "Personally, it's much less comfortable."
Determined to increase foreign investment and trade, the state's business leaders are campaigning to soften the taciturn and insular qualities that people here are known for.
"We have to break down these closed, introverted habits," said Emerson de Almeida, dean of the Dom Cabral Foundation, a local business school. "To get more investment, we have to create a more international environment, with language training and international schools."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Short-Term Treasury Issues Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of short-term Treasury securities rose yesterday, while the long bond remained unchanged, as investors turned their attention to the final leg of the Government's quarterly refinancing.
The market also braced for a batch of important economic data, which many analysts suspect will be magnified because it is coming ahead of the meeting on Tuesday of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's policy-making body, which will decide when another increase in interest rates will come. 
 The auction yesterday of $12 billion of new 10-year notes, which traders said was a modest success, buoyed the bond market slightly in the afternoon. An early weakness in prices was attributed to comments by the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, to a House Government Operations subcommittee.
Analysts said that while Mr. Greenspan's comments differed little from previous comments he had made, their impact was greatly increased by the scheduled release this week of July producer and consumer prices and retail sales, ahead of the Open Market Committee meeting.
The 30-year bond was unchanged, at 84 20/32 , to yield 7.57 percent, while short rates declined sharply, suggesting that investors are moving away from the more volatile long end to the safety of the short end.
In when-issued trading, the yield on a 10-year note dropped to 7.28 percent, from the average 7.33 percent at auction. Tomorrow the Treasury will auction $11 billion of 30-year bonds, which were offered in late when-issued trading yesterday at a price to yield 7.46 percent, unchanged from the previous day.
Hugh A. Johnson, chief investment strategist for the First Albany Corporation, described the 10-year auction as solid, but not spectacular.
"Essentially when you look at all technical ways to measure the success of an auction, the auction came off as about as expected," he said. "Some of those ways being the average yields, the so called tail, or spread between the high and low bids, and the level of noncompetitive bids."
Mr. Johnson said traders were not disappointed by the auction yesterday. "There was some short covering by dealers when they saw the results," he said. "However, Thursday promises to be a very big day in bonds, with plenty of room for major surprises or disappointments."
With that in mind, he said, many dealers looked at the auction results yesterday as an excuse to cover their short positions.
The market's primary focus today will be on the Producer Price Index, which is expected to increase by about 0.4 percent overall, and 0.2 percent at the core.
"The principal source of its strength is expected to come from gasoline and coffee prices," Mr. Johnson said. "In addition, we also expect July retail sales to increase either 0.1 percent, or remain flat. Excluding auto sales, retail sales are expected to register an 0.5 percent increase."
Traders and analysts said Mr. Greenspan's comments contained few surprises, as he reiterated concerns about the inaccuracies of inflation data. They said his contention that the Consumer Price Index was overstated inflation was nothing new.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Foreign Offering's Unsure Pedigree

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Peddling a Chinese power company to American investors would appear to be a classic no-brainer. China, currently one of the world's fastest-growing economies, is badly in need of more electricity; its total output of 181 million kilowatts is already 20 percent less than overall demand, which is expected to grow by a whopping 17 million kilowatts a year until the turn of the century.
Why, then, are American depository receipts for shares of Shandong Huaneng Power Development Company Ltd., which operates three power stations in China's second-fastest-growing province, selling for below their offering price since they began trading on the New York Stock Exchange last week? 
 The answer reveals as much about China's bid to attract international financing for its modernization as it does about Wall Street's ambition to become banker to the mother of all emerging markets. What seems to have been lost in the middle were the concerns of the investors required to put up the money.
Shandong Huaneng's rocky debut may also deal a blow to China's efforts to raise money to improve its infrastructure. Three more power companies are expected to be listed in New York and Hong Kong in the coming months. Unless Shandong Huaneng begins to trade above its offering price, those issues may have to settle for lower prices.
"You clearly have to take this into mind and probably price accordingly," said Anthony Cragg, who manages two international funds for Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management Inc. based in Menomonee Falls, Wisc. "I can't see now how it could not have an impact."
Doubts about Shandong Huaneng, which is the first Chinese utility to be listed overseas, developed soon after its stock opened last Thursday. More than 14 million shares -- or 60 percent of the total offer -- traded hands on the first day. Though the shares closed at $14.25 each, the same as the offering price, rumors that CS First Boston, the issue's lead underwriter, was supporting the price further eroded investor confidence.
The stock opened at $14 on its second day of trading, indicating to some fund managers that CS First Boston was no longer willing to prop it up. More investors bailed out.
This week, Shandong Huaneng shares drifted down until yesterday, when they closed at $13.875, up 37.5 cents on a volume of 274,000 shares.
CS First Boston said that it could not comment on the stock, citing regulations prohibiting an underwriter from commenting publicly about one of its deals until 25 days after it begins trading.
But several analysts put the blame for the stock's weak performance in part on the fact that Shandong Huaneng is a company created just for this deal so that American depository receipts, representing 30 percent of the new company's shares, could be listed in New York.
"The company wasn't really a company," said Sheldon Kasowitz, a utility analyst and director at Jardine Fleming Asia Research Ltd., in Hong Kong. "It was just a bunch of discrete plants that they tied a bow around and wrote a prospectus on."
Mr. Kasowitz and other Hong Kong-based analysts have also charged that the New York Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission relaxed their listing standards for Shandong Huaneng because they want more Chinese companies to come to New York.
For example, the S.E.C. only required the company to produce one year's audited accounts. In Hong Kong, which is competing with New York for Chinese listings, regulators require three years of audited accounts.
Officials from both the S.E.C. and the Big Board said that the company got no special treatment. The New York exchange said it received one year of audited accounts and two additional years of pro forma accounts, while the S.E.C. said examining more than a single year's accounts would have been irrelevant since the power stations were operating within state-owned entities.
"We feel that we got the kind of disclosure that was relevant given the kind of environment in which this company existed," Robert Bayless, associate director of corporation finance at the S.E.C., said.
But the problems with Shandong Huaneng are more fundamental, analysts say. The company plans to use the $311 million it received from the offering to retire $83 million in loans from two of the three Chinese state entities that together own 70 percent of the company. It also plans to use the new capital to expand its overall generating capacity, including the completion of a fourth plant now on the drawing board.
The prospectus offers an annual return of 15 percent on the company's average net fixed assets. But the return is denominated in Chinese yuan, which was devalued against the dollar by a third earlier this year. That would have cut the return to American investors by a third as well. And the yuan may face further devaluations as China's annual rate of inflation continues to top 20 percent.
Since the stock began trading, some fund managers have also been surprised to learn that the guarantee of a 15 percent annual return on assets is not as firm as they had thought. Between the initial and final versions of the prospectus, CS First Boston inserted new language revealing that only part of the interest costs on future debt raised by the company will be paid for by raising its customers' rates for electricity. Thus, the return on assets will likely fall below 15 percent, depending on how much the company borrows in the future.
Despite these pitfalls, some investors argue that the issue would have been successful had it been priced more cheaply. But one member of the underwriting syndicate, who requested anonymity, said that the Chinese insisted on a high price to raise as much cash as possible.
The competition for Chinese listings among investment banks is fierce. Rather than risk losing the business, CS First Boston apparently priced the issue aggressively, according to several fund managers.
At the offering price of $14.25, most demand for the stock was met, meaning that when it started trading there were few other buyers waiting in line. Once the stock began wavering, short-term investors hoping to make a quick profit began to sell.
"There are a lot of people at the moment who take new issues and are looking for an instant pop," Mr. Cragg, of Strong/Corneliuson, said. "If they don't get it, then they dump it and move on to the next one."
