HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
As Baseball Strike Looms, Many Bystanders Are Out

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
The looming baseball strike is all about millionaires fighting millionaires for the last Learjet on the lot. Isn't it about time they thought about the others involved -- the hot-dog vendors, the parking attendants, the 10-year-olds who would rather watch the Yankees than Beavis and Butt-head?
Wait; don't touch that dial. Such sentiments may be commonplace. This time, though, they are echoed by economists generally known for their distance from the fray and faith in contracts signed by consenting adults. "There is a good argument here for a forced resolution," confirms Lawrence White of New York University's Stern School of Business. 
 Economists have always had an uneasy time with the right to strike. Sellers of steel or baby formula are not permitted to set prices collectively, the argument goes; why, then, should groups of workers who make the steel or baby formula be permitted to withhold their labor unless they are paid the wages they collectively demand?
 
Employers Have an Advantage
 The answer is that labor markets do not quite work according to Hoyle. Employers, especially big ones, have an advantage in bargaining with individual workers, who cannot lightly put their livelihoods at risk by holding out for better terms.
The right to organize -- and the strike threat -- can neutralize the advantage. What's more, notes Daniel Hamermesh, an economist at the University of Texas, the social consequences of labor negotiations that end in impasse are generally modest. "Even when strikes do take place," he points out, "they usually have very few consequences for the average consumer."
There is nothing usual, however, about Major League Baseball, notes Louis Guth, a senior vice-president of National Economic Research Associates. Baseball is an unregulated cartel, uniquely exempt from the antitrust laws. It is also heavily subsidized, with sweet deals on stadiums in many locales. And both facts suggest that the public should have some standing in contract talks.
By the same token, baseball players are hardly potential candidates for Karl Marx's reserve army of the unemployed. Their salaries are modest in the first few years, but only in comparison with those of middle-aged investment bankers and neurosurgeons. Thereafter, players' wages are determined by arbitration or free agent negotiation -- with average deals well above $1 million a year. And in Mr. Guth's view, generous arbitration awards have actually cost the owners more than free agency bargaining.
The core issue apparently dividing the players and owners is a salary cap. The owners claim some clubs are losing money, and that the only practical way to prevent a continuing escalation of budget-busting salaries is to limit the total amount paid by each team to a percentage of league revenues.
That doesn't sound right to Mr. White, though. If the idea is to reduce the temptation of richer clubs to bid up the salaries of superstars, he notes, the clubs could always pool a higher percentage of their own revenues. Mr. Guth agrees: "All they're arguing about is who gets the money."
Still, economists are reluctant to have third parties dictate contract terms. Arbitrators typically look for the middle ground, even when it makes little economic sense. In the case of rail labor disputes, for example, imposed settlements have probably slowed the end of featherbedding.
But in the case of baseball, Mr. White argues, little seems to be at stake other than who gets the gravy. And while baseball may not be vital to the economy, the loss to the public from a strike would be large compared with potential economic losses built on an arbitrator's middle ground.
What middle ground? Ray Fair and Sharon Oster, both economists at Yale University, are glad to be asked. They imagine a compromise in which teams would be discouraged (rather than barred) from paying salaries above a negotiated threshold -- say $2 million.
Owners would be obliged to contribute a portion of every dollar above that threshold -- say 30 percent -- into a fund that would be distributed among the teams and players. Just how to parcel out the cash would also be a matter of negotiation, says Mr. Fair, as long as it did not go back to the clubs or players who had negotiated the "excessive" salaries.
The probable impact on salaries is not clear. The threshold might serve as a benchmark for the highest salaries, a psychological line not easily crossed. On the other hand, if the threshold were set low, it might serve as a minimum that every free agent demanded and expected.
But from the public's perspective, it would not matter much: Changes in salary scales this rich would presumably have little effect on player effort or recruitment. Hardly anybody, presumably, decides to become an insurance salesman instead of a third baseman because the latter are paid $1.5 million a year rather than $2 million.
What matters is that the players would play ball rather than golf for the rest of the summer. And that would make the hot-dog vendors, parking attendants and 10-year-olds much happier.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
A Movement In the Labor Negotiations: Out the Door

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Negotiators for baseball's club owners and players have not reached an impasse, one of them said yesterday, but their talks clearly are stalemated and the players will walk out after they play the 10 games that are on the schedule for today and tonight. Practically speaking, the strike already has started for the players on the eight teams that aren't scheduled.
Technically, the game's eighth work stoppage in the last 23 seasons will not be official until tomorrow's night's schedule of 14 games is wiped out. But as Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, said yesterday, even if a settlement to the labor dispute somehow developed overnight, many players already would have left game sites. 
 Chances of a settlement, though, are so remote that the negotiators did not even set another bargaining session after they ended yesterday's meeting in two and a half hours.
Asked if the two sides are at an impasse, in the legal sense of the term for labor purposes or otherwise, Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, said, "I don't consider we are right now."
Fehr did not answer the question directly, saying, "We have not even reached the point in which there is a conceptual framework within which we can negotiate a deal."
The owners remained firm in their quest for a new economic system, the focal point of which would be a salary cap. The players remained equally as firm in their opposition to the drastic change, preferring instead to continue the existing system.
"Players have a choice," Fehr told a news conference at the Hotel Inter-Continental in Manhattan. "Take a salary cap proposal now, take it after the season because they impose it or strike. The owners have very deliberately left the players no choices at all."
Fehr repeated his contention that the owners wanted to force a strike. Ravitch denied the assertion, saying: "There is no owner who wants a strike. Don't be fooled for a minute that any owner wants this, that there was any plan to bring this about. That is not the case."
But it is the case that no agreement looms on the horizon on this or any other planet.
"At this point," Fehr said, "I have no reason to believe that anything of significance will occur today or anytime soon."
Ravitch did not express a different view.
"We will continue to hope," Ravitch said, "that maybe, as Don put it in the meeting, that lightning will strike and one of us will have a good idea that can bridge this gap in the next day and a half. I'm not optimistic."
 
Who's Not Being Responsive?
 In his remarks, Ravitch continued hammering at the theme that the players have been unresponsive to the economic problems the owners have described.
"If they are unwilling to address the underlying economic issues of the game and work with us to solve them," he said, "not much is gained by sitting across the table and exchanging disagreements."
Fehr, however, said the players have been responsive, presenting their ideas on revenue sharing last week. He did not provide details, saying he wanted to hear the owners' response first.
"We have given the owners ideas on how to ameliorate these problems," he said. "We had outside economists review the situation and suggest a number of changes which they believe will respond to the problems the owners have articulated. There are a lot of basic things you can do that will go a long way to solving these problems. The trouble is the owners don't want to do it. They want a salary cap instead."
 
A Revenue-Sharing Plan
 The owners adopted their own revenue-sharing plan last January but linked it to the players' acceptance of a salary cap. Fehr has stressed that the owners' economic fight is an intramural matter, low-revenue clubs vs. high-revenue clubs.
Ravitch dismissed the union's revenue-sharing ideas, saying they have "nothing whatsoever to do with the player compensation system. They suggested that big markets should contribute more money to the smaller markets, not too much because the smaller markets might put that money in their pockets instead of spending it on players."
Although the bargaining session produced no movement, except out the door, Fehr said the union representatives were pleased to hear "frank acknowledgments" from Charles O'Connor, Ravitch's general counsel, "that their proposals are designed to limit salary growth and put artificial limitations around free agency. That is the purpose of it."
"He's alluded to that before," Fehr said. "This was the frankest expression of it."
 
Restricting Free Agency
 Curt Schilling, a Philadelphia Phillies pitcher who drove to New York for the meeting that also was attended by 12 members of the Yankees and Baltimore Orioles, said he asked if a salary cap would restrict free agency and "they said yes."
Ravitch told the players that the owners were not proposing the new system because they have an inability to pay. If the owners did make that claim, they legally would have to open their books to the union.
But, Ravitch added, "That doesn't mean the industry doesn't have economic distress."
 
The Talking Has Stopped
 Both sides said they would meet if either had a reason to meet. Asked if he thought there could be a lengthy adjournment in the negotiations, Ravitch said: "I don't know. I believe any opportunity to talk is useful. I certainly do not believe we should stop talking no matter what."
The players at the meeting addressed a report that some owners apparently think the players will return from a strike after they miss their second paycheck.
"They clearly indicated if anybody holds those illusions, they should think about it again," Fehr said.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
JACKIE MASON thinks so, and filed a $25 million lawsuit this week in New York State Supreme Court against five organizations that select the Tony nominees. He charged that their failure to consider him this year for his one-man Broadway show, "Jackie Mason: Politically Incorrect," constitutes discrimination.
HARVEY SABINSON executive director of the League of American Theaters and Producers, which administers the Tonys along with the American Theater Wing, said he could not comment directly on the suit yesterday because he was not aware of it.

Mr. Mason no longer has that Tony: he returned it in protest on June 7, five days before teh TOnys were awarded.
Contending the Mr. Mason met all the requirements for a Tony nomination, MEL SACHS, his lawyer, said, "They failed to abide by his human and civil rights and didn't give him the proper opportunity to enhance his economic, cultural and intellectual life."
Mr. Mason said yesterday, without a hint of humor: "It was an abridgment of my rights as a human being. They can't stand a guy with a big mouth who donesn't conform to the elitism of the inner circle."

HEADLINE: Speed the Train to the Plane

 BODY:
There are better ideas for connecting midtown Manhattan with La Guardia and Kennedy Airports than the Port Authority's plan. Some of the others would be cheaper, some more convenient, but all want for money.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, owner-operator of both airports as well as Newark's, has money -- from a $3 charge that all departing passengers pay. It has a plan -- not perfect, but workable. Moreover, the airports and the city have a desperate need -- for relief from congestion that pollutes the air and slows taxi and limousine connections to a nerve-racking crawl. 
 The Authority wants to build a 22-mile overhead track from Kennedy to La Guardia to the 59th Street bridge crossing the East River from Queens to Manhattan, then across to an underground station just south of Bloomingdale's. The estimated construction cost is $2.5 billion.
Ideally the train should go to one or both of the city's big terminals -- Grand Central or Penn Station -- where it could connect with railroads and subways. But just to tunnel to Grand Central would cost an extra $600 million, which no one has.
It would also be better, and cheaper, if the train could run on existing track. But under the 1992 Federal authorization for the $3-per-ticket charge, the money can only be spent on airport-related improvements; the train could not carry local traffic, only air travelers and airport employees. An all-new system for a limited body of users is obviously costly. That is a serious constraint, but Congress is not about to rewrite the law.
Any number of critics would be delighted to see the project halted, first and most forcefully the airlines, which want the money used to improve airport facilities. Second and most vocally are New Yorkers whose neighborhoods in Queens and the Upper East Side of Manhattan would be disturbed by the trains and by added street traffic at the Manhattan end. However, Claire Shulman, the savvy Borough President of Queens, where both airports are and all the overhead track would be, supports the plan enthusiastically.
Air travelers should be enthusiastic, too, for more reasons than just a faster trip. Train fare would be much less than a taxi, in the neighborhood of $9 to La Guardia and $12 to Kennedy. Airline competition should improve as well, with more domestic flights in and out of Kennedy when the airport itself is more accessible.
Several hurdles remain: completion of economic studies this month, official authorization of the final design by the Port Authority board later this year, negotiations with airlines and, possibly next year, final approval by the Federal Aviation Administration. Congestion can only get worse the longer the project is delayed. Rather than wait for a perfect system, the Authority should be authorized to proceed with its good one.

GRAPHIC: Map of Brooklyn, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Haiti's Thugs May Listen to Nothing but Force

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Since 1968 I have traveled to Haiti many times as a volunteer surgeon. On my visit in February 1991, two weeks after President Jean-Bertrand Aristide's election, it was obvious that something good had happened! The streets were clean (relative to the past and present), people seemed to be filled with hope and optimism, and smiles abounded everywhere.
During the next few months people began to return from the United States to homes in Haiti. Many opened businesses. Government programs for medical care, education and land reform were begun. President Aristide began restructuring Government finance, beginning with his own refusal to accept the presidential salary of $10,000 a month. 
 The "boat people" phenomenon began in 1973. Under President Aristide, however, the number of people leaving Haiti to seek political asylum dropped to its lowest. Those who traditionally had profited from government handouts, corruption and drug smuggling felt their livelihoods threatened by the new regime.
Military leaders, supported by these people, seized control in September 1991. Since then, Haiti has deteriorated dramatically. Attempts by the United States in the last three years to restore the elected government have failed. These have included lengthy discussions and increasing economic sanctions. The sanctions have hurt the masses of poor people who elected President Aristide and not those illegally in power.
During my most recent visit to Haiti last February, conditions were worse than ever. Since that time they deteriorated even more. Cessation of commercial flights will stop outside trade into Port-au-Prince. The country's leadership, which has access to military planes and private aircraft, will not be affected.
The elimination of financial transactions between the United States and Haiti will have only minimal effect on the country's leaders since their assets have already been transferred out of the country. Instead, the people in the streets who have been receiving $20 to $40 money orders from a family member in the United States will be most affected.
The Haitian people are dying in increasing numbers as the country's economy, medical care, sanitation and police forces deteriorate.
If heightened sanctions do not cause the leaders of Haiti to leave very soon, the sanctions must be considered a failure and the military incumbents must be removed by force.
 
JOHN P. JUDSON, M.D.
Lemoyne, Pa., Aug. 1, 1994

HEADLINE: Big Firms Gain Bond Work Set For Minorities

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
In recent years, many Government agencies have decreed that some of the bondsthat they issue must be sold by minority-owned brokerage firms. As a result, about 300 such firms have been established, and they have taken a healthy share of the $2 billion in fees paid annually to brokers for selling public securities.
 Now, Wall Street firms, among them Merrill Lynch and Bear Stearns, and regional brokerages are finding ways to capture some of this business for themselves. They are buying stakes in minority-owned firms, enabling them to profit from these set-aside programs too. 
It is a trend that troubles many independent, well-established minority-owned firms. They say that they are losing business to these new competitors, who are perverting the intent of affirmative action.
 "Women and minority firms built from scratch on a shoestring are now up against firms that are a quasi-subsidiary or arm of major underwriting firms," said Robert B. Lamb, a professor at the Stern School of Business at New York University, who plans to publish a study on minority-owned firms.
Among the most outspoken executives of established black firms is Napolean Brandford 3d, vice chairman of Grigsby Brandford & Company, a black-owned firm in San Francisco. "African-American firms are an endangered species," he said. "This is an attempt to circumvent inclusion or prevent major African-American firms from getting to the next level. These are not minority firms."
 Muriel Seibert, who heads a woman-owned brokerage firm, commented: "On one hand, it's wonderful these big firms are letting some of these people get into the business. But you've got to question their intention and what the real purpose is. I know I've lost business to them."
 Some minority-owned firms say they are also losing out to small but politically connected "storefront" minority firms, which have no employees, no ability to sell bonds and no intention of building a business. Still, they are given bonds to sell; they hand them to Wall Street firms and split the profits. Professor Lamb estimated that, based on his research, about half the 300 or so minority-owned firms are illegitimate.
 As the number of black and women public officials has grown, so has the number of programs to give minority-owned firms a bigger piece of public finance business. Typically, public agencies issuing bonds hire brokerage firms to advise them how to design the bonds and, later, to buy the bonds and resell them to the public. This is a risky business -- the firms need large sums to buy bonds and, often, to hold them in inventory. But the fees are lucrative.
 The programs requiring that a portion of the securities be sold by minority firms take various forms. Some include quotas. For example, in California, 15 percent of local and state bonds must be sold by minority firms, and 3 percent by women. Other large issuers, like New York City, simply aim for more minority inclusion.
 
Merrill Helps Utendahl
 In response, large Wall Street firms have helped establish and taken an interest in minority-owned firms that are geared to win business selling securities from Federal agencies. The most successful has been Merrill Lynch's investment in Utendahl Capital Partners, headed by John O. Utendahl, an African-American and former Merrill trader. Merrill Lynch has invested $3 million and extended a $9.9 million line of credit for a 25 percent stake in Utendahl.
 In its first year, Utendahl participated in underwriting syndicates that have sold $9.8 billion in Government mortgage-backed securities. Its assets have swollen to $13.9 million from $100,000, and its surplus capital, a rough indication of net worth, has reached $12.2 million.
 Merrill declined to discuss its involvement in Utendahl beyond describing it as a "passive, minority-ownership interest." A spokeswoman for Utendahl also declined to comment. But others are not so reticent.
 "It cloaks Merrill in minority status," said Harold E. Doley Jr., who is black and heads Doley Securities Inc., a brokerage firm. "It's as though these big firms are creating their own minority firms."
 
Resentment is Stirred
 "I resent it," said Donald Rice, president and chief executive of GB Derivatives, an affiliate of Grigsby Brandford. "Merrill's relationship is not some uninvolved third party providing capital. This is an ongoing relationship. Merrill people sit on the Utendahl board. The original offices were at Merrill. It was established as a bit of a front."
 Bear Stearns invested $10 million for a 25 percent stake in Blaylock & Company, headed by Ronald Blaylock, who is black and a former Paine Webber trader. "We're really independent of Bear Stearns on a day-to-day basis," Mr. Blaylock said. "But if they can help us, they will."
 Regional brokers are also embracing minority-owned firms to stanch the loss of business to them. For example, J. C. Bradford & Company, a Nashville firm, has joined forces with Ward & Associates, a black-owned firm in Atlanta, to create Ward, Bradford & Company, which is 40 percent owned by Bradford and 60 percent by Felker Ward, chief executive of Ward & Associates.
 "This arrangement gives us bonds and the opportunity to be in deals we wouldn't be in without Ward," said J. Ronald Scott, national municipal manager at J. C. Bradford. "For them, it helps with overhead. They don't have to have a big network to sell bonds."
 In another case, Estrada Hinojosa & Company, a Hispanic-owned firm in Dallas, recently sold about a 30 percent stake to Morgan Keegan & Company, a Memphis regional firm. Estrada will sell all the bonds it can, and Morgan has a right of first refusal on bonds that Estrada cannot or does not want to sell.
 "I gave up 30 percent ownership," said Robert Estrada, the firm's chief executive. "But it was worth it to have a safety net of capital and to be able to tell an issuer, 'If you put us in a deal, we will sell the bonds and not just be excess baggage.' "
 In addition, Morgan will advance Estrada additional capital to land bigger deals. "This is very different from what people see as a front," Mr. Estrada said. "Those have no intention of selling bonds. But we do. And we can tell clients if they hire us, they get access to Morgan's distribution network. With Morgan and us, it's, 'you help me and I'll help you.' "
 Indeed, minority-owned firms in such deals say they want to avoid the situation faced by many legitimate start-up minority firms: being picked to join an underwriting syndicate, yet not being able to sell bonds. Many small firms in that position have often sold their bonds back to the Wall Street firms in the syndicate, a practice that yields small fees for the minority firm but also raises questions about what real business function they perform.
 
Need for Capital Cited
 "We want to distribute bonds and incur market risk, and we need capital," said Daniel H. Kolber, chief executive of Jackson Securities of Atlanta, whose chairman is Maynard H. Jackson, the black former mayor. Jackson Securities is 15 percent owned by Wheat First Butcher Singer Inc., a Richmond broker.
 "This helps us get off the ground, and it gives Wheat First a return on their investment in us," Mr. Kolber said.
 Public finance firms are often started by women, black or Hispanic brokers with a background in the business but with more energy and brainpower than capital. For years, minority-owned firms with little money were given business by sympathetic public officials -- on the notion that once well funded, these firms could contribute beyond their minority status. As a result, even many legitimate firms, in their early days, did little to earn their fees.
 But regulators say that these firms are different from politically well connected minority-owned firms that do no work but are cut into a bond deal by Wall Street firms trying to curry favor with the officials deciding which firms get business.
 "Without having business directed to them in the past, a lot of good minority firms would not be here," said Richard Y. Roberts, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission. "But it's gotten to the point that firms are being handed business that have no intention of growing. It's often difficult to differentiate where social policy ends and where you have glad-handing to political cronies."
 
An S.E.C. Investigation
 The S.E.C. is investigating reports of potential abuses involving minority-owned firms in at least three states -- Louisiana, Florida and Georgia -- as part of a larger investigation into political influence-peddling and questionable campaign contributions in municipal finance.
 For instance, in Louisiana, the S.E.C. is investigating an arrangement in which a local minority-owned firm got $240,000 in fees from First Boston and Lazard Freres but sold no bonds. The two Wall Street firms said the payment was suggested by local politicians.
 As another example, the S.E.C. is investigating AIBC Investment Services in Miami, partly owned by a Hispanic city commissioner, which received $350,000 last year without selling a single bond.
 "The whole point of economic opportunity programs is to create a level field," said Robin L. Wiessmann, a principal at Artemis Capital Group, a woman-owned firm. "But we've seen situations where firms are put in because of deals cut, and they've pocketed money with no notion of reinvesting in their firms."
 Complicating the debate is that municipal bond underwritings have fallen offthis year. And, set-aside programs that once assured many minority firms of steady business often work against them -- becoming more of a ceiling on future growth. Some government bond issuers are increasingly lumping all minority-owned firms together and giving each the same amount of bonds to sell, without regard to their size, skills or capabilities.
 "We sometimes get hurt by the tag of minority," said Richard M. Ramirez, chief executive at Apex Securities, a Hispanic- and black-owned Houston firm. "We don't want to be limited to little pieces of a deal. We want a bigger bite at the apple."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 19, 1994, Friday

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: AN EXXON VERDICT OF $286.8 MILLION

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER 

 BODY:
A Federal jury in Alaska decided yesterday that the Exxon Corporation should pay $286.8 million in compensatory damages to Alaskan fishermen, about a third of what they said was due them for harm caused by the nation's worst oil tanker spill five years ago.
The verdict was delivered in the second phase of a three-phase trial that began 15 weeks ago in Federal District Court in Anchorage. It was the product of 23 days' deliberation by the jury of nine women and three men on damage claims by more than 10,000 fishermen who work the waters of Prince William Sound, Cook Inlet and Kodiak Island. 
 Exxon had said the losses to commercial fisheries in the region totaled about $113 million; the plaintiffs had sought $895 million in compensatory damages.
After the jury's decision yesterday, Exxon's legal team argued that, on balance, the verdict seemed to favor their side, a point that the plaintiff's lead trial attorney, Brian O'Neill, did not vigorously dispute.
"It isn't what I wanted," Mr. O'Neill said. "I don't know what it means for the next phase. This is a very independent-minded group. Right now you just don't know how the ledger washes. I know it does mean one thing: the case won't settle. It will stiffen Exxon a bit."
In June, ending the first phase of the trial, the same jury found that the Valdez spill on March 24, 1989, was caused by the reckless behavior of Exxon's executives and the captain of the supertanker Exxon Valdez, Joseph J. Hazelwood. In the third and final phase of the trial, which resumes on Aug. 22, the jury will decide whether Exxon is liable for punitive damages. The plaintiffs are seeking $15 billion.
After yesterday's verdict, one of Exxon's trial lawyers, Patrick Lynch, said he was guardedly optimistic.
"The jury is a thinking, careful, judge-like jury," Mr. Lynch said. "They did not accept numbers that either side presented. That makes me optimistic going into phase three that they will listen to the evidence and give us a fair hearing. It's a signal."
The jury's decision yesterday was announced after the markets had closed. The price of a common share of Exxon stock on the New York Stock Exchange was $58.125, down 87.5 cents from the previous day.
In the annals of environmental cases, nothing has rivaled the legal battle under way in Anchorage between Exxon and thousands of Alaskans.
 
Mastering the Case
 On both sides, lawyers amassed millions of pages of documents, interviewed and prepared hundreds of witnesses to appear, if needed, in court, spent months in technical libraries to master such pivotal details as the life cycles of five species of salmon, the potential consequences of exposing herring and salmon larvae to trace levels of oil, and the way to distinguish the chemical signatures of the crude oil that the Valdez carried from Prudhoe Bay from the signatures of oil said by Exxon to be seeping naturally into Prince William Sound.
On top of this came data about marine sediments, the slopes of Prince William Sound's rocky beaches, the importance of sea plants like fucus and kelp to Alaska's marine environment, and whether the spill had injured plant and animal zooplankton, the foundation of Alaska's coastal food web.
From such details, Mr. O'Neill and his colleagues on the plaintiff's legal team built a scientific and economic case that essentially argued two points.
First, the lawyers said that the tanker's spilling of 11 million gallons of crude oil into Alaskan waters ruined fishing in 1989, because the spill prompted Alaska to close Prince William Sound and other areas for fishing. Second, Mr. O'Neill said, the spill continued to harm the fishermen in 1990 and 1991 by diminishing the price they received for their fish, particularly in Japan, their largest market.
Third, Mr. O'Neill told the court, the spill caused a cascade of toxic effects to the natural environment in Prince William Sound, ruining salmon and herring fishing by causing genetic damage and other injuries to the fish.
 
Fish Deformities
 A principal witness for the plaintiffs was Dr. Richard Kocan, an aquatic toxicologist from the University of Washington. He testified that he had conducted experiments for the Government in his lab and had determined that when herring embryos were exposed to the trace levels of crude oil that he had collected from the Exxon Valdez, many developed severe birth defects, like misshapen jaws, kinked spines and eye defects.
Dr. Kocan said it was his opinion that the spill had either killed millions of herring or had seriously weakened the survivors. The result, he said, was that Prince William Sound's herring have developed a viral disease that causes lesions and a collapse in their numbers. This year, Alaska closed the sound's herring fishery because there were too few fish and some were sick.
According the verdict form that the jury gave the judge yesterday and that itemized the monetary damages, jurors accepted the plaintiff's evidence that the spill caused hundreds of millions of dollars in direct losses to fishermen in 1989, and the bulk of the $286.8 million that the jurors awarded the fishermen came from damages incurred that year. But the jurors' responses showed that they had largely rejected much of the rest of the plaintiff's case.
The jurors said they agreed with Exxon that the collapse of salmon prices in 1990 and 1991 were not caused by the Valdez spill. Exxon had argued that the price reductions were caused by competition from salmon raised on fish farms in Washington state and elsewhere.
The jury also rejected significant portions of the plaintiff's scientific case, the verdict form showed. The fishermen claimed that lingering toxic damage from the spill in Prince William Sound was expected to cause more than $82 million in losses in the herring and pink salmon harvests in 1992, 1993, 1994 and expected losses in 1995. The jury awarded the fishermen $29.3 million for losses in 1992 and 1993, but nothing for 1994 and 1995.

HEADLINE: Creaky Juggernaut: A special report.;
Torn by Change, Mexican Party Fights On

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 11

 BODY:
As the Institutional Revolutionary Party heads toward what may be the toughest election of its 65 years in power, it is mired in what many of its leaders consider the most profound internal crisis of its history.
Radical economic changes made by the Government of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari have grated on the party's traditional support among labor unions and peasant groups. Ambitious efforts to build a new base of individual members rather than organizations have produced more conflict than success. In a society pressing ever more vigorously for democratic change, the party continues to depend on authoritarian controls. 
Yet for all the conflict that the party has endured in a year that has included the assassination of its first presidential candidate and a brutal fight over his replacement, the hulking machine known as the PRI has patched itself together and rolled forward once again.
It has raised tens of millions of dollars, enlisted hundreds of thousands of local organizers and dominated every advertising venue from prime-time television to whitewashed adobe walls. According to a growing number of political analysts and national opinion polls, it also appears increasingly likely that the party will do again on Aug. 21 what it has done throughout its history: Win.
"This party is like a floating log," one of its senior officials said, trying to explain how embittered older leaders of the PRI could have united around Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, the 42-year-old economist whose candidacy many of them tried to block after the assassination of Luis Donaldo Colosio on March 23. "You either grab on or you sink."
The mere prospect that the PRI could win a plurality of the vote is testament to the extraordinary ability of the world's longest-ruling political party to put aside its differences in the quest for continued power.
At the same time, many analysts believe the party's ability to survive by modernizing its vote-getting apparatus and adapting minimally to a changing political system while resisting more fundamental reform augurs darkly for the country's transition to full democracy.
"The party as it exists is undoubtedly in a terminal crisis and it has been held together only by the authority of the President," said Luis Javier Garrido, a longtime student of the PRI who teaches at the National Autonomous University of Mexico. "The problem ahead is that it does not know how it can make the transition from a party of the state to one more part of the system of parties that is coming into being."
In a speech last week that could prove either hypocritical or of fundamental importance to the PRI's future, Mr. Zedillo answered the rising demand for party democracy by vowing that if elected, he would give up the control that all of his predecessors have exercised over the party's internal affairs and choice of candidates.
 
Backing Down on a Pledge
 President Salinas also promised to make the party independent of the state, though he was never so explicit about how he would do so. He backed down from his pledge, many of his aides say, because he feared the consequences of free choice in an organization in which support for his policies was far from uniform.
And it was notable that when Mr. Zedillo spoke of ceding power over the party to its members, some of the most enthusiastic responses came from leaders of the old guard who apparently understood that their chance at a new political life may have come.
"What was crazy was to see all these men listening to this and applauding ferociously," said one of Mexico's leading businessman, Juan Sanchez Navarro, who was in the audience. "I could not believe they were hearing the same thing I was hearing."
Humberto Lira Mora, the party's electoral secretary, said the PRI "has always been able to allow different generations to mix and antagonistic currents to come together."
"If you study the PRI closely," he added, "you will see that its capacity to change is enormous."
 
Revolution's Heirs
Resisting Change, Seeking Stability

The problems that the PRI now faces have their origins in its stubborn resistance to change despite a radical reorientation of the Mexican economy and gathering pressure for democratic change.
From its creation as the National Revolutionary Party in the wake of another assassination, that of President-elect Alvaro Obregon in 1928, the party was meant to unite virtually all of the political forces that emerged from the 1910 Revolution.
A decade later, President Lazaro Cardenas renamed it the Party of the Mexican Revolution and began to reorganize it by sectors: The National Peasant Confederation handled rural problems. Bureaucrats were assigned to a National Confederation of Popular Organizations. Labor was eventually dominated by the Confederation of Mexican Workers. The farm and labor sectors, especially, would remain central pillars of the PRI.
The system worked well for the small elite of a largely rural nation and made Mexico a relative island of stability and development in a region more accustomed to turmoil. Politicians who controlled a union or province could trade their constituents' support for positions in a vast state bureaucracy. By banning re-election, the system reduced the incentive to break away. With weak opposition and the elaborate use of fraud, PRI candidates almost always won easily.
 
Debt and Independence
 The party's power began to wane as Mexico grew more urbanized and complex. Government could no longer be run by union and peasant leaders and provincial politicians.
After a foreign-debt crisis that exploded in 1982, budgets and jobs were slashed and the party dole shrank quickly. Mexicans began to organize themselves independently, and political opposition grew. Even within the governing party, tensions over the resistance of older party leaders to accommodate change contributed to a split in 1987 that prompted President Cardenas's son, Cuauhtemoc, and some other prominent PRI members to join with small leftist groups in what became the Democratic Revolutionary Party.
As young men like Mr. Colosio and Mr. Zedillo poured into Government, they brought Ivy League degrees but relatively few ties within the party. And as they moved from a closed, state-dominated economy to free trade and export-driven growth, their loyalties shifted from labor and peasant groups that depended on Government protection to middle-class people who relished the cheaper imports and businessmen who bought up state companies.
 
Colosio's Vision of Revival
 Mr. Colosio, who was made head of the PRI after Mr. Salinas took office as President, had a vision for its revival.
He would, he said in an interview at the time, "take the party back to its grass roots," approaching Mexicans as citizens rather than as workers or farmers, and offering to solve the problems of their communities rather than guaranteeing their jobs.
The scheme was closely linked to the National Solidarity Program, an ambitious anti-poverty initiative that Mr. Salinas built into a $3.8 billion-a-year empire of programs ranging from new water and electrical lines to scholarships so that children could go to school instead of to work.
To harness community involvement and assure a political benefit to the Government, the program called for the election of tens of thousands of local "solidarity committees." The new program engaged many of the Mexicans who had slipped beyond the Government's influence during the economic crisis, and identified thousands of local leaders untinged by the corrupt networks of the PRI.
At the party's 14th general assembly in 1990, Mr. Colosio, at Mr. Salinas's direction, began trying to extend the reform to the structures of the party itself.
 
Call for Internal Elections
 Most importantly, he called for the internal election of candidates to high office who in the past had always been chosen by the President. After one of Mr. Salinas's favorites for a gubernatorial nomination was outvoted by the rank and file, however, the practice was quickly scrapped.
The limits to Mr. Colosio's success became evident first when the party's leadership assembled again last year. Labor-union stalwarts, on whom Mr. Salinas had depended to push through controls on wages and the North American Free Trade Agreement, mocked the idea that they could be pushed aside, chanting of the citizens' movement, "Where is it?"
After Mr. Colosio was shot as he left a rally in the northern city of Tijuana, the older PRI leaders rushed to reclaim power. Close associates of Carlos Hank Gonzalez, 66, who amassed one of the country's biggest fortunes during a long career in public service, took over the presidency of the PRI and other key posts. A few others went to officials tied to Fernando Gutierrez Barrios, Mr. Salinas's former Interior Minister and a longtime national-security official.
But in spite of old-line PRI leaders' public grumbling that Mr. Zedillo would be even more "technocratic" than Mr. Salinas, the Yale-trained former Planning and Budget Minister was picked to replace Mr. Colosio. In imposing his choice, Mr. Salinas could risk some opposition within the party because he could assume wider support for his candidate outside it.
Almost as striking as the public challenge to the President's traditional prerogative of naming the party's candidate to succeed him is the way in which bitterly contending elements of the PRI have since been pulled together and harnessed to Mr. Zedillo's campaign.
 
Keeping Solidarity
The Old Guard Fights On

In Baja California, the state where Mr. Zedillo was born and Mr. Colosio was killed, the remnants of the old PRI organization, which suffered the party's first-ever loss of a governorship in 1989, remain in place. In several congressional districts, the candidacies were doled out to old union leaders, farm bosses or figures of the party's old guard.
Jaime Martinez Veloz refers to such figures as members of "the party," almost as though he belonged to another.
Mr. Martinez Veloz, a charismatic, 40-year-old architect who is running for the lower house of congress from Tijuana, is a candidate of the PRI himself. But almost more than that, he is a political product of the Solidarity program.
He has lived in the city less than three years. A former student leader in the northern city of Saltillo, he campaigns in jeans and sunglasses. His conversation is strewn with phrases like "the organization of the people." He tends to describe the moderately right-of-center city government of the National Action Party as "fascist."
And until almost the day he took to the campaign trial, he was the Government official in charge of the Solidarity program in Tijuana, the man most closely identified with the streets it paved, the sewers it dug and the 850 neighborhood committees it formed.
"The truth is, if we did not have that structure, we would never be able to do this," Mr. Martinez Veloz said. By "this," he meant the dislodging of the labor union hierarchy that once controlled his district for the PRI, fought bitterly against his candidacy and then pressured him unsuccessfully to accept one of its members as his second.
Officials of the National Action Party complain that Mr. Martinez Veloz represents merely a modernizing turn on the PRI's traditional dependence on state resources to maintain its political power. Where the old unionists could promise the voters jobs and coerce them with goons at the polls, Mr. Martinez Veloz barnstorms the neighborhoods where he has worked, avoiding explicit promises of more Solidarity projects but making it abundantly clear who has gotten the job done in the past.
"It is grotesque that the head of Solidarity would become the PRI candidate!" said Mario Herrera, a community organizer and political analyst who advises the National Action city government. "The entire basis of his campaign is that structure the Government set up."
Vehemently as it is sometimes expressed, however, such criticism is almost inaudible by comparison with that voiced at more traditionalist PRI campaigns in the area. After National Action won the statehouse in 1989, the new officials discovered checks and allocations that they said showed more than $10 million in direct outlays from the state budget to the PRI gubernatorial campaign.
But in an increasingly competitive political environment, the old controls of the PRI have eroded or broken down in countless ways.
At the international border crossing that connects Tijuana to San Ysidro, Calif., Lino Ronquillo, 34, a street vendor hawking pink-and-white ceramic piggy banks told how his support for the PRI ended abruptly when the opposition took over City Hall and stopped giving out the vendors' licenses through their PRI-affiliated union.
"Before, the union would take us all to certain polling stations to vote, and say that if you don't vote for so and so, you're not going to work anymore," said Mr. Ronquillo, who scoffed at the notion that such ballots were secret. "Now we are independents. You vote for whomever you want."
'Vote Promoters'
Seeking Support With Organization
 The PRI's essential adaptation to the loss of such controls has been one of organization: More than 3,600 PRI lawyers have been signed up to move around the country on election day to defend the party's vote if charges of fraud arise. Another 295,132 PRI representatives -- far more than any other party -- will monitor the 96,000 polling stations themselves.
As part of a strategy that the PRI began to develop in state elections while Mr. Colosio was its president, the party has blanketed Mexico with a network of "vote promoters" who canvass door to door.
In theory, the promoters merely encourage people to vote for the PRI and then, if they say they will, go back to their homes on election day to make sure they have voted or even physically lead them to the polls. As of last Friday, the promoters numbered 520,843 at the block level alone, with 366,111 more working individual sidewalks in the country's 10 largest cities.
Recent interviews with scores of voters around the country suggest that PRI votes will come from a mix of sentiments ranging from the almost-religious faith of those who could not fathom another Government to the cynical resignation of others who assume it would be a waste of time to vote for the opposition in a contest that will surely be decided by fraud.
 
Getting Out the Vote
 But many political analysts say that the persuading, cajoling and getting out of individual votes could be critical for the PRI.
"The fight of the elections is not at the macro level but at the micro level," said Mr. Lira Mora, the party's chief of electoral action. "You have to go to the street, house by house, vote by vote. We tell our candidates where the votes are and they go get them."
In the western city of Guadalajara last week, a courtly former mayor, Gabriel Covarrubias, 64, was out in one of the working-class neighborhoods he was trying to get to send him to the Congress, knocking on doors.
As he rebuttoned the button on his dark wool suit despite the afternoon heat, Mr. Covarrubias agreed with Maria Flores, 72, a retired shopkeeper, that the world had gotten very tough. Very tough.
"We must try to keep what we have," he advised her.

HEADLINE: 2d Atomic Sample, Likely From Russia, Found in Germany

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BONN, Aug. 11

 BODY:
The German authorities have discovered a second tiny sample of weapons-grade nuclear material that may have been smuggled out of Russia to interest foreign governments or terrorist groups that may want to build atomic bombs, the police said today.
They said they had seized the material, 0.028 ounces of highly enriched uranium-235, in June in Landshut, Bavaria, and have since arrested five Czech and Slovak men and a German woman as suspects in what they surmise was an attempt to arrange the sale of a larger amount to someone who wanted to build a bomb. 
 The amount of uranium-235 seized is minute, about one ten-thousandth of the amount necessary to build a nuclear explosive. But officials are concerned that this might indeed be a sample from a larger amount available on the black market.
"This could turn into the most serious security threat since the end of the cold war, and it is getting steadily worse," a high-ranking German official said. "We have not even begun to get it under control, and we won't unless we all -- Americans, Europeans and Russians -- work at it together."
The police also found two-tenths of an ounce of highly enriched plutonium-239 in May in the garage of a German businessman in Tengen, near the Swiss border in southern Germany. The businessman, Adolf Jakle, is under arrest and has told investigators that other samples of uranium and plutonium from the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe were in Germany and Austria.
But senior German officials say Mr. Jakle has not yet led them to any prospective customers interested in buying the material, which is used in nuclear warheads. The authorities suspect he was negotiating with contacts from Iraq or Iran on a deal to make one of those countries capable of building a nuclear weapon.
The police said that the uranium in the latest case was seized on June 13, but that they announced it only now so they could complete their investigations. The German woman, a real estate dealer, was arrested on Monday, the police said, and was regarded as the ringleader.
There is no apparent connection with the plutonium case, but it is also not clear whether the police have any leads to the woman's prospective customers for the uranium. They did not release her name.
"The latest discovery in Landshut shows that international organized crime -- a real atomic mafia -- is at work here," said Gunther Beckstein, the Bavarian interior minister. German officials fear that former officers of the Soviet K.G.B. are involved in procuring the materials for sale abroad by criminal groups.
Russian officials denied that the plutonium found in Mr. Jakle's garage had come from their country, but German experts have told the Government here that they are certain it did.
The Bavarian police said they had also seized 21.2 ounces of uranium pellets not suitable for bombs from a 35-year-old Czech man when they arrested him at a highway rest stop near Munich on July 4. He is not involved in the latest case.
The plutonium, analyzed in the Trans-Uranium Institute in Karls ruhe, could have come from a Russian nuclear power plant or a deactivated atomic submarine, according to the Bavarian police.
During the last year, there have been 123 cases of smuggling of radioactive materials -- mostly cesium or uranium used in medicine or industry -- from formerly Communist countries into Germany, the police said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Increases in European Rates Send Dollar Down vs. Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar plunged against the German mark and declined against other leading currencies yesterday as traders were unnerved by rising European interest rates.
Trading centered on European currencies for much of the day after the Swedish and Italian central banks raised their official lending rates. Those moves, in turn, fanned speculation that the Bundesbank of Germany would raise its rates. 
 The German mark advanced broadly, hitting a record high against the Italian lira. Trading in dollars was thin, exaggerating the dollar's fall, dealers said.
The Swedish and Italian rate increases quickly ended an early dollar rally on news that producer prices rose 0.5 percent in July -- heightening expectations that the Federal Reserve will raise short-term rates next week to head off inflation.
The unexpected rate increases sparked a sell-off in bond markets across Europe and flight from the continent's weaker currencies into the mark. That gave American dealers an excuse to sell the dollar.
With Europe's economy picking up steam, many traders say, other European interest rates are likely to rise, which could put further pressure on the dollar. Rates in Germany already are higher than American rates. Countries with higher interest rates tend to attract capital flows, strengthening their currencies.
"The Swedish and Italian rate hikes came on top of fears that we won't see any cuts in Europe," said Hubert Pedroli, foreign exchange manager for Credit Suisse in New York. "Today, we got the coup de grace."
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.5608 German marks, down more than two pfennigs from 1.5844 marks on Wednesday and the lowest level since July 18.
The dollar also fell to 100.15 Japanese yen from 101.45 yen. And it dropped to 1,579 Italian lire, from 1,591 lire.
The British pound rose to $1.5458 from $1.5365.
Compounding the dollar's interest rate woes, the Treasury's offering of $11 billion in 30 1/4-year bonds was poorly received, prompting heavy selling in the bond market.
"There was some panic selling of dollars," said Paul Farrell, manager of strategic currency trading at Chase Manhattan Bank. "There was a bit of an overreaction."
In recent months, weakness in American securities markets has hurt the dollar. Falling interest in dollar-denominated assets among foreign investors means less demand for the currency.
Mr. Pedroli of Credit Suisse said yesterday's events simply gave dealers bearish on the dollar an excuse to sell. He noted that the dollar had been hovering over 101 yen and near 1.59 marks for more than a week.
"Everyone has been waiting for a break either up or down. I think it happened today," he said.

HEADLINE: Fed Nominee Is Confirmed By Senate

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
The Senate confirmed President Clinton's nomination of Janet L. Yellen, a California economist, to the Federal Reserve Board tonight by a vote of 94 to 6.
Senators were eager to put Ms. Yellen on the board before next Tuesday's meeting of the central bank's interest-rate policy committee. 
 It is standard procedure for the Senate to try to hold votes on Federal Reserve nominees before they are next needed at a committee meeting, and Ms. Yellen is particularly popular because she expressed limited enthusiasm at her confirmation hearing for raising interest rates.
Few experts on the Federal Reserve expect Ms. Yellen's addition to the board to have any substantial effect on next Tuesday's meeting. New nominees to the board are seldom outspoken at their first interest-rate committee meeting and have only one voice among 19 members of the committee, said David C. Munro, a Fed watcher and economic consultant in Manhattan.
 
Decision by Consensus
 Ms. Yellen's addition is even less likely to affect the outcome because the committee does not appear to be split into factions that might give her a chance to cast a deciding vote, Mr. Munro said. The committee typically makes decisions by a consensus that Alan Greenspan, the chairman, usually shapes.
The interest-rate committee consists of seven Federal Reserve Board governors and the presidents of the 12 regional Federal Reserve Banks. The governors and the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York each have a vote at the rate meetings, and no more than four of the other 11 presidents cast votes at the meetings. The 11 presidents take turns casting votes during the course of a three-year cycle.
The Senate Banking Committee had approved Ms. Yellen's nomination last week by a vote of 18 to 1. The only vote against her came from Senator Lauch Faircloth, Republican of North Carolina, who had told Ms. Yellen at her confirmation hearing that her concerns should be limited to "inflation, inflation and inflation."
Ms. Yellen said at the hearing that she would seek to follow the Federal Reserve Act, which under a 1978 amendment calls for the central bank to pursue "maximum employment, stable prices and moderate long-term interest rates."
In addition to Senator Faircloth, five other Republican Senators voted tonight against Ms. Yellen's nomination. They were Hank Brown of Colorado, Jesse Helms of North Carolina, Charles Grassley of Iowa, Larry Pressler of South Dakota and Malcolm Wallop of Wyoming.
Ms. Yellen, an economics professor at the University of California at Berkeley who is best known for her writings on unemployment, has been confirmed to a full 14-year term on the Federal Reserve Board. She replaces Wayne Angell, who resigned as his term was expiring in early February and is now an economist at Bear, Stearns & Company.

HEADLINE: Reno Vows to Thwart Exodus From Cuba

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
In a swiftly escalating immigration dispute between the United States and Cuba, Federal authorities announced tonight that a speedboat carrying 20 Cubans was detained in the Florida Keys today, and Attorney General Janet Reno said the Government would take strong legal steps to stop a mass exodus from Cuba.
In a highly unusual evening news conference today, Ms. Reno said any United States-flagged vessels that appeared to be bound for Cuba to pick up immigrants might be stopped, boarded and seized by the Coast Guard. She warned that anyone trying to bring Cubans to the United States may be prosecuted. 
 "The solution to emigration pressures from Cuba is rapid, fundamental and far-reaching political change and economic reform," Ms. Reno said. "Uncontrolled exodus from Cuba does nothing to address Cuba's internal problems and places large numbers of persons at risk on the high seas."
Her remarks revealed the anxiety within the Clinton Administration over the possibility of another 1980 Mariel boatlift, when a rag-tag flotilla of American boats streamed from Florida to Cuba to ferry a cargo of 125,000 Cuban immigrants back to the United States.
The action follows harsh Cuban complaints after four hijackings of vessels in Cuba in the last two weeks by people who made the 90-mile run to Florida. Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, has said he might make lower barriers to immigration if the seizures continued.
Tensions have been climbing since the hijacking of a Government boat on Monday. Cuban officials are demanding the return of 26 Cubans on board. Instead, American officials released all but one of the boat's passengers.
The boat stopped today by United States Customs agents, was boarded at a beach resort in Key Largo, south of Miami. It was the first vessel known to have crossed the Florida straits to bring Cubans into the country, law enforcement officials said tonight, adding that the high-profile announcement of the detention of the craft and its crew of three was intended as a signal that authorities would not tolerate another boatlift.
The three crew members were turned over to immigration officials and were charged with illegally transporting aliens to the United States. The 20 passengers were held at a immigrant center in South Florida for processing under a program that, after a year, permits Cubans to seek permanent residency in the United States.
The Coast Guard is ready to rush more ships to the Caribbean in response to any mass migration from Cuba, the State Department said today.
At the time, Castro said that if Washington did not take swift steps to change its immigration policy, Cuba would make it easier for people to leave the country, and allow their relatives to come from the United States to pick them up.
Justice Department officials said today that each hijacking had been investigated but that no action had ever been taken after such seizures. Cuban officials say this encourages more such criminal acts.
State Department officials have said Mr. Castro has assured them that he would not set off another wave of emigration. In what some Cuban-Americans regard as an effort to soothe Mr. Castro, the State Department appeared to signal a tougher attitude toward hijackers. One State Department spokesman has said the hijackings are disturbing trend that places everyone involved in danger.
The Coast Guard has reported that immigration from Cuba has been increasing. The agency said it picked up 539 fleeing Cubans this month and 5,270 since the beginning of the year. That compares with 3,656 Cubans picked up last year and makes this year the highest level of entries since the Mariel boatlift.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Castro on U.S. Television
 By The Associated Press
Speaking from Havana on a Cuban television broadcast that was carried live on CNN in the United States, Mr. Castro accused the United States tonight of covering up Monday's hijacking and reiterated the accusation that a Cuban military officer had been killed. He said body of Cuban Lieut. Roberto Aguilar Reyes was found on Wednesday.
Mr. Castro also said the United States Government was responsible for the number of Cubans fleeing because of its embargo and its acceptance of Cubans fleeing in rafts and boats, contrary to Cuban law.
"They insist that we be the guardians of the U.S. border," he said. "They've created this situation of violence and hijackings."

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE;
Excerpts From Speeches by Senators on the Mitchell Health Care Proposal

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from statements made yesterday on the Senate floor in the third day of debate over the health care bill, as transcribed by The New York Times from a broadcast on C-Span.
 
STATEMENT BY SENATOR GRAMM
 I can hardly believe my ears when the health care system of the United States of America is compared unfavorably to the health care systems of Canada, Great Britain and Germany. Last year more people died in Canada waiting to get into the operating room than died on the operating table. People all over the world under government-dominated systems are dying because health care that is readily available in America is not available in those countries. And I want to begin my debate on this issue -- since everybody is talking about what we are going to gain by vastly expanding the role of government in health care decisions, I want to start by talking about what we stand to lose. . . . 
 First of all, we have, in the United States of America, the greatest health care system in the history of the world. In the last 25 years, 90 percent of all the pharmaceuticals, 95 percent of all the medical procedures, 90 percent of all the routine miracles that we expect every time we go to the doctor, every time we go to the hospital, they have all been developed by Americans.
It is very interesting to me that so many of my colleagues, when they think of medical perfection in the world, look to the north to Canada, and yet I notice when they and people they love get sick, they never ever go to Canada to try to get well. And yet on any given day in America, in any referral hospital, and I would ask my colleagues today to go out to Johns Hopkins University to their great medical center, and they will find that those referral wards are full of rich or politically powerful Canadians. They're full of people who have had an opportunity to look socialized medicine in the face in Great Britain and Germany and have found that face to be an ugly, uncaring face. And they have come to the United States of America to get health care.
Now, that may not tell some people anything, but it tells me something: and that is we have a lot to lose in this debate as well as a lot to gain. I am not going to support tearing down the greatest medical care system in the history of the world to rebuild it in the image of the Post Office. [Applause.] . . .
But let me talk about access because it is an area where there is a great deal of agreement. And that has all been forgotten in this debate. First of all, we have had now some two dozen bills introduced and every one of these bills tries to deal with the problem we call portability. Every one of these bills tries to make it easier for people to change jobs without losing their health insurance. When we talk about 37 million Americans last year who didn't have health insurance on at least one day, over 75 percent of those people, by some studies, didn't have health insurance for one reason: they changed jobs. And when you change jobs in America, you lose the insurance through the employer you're with and you don't get insurance on the new job until, generally, you've been there for 30 days.
We can solve 75 percent of the problem of people not having insurance on a provision that as far as I know every single member of the Senate supports: Make it easier for people to change jobs without losing their health insurance. That was in the two bills I introduced. It was in the bill that Senator Dole introduced. It's in the Mitchell bill. It's in the Clinton bill. It's in the Gephardt bill. It's in everybody's bill. That's not what we're debating here. Every bill that has been introduced, as far as I'm aware, deals with the problem of permanence. . . .
Then what problems remain if you deal with permanence and portability? Well the next problem is people who already sick, people who have what are called pre-existing conditions. In listening to the White House and listening to some of my colleagues, they sound as if they believe that by passing laws we can eliminate pre-existing conditions. Only God can eliminate pre-existing conditions.
 
STATEMENT BY SENATOR WOFFORD
 In yesterday morning's Washington Post, one of my Republican colleagues was quoted as saying that health care is too important -- get those words -- health care is too important for this Congress to pass a reform bill now. Instead of acting, he says, we should commission a study -- a study! Mr. President, we've had years of studies, mountains of studies. We don't need another study to tell us what is wrong with this system; we need the backbone to fix it. Not after the next election, not sometime in the next century, now! Health care delayed is health care denied.
To those advocates of delay who say the remedy offered by Senator Mitchell is too complicated to understand without a study, that the remedy offered by Senator Moynihan and the Finance Committee and now incorporated in great part in the bill we will be considering from Senator Mitchell, is too complicated to understand without a study, I say study this: this is the Federal employees benefit plan. It's a model of what we are proposing to do, to guarantee all Americans the kinds of private, affordable coverage; the choice of private health plans; not government-run plans, your own doctor plans and H.M.O.'s, your choice, that members of Congress arrange for themselves. What's so complicated about that? . . .
If members of this Congress want more time to study, let them study what it's like to be a middle-class American caught up in the health insurance mess. Let them study what it's like to try to buy insurance on the open market without the help of their employers. So, I'm serving notice that if the defenders of the status quo succeed in blocking this, in causing further delay or study, I will introduce an amendment that will disqualify every member of Congress from participating in the Federal employees health plan until we pass a bill which will do four things: 1, put us on a certain path to universal coverage; 2, open the Federal employee benefits plan to the American people and to small businesses; 3, end insurance discrimination, meaning real portability, meaning an end to pre-existing conditions, exclusions. Senator Gramm said only God can end a pre-existing condition. This Congress, in the bill we're seeking, can end pre-existing conditions, an end to lifetime caps on benefits and an end to discrimination against older Americans. And 4, contains real serious effective measures to control health care costs so we don't increase the deficit. . . .
The problem with our present system of health insurance is that so much of it is phony. You pay and pay and then just when you need it, it isn't there. . . .
I've heard members of Congress say that doing nothing on health care doesn't hurt me at all. Well, it should. It should hurt every one of us if we fail to act, because it sure is going to hurt the American people and the American economy.
 
STATEMENT BY SENATOR BOREN
 I came to this chamber today, I must confess, with something of a heavy heart, Madam President, because I believe we're on the wrong path. Senator McCain quoted Yogi Berra a few moments ago when he said "deja vu all over again." A little over a year ago I think we made a tragic mistake in this country by passing the budget of the United States Government for the first time in modern memory totally along a party-line vote, 51 votes in the Senate and a tie-breaking vote, all from one party, all of the other party in opposition. The same happened in the House of Representatives.
And what a tragedy that is for the country, because like the changes that will come in health care, the need to bring down the deficits of this country will take a long, sustained joint partnership on the part of all of the American people. While we have made some progress toward getting the deficit down, the job is far from over. The Administration's own figures indicate that with additions to the deficit that are anticipated under the budgets we have passed shortly into the next century we will reach the point in which all of the private savings, 100 percent of the private savings in this country, will be used just to pay the interest on the national debt.
That, Madam President, will mean that our economic growth in this country is imperiled and our future will be subject to the decisions of investors in other countries, not in this country. And the only way we're ever going to get the deficit under control and sustain a long-range approach is to have a bipartisan plan, one that will have the support of the vast majority of the American people in both of our political parties. And the only way, Madam President, that we're going to have health care carried through in an efficient and an effective way is to reach a bipartisan consensus so that that plan can be sustained for many years. . . .
And if we ram a bill through this Congress, and I hope my colleagues will hear me, I pray that they will hear me, I plead with them to hear me -- because we've got to stop this train right now and get off and go back to the drawing boards and start on the basis of trying to get something done together.
Let's not destroy the quality of health care in this country by passing a bill along party lines, by having 51 votes and ramming it through. And then waiting until the next election and have it reversed as the political fortunes of one party or another change. Nothing discouraged me more, Madam President, than to read that the First Lady in a press conference two days ago said, "I have a lot of confidence in the outcome, and if it's a 51-vote outcome, fine." And she went on to say that's what we had on the budget and it was fine then.
Madam President, it wasn't fine.
 
 
STATEMENT BY SENATOR KERREY
 Madam President, following on remarks made by the distinguished Senator from Oklahoma, an appeal for a bipartisan bill, I'd like to describe what I think are ways for us to close the differences between the Republicans and the Democrats on this very important piece of legislation, and would begin with an observation that two people who are apparently a long ways apart -- at least I think observers would say that we're a long ways apart on this issue of health care -- are much closer than what meets the eye.
In this case, it is the Republican leader. Senator Dole and I share a very similar experience (He's a bit more visible than I). I'm fully dressed, you can hardly tell that I've been the recipient of health care to save my life, without which I would not be here today, which might trouble some in this country. Nonetheless it is important to note that similarity.
I have read Senator Dole's bill, it's got the distinguished Senator from Oregon's name on it as well, it's S.2374 and unlike some who have urged me to come to the floor and say it's a sham, I don't believe it is a sham. I see principles in this bill that are similar to principles I have as well.
Indeed, I think it's quite fair to say that the mainstream group has worked very closely both with majority leader Mitchell and the distinguished Senator from New York and the distinguished Senator from Massachusetts trying to fashion an amendment that would strike many of the government provisions that have been identified so eloquently, and sometimes I might say a bit preposterously, by those who would like to describe the Mitchell bill as a government takeover of health care.
I note with some pride that yesterday's speech by the distinguished Senator from Rhode Island, Senator Chaffee, identified 10 areas where he's prepared to make changes, where he wants changes made in the Mitchell bill. And I noted with some considerable excitement that the distinguished Senator from Massachusetts immediately went and spoke for a considerable period of time, and my understanding is that there's a possibility of agreement between those two distinguished Senators, apparently of opposite parties and apparently of opposite views. Apparently as well, preparing to resolve the conflicts they have about the Mitchell bill.
If we can resolve those conflicts, Madam President, we will have taken a very big step forward, we will have taken a lot of the government intrusion out of this thing and perhaps we can come to the floor and talk about some other things, some other differences that we have with one another.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Photos: "THE PLAYERS: Debating in the Senate"
 
PHIL GRAMM
 Republican of Texas. A leader of the conservatives in his party, he is expected to wage a strong fight against Senator George J. Mitchell's bill. He has made a reputation in Congress as an opponent of ever-rising Federal deficits, and many in his camp regard a new health care program as a likely cause of more deficit spending.
 
HARRIS WOFFORD
 Democrat of Pennsylvania. His victory in a special election in 1991 rested heavily on his advocacy of a health care bill and, at the same time, refocused Washington on the issue. He is seeking elected to a full term this fall and, as he has sought to depict himself as someone at the center of the debate, passage of a bill would help his campaign greatly.
 
DAVID L. BOREN
 Democrat of Oklahoma. He is a conservative Democrat who has joined with several Democrats and Republicans to form a bipartisan bloc that seeks to come up with a health care plan that is less costly than the Mitchell bill. His view, as emphasized in his speech today, is that an effort should be made through compromise to fashion a bill that would pass with wide support, not a partisan Democratic measure that squeaks by with a narrow 51-vote victory,
 
BOB KERREY
 Democrat of Nebraska. Like Senator Boren, Mr. Kerrey advocates putting together a bill that would win broad bipartisan support in the Senate. He has taken the role of one of the chief Democratic critics of the Mitchell bill, contending that it would not contain rising costs and would centralize control of health care in a Federal bureacracy.
