HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE HOUSE;
Uncertainty Is Clouding Health Bill

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
The course of health care legislation became increasingly uncertain in the House today. The Democratic leadership acknowledged that it would delay all voting on the issue, and a rival bipartisan group unveiled a plan of its own and began trying to muster the conservative votes needed to pass it.
The Democratic leaders, stunned by their loss on the crime bill tonight, later met with their Senate counterparts and White House officials but emerged with nothing definite to say about when they would take up health care. 
 The House had been set to begin the health care debate next Monday and begin voting on Wednesday. But the leaders said today that it would be impossible to meet that schedule because the Congressional Budget Office was still far from completing the necessary financial analyses of the legislation.
The Democratic leaders said tonight that they would keep the House in session next week and try to revive the crime bill, which failed on a procedural vote this evening. "I'm not going to set any kind of deadline on when we can get to health care," Speaker Thomas S. Foley said, "because I don't know when C.B.O. is going to be able to finish."
 
No 'Concocted Excuse'
 Mr. Foley angrily rejected any thought that the leadership was delaying action because it did not have the votes for its proposal.
"The problem," he said, "is that we are all of us -- Republicans and Democrats, everybody in this debate -- committed to the notion that there cannot be an effective debate and vote without clear economic estimates of the cost and reach of the programs.
"There's no mystery about that. It's not some kind of concocted excuse."
Still, in the view of both allies and opponents on Capitol Hill, the delay only added to the problems of the Democratic leaders, who have been struggling to rally their members behind a sweeping bill that would seek to achieve universal coverage by imposing a requirement that employers pay 80 percent of the cost of insuring their workers.
Moreover, the leaders will have to cope with the severe setback dealt them tonight when, despite vigorous efforts by President Clinton, they proved unable to move the Administration's crime bill to the floor. Tony Blankley, a spokesman for Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip, said of the Democratic leadership's health plan: "I know they don't have the votes. I don't think they'll get the votes. And today didn't help them."
The House majority leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, said tonight, "I don't think the issues are related that much.
"Obviously, we wanted to win the crime bill," Mr. Gephardt said, but "the health bill is the health bill."
 
The Membership Grows Angry
 Democratic strategists had long been proceeding in the belief that sending members home for their summer recess before they voted on a health care bill would only feed their apprehensions by exposing them to more lobbying. On the other hand, depriving them of the recess week after week, with no certainty as to when they can vote, is only angering them, some lawmakers said. The recess, which has important political uses in an election year, was originally scheduled to begin on Aug. 12 and last until after Labor Day.
"There's no question now the members are discouraged," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat who supports the leadership's plan. "And frankly, the longer we stay here without a vote, the more discouraged they get."
The delay is certain to please some back-bench Democrats, who have been eager to put off a health care vote until they get some sense of what the Senate will do. Senate Democrats are being asked to vote on a much less sweeping bill in which one of the most vexing questions of the debate -- whether employers should be required to pay much of the cost of their workers' insurance -- is answered with a provision that would not require such payments until 2002, if then. Some of the more conservative House Democrats are asking why they should vote for something far more stringent.
 
Rival Plan Offered
 Tensions within the Democratic caucus were evident today when a bipartisan group of 10 lawmakers finally produced their health care plan. They noted that it included no requirements for employer payments, no new taxes and no price controls.
Instead, they asserted, it is a "common sense," moderate attempt to make insurance more accessible and affordable through new regulation of the insurance industry, new market structures like insurance purchasing cooperatives and subsidies for low-income people. It would be financed largely by savings in Medicare and Medicaid, the authors said.
"We sought to develop a new plan that truly fixes what is broken and keeps what works," said one of the plan's architects, Representative J. Roy Rowland, Democrat of Georgia, who acknowledged that it would raise the percentage of insured Americans to only 90 percent, from the current level of 85 percent.
Another sponsor, Representative Jim Cooper, a Tennessee Democrat who has been a persistent critic of the approaches advocated by the Administration and the Democratic leaders, said, "The principles that united people from both parties were that health care reform should be voluntary, it should be market-driven, and it should offer maximum consumer choice."
Democrats close to the leadership said the bipartisan plan had been "held hostage" by the Republicans and, as a result, was lacking on every major goal of health care restructuring. Not only does it fall far short on expanding coverage, they argued, but its subsidies would give little help to working families. Further, the proposal's opponents said, the elderly would be deprived of the prescription-drug and long-term-care benefits that would be provided under other plans.
At a news conference, Representative Vic Fazio of California, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said he hoped that the conservative Democrats among the bipartisan group would return to the leadership fold. The Republicans, he argued, had "an inordinate amount of influence" on the plan.
Mr. Rowland, who said he thought that the bill had enough votes to pass, acknowledged that he had no hard count.
Still, the Democratic leadership can afford to lose very few Democrats. And the bipartisan plan at least complicates the leaders' strategy, particularly if the bulk of Republicans move behind the bill, as some on Capitol Hill expect.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Up 0.5% in July

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
Producer prices rose one-half of 1 percent in July, the biggest increase in 15 months, while retail sales slowed slightly, the Government said today.
But both overall figures masked changes in key sectors of the economy that give contradictory indications of whether the current economic expansion will lead to a sharp rise in inflation. And, taken together, the figures further muddled the question of whether the Federal Reserve would push up short-term interest rates again when its main policy committee meets Tuesday, Wall Street analysts said. 
 Stock and bond markets fell after the release of today's economic reports, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 15.86 points to close at 3,750.90, while the interest rate on 30-year Treasury bonds rose to 7.65 percent, from 7.57 percent. [Pages D4 and D12.]
 
The Parts, Not the Whole
 The overall figures released today were much less important than their components, Wall Street analysts said. The big increase in overall producer prices, for instance, mainly reflected a sharp rise in food and energy prices, especially for coffee and gasoline.
Producer prices for the rest of the economy, which Federal Reserve officials have cited as more important to their interest-rate decisions, only crept up by one-tenth of a percentage point, the Labor Department said.
But producer prices for so-called intermediate goods, like lumber and paperboard, rose four-tenths of a percent in July after an increase of six-tenths of a percent in June, a pattern that several analysts called an ominous harbinger of possible consumer price increases ahead.
Prices for intermediate energy goods, including gasoline, diesel fuel and jet fuel, rose 1.7 percent, while prices for nondurable manufacturing materials like paperboard, wood pulp and various chemicals climbed nine-tenths of a percentage point.
While overall retail sales fell by a tenth of a percentage point, that figure was deceptive. It mainly reflected a 1.7 percent drop in sales of cars and trucks, which have been in short supply as factories struggle to refill dealer lots that consumers nearly picked clean last spring.
Excluding autos, retail sales rose four-tenths of a percentage point in July. The Commerce Department also revised its estimate of June retail sales growth to eight-tenths of a percentage point, from six-tenths.
Retail sales were especially strong in July at furniture and home furnishings stores, up 1.3 percent, and in restaurants and bars, also up 1.3 percent. Sales at building materials and garden supply outlets rose 1.5 percent while clothing-store sales fell nine-tenths of a percent.
 
'Ambiguity and Uncertainty'
 Allen Sinai, the chief economist at Lehman Brothers, was skeptical that today's figures would tilt the central bank for or against a fifth interest rate increase this year. "They add to the ambiguity and uncertainty of whether the Fed will raise interest rates," he said.
Several other important economic reports are scheduled for release before Tuesday and may also influence the central bank's decision: the Consumer Price Index on Friday and the industrial production and industrial capacity utilization figures on Monday. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, emphasized in Congressional testimony on Wednesday that no single economic indicator determined the course of American monetary policy.
Mickey D. Levy, an economist in the New York offices of Nationsbank, said today's economic news made it more likely that the nation's central bank would raise to 4.5 percent from 4.25 percent its target rate for overnight loans between banks.
"It certainly validates the Fed's moving a quarter of a point," he said. "Unless we get a shocking C.P.I. number, I don't think we'll see a half-point move."
 
Working Off Inventories
 The July retail sales statistics, and the upward revision of the June figures, mean that stores and wholesale warehouses may not be as crowded now with unsold goods as previously thought, said Robert Giordano, an economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. The Commerce Department had announced on July 29 that the economy had grown at a 3.7 percent annual rate in the second quarter, but that more than half the extra goods had gone into inventories as consumer spending slowed sharply.
Based on today's sales figures, Mr. Giordano said, "there's less of a pileup on the shelf than it seemed on the initial report."
Top Federal Reserve officials have said in interviews over the last two weeks that the rising inventories were important because factories might slow down until the extra goods were sold.
Other Federal Reserve officials had played down worries about the inventories, saying that they felt that businesses would likely be able to sell them and that much of the buildup might have consisted of imports. If stores cancel orders for additional imports, foreign factories might slow down but there would be little effect on the American economy.
 
Buying American
 Today's retail sales report appeared to show that American-made goods in particular were selling well, which could be interpreted by the Federal Reserve as a sign of strength in the economy and an argument for raising interest rates. The retail sales figures were held down by a drop in sales of clothing, which tends to be imported, while sales of building supplies and food rose.
Analysts said financial markets would have fallen even more today if retail sales excluding cars had risen by more than the four-tenths of a percentage point that the Commerce Department reported. "If we had gotten a 1.0, I think the market would have gotten annihilated," Mr. Levy said.
Investors fear rapid economic growth because it can lead to shortages of materials and skilled labor and thus produce inflation, which erodes the value of fixed stock dividends and bond interest payments.
Mr. Sinai said the July increase in retail sales, excluding autos, showed some strength in the economy but pointed out that these sales grew twice as fast in June. "Consumer spending in the third quarter, like the second quarter, continues to look on the soft side," he said. "Today's data told me the economy is still on a softer growth path."
Although analysts said they were eagerly awaiting the release of the Consumer Price Index on Friday, Mr. Greenspan criticized the index in his testimony on Wednesday, saying that it overstated inflation.
Paul A. Armknecht, the assistant commissioner for consumer prices at the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics, said today that the agency was developing another index for retail price inflation that would address some, but not all, of Mr. Greenspan's concerns.
The new index will be ready by 1996, if the agency has adequate resources, and will be compiled once a year to give policy makers a sense of how much, if at all, the consumer index overstates inflation, he said.

HEADLINE: Italy and Sweden Raise Their Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: ROME, Aug. 11

 BODY:
The Bank of Italy raised its discount rate today, joining Sweden in the first European rate increases to fight inflation in nearly two years.
The move drove down stock prices in Europe and also weakened the dollar. Some analysts said they were concerned that the rate increase could signal the end of rate reductions throughout Europe, especially in Germany. 
 Italy raised its discount rate to 7.5 percent, from 7 percent, its first increase since September 1992. The Italian central bank said in a statement that the rate increase was aimed at allowing "economic recovery to continue without reigniting inflation."
The Swedish central bank, the Riksbank, lifted its money market rate, the securities repurchase rate, to 7.20 percent, from 6.92 percent. It raised its key lending rate -- what it charges banks for loans -- to 8 percent, from 7.5 percent.
"With Italy and Sweden raising rates, Germany can't be far behind," said Paul Kasriel, an economist at Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "Interest rates in Europe are already higher than in the U.S., and now they're heading higher."
"The rate increases show that the recovery in Europe is stronger than we thought," said Mark Vitner, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C. Even so, Mr. Vitner said he thought the dollar's slump today was overdone because Germany was still likely to cut interest rates at least once more this year.
The interest rate increases also hurt stocks because of concern that they would jeopardize the fragile economic recovery on the Continent.
Urban Baeckstron, governor of the Riksbank, said the central bank was moving at "an early stage to counter a tendency to increased inflation."
In London, the Financial Times Stock Exchange index fell 28.80 points, to 3,138.2. In Frankfurt, the DAX 30-share index closed 5.09 points lower, at 2,155.28. And the CAC 40-share index in Paris fell 25.24 points, to 2,038.93.
Italian Government bond prices tumbled today, pushing the yield on the benchmark 10-year bond as high as 10.38 percent, from 9.74 percent yesterday. The Italian lira fell to a record low of 1,018 lire to the German mark today. It was last quoted at 1,014.09 lire, weaker than 1,006.06 lire on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: At Woodstock '94, Will the Odds Let the Big Bucks Roll This Time?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
A quarter-century ago, a half-million baby boomers gathered on a farm in Bethel, N.Y., to enjoy three days of sex, drugs and rock-and-roll -- and the promoters lost their shirts. As many as 250,000 twenty-somethings are expected to be in Saugerties, N.Y., this weekend to celebrate the anniversary. Only this time the three impresarios who staged the original Woodstock and have returned to produce Woodstock '94 seem to stand little chance of losing money and an excellent chance of making millions.
That prospect has left some news commentators grumpy. But the promoters fiercely defend their American right to do well by doing good. 
 Nobody planned to run a charity event back in 1969, Michael Lang, 49, one of the three, recalls. The idea was to sell a lot of tickets for $18 each, put on a good show and then use the profits to build a commercial recording studio. But the enterprise fell victim to the magic of the moment.
 
No Money for Fences
 Monterey Pop, an earlier music festival in California, drew 28,000, Mr. Lang said, "so we figured on a maximum of 50,000." When it became clear in the last weeks before the 1969 festival that far larger numbers were coming, the young entrepreneurs put their remaining cash into basics to accommodate the crowd. That left them no money to build fences or even to set up ticket booths for those willing to pay.
About $3.3 million was spent -- the bands and the contractors still had to be paid -- and just $1.7 million from initial ticket sales was collected. Mr. Lang's partners, Joel Rosenman, now 51, and John Roberts, now 49, lost $250,000 of their own money and owed the rest to a bank.
The partnership, Woodstock Ventures, eventually recouped its losses with a decade of record and movie royalties. But the memories still rankle: Warner, the distributor, ended up with most of the profit, which reportedly ran to tens of millions of dollars.
 
Older and Wiser
 This time, the promoters are older and wiser, and virtually everything is different, save for their determination to deliver value for a dollar.
The $30 million fixed cost of the project -- everything from the fees for the performers to water tanks with the capacity to serve a city -- has been underwritten by Polygram Diversified Ventures, which is 75 percent owned by Philips N.V., the Dutch giant. Cash and in-kind services of an unspecified value have come from Pepsico, Haagen-Dazs, Nobody Beats The Wiz, Gibson Guitars and Continental Airlines. And in an adjacent field where hippies might have staged a nude happening in 1969, Apple Computer and Philips have erected air-conditioned tents to demonstrate their latest electronic toys.
Much has been written, generally with distaste, about the miles of fencing, the metal detectors, the 1,200-strong security force and the absolute policy of admitting no more than 250,000 patrons at a whopping $135 a person. But little, Mr. Lang argues, has been said about the positive side of Woodstock '94's upscale, button-down approach.
He has a point. Barring food and drink from outside will sharply reduce the amount of broken glass strewn about -- the largest source of injury at Woodstock '69. And a mini-hospital, staffed around the clock with 300 medical people and backed up by three Medivac helicopters, will replace Wavy Gravy's makeshift effort at talking down acid-trippers.
 
A Ban on Alcohol
 Most significant, no alcoholic beverages will be sold or permitted on the 840-acre site. This will sharply undermine the profitability of the food concessions, Mr. Lang notes, but will also reduce the risk of violence.
All that said, will Woodstock Ventures and Polygram, equal partners in the enterprise, come out ahead?
Polygram is unwilling to talk about the finances of a project that Howard Vogel, a Merrill Lynch analyst, notes is "a relatively minor event from the company's long-term perspective." It is still possible, though, to piece together estimates that strongly suggest Woodstock '94 is the closest thing in the music business to a sure thing.
The widely cited cost estimate of $30 million -- four times the budget of Woodstock '69 after adjustments for inflation -- may seem high at first glance. But remember that music is big business now. Rolling Stone magazine estimates that top acts including Bob Dylan, Peter Gabriel and Arrested Development will receive $350,000 for their live performances, compared with just $15,000 last time around.
What about revenues? To date, more than 160,000 people have signed up for three days of peace and music. Even if that figure hits 200,000 by show time today, the box office would be $3 million short of break-even. Food services, with what some call ball-park prices, will surely gross many millions. But unlike most ball parks, Woodstock '94 will have very high one-time costs of preparation and cleanup, and there will be no beer to pad the margins. So it is at least conceivable that concessions will contribute little to the bottom line.
 
Ancillary Rights
 Hence, simple arithmetic suggests that Woodstock '94 could be in the red after the last ticket has been sold and the last slice of pizza is swallowed.
But the prospect of a deficit of a few million dollars on Monday need not faze the producers since a rich pot awaits them from ancillary rights.
Start with pay-per-view television. Access to one day's performance runs $35; two days, with a full 28 hours of coverage from 14 cameras, runs $50. "Three days out, sales are the highest I've ever seen for a concert," said Katherine Lewis, a vice president of Time Warner Cable, which is offering the pay-per-view telecasts in the New York City area.
Mr. Vogel estimates that 1.3 to 1.5 percent of the 22 million homes in the system will probably sign up. At that rate, at least 285,000 viewers will pay an average of $45, for a gross exceeding $12 million. Roughly half of that will be left after the distributors are paid. Some of the remaining amount will go to performers as royalties. And a minimum $3 million should end up on the producers' bottom line.
Next is the audio recording, due out in November. Mr. Vogel estimates the base sales of any album featuring this much brand-name talent and with this much publicity at 2 million copies, with much higher numbers possible. And while profits depend crucially on the unspecified terms of the royalty contracts with the performers, it is hard to believe that Polygram and Woodstock Ventures won't net a few dollars per recording.
 
The Movie Outlook
 Then there is the movie. There is no guarantee this film will do as well as its blockbuster namesake. But Woodstock '94 does start with a variety of advantages.
The director, Barbara Koppel, is an Academy Award winner in documentary film. The break-even point is low since the performers will receive percentage royalties rather than up-front fees. Most important, perhaps, is that this Woodstock movie is to be widely distributed on home video.
Last but hardly least there is the market for the logo, the outline of a bird sitting on a guitar. Unlike earlier sales promotions, says one relieved insider, "there will be no Woodstock underwear or air-freshener." But those are about the only products to be excluded. Along with the expected T-shirts, sweats and posters, the promoters have licensed an official Woodstock '94 condom.

Unlike the promoters 25 years ago, they stand little chance of losing money and may well make millions. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE SENATE;
Centrist Group Is Seeking Consensus on Health Care

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
A bipartisan group of senators, more concerned about cost controls and bureaucracy than about the loudly debated topics of universal coverage or employer mandates, met for nearly three hours tonight to try to clear a path to consensus in the health care debate.
The centrist group, which calls itself the "mainstream coalition," had a major role in the Senate Finance Committee debate several weeks ago, but has been in partial eclipse ever since. 
 But its Republicans are the most conciliatory voices in this week's Senate debate, and the Democratic allies of Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, are eager to deal with them. These Democrats hope that some changes in Mr. Mitchell's bill could win their support, especially since the moderate Republicans' main concern does not appear to be the universal coverage provisions which President Clinton has said cannot be weakened.
 
Back to Basics
 The coalition itself is not sure whom it wants to deal with, and how. So today, several members said after the meeting, they went back to basics and began discussing what an acceptable health insurance bill should contain, not how to achieve it.
Senator John H. Chafee, a Rhode Island Republican, said the group planned to stay in touch with both Mr. Mitchell and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, whose bill it also finds unsatisfactory in terms of cost controls. "The ideal objective would be to have everybody aboard," Mr. Chafee said tonight. "But maybe I'm dreaming."
 
One of Its Largest Crowds
 In a reflection of the Senate's uncertainty about the battle lines of health care legislation, the mainstream group attracted one of its largest crowds ever to today's meeting. There were 14 senators present, 7 Republicans and 7 Democrats.
The Republicans ranged from Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, the only member of his party to support President Clinton's original bill, to Senator Slade Gorton of Washington, who is quite conservative. Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey may have been the most liberal Democrat there today, and Senator David Boren of Oklahoma the most conservative.
The senators were unwilling to discuss the substance of their discussion today, which they conducted with only a single staff member present. Mr. Chafee said they were "going over some of the hot button issues" of health care to see where they stood.
Senator David Durenberger of Minnesota said the group's thinking was "rather than sit around and complain about other people's work, let's revisit our own." But he added, "Nobody knows how many votes there are for anything."
 
Amendments and Rewrites
 The obvious tactical alternatives before the group are to try to amend the Mitchell bill; amend the proposal put forward by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader; orassemble an entire bill from scratch. Since the group lacks the sort of staffs whom committee chairmen or leaders command, the last option is perhaps the most difficult.
Senator Mitchell says his bill would cover 95 percent of Americans by 2000, mainly by offering Federal subsidies to help the poor buy insurance. Senator Dole's bill offers smaller subsidies and less coverage.
Since the Mitchell proposal is likely to be before the Senate and open to amendment on Friday, amending it may be the simplest device. Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, predicted after leaving today's meeting that "the mainstream group is going to work with Mitchell," by offering amendments to reduce bureaucracy and "taking away the argument that this is a government takeover."
Mr. Chafee said the group expected to meet again Friday morning and to be able to announce its position later in the day.
 
Attack by Gramm
 Otherwise, today's Senate debate produced more heat and squabbling than progress. Senator Phil Gramm, a Texas Republican, led off for his party, assailing the Mitchell bill, saying it would fail because "the government domination approach wil not work."
Senator Robert Bennett, Republican of Utah, called for delay, saying the American people wanted action postponed. Senator Boren took the same tack, saying: "Let's stop this train. Let's stop this mistake."
But Senator Harris Wofford, a Pennsylvania Democrat, who won election to the Senate in 1991 in a campaign in which he emphasized health care problems, shot back that "health care delayed is health care denied."
And Senator Barbara Boxer, a California Democrat, challenged Republicans who disliked the bill to propose changes. "To delay would be cowardly," she said. "To filibuster would be cowardly."
 
Moynihan Has Changes
 Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who heads the Finance Committee and has been managing the Democratic speakers, again attacked the Mitchell bill over its provisions for medical training, a sore point for New York's many teaching hospitals. Mr. Moynihan has already succeeded in removing precise limits from the Mitchell bill, but it still calls for overall reductions in the number of residencies in hospitals and aims to have 55 percent of medical graduates work in primary care rather than specialties.
"In my judgment," Mr. Moynihan said, "it would be an act of hubris for the United States Senate to presume to know what the course of medical science will be, let alone to try to dictate that course through regulatory controls."
Supporters of limits like those he decried argue that a surplus of specialists is a major cause of health care inflation, as more specialists simply perform more procedures, often unnecessarily. Mr. Moynihan said later that there was merit to that argument, but that other means than an arbitrary limit on residencies should be found to deal with that problem.
Senator Frank Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, announced today that he would support Mr. Mitchell's bill.
 
'In Our Country Every Day'
 "No family should be forced to choose between putting food on the table and taking care of their children's health." he said in a statement issued today. "Or chose between helping with a college education and health care. Or jeopardizing their own retirement to take care of a parent stricken with Alzheimer's disease. But that happens in New Jersey and our country every day."
Mr. Mitchell's bill, he said "does promise to extend quality health care to our people at affordable prices, whether they work for a large corporation, a small company, or are self-employed."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Drop On Rate Speculation

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday, after two Government economic reports increased speculation that the Federal Reserve was ready to raise interest rates again.
Investors also reacted negatively to the higher-than-expected average yield at the Treasury's auction of the new 30 1/4-year bond, the last leg of the Treasury's quarterly refunding. The average yield at the auction of the new bond was 7.56 percent, the highest since November 1992 when the yield was 7.66 percent. 
 The market could be in for more selling today if the Consumer Price Index for July turns out to increase more than expected.
In trading in the secondary market, the outstanding 6 1/4 percent 30-year bond fell as much as 15/32 percentage points just before the results of the auction were released, but recouped at the close of the New York market to finish down 29/32 at 8325/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, jumped to 7.65 percent -- its highest point since July 13 -- from 7.57 percent on Wednesday.
 
 
Producer Prices
 Yesterday, the Labor Department reported that the Producer Price Index for July rose by five-tenths of 1 percent, largely as a result of a 42.8 percent increase in coffee prices, while the core rate, excluding food and energy, rose a muted one-tenth of 1 percent. The Commerce Department said that retail sales dropped one-tenth of 1 percent in July.
In the face of today's consumer price report and next week's meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy making committee, "there is a lot of nervousness in the market," said Mr. Charles Roden, a managing director and head of fixed-income investing for Josepthal, Lyon & Ross. "Trading is very thin and every move in prices is magnified."
Mr. Roden added: "The surprise at this point of the game would be if the Fed did nothing. And while many long-term investors are worried about the economy, it is the long end of market that has held up well relative to short end."
Before the auction results were announced, traders and investors had been expecting the average yield in the auction to be 7.55 percent. The 30 1/4-year bond will be issued Aug. 15 and will mature on Nov. 15, 2024.
 
 
Zero-Coupon Bonds
 Last year, the Treasury decided to sell bonds twice a year instead of quarterly, and borrow more money at shorter maturities. Officials chose a 30 1/4-year bond at this quarterly refunding, instead of the regular 30-year bond, to spread out the interest rate payments on the bonds. Some economists have noted that an odd-dated maturity helps the market for zero-coupon bonds.
Unless the Treasury sold an odd-dated bond, securities firms would not be able to meet demand for zero-coupon bonds with a May or November maturity date, the months dropped from the quarter financing schedule last year.
Yesterday, the Treasury also sold $7 billion of 38-day cash management bills at an average rate of 4.37 percent. The cash management bills are used to meet short-term borrowing needs beyond the cash raised through securities sold at the Government's regularly scheduled auctions.
In the corporate market, the Money Store Inc. sold $600 million in triple-A-rated asset-backed securities through a trust. The securities, which are backed by home equity loans, were divided into several parts and priced through Prudential Securities and CS First Boston.
The average life for the issue ranged from one year to 15.3 years and was priced to yield from from 6.332 percent to 8.491 percent. Underwriters said the yield spread over Treasury securities with similar maturities was from 68 basis points to as much as 120 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
One of the parts offered to investors consisted of floating-rate securities with an average life of 4.6 years that were priced at par to float 45 basis above the one-month London interbank offered rate.

HEADLINE: Attention Shoppers: Internet Is Open

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
At noon yesterday, Phil Brandenberger of Philadelphia went shopping for a compact audio disk, paid for it with his credit card and made history.
Moments later, the champagne corks were popping in a small two-story frame house in Nashua, N.H. There, a team of young cyberspace entrepreneurs celebrated what was apparently the first retail transaction on the Internet using a readily available version of powerful data encryption software designed to guarantee privacy. 
 Experts have long seen such iron-clad security as a necessary first step before commercial transactions can become common on the Internet, the global computer network.
From his work station in Philadelphia, Mr. Brandenburger logged onto the computer in Nashua, and used a secret code to send his Visa credit card number to pay $12.48, plus shipping costs, for the compact disk "Ten Summoners' Tales" by the rock musician Sting.
"Even if the N.S.A. was listening in, they couldn't get his credit card number," said Daniel M. Kohn, the 21-year-old chief executive of the Net Market Company of Nashua, N.H., a new venture that is the equivalent of a shopping mall in cyberspace. Mr. Kohn was referring to the National Security Agency, the arm of the Pentagon that develops and breaks the complex algorithms that are used to keep the most secret electronic secrets secret.
Even bigger organizations working on rival systems yesterday called the achievement by the tiny Net Market a welcome first step.
"It's really clear that most companies want the security prior to doing major commitments to significant electronic commerce on the Internet," said Cathy Medich, executive director of Commercenet, a Government and industry organization based in Menlo Park, Calif., that hopes to establish standards for commercial transactions on the Internet and other networks.
The idea is to make such data communications immune to wiretaps, electronic eavesdropping and theft by scrambling the transmissions with a secret code -- a security technique known as data encryption.
While Commercenet and other organizations have been working to develop a standard for the automated data encryption of commercial transactions, the small band of recent college graduates who formed the Net Market Company in New Hampshire appear to be the first to implement such technology successfully.
Tests of Commercenet's encryption system, which is based on algorithms -- mathematical formulas -- developed by RSA Data Security Inc. of Redwood City, Calif., are expected to begin this fall.
Commercenet hopes to create an easy-to-use industry standard for protecting Internet transactions.
For now, Net Market's approach is available to the limited number of computer users who have work stations running the Unix software operating system and a sophisticated Internet navigational program called X-Mosaic. The data encryption program is called PGP, for Pretty Good Privacy, which is based on the same RSA algorithms used by Commercenet.
PGP is available free, but it requires technical expertise to download it from the Internet. But within a few months commercial versions of PGP are expected to be available for personal computers using the Windows and Macintosh operating systems, which comprise the vast majority of computers in North America.
 
Security Breaches Reported
 The widespread adoption of standard data encryption tools cannot come too quickly for many Internet entrepreneurs, who hope to foster new levels of commerce on the rapidly growing network.
Alarmed by increasing reports of security breaches on the Internet, many people and businesses are reluctant to transmit sensitive information, including credit cards numbers, sales information or private electronic mail messages, on the network.
But the use of standard data encryption software, which scrambles messages so they can be read only by someone with the proper software "key," has been hindered by a combination of Government regulations and software patent disputes.
Experts say the PGP encryption software used by Net Market is at least as robust as the so-called Clipper encryption technology that the Clinton Administration has been pushing as a national standard. But unlike the Clipper system, the software keys for opening and reading PGP-encrypted documents is not controlled by the Government.
A version of PGP for individuals is available free through the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, but users must retrieve it from an M.I.T. computer through the Internet.
Organizations wanting to use PGP for commercial purposes must obtain it on the Internet from a company in Phoenix called Viacrypt, a maker of computer security software and hardware tools. Prices for PGP begin at $100 a copy.
 
A Browsing Feature
 One achievement of the young programmers at Net Market was to incorporate PGP into X-Mosaic, the software that many Internet users rely on for browsing through the global network.
X-Mosaic is a software tool that allows the users of Unix computers to browse a service of the Internet called the World Wide Web, where companies can post the electronic equivalent of a glossy color brochure with supporting sales or marketing documents.
In the case of Noteworthy Music, the record retailer that leases a "store front" in Net Market's Internet computer, a shopper can look at color pictures of CD album covers.
Mr. Kohn, a 1994 honors graduate in economics from Swarthmore College, came up with the idea for Net Market during his junior year abroad, at the London School of Economics. There, he persuaded an American classmate, Roger Lee, to join his venture.
Mr. Lee, who graduated from Yale this past spring with a degree in political science, is president of the company. For technical expertise, they recruited two other partners from Swarthmore, Guy H. T. Haskin and Eiji Hirai.
The four men live upstairs in the house in Nashua, commuting downstairs each morning to run the business. Because of the pressures of running the system and debugging the software, they rarely venture outside, even though they have a backyard swimming pool.
"We don't get much sun," Mr. Kohn said, "but we're down to a case of Coke a day."
 
'An Important Step'
 Although Net Market has been selling various products like CD's, flowers and books for several months on behalf of various merchants, yesterday was the first time they had offered digitally secure transactions.
"I think it's an important step in pioneering this work, but later on we'll probably see more exciting things in the way of digital cash," said Philip R. Zimmermann, a computer security consultant in Boulder, Colo., who created the PGP program.
Digital cash, Mr. Zimmermann explained, is "a combination of cryptographic protocols that behave the way real dollars behave but are untraceable."
In other words, they are packets of worth that have value in cyberspace, the same way dollars have value in the real world, except that they have the properties of anonymity, privacy and untraceability. Many details remain to be worked out, Mr. Zimmermann said.
For now, Mr. Brandenberger, despite his historic transaction yesterday, will be paying with plain old dollars, when he gets his credit card bill. And sometime today, the Sting CD will arrive by fairly conventional means -- shipped FedEx from the Noteworthy Music warehouse in Nashua.

HEADLINE: At the Bar;
When this lawyer for New York City recounts La Guardia stories, she means her old boss.

BYLINE: By Richard Perez-Pena 

 BODY:
At a reception for the newest of New York's corporation counsels earlier this year, Edith I. Spivack was asked to say a few words about several of her former bosses in the New York City Law Department. When she got to Victor A. Kovner, who was corporation counsel in 1990 and 1991, she said she had been around to celebrate his bris.
She wasn't joking. When Mr. Kovner was born in 1937, Ms. Spivack was a lawyer in the Law Department and attended his brith milah, or bris, the religious rite of circumcision on the eighth day after birth. 
 Today, at age 84, Ms. Spivack is still there, as the Executive Assistant Corporation Counsel, one of the agency's half-dozen highest positions. For members of the calculator crowd, that means she has been on the city payroll for 60 years, a record for the Law Department, possibly for the city.
There is a temptation to call Ms. Spivack, who has worked for nine mayors and 21 corporation counsels, an institution. In a career that has spanned much legal and political history and has brought her into contact with some noteworthy characters, she has shown remarkable tenacity and a knack for defying expectations. But institutions are often sluggish creatures, and sluggishness doesn't suit Ms. Spivack at all.
She scampers through stories, peppering breakneck speed narratives with asides -- "Do you know about the Seabury investigations?" -- to insure that younger listeners can keep up. A few of her tales are ribald, like the one about Mayor Fiorello H. LaGuardia dispatching her and other women in his administration to determine whether a burlesque show had artistic merit. (Their verdict: smut). Others are harrowing, as when, at age 75, her back was broken in a car accident in Albany, where she had gone to argue a case.
She also has stories that sound medieval to contemporary ears, about the days when few women practiced law, let alone while raising children, and fewer still declined to take their husbands' names.
She had a moment of fame in 1980, in a showdown in her office with the Colombian consul. The cash-starved city had begun charging consulates for water, and Colombia had refused. Ms. Spivack threatened to turn off the tap; the consul capitulated.
Her career is notable not only for its longevity but also for the law she has practiced. Her colleagues attest that she has unparalleled expertise on property taxes, her specialty since 1944.
"She has participated in virtually every piece of legislation, every major case in this area, and generations of lawyers in that office have learned the subject from her," Mr. Kovner said.
In the early 1970's she represented the city in the Penn Central bankruptcy, collecting $93 million in delinquent taxes and interest on the railroad's Park Avenue real estate. A few years later, she helped negotiate the $2.3 billion Federal loan that staved off city bankruptcy.
Allen G. Schwartz said Ms. Spivack defused the first crisis he confronted as corporation counsel in 1978. The city faced $2 billion in refund claims under a Court of Appeals ruling against its property tax structure. "She negotiated settlements with all these property owners so that the city wouldn't be bankrupted," Mr. Schwartz said.
Ms. Spivack grew up in the Western Bronx and on the Upper West Side, graduating from Barnard College in 1929 at age 19. Though her parents were not well off -- she had been able to attend college only through a Regents scholarship -- she went on to Columbia Law School; it was only the third year in which women were accepted.
"My father's friends would say to him, 'Why does she have to go to law school? She's probably going to get married,' " Ms. Spivack recalled. "But my mother said, 'If Edith wants it, she can have it.' "
She graduated in 1932, at the nadir of the Depression, but met greater obstacles than the feeble economy. Most firms she approached told her that they did not hire women, while many would not take her because she was Jewish. A few, she said, kept their women lawyers in trusts and estates, "where all the clients were dead and no one would see you."
In December 1933, she married Bernard H. Goldstein, whom she had met at Columbia. At age 87, he, too, still practices law, as a partner at Tenzer, Greenblatt, Fallon & Kaplan in Manhattan. In tribute to her parents, Ms. Spivack kept her family name.
When LaGuardia took office in 1934, political appointees were swept from the Law Department and replaced through civil service testing. Told that the city had no money to pay her, Ms. Spivack joined the department as a volunteer. She was hired in July, at half salary -- $1,700 a year.
When her two daughters were born, in 1941 and 1946, her maternity leaves consisted of hoarded sick days and vacation. Each time, her return to work was met with surprise from colleagues. Still, she said, she was treated with respect and never suffered sexual harassment. "I know that other women had to put up with that, but I never did," she said, crediting her good fortune to the honorable bent of the men with whom she worked.
One of the first city employees to take advantage of the elimination of mandatory retirement in the early 1980's, Ms. Spivack says she has never seriously entertained the notion of retiring. She still takes the 6:20 A.M. train every day from Port Washington, L.I., and more often than not she is the first person in the office on Church Street.
Her pension has grown so large, she says, that she would make more money collecting it than collecting paychecks -- one reason, she concedes, that some of her co-workers think she's "a little nuts" for continuing to work.
But then she insists, "One of the things that I don't get terribly concerned about most of the time is what other people think."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edith I. Spivack has collected property taxes, penalties and notoriety in her 60-year career. (Steve Hart for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A young American agency turns to a British import to raise its creative pitch.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
A LEADING British creative director is joining Berlin Wright Cameron as the agency, nearing its first anniversary, seeks to emphasize further its creative capabilities.
Jon Matthews, a copywriter who has helped to produce popular and successful campaigns at BMP DDB Needham in London for accounts like the Barclaycard credit card and Clarks children's shoes, is coming to Berlin Wright in New York in the new position of creative director. Scott Burns, a partner in the agency, continues as executive creative director. 
 "I got a telephone call from a headhunter in London asking if I could recommend someone for this job," Mr. Matthews said in an interview, "and I said, 'Apart from me?' "
"I've always thought about the U.S.," he added, "because I've always been a great admirer of the best of the U.S. work."
When Mr. Matthews, 35, arrives at Berlin Wright early next month, he will join a lengthening list of British advertising talent migrating to the United States. Indeed, at the agency, which has billings of $150 million to $175 million from clients like Volkswagen of America, NBA Properties, Conde Nast Publications and the G.E. Rewards credit card, he is the fourth bundle from Britain. The others are Tony Wright, president and partner; Ewen Cameron, planning director and partner, and Alison Butler, head of client services.
"Sometimes, when we go to new business meetings," Mr. Wright said, "and Ewen and I are presenting, we say, 'We do have some Americans back at the agency.' "
Yet Andy Berlin, chairman and chief executive, insists that his agency, which opened almost a year ago as a spinoff from DDB Needham New York, is no Madison Avenue chapter of the Anglo-American Amity League.
"One problem with American advertising is that I don't think it's attracting the caliber of people it did 15 or 20 years ago," he said. "The British industry, at least until the recession, certainly had been attracting those people."
His penchant for British staff members, he added, also reflects an admiration for BMP DDB Needham, which he considers "one of three great models" along with BBDO Worldwide and the Leo Burnett Company. Of Berlin Wright's British quartet, all but Mr. Wright worked for BMP DDB Needham.
British executives plying their trade in this country have met with mixed results. For instance, of two recently imported to work for Bates Worldwide in New York, one, Les Stern, has already returned to London, while the second, Andrew Cracknell, is relinquishing his oversight of the New York office's creative output to take on more of a worldwide role. Campaign, the British advertising trade weekly, described those shifts as "bringing down the curtain on what has been a less than successful experiment at rejuvenating the U.S. shop with British talent."
Mr. Wright said the difficulties British executives face may stem from "the culture of the advertising industry being very different here than there, much older and much more serious."
"To be in advertising in Britain is a complete life style," he added. "You go to the pub at six o'clock with everyone you work with and you see everyone else you know."
Mr. Burns likened it to "a great big Martin Amis novel."
To Mr. Matthews, the cultural differences between the two countries "are not that big."
"We watch the same movies," he said, "only we get them three months later." One that filmgoers of both nations enjoyed was the British comedy "Four Weddings and a Funeral," which features as a malaprop-prone clergyman the actor Rowan Atkinson, who portrays an inept spy in Mr. Matthews's Barclaycard campaign.
Mr. Matthews began his career in 1981 as a client, working for Unilever on washing powders -- detergents on this side of the Atlantic -- and soaps. He switched to the agency side four years later after he had what he described as "a real 'road to Damascus' experience: I was asked to write this campaign for mayonnaise and had the most fun in my life."
He worked at the London offices of J. Walter Thompson, Gold Greenlees Trott and Collett Dickenson Pearce before joining BMP DDB Needham in 1990.
Mr. Wright called the hiring of Mr. Matthews "another phase of our development."
"We really want to put our investment in people who create ads," he said. "It's a lopsided investment in the creative department -- lopsided by industry standards."
Mr. Matthews, in addition to writing, will assume administrative duties from Mr. Burns, who has been supervising the 30 members of Berlin Wright's creative department while handling his own writing assignments. Mr. Matthews will report to Mr. Burns.
"They're a talented group of young children," Mr. Burns, who is 32, said of his charges, laughing, "but they need care and supervision and watering. I like to write."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Some Wonder if This Is When Cheering Stops By Claire Smith

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
In a game that supplies an endless amount of irony in its laborious collective bargaining wars, one of the more intriguing situations unfolded at Veterans Stadium last night.
Fernando Valenzuela, who as a rookie injected the one iota of innocence into the strike-ravaged 1981 season, took the mound for the Phillies in what could be his swan song as a major league pitcher. 
 Valenzuela is now, of course, a grizzled veteran of who knows how many years of age (that has always been one of baseball's bigger mysteries). But in 1981, Valenzuela represented youth, enthusiasm and a touch of idealism in a game that dripped with cynicism by the end of a 50-day strike.
Valenzuela, a darling of the fans before the strike, was still that when the walkout ended officially with a much-delayed All-Star Game in Cleveland, the beginning of a truncated second half of the season. Just about every other All-Star had used up his allotment of good will during the strike, as far as a booing, angry crowd at Cleveland Stadium was concerned. But not Valenzuela, a youngster with little command of the English language but in obvious command of any kind of sentiments that survived the off-field strife.
Now, 13 years later, another strike that could wreck the major part of a season is at hand. And Valenzuela was called on to start one of the final 10 games scheduled before the clock stopped where the players warned it would if the owners insisted on pushing for a salary cap. "Yes, yes," Valenzuela said with a smile when reminded that this was where he kind of came into the game -- in the middle of a labor fracas.
Then he went out and gave another crowd yet more reason to cheer in an otherwise grim situation, pitching eight innings of one-run ball in a game the Phillies won, 2-1, in 15 innings.
The 37,605 fans who filed into Veterans Stadium were cordial as the two teams turned in professional efforts. But, as the players know, the fans of '94 feel much like the fans of '81 about work stoppages. The public didn't commiserate 13 years ago when players had to work temporary jobs to avoid going penniless. They certainly won't be any more sympathetic in an era of million-dollar-a-year-plus averages.
Believe it or not, the players of 1994 understand that anger, just as the players in 1981 did. "You're never going to win that battle," said Pete Incaviglia of the Phillies. "The players are obviously the ones who are going to be torn up, in the media, by the fans. That's just a part of the game."
Rusty Staub, an announcer for the Mets, the club for which he played in 1981, agreed. He said he fully understood the reason behind the fans' targeting. "I feel a real attachment to the emotion that fans have," he said. "It's very difficult for them to comprehend when they see the money that's in the game. But it's not just about money. It's more about power and who's going to have the power, who's going to have the authority."
Players like himself risked their livelihoods, if you will, in 1981. Because there was no guarantee that the owners wouldn't turn to replacement players, as the National Football League owners did a few years later. There was no guarantee that the fans, whose money accounted for much of the economic base, would, indeed, come back.
The treacherous nature of that strike, as well as the one in 1985 and the lockout of 1990, has not only been drilled into the players who have arrived since then but is still very fresh in the minds of ex-players like Staub and veterans like Incaviglia. And, undoubtedly, Valenzuela, who went from being a $32,500 minimum-wage rookie to being a millionaire many times over.
So it's not surprising, and quite understandable, when a Staub says, "To just give it back, in the form of a salary cap, I just don't think it's going to happen."
And so it is that players with much more than money at stake are supporting their union. Players like Valenzuela, Don Mattingly and Larry Andersen, all of whom know that a prolonged strike could sound a death knell for their careers.
"If it is the end for me, it's not really the way I'd want to go out," said Andersen, a pitcher in his third decade in the major leagues. "But if the strike ends my career, I correlate that with the guys who are chasing records -- so be it."
Many people will never understand that sentiment. Never understand why the Matt Williams, Ken Griffeys, Frank Thomases and other record-chasers fully echo those sentiments. Why a Mattingly, on the brink of his first-ever post-season does, too. It's a unity, Incaviglia says, that helps fuel the cause when it is needed the most. Like now, when the players stand very much alone against public sentiment.
And since the players feed off the single-mindedness of veterans and rookies, of $7 million-a-year players and minimum-wagers, another strike to test the will of owners has occurred.
Now fans have only to wait and stew. And players and owners have only to pray that when they settle this mess, they will come back to parks like Veterans Stadium and find a modicum of forgiveness.
If the two sides do return the game to the field soon, veterans like Valenzuela, Mattingly and Andersen will get to breathe some more life into their careers. And 1994's versions of the young Fernando, like Jason Jacome, the Mets' rookie starter who pitched seven innings of one-run ball last night?
If today's rookies are lucky, like Valenzuela once was, they may yet hear the cheering again. Just like the players eventually did in 1981 when, as Rusty Staub says, "the fans put the anger aside when the saw their first great play or somebody got their first big hit to help their ball club win a game."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Steinbrenner Trying to Make 'Economic Sense' of It All

BYLINE: By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
George Steinbrenner, whose profitable baseball operation stands to be one of the biggest losers from a prolonged strike, admitted yesterday that he has a problem with his fellow owners arguing for competitive balance.
But the Yankee owner claims he has not broken ranks, that he will remain a good soldier and that he plans on supporting his peers throughout negotiations, regardless of how the owners are being represented. 
 He declined comment when asked in an interview during yesterday's game whether by taking this stance he was giving the owners' chief negotiator, Richard Ravitch, a vote of confidence. Instead, he preferred to shower baseball's acting commissioner, Bud Selig, with praise.
Steinbrenner especially took issue with one of the owners' main selling points in negotiations, that of smaller-market clubs being financed by larger-market teams and how revenue sharing would hurt the game.
"It's very difficult for Ravitch to argue competitive balance, per se, when Montreal, with the second-lowest payroll, has baseball's best record," Steinbrenner said. "Maybe they just don't support baseball in Montreal. In that context, it's like any good business. Year after year if your store doesn't get the customers, you move it or you close it."
Steinbrenner said he doesn't consider the Expos "truly a small-market club."
 
Helping the Small-Market Teams
 "If anyone deserves the fans' support," he said, "it's Montreal. But we still have to bring some economic sense to baseball. We need to bring sense whereby the Pittsburghs and Milwaukees can survive. We never want what happened to Pittsburgh again, where they lost their players.
"We have to find a way to help those teams."
With the Yankees in first place this late in the season for the first time since 1987 and possibly headed for the post-season for the first time since 1981, Steinbrenner separated his emotions for his club from labor-management matters.
"That would be very selfish and shortsighted on my part," he said of the prospect of missing out on the post-season. "There's a lot of things about the whole picture I don't like. But if you look at the long haul, we've got to do something."
 
Feeling for Mattingly
 Regarding Don Mattingly's possible retirement should the strike pre-empt part of next season, he said: "I think that was in the heat of frustration. I wouldn't compare it to George Foreman saying he's going to retire, but I think he's too competitive to give back a year on his contract. He wants to play.
"My heart bleeds for the guy. Here he is, after all these years, and now this."
Steinbrenner also reiterated his stance concerning owners being present at the bargaining table.
Then, when asked why he has not been more vocal among the ownership group, he said: "Bud Selig is leading this ship. I've got enough on my plate. I'm tired of the harpooning and hits he's taking.
"My interests are being represented. I do not intend to show any split in this group."

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The Hidden Horror

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Even in a world with Rwanda and Bosnia, the cruelty at this place has been horrifying: an invasion by a foreign army that has killed as much as a third of the population.
The place is East Timor, the killers the Government and army of Indonesia. East Timor is half of an island 300 miles north of Australia, so remote that Indonesia has been largely successful in hiding from the world the slaughter and repression it has carried out since occupying the territory in 1975. 
 The shroud covering the occupation was pierced in 1991, when Indonesian soldiers fired into a crowd of mourners at a cemetery, killing more than 100. An American was there and wrote about the massacre, and a Briton filmed parts of it.
Now we have powerful new evidence of the horror in East Timor. John Pilger, an Australian reporter, and two others went in incognito and used hidden cameras. British Independent Television has shown their film, "Death of a Nation: The Timor Conspiracy."
The film includes firsthand descriptions, ghastly in their detail, of the mass killing of Timorese civilians. It also has much new material on the role of Britain, Australia and the United States in aiding Indonesia and condoning the invasion.
President Ford and Secretary of State Kissinger visited Indonesia for several days just before the invasion. Philip Liechty, a C.I.A. official there at the time, says in the film that he is sure President Suharto "was explicitly given the green light to do what he did."
Mr. Liechty says that most of the weapons used by Indonesia, as well as ammunition and even food, were American. Aides cabled Secretary Kissinger that such use of materiel supplied for "defense" would violate American law. He excoriated them for putting the point in writing, saying that it might leak and embarrass him.
The Pilger film quotes Mr. Kissinger as telling a staff meeting: "Can't we construe a Communist Government in the middle of Indonesia as self-defense?" The Timorese, 90 percent of them Roman Catholics, had shown no sympathy for Communism. They just wanted independence for their country.
Today, nearly 20 years after the invasion, the Suharto Government continues to make strenuous efforts to prevent international discussion of East Timor. It put pressure on the Philippine Government to limit a conference on the subject in May and is now trying to stop a meeting in Malaysia.
But more evidence of continuing repression is emerging. Some of it comes from Western journalists who have been allowed into East Timor this year on tours that were carefully controlled but that nevertheless let reality slip through from time to time.
The Economist magazine had a writer there with others on a guided tour in April. He wrote that they were treated to robotic praise of Indonesia but that discontent was evident. The Indonesian-appointed Governor, Abilio Soares, admitted to them that between 100,000 and 200,000 Timorese had died as a result of conflict since the invasion. Before, the population was 688,000.
A conservative British weekly, The Spectator, had a piece in February by Edward Theberton. On a visit to East Timor he found it reminiscent of the Baltic States when they were under Soviet occupation, full of soldiers and informers and lies. The striking sights, he said, were the countless cemeteries. He concluded that President Suharto was "the Pol Pot of East Timor."
The world is said to be suffering from compassion fatigue these days. A place as small and distant as East Timor is going to have a hard time persuading major governments to support its people's desire, simple as it is, for the right to express their views in a referendum on how they should be governed.
But President Clinton will have an opportunity to say a private word to President Suharto this fall, when he is scheduled to go to Indonesia for a summit meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. He could at least make clear American disapproval of the repression in East Timor.
And the press should continue to bring the world's attention to the reality of East Timor. In that regard it is shameful that "Death of a Nation," which has been seen in Britain and 35 other countries, has not yet found an outlet on American television.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
No Runs, No Hits, No Errors: Baseball Goes on Strike

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
With the two sides in baseball's labor dispute far apart and rigid in their positions, major league players went on strike after last night's games, shutting down the season with the eighth work stoppage in 23 seasons.
The dispute, centering on the owners' demand to create cost control by putting a limit on player payrolls, was so severe that negotiators for the two sides didn't even bother to meet and barely spoke to each other yesterday. 
 There were early reports, later denied, that some owners had made suggestions intended to generate movement on their side. Barring a change in the owners' position, which has occurred in previous shutdowns, or a collapse of the players' solidarity, which never has happened, the strike threatens to wipe out the last 52 days and 668 games of the regular season and, for the first time, the playoffs and the World Series.
Baseball's labor history since the inception of the union in 1966 is filled with strife. The owners have locked out the players three times, all in spring training, while this is the players' fifth strike. The longest strike occurred in 1981, when the players shut down the major leagues for 50 days. The most recent strike, in 1985, lasted only two days, Aug. 6 and 7.
"There is no doubt in my mind the players are united, as always, and the owners are united this time for a significant series of reasons," Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, said. "But having said that, now we have to figure a way to solve this thing."
No one had a clue how to do that yesterday, as the 10 games on the schedule slipped past and brought the players closer to their strike deadline.
The Yankees, who last week assured themselves of being in first place in the American League East at the time of the strike, played at Yankee Stadium yesterday, losing to the Toronto Blue Jays, 8-7, in 13 innings. When Selig, during a telephone interview, asked who won the game, he was told the teams were in extra innings and extending the season. He laughed, but people on both sides found little else humorous during the final day.
The Mets approached the strike with a 15-inning 2-1 loss at Philadelphia last night. The game at Oakland between the Athletics and the Seattle Mariners, which ended at 12:45 A.M. E.D.T., might have been the last in a season of remarkable individual performances, including Tony Gwynn's pursuit of a .400 batting average (he's hitting .394) and a core of sluggers chasing home-run records.
If the dispute were to be resolved in time only to play the post-season, the new expanded playoffs would start with Montreal at Los Angeles and Cincinnati at wild-card Atlanta in the National League and in the American League the Yankees at wild-card Cleveland and the Chicago White Sox at Texas.
Off the field, some owners, including George Steinbrenner of the Yankees, spoke out in ways that the union interpreted as hopeful, and reports circulated that some were trying to maneuver behind the scenes if not to avert a strike at least to create some movement that could lead to a settlement in time to salvage the season.
But Selig, the Milwaukee Brewers owner who earlier had presided over a conference-call meeting of the owners' executive council, denied that the owners had any intention of budging from their position on limiting player payrolls through a salary cap. The executive council runs baseball in the absence of a commissioner.
The players, who want to maintain the existing free-market system, are striking because they are certain the owners would imposed their salary cap in the off season after declaring and impasse in negotiations.
The most intriguing maneuver mentioned during the day was a reported effort by an unidentified group of owners to come up with a way of averting the strike. The group, meeting by telephone conference call Wednesday evening, was said to have considered proposing that the union agree to eliminate salary arbitration in exchange for the owners' granting free agency to players after three years of major league service, instead of the current six years, with no restrictions.
But the group also was said to have rejected the idea in the face of loud objections from some of the small-market clubs, which want greater sharing of revenues like local television deals and gate receipts. The owners adopted a revenue-sharing plan last January, but it is contingent on the players' acceptance of a salary cap.
 
'Little Bit of Movement'
 Peter Angelos, owner of the Baltimore Orioles, said he had heard talk of the swap of salary arbitration for earlier, unrestricted free agency. "I think there's a little bit of movement," he said by telephone from Baltimore, "but I don't know where it's coming from."
Jerry McMorris of the financially successful Colorado Rockies went even further. Speaking in Denver, he said he believed the salary cap was a negotiable issue. "I think we could negotiate a settlement that did not include a salary cap," he said.
One owner who wanted to avert a strike indicated last week there weren't enough owners to force a change in the salary-cap stance. "If there were, it would've been done, but it wasn't," he said.
People on the players' side who heard of the owners' conference call said they believed there was a perception by Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, that some owners wanted to try to get a settlement and he killed the effort. Ravitch did not return a telephone call seeking comment on the union's understanding of those events.
Ravitch and Donald Fehr, the union chief, appeared together on the "Today" show yesterday morning but did not speak to each other the rest of the day, according to people on both sides. They appeared together on yet another television show, "Larry King Live," last night. They have scheduled no bargaining sessions, having met last on Wednesday.
"Nothing has changed," Fehr said as the first pitches of the last games approached. "That's it."
 
'Most Exciting Season'
 In Washington, President Clinton urged both sides to find a way to get back together and finish the season.
"There are a lot of little kids out there who want to see this season come to a close," he said, "and there are a lot of not-so-little kids out there who know that this is the most exciting baseball season in 40 years."
At Yankee Stadium, Steinbrenner offered mixed views on the dispute. Referring to Ravitch's contention that a salary cap is needed to maintain competitive balance between wealthier clubs and poorer clubs, the Yankees' principal owner said, "It's difficult to argue competitive balance in view of Montreal having the second-lowest payroll but the best record in baseball."
But he added: "The thing is to enable them to keep some of those players, to have the financial wherewithal to do it. We don't want to happen to Montreal what happened to Pittsburgh, where they couldn't afford to keep those players."
When earlier remarks by Steinbrenner appeared in The Philadelphia Inquirer yesterday, he appeared to be making the first break in the solidarity of the ownership group. But in his comments yesterday, he seemed to soften his stance, saying: "As far as splintering from the group, absolutely not. We are as strong as ever. I don't see any splintering whatsoever."
 
Owners at the Table
 Steinbrenner nevertheless reiterated his view that owners should sit at the bargaining table, a position articulated strongly by the players.
Angelos also said he thought owners should attend bargaining sessions, but only as observers.
"That is a reasonable request by the players," he said.
Despite the prospect of having no more games this season, Bill Giles, the Phillies' managing partner, left his team's game before it was over, walking out in the 11th inning with the game tied, 1-1. Giles explained, "I have to get up early and drive to Vermont to go fishing."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 13, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page headline yesterday about the baseball strike referred incorrectly in some editions to the number of games played. Nine major league games were played yesterday. A scheduled 10th, between Boston and Baltimore, was rained out.

HEADLINE: How Clinton Can Be F.D.R.

SERIES: HEALTH CARE: SECOND OPINIONS -- An occasional series.

BYLINE: By Alan Brinkley; Alan Brinkley, professor of history at Columbia, is author of the forthcoming "The End of Reform: New Deal Liberalism in Recession and War."

 BODY:
After a year and a half in office, the Administration finds itself in a bizarre political condition. It is so beleaguered -- even the anticrime bill was rejected in the House yesterday -- that Bill Clinton's own pollster is encouraging Democratic candidates not to identify themselves too closely with him this year. Yet it is also agonizingly close to a monumental policy achievement.
Liberals (and others) have dreamed of national health insurance in vain for nearly a century. Even five years ago, passage of any such program seemed virtually inconceivable. Now, uncertain as its prospects remain, it is closer than it has ever been. 
 Other Presidents have encountered great political difficulties. And others have pursued and achieved grand social policy ambitions. But never has an Administration straddled these two courses in the way that this one is trying to do.
The character of the national health care reform (if any) that emerges from Congress will reflect President Clinton's boldness and weakness. The boldness of the effort is clear. No domestic proposal since the Social Security Act of 1935 would affect the lives of so many Americans. And unlike Social Security, health care legislation will pass -- if it does -- over the strenuous opposition of an extraordinary range of well-financed and ferociously active interest groups as well as Republicans determined to deny the Administration a victory.
Any plan Congress approves will only faintly resemble the complicated proposal the President submitted. But that will not, and should not, prevent him from receiving the lion's share of the credit (or blame) for the result. Franklin D. Roosevelt did not initiate, and for a time opposed, the most important provisions of the National Labor Relations Act of 1935. He had little to do with drafting the Social Security Act. Yet both are linked to him.
The pressure for health care reform comes from many places and was building well before Mr. Clinton embraced the issue. But if a serious program is enacted, it will be his achievement more than anyone else's. No President has staked so much political capital on universal health care; that Mr. Clinton has done so, so steadfastly, is all the more striking because he has so little capital to spare.
For that very reason, the battle reflects his considerable political weakness. He has been criticized for a lack of firmness and commitment. He will be strongly tempted to veto any bill that does not guarantee universal coverage. But he also badly needs a victory and will be tempted to accept almost any package that substantially expands coverage. Both temptations pose dangers.
The history of the Social Security Act of 1935 suggests the risks of making an excessively rigid commitment to universal coverage. When it was enacted, its benefits fell much further short of universality than almost any health care measure now debated. Huge categories of people were excluded.
When the first pension payments began, in 1940, they reached fewer than a quarter of all workers and virtually no one outside the paid labor force. Yet within four years, Congress began to expand the system. Today, Social Security pensions are the closest thing we have to a universal system of social insurance. Whatever its flaws, it is the most popular and politically unassailable social program the Government has ever produced.
The Social Security Act was successful because it established the principle that Americans were entitled to certain social protections. That principle quickly produced almost irresistible popular demands for continued expansion of the system. Surely, legislation establishing the principle but not the reality of universal health care would similarly generate substantial public pressure for expansion.
On the other hand, the 1965 Medicare Act illustrates the dangers of establishing a principle of entitlement without an adequate structure for financing and containing it. President Lyndon B. Johnson believed, correctly, that once he established the principle of a right to health care for elderly people, it would be impossible ever to rescind it. But he established no effective mechanisms for controlling the costs, and by the late 1970's they were growing at a phenomenal rate. Later efforts to contain them led to a shifting of economic burdens to other groups of recipients, driving up insurance premiums for people under 65 and helping to push many out of coverage altogether.
The unintended consequences of Medicare are among the causes of today's health care crisis. And they support Mr. Clinton's argument that a system too far from universality could make things worse, not better, for people who need help the most.
The President faces the unenviable task of balancing these conflicting legacies -- from a position of political weakness. The result will, no doubt, be far from perfect. But it seems reasonable to expect him to insist that any legislation at least create a path toward an effective system of universal coverage (as the Social Security Act did) and not a route to crippling imbalances in the cost of health care (as the Medicare bill inadvertently managed to do). If he can achieve this, the controversies swirling about him are likely to seem as ephemeral in the end as the long-forgotten partisan squabbles of 1935.
