HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Rose 0.3% in July

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose three-tenths of a percent in July, buoyed by rising gasoline and grocery store prices, and business inventories increased in June, the Government said today.
Excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, consumer prices rose only two-tenths of a percent, slightly less than many analysts had expected. Financial markets rallied strongly on this signal that the so-called core rate of inflation might still be under control. Lower inflation puts less pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates again soon. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 17.81 to close at 3,768.71, while the interest rate on 30-year Treasury bonds dropped to 7.50 percent from 7.65 percent. [Pages 38 and 46.]
 
 
 
Doesn't Clear the Air
 Laura D'Andrea Tyson, who heads the Council of Economic Advisers, played down the overall rise in the Consumer Price Index. "You instead see signs, if you take out the volatile food and energy prices, that the core inflation rate remains subdued," she said in a telephone interview.
Wall Street analysts said that today's economic indicators did little to clear up the general confusion about the economy's health, and would not push Federal Reserve officials noticeably in favor or against higher interest rates at a meeting on Tuesday of the central bank's interest-rate-policy committee. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has said repeatedly that the central bank is worried about possible future inflation and is not trying to set policy based on price increases that have already occurred.
Inventories of manufacturers, wholesale distributors and retailers rose four-tenths of a percent in June, led by a 1.4 percent increase in retail inventories, the Commerce Department said. The overall increase was twice as large as analysts had expected, even given the department's estimate on July 29 that inventories grew more in the second quarter than at any time since the end of 1987.
 
 
 
Slow Growth Is Seen
 Some Wall Street analysts said the extra inventories meant that growth was more likely to slow in the coming months as stores cut back on new orders until consumers cleared their shelves. "The economy is decelerating and inflation remains subdued," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch.
The increase in inventories particularly surprised analysts because the Commerce Department said on Thursday that retail sales, excluding cars and light trucks, had grown four-tenths of a percent, also more than many analysts had expected.
Darwin Beck, an economist at First Boston in New York, said that the only way sales and inventories can both increase by unexpectedly large amounts is if the American economy produced even more goods in the second quarter than anyone had previously thought. The Commerce Department estimated on July 29 that the economy grew at an annual pace of 3.7 percent in the second quarter; it is scheduled to refine that estimate on Aug. 26.
"We will have higher growth in the second quarter than previously estimated," Mr. Beck predicted.
But Ms. Tyson at the Council of Economic Advisers said such speculation was premature. "I don't think there's any reason to draw that conclusion yet," she said in a telephone interview today.
 
 
 
Optimism in Southeast
 In one possible sign that growth will not slow later this year, manufacturers in the Southeast expressed optimism about future sales in a monthly survey released today by the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta. The bank's regional indexes of output, shipments and new and unfilled orders all increased.
But the Atlanta Fed also said that a sharply rising share of Southeastern manufacturers reported paying higher prices for materials and charging higher prices for their products.
Consumer prices rose particularly fast in July for coffee, up 22.4 percent; fresh fruit and vegetables, up 3.4 percent; gasoline, up 3.5 percent, and airline fares, up 1.3 percent. The overall price increase was held down by falling prices for beef, down 1.2 percent, and clothing, down four-tenths of a percent.
Many products rose in price roughly in line with the overall Consumer Price Index, including car prices, up four-tenths of a percent; medical care costs, also up four-tenths of a percent, and housing, up a tenth of a percent.

 
 
Remarks by Fed Governor
 While today's economic indicators may have provided no clear clues to the Federal Reserve's intentions, off-the-cuff remarks this morning by John P. LaWare, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, convinced some analysts that another quarter-point increase in short-term interest rates on Tuesday was even more likely than it already seemed.
Reuters reported that Mr. LaWare said he expected the economy to grow at a pace of 3.25 to 3.5 percent this year, and by 2.7 percent to 3 percent next year. He spoke in Randolph, Mass., before the South Shore Chamber of Commerce.
In contrast, the Fed officially estimated at its July meeting that the economy would grow 3 to 3.25 percent this year and 2.5 to 2.75 percent next year.
An upward revision of those estimates could mean that the Federal Reserve is more worried that the economy may overheat and feed inflation, said Eugene J. Sherman, director of research at M. A. Schapiro & Company, a New York brokerage firm. Such worries would put pressure on the central bank to raise rates again.
Mr. LaWare, a former chairman of the Shawmut National Corporation, is the Federal Reserve's top expert on banking issues, but is widely believed to rely on the central bank's influential staff for economic forecasts. He was traveling today and could not be reached for comment.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE;
Mitchell Sees Room for Dealing On Rival Health Care Proposals

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
Taking a major step toward agreement on national health insurance, Senator George J. Mitchell, the majority leader, said today that the issues raised by bipartisan moderates led by Senator John H. Chafee appeared to be negotiable.
Mr. Mitchell said he could not judge the details of the group's proposals, which are expected to focus chiefly on questions of bureaucracy, cost controls and malpractice litigation, until he receives them on Tuesday. 
 But, referring to a Senate speech two days ago in which Mr. Chafee outlined his own concerns, the majority leader said, "Those appear to be matters where there can and should be discussion and compromise among reasonable people."
Mr. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, said that there would be areas of disagreement in addition to those he listed in his speech but that he did not believe that Mr. Mitchell would find any of the moderates' proposals unreasonable.
The Chafee group is not expected to challenge the efforts of Mr. Mitchell's health insurance bill to seek universal coverage, including a provision that might ultimately require employers to pay half the cost of insuring their workers, a point on which the moderates are not united. In the end, some members of the group might oppose a bill on that point, but most do not regard it as a central issue.
If the Chafee group's precise package, which Congressional aides will spend the weekend writing, proves acceptable to Mr. Mitchell, it is almost certain to command the support of other leading Democrats, like Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, who has been working very closely with the majority leader.
With their backing, Mr. Chafee's "mainstream coalition," whose fluctuating membership reached a high of 16 senators today, could command a Senate majority for its proposal.
But while Mr. Mitchell was on the verge of progress with some Republicans, others were threatening to stall.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, blocked any effort to set a vote on an amendment, the first offered to Mr. Mitchell's bill, that is intended to speed insurance coverage for children and pregnant women. Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, said that 28 Republicans still had opening statements to make in the Senate's health care debate and that several needed three or four hours each.
After Senator Kennedy told reporters that this was the equivalent of a filibuster, Mr. Packwood took the Senate floor again, this time to attack him. Mr. Packwood said the Republicans' speeches were the only way they could educate the public about the weaknesses in the Mitchell bill. "It may take us days, or weeks, or months," he said, and then quoted Gen. Ulysses S. Grant's vow, at the Battle of Spotsylvania Courthouse in Virginia during the Civil War, to "fight it out on this line if it takes all summer."
 
Needed: A Boost for the House
 But the indefinite delay that has gripped health care efforts in the House appeared more ominous than any contentiousness in the Senate. Thrown off balance by the defeat of the Clinton Administration's crime bill on Thursday, House Democratic leaders are trying to figure out how to rescue that measure and regain some momentum that would help health care legislation.
Action in the Senate could restore House confidence, especially if Mr. Mitchell can preserve his requirement that employers pay half the cost of their workers' health insurance should subsidies and other measures not push insurance coverage to 95 percent of the public by 2000.
The moderates are focused on less-debated sections of the Mitchell bill, for instance its provisions on malpractice litigation and on competition among cooperatives that would be created to help individuals and businesses buy insurance.
Several of the issues they have identified, like the size of the businesses that would be required to insure their workers through such cooperatives, were discussed in Mr. Kennedy's Labor and Human Resources Committee when that panel was drawing up a health care bill earlier this year.
Republicans on the committee then, like members of the coalition now, favored increasing the number of businesses that would be exempted from any such requirement. The Republicans' preference was defeated in committee, but only after they told Mr. Kennedy that even if he made the change, they would not support the bill. Now, with real votes on the table, Mr. Kennedy and his allies would have reason to make a deal.
Some of the moderates' other concerns, like how detailed the benefits package should be or how insurance rates could be adjusted for age, and for how long, are the stuff of obvious compromise when senators are ready to cut a deal.
And there might be easy agreement on some of the coalition's other proposals, like allowing the states to establish more stringent rules on malpractice litigation than the Federal standards that the bill would create. Another probably painless change would be to permit insurance plans created for associations -- like those of lawyers, for instance -- to continue even if new ones were barred in an effort to prevent young, healthy people from clustering together in an insurance pool.
Even issues of more complexity, such as altering the bill's methods for preventing spending from outrunning estimates, would appear to be negotiable.
But there are still several obstacles to agreement, even beyond the details that turn up in the moderates' proposals.
Some of the senators at today's meeting of the "mainstream coalition," especially its Republicans, want to draft an entirely new bill rather than merely a package of amendments. Mr. Mitchell and his allies do not want to start from scratch, which would be a very time-consuming process.
Nor is it clear how the Senate minority leader, Mr. Dole, will respond. Mr. Chafee said today that the group would be presenting its ideas to him too, but since his underlying proposal is very different from Mr. Mitchell's, it is not clear what would happen next.
An aide to Mr. Dole said today that the Senator would like to hear the group's proposals but believed it was necessary to start over and prepare a whole new bill.
The floating membership of the bipartisan group itself is another complication. Today, for example, 16 senators attended the coalition's meeting, and two of the Democrats there -- Sam Nunn of Georgia and David L. Boren of Oklahoma -- later announced that they were going to introduce an entirely different bipartisan health proposal, patterned on a measure offered by a bipartisan House group.
Senators Nunn and Boren were joined in that enterprise by two Republicans who have often attended the moderates' meetings: Senators Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico and Robert F. Bennett of Utah.
Just after 5 P.M. today, the Senate took up the first amendment to Mr. Mitchell's bill. The stated aim of the amendment, offered by Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, is to speed up by 18 months, to next July, the Mitchell bill's provision that private insurers be required to include preventive care for pregnant women and infants as a standard benefit in any health policy they sell.
Easy agreement might have been expected on this "motherhood" proposal. But after an hour in which several Democrats spoke in favor of it, Mr. Dole rose to complain that Mr. Dodd had simply "farmed out the floor" for speeches suggesting "that the Democrats like children and we don't like children."
"Maybe I haven't been here long enough to understand what I thought was going on," Mr. Dole allowed. "Or maybe I've been here too long." Later, other Republicans asked how such a measure might increase premiums -- or tax deductions by employers who chose to pay for such benefits, thus reducing tax revenue.
"We'll ask him more later what the revenue impacts might be," said Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, who predicted a vote next week.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Scurrying from a White House strategy session yesterday, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, and Health and Human Services Secretary Donna E. Shalala sped to the Capitol to lobby for health care legislation. Then at least one of them, Ms. Shalala, joined by one of her aides in the office of Senator Charles S. Robb, had to wait. Chart: "Players: The Senate's 'Mainstream Coalition' "
The bipartisan group called the "mainstream coalition," which is planning to offer a package of health care ammendments, has six core members, although other senates have been allied with it on various issues. The six core members are:
 
JOHN H. CHAFEE: Republican of Rhode Island. Mr. Chafee, the organizer of the "mainstream coalition," has contended that the bill introduced by Senator George J. Mitchell would impose "the heavy hand of government intervention in the private market." Senator Chafee, who will introduce the coalition's alternative next week, also maintains that the Mitchell measure would not hold down costs.
 
DAVE DURENBERGER: Republican of Minnesota. He maintains that the Mitchell measure would establish an unneeded bureaucracy, impose anti-competitive rules and shift costs onto working people. He points to the success of health maintenance organizations in Minnesota as cost-effective providers of high quality health care.
 
JOHN C. DANFORTH: Republican of Missouri. He said that his opposition to Senator Mitchell's bill was grounded in both economics and philosophy. "His subsidy for low-income people is necessary," Senator Danforth said, "but he's also created entitlements for prescription drugs and long-term care. We can't do that. That's a mistake."
 
JOHN B. BREAUX: Democrat of Louisiana. His opposition to the Mitchell measure is based partly on its provision that could eventually require employers to pay half of workers' health insurance premiums. A Congress sitting in 1994 cannot know what will be needed in 2001 and should not seek to lock in a solution now, he says.
 
BILL BRADLEY: Democrat of New Jersey. Senator Bradley supports the Mitchell provision on employer payments, which is said meets his goal fof reaching universal coverage through "shared responsibility." But he opposes the cost-containment provisions of the Mitchell bill, which he says would impose taxes on too many people.
 
KENT CONRAD: Democrat of North Dakota. He objects to the Mitchell measure on the grounds that it would create a huge new bureaucracy and cause the Federal deficit to balloon. Senator Conrad has called for a health care program that would pay for itself. (pg. 8)

HEADLINE: Democratic Leaders Promise to Try Again on Crime Bill

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
After the worst legislative drubbing of the Clinton Presidency, Democratic leaders in Congress promised today that they would revive the crime bill that the House of Representatives sidetracked on Thursday and win its approval next week.
 The Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, said that crime legislation and the procedural hurdle that blocked it this week would be the main order of business before the House beginning on Tuesday. He predicted that one way or another the bill would get to the floor.
 
 Others in the House echoed that view. But no one was sure what would have to be done between now and then to guarantee enough votes.
 "I feel that some kind of crime bill will pass," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat who was largely responsible for steering the crime measure through the House the first time around. He suggested that when they return next week, House leaders would figure out a way to "rejigger the dial a bit" to win enough votes for passage.
 The problem is that the bill that was blocked on Thursday was a delicate compromise molded over weeks by Senate and House negotiators to satisfy various interests. "Every change we make is going to make it better for some groups and worse for others," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan.
 By a vote of 225 to 210, the House defeated a procedural motion that would have allowed the bill itself to come up for a vote. The majority was composed of an unusual coalition of Republicans and 58 Democrats. Most of those Democrats represent rural districts and opposed the bill's ban on some assault weapons, but 10 were black representatives from big cities who objected to the bill's provisions on capital punishment.
 Republicans and Democrats alike said that if the bill can clear the roadblock of the procedural motion, it will be passed overwhelmingly by the House. Few lawmakers want to be seen as voting directly against a bill that is called an anti-crime measure.
 And in the Senate, Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democrat from Delaware who heads the Judiciary Committee, said, "Whatever they get out of the House, I'll pass."
 
Gleeful Republicans
 Republicans, an increasingly unified and aggressive minority in the House, reveled today in the embarrassment they had handed the Clinton Administration and their Democratic antagonists in the Capitol.
 At a news conference, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip, said the vote should teach President Clinton that if he wants his legislative agenda to succeed, he must work with Republicans.
 Representative Dick Armey, Republican of Texas, teased the Democrats for having overassessed their strength when they brought the crime measure to the floor. If the Democrats hope to get health legislation approved, he said, "they'd better be better at counting votes than they were on crime."
 Taunting the President, Republican leaders from the House and Senate faxed a letter to Mr. Clinton on Air Force One offering to meet with him when he returned from Minneapolis to Washington tonight "to discuss how we can work together to pass a strong crime bill as soon as possible."
 
White House Rebuff
 Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, declined for the President. In a letter to the Republican leaders, Mr. Panetta wrote: "What disappointed me, and what disappointed the President, is that the very spirit of bipartisanship you wrote about today was torn asunder in the House."
 Among the main provisions of the crime bill, which would cost $30 billion over six years, are financing for 100,000 new police officers nationwide; a ban on some assault weapons; the death penalty for scores of crimes; financing for new prisons; social and rehabilitation programs for criminals and those at particular risk of becoming criminals, and a guarantee that people would be sentenced to prison for life if they were convicted of a violent felony for the third time.
 The National Rifle Association lobbied with all its considerable might against the ban on assault weapons, and some lawmakers said that striking that provision from the bill might win enough votes for passage. Others said that dropping the ban would lose more votes than it would gain.
 Another possibility would be to drop from the bill provisions that Republicans referred to as pork barrel. The Republicans pointed particularly to a $10 million grant for a criminal justice center at Lamar University in Beaumont, Tex., the alma mater of Representative Jack Brooks, chairman of the Judiciary Committee and head of the House conferees on the legislation.
 Asked if he would permit the grant to be dropped, Mr. Brooks, a Democrat from Beaumont, replied: "Hell no! Are you out of your mind?"
 For the bill to be changed, it would have to be reconsidered by the House-Senate conference committee. Senator Biden said he was opposed to reconvening the conference, and he argued that the leaders in the House should try to switch the eight votes necessary to win approval of the measure as it stands.
 It is always hard to get lawmakers to switch votes once they have been cast without some face-saving change in the legislation. But it has been done before. In 1985, for example, the House rejected a similar procedural motion, thus denying Ronald Reagan a vote on his bill to change taxes, the most important legislation of his second term.
 Mr. Reagan went to the Capitol, met with all the members of his party, pleaded for their votes and won approval of the motion the second time around.
 Mr. Clinton may not be popular enough in Congress or in the country to pull off a similar feat. Asked to assess the President's muscle, Senator Biden suggested that reporters take a look at recent public opinion polls that show Mr. Clinton at the lowest point of his Presidency.
 Going into the vote Thursday night, Democrat leaders said today, they thought they had commitments of "yes" votes from 200 of the 256 Democrats, 15 of the 178 Republicans and the one Independent, two short of the 218 votes needed for a majority.
 The leaders said they thought that if the vote went down to the wire, two or three representatives who had not committed themselves would succumb to pressure and put the tally over the top. That is what happened last year on the President's budget, which was approved in the House by a two-vote margin.
 But this time, the last two or three votes were not forthcoming. Once defeat was certain, several representatives who had promised their votes if they were absolutely necessary voted "no."

Some Republicans and conservative Democrats who opposed the anti-crime bill say their objections are based in part on spending for crime-prevention programs that they considered unnecessary. The measure would have provided more than $7 billion over six years for various prevention programs like the following:
 
Community Schools - $630 million for after school, weekend and summer programs to provide children with positive activities and alternatives to the street life of crime and drugs.
 
Youth Employment and Skills Crime Prevention Grants (Y.E.S.) - $650 million to provide jobs to young adults in high crime areas.
 
Violence Against Women Act - $1.8 billion to fight violence against women.
 
Local Partnership Act - $1.8 billion to local governments for anti-crime efforts, such as drug treatment, education and jobs.
 
Community Economic Partnership - $300 million for lines of credit to community development corporations to stimulate business and employment opportunities for low-income, unemployed and underemployed people.
 
Anti-gang grants - $125 million for programs to give people positive alternatives to gangs (such as academic, athletic, artistic after-school activities, mentoring programs, scout troops, and sports leagues).
 
Midnight Sports - $40 million for midnight sports leagues for youths in high-crime areas.
 
Olympic Youth Development Centers - $50 million for the U.S. Olympic Committee to develop supervised sports and recreation programs in high-crime areas.
 
Boys and Girls Clubs - $30 million to establish clubs in low income housing communities, and $10 million to encourage police officers to live in those communities.
 
Visitation Centers - $30 million for supervised "safe havens" where divorced or separated parents with a history of physical or sexual abuse may visit their children.

HEADLINE: Statement By N. Korea And the U.S.

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Saturday, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the text of the statement issued early today by negotiators for the United States and North Korea:
Both sides reaffirmed the principles of the June 11, 1993, DPRK [Democratic People's Republic of Korea]-USA joint statement and reached agreement that the following elements should be part of a final resolution of the nuclear issue: 
 1. The DPRK is prepared to replace its graphite-moderated reactors and related facilities with light water reactor (LWR) power plants, and the USA is prepared to make arrangements for interim energy alternatives to the DPRK's graphite-moderated reactors. Upon receipt of USA assurances for the provision of LWRs and for arrangements for interim energy alternatives, the DPRK will freeze construction of the 50-megawatt (e) and 200-megawatt (e) reactors, forego reprocessing, and seal the Radiochemical Laboratory, to be monitored by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA).
2. The DPRK and the USA are prepared to establish diplomatic representation in each other's capitals and to reduce barriers to trade and investment, as a move toward full normalization of political and economic relations.
3. To help achieve peace and security on a nuclear-free Korean Peninsula, the USA is prepared to provide the DPRK with assurances against the threat or use of nuclear weapons by the USA, and the DPRK remains prepared to implement the North-South Joint Declaration on the Denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula.
4. The DPRK is prepared to remain a party to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and to allow implementation of its safeguards agreement under the Treaty.
Important issues raised during the talks remain to be resolved. Both sides agree that expert-level discussions are necessary to advance the replacement of the DPRK's graphite-moderated program with LWR technology, the safe storage and disposition of the spent fuel, provision of alternative energy, and the establishment of liaison offices. Accordingly, expert-level talks will be held in the DPRK and USA or elsewhere as agreed. The DPRK and USA agreed to recess their talks and resume in Geneva on September 23, 1994.
In the meantime, the USA will pursue arrangements necessary to provide assurances for the LWR project to the DPRK as part of a final resolution of the nuclear issue, and the DPRK will observe the freeze on nuclear activities and maintain the continuity of safeguards. . . .

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in July, buoyed by rising gasoline and grocery prices, while business inventories increased in June, the Government reported. Excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, consumer prices rose only two-tenths of 1 percent, less than many analysts had expected. [Page 37.] 
 The Clinton Administration and House Republicans reached agreement on the broad outlines of deals on financing for a world free trade pact and on the Administration's future trade negotiating authority. The move was seen as another step toward Congressional approval of the accord. [37.]
The Government announced the largest clothing recall ever, a quarter-million rayon skirts made in India that can be set on fire with a cigarette and burn faster than a newspaper. [6.]
 
Companies
Comcast is intent on staying in the home shopping business because the company's top officials, Ralph and Brian Roberts, believe the $2 billion industry still has plenty of room for growth. The trick is to make the programming evolve beyond impulse purchases by couch potatoes to become a service that competes with mail-order catalogues for the dollars of busy, sophisticated people with specific shopping needs. [37.]
Regulators in Canada and the United States seized control of the Confederation Life Insurance Company, Canada's fifth-largest insurer, in one of the largest insurance company failures. [37.]
Walt Disney will pull "The Lion King" from movie theaters after next month, even though the animated film is still drawing crowds. In an attempt to bottle up demand until the big holiday movie-going season -- and make up for not having a new animated release for Thanksgiving for the first time in several years -- the company said it would withdraw the film from theaters on Sept. 23 and re-release it in late November. [37.]
Several big airlines said they were cutting fares as much as 50 percent on flights this fall, adding to a string of recent air fare sales. Although the airlines are having a busy summer, the fare sales suggest that carriers are not selling as many seats as they would like for the fall. [39.]
Novell said Robert J. Frankenberg, who was named president and chief executive in April, had added the title of chairman. He succeeds Raymond J. Noorda, who will remain on the board. [39.]
Bell Atlantic plans to announce aggressive cost reductions, the closing of certain offices and the elimination of jobs, at a news conference on Tuesday, a company memorandum says. [49.]
 
Markets
Stocks followed bonds higher, after a smaller-than-expected rise in July consumer prices stirred hopes that the Federal Reserve would not be so aggressive in raising interest rates next week. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 17.81 points, to 3,768.71. [38.]
Prices of Treasury securities rose for the first time in five days, after the consumer price report showed prices rose only modestly in July. The yield on the new 30 1/4-year bond was 7.50 percent, down from 7.65 percent on Thursday. [46.]
The dollar fell against the German mark, but ended modestly lower against most other currencies. [45.]
Silver prices retreated, pulled down by economic factors and heavy selling in gold. Cotton plunged the limit allowed for daily trading and oil prices fell sharply. [45.]
 
Your Money
Insurance policies can be canceled if policy holders lie about personal information like their medical history. [35.]
Looming competition in the utility industry may change the way investors look at the stocks of utility companies. [35.]
Delays have occurred this summer for people who want the National Association of Securities Dealers to arbitrate disputes with brokers. [36.]

HEADLINE: Mexico's Battling Presidential Contenders Converge on Economic Matters

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 12

 BODY:
As the three leading candidates head toward Mexico's presidential election next week, they have shown surprisingly little disagreement over what could well have been a major issue: The ruling party's economic dealings with the United States and the shock treatment it has used to transform Mexico's system of free enterprise.
 Long one of the most ardent supporters of state ownership of businesses, the Mexican Government has almost entirely withdrawn from the private sector during over the last six years and thrown open the economy to fierce competition, especially from American companies.
 
 Unemployment has soared, and Mexican businesses felt they were left to sink or swim in the new economy and tougher competitive environment created by Mexico's entrance into the North American Free Trade Agreement. Yet, while the candidates are worlds apart in their political views, the handling of the economy has not become a dividing line in the campaign.
 The clearest signal of the extent to which many Mexicans seem to have conceded their need for a free market comes from the leftist candidate, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas of the Party of the Democratic Revolution, known by its Spanish initials, P.R.D.
 He rejects nearly all the current Government's social and political policies but basically supports the ruling party's approach to fighting inflation and encouraging development. He has also abandoned his opposition to the trade pact, saying only that some sections, especially those dealing with the crops of small farmers, should be renegotiated.
 Both Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, known as the PRI, and Diego Fernandez de Cevallos of the conservative National Action Party, or the PAN, also say they will uphold the trade pact. They both plan to stick to the basics of the Salinas administration's economic itinerary, a double-edged approach that rigidly controls inflation while relying on the market, rather than Government intervention, to spur real growth.
 All three candidates have said that they would carry on the major modernization projects undertaken by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, which include privatizing or dissolving more than 900 state-owned companies and granting autonomy to the central bank. They differ only in some details of how the Government can encourage economic growth.
 "The opposition has learned that there is no room for adventures, for tinkering with sound economic and fiscal policies," said Rogelio Ramirez de la O, a business consultant in Mexico City who is often critical of the Government. The ruling party, he said, has realized "that it has sacrificed economic growth for the sake of some economic goals."
 
Feelings of Insecurity
 Many Mexicans say they feel the Salinas administration has destroyed the meager security they once enjoyed. They are especially galled by the number of Mexican billionaires -- 24, up from 2 when Mr. Salinas took office. Economic injustice was a central complaint in the Chiapas uprising last January.
 But, unlike the mood in the 1988 election, in which 29 percent of voters expressed anger over low wages and rising prices by voting in large numbers for Mr. Cardenas, sentiment this year is different. Real wages are still below the levels they had reached in 1980, but they have increased every year since 1988.
 Perhaps more important, the daily shock of rapid inflation that enraged Mexicans every time they went to buy a bag of beans in the mid-1980s no longer exists. The PRI Government has managed to bring down inflation from an annual rate of 159 percent in 1987 to below 8 percent.
 "People have noticed very dramatic changes in lifestyle that have to do with the economic reforms," said Alejandro Hernandez Delgado, director of the center of economic studies at the Autonomous Technological Institute of Mexico in Mexico City. "Some of those changes are as simple as going to the supermarket and seeing stable prices and a larger variety of goods produced in Mexico and outside."
 
Shoring Up the Peso
 Nonetheless, the need to demonstrate the economy's stability and shore up confidence in the peso prior to the vote last year on the trade pact led the Government to keep interest rates high.
 That, combined with doubts about the pact, meant the economy slumbered until the beginning of this year. Then came the rebel uprising in Chiapas state in January and the assassination of the PRI candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio, in March, which caused the recovery to stumble. First quarter growth this year was only 0.5 percent.
 Of the three candidates, Mr. Zedillo is the business community's clear choice because of his economics degrees from Yale, the time he spent working at Mexico's central bank and his preference for an open market free from most Government controls. As his standing has risen in polls in the last three weeks, the Mexican stock exchange and money markets have responded favorably.
 Mr. Zedillo acknowledges that the hard-line approach to economic modernization that he helped draft as Mr. Salinas's Budget and Planning Minister has cost many jobs and created hardships. He is expected to focus less on fighting inflation and more on encouraging growth.
 He has said that he will not privatize the three remaining big state-owned enterprises -- oil, electricity and railroads -- and wants to offer more subsidies and credits to help local businesses adapt to post-Nafta competition.
 If Mr. Fernandez de Cevallos were to win, he would not be expected to fiddle much with Mexico's economic path since the PRI has adopted as its own many PAN proposals from previous years. He has said Mexico should try for "more humane growth" that does more to assure people jobs and provide businesses with the capital to compete. He supports the trade agreement, has proposed transferring some responsibilities for economic development from the President to Congress and has talked about the need for a balanced-budget law.
 It is Mr. Cardenas who represents the biggest question mark if he beats the odds and wins. He has considerably moderated the radical leftist economic views he espoused in the 1988 presidential election, apparently in the hope of winning over middle class voters. He now accepts the main Salinas ideas of opening up Mexico's economy and controlling inflation and debt -- a big change from 1988, when he said Mexico should not pay its huge debt at all.

HEADLINE: World Trade Pact Advances With Some Bipartisan Deals

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration and House Republicans took another step today toward Congressional approval of a world free trade agreement, reaching the broad outlines of deals on financing for the accord and on the Administration's future trade negotiating authority.
But many obstacles remain before the agreement to reduce tariffs and other trade barriers, which was reached in December, can become part of American law. The legal language for today's deals is still being drafted, House Democratic leaders have yet to endorse the compromises and a conference has yet to be held to reconcile differences between House and Senate versions of the approval legislation. 
 That conference could be especially difficult because of the nature of today's deals. One calls for Congress to review American participation in the trade pact after five years, with a possible vote then on whether to pull out, said Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the ranking Republican on the Ways and Means Committee.
Mr. Archer added that the financing package reached today would not actually make up for all of the revenue reductions the trade pact would cause as less money is taken in from tariff duties. The package eliminates a $1 billion tax on retail inventories that offended Republicans, but does not replace it with anything, leaving the House-Senate conference to decide how to raise the money.
While most trade experts expect the agreement to be approved eventually, it remains unclear whether Congress can find the time and political energy to reach a decision this year, particularly given the bitterness of struggles over crime and health care bills.
Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat who brokered today's deals, emphasized that putting them into legal language might be difficult. "The agreement that has been reached conceptually is still subject to drafting," he said. "I am cautiously optimistic that it will be finalized pending the outcome of the drafting."
Mr. Archer said that an aide to Representative Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, had also endorsed today's arrangements. He predicted that the full Ways and Means Committee would endorse the deal on Tuesday and that the House-Senate conference would start soon thereafter.
If approved by Congress, the trade pact would reduce tariffs around the world and bring new industries like farming and accounting under the free-trade rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. It would also replace the existing GATT secretariat in Geneva with a new World Trade Organization that would have broad powers to arbitrate international trade disputes.
 Today's deal also calls for reviving for two and a half years the President's so-called fast-track authority to negotiate a trade agreement and submit it to the House and Senate for a single vote in each chamber with no amendments allowed. The Administration had been seeking a seven-year renewal of the authority, which lapsed on Dec. 15, 1993.

HEADLINE: Bonds Post First Gain In 5 Days

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday for the first time in five days after the Consumer Price Index report showed that prices were up only modestly in July.
The report raised questions about the size of the next interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve. 
 The new 30 1/4-year 7 1/2 percent bond rose 20/32 , to 1001/32 , for a yield of 7.50 percent, down from 7.65 percent the previous day. On Thursday, the Labor Department said the Producer Price Index had risen a stronger-than-expected five-tenths of 1 percent in July, and weak demand at the Treasury's $11 billion bond auction that day had pushed bond yields up 8 basis points.
Marilyn Schaja, a money market economist for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, said the concern about higher inflation numbers and expectations of a fifth increase in interest rates had left the market oversold.
She said that with the July inflation numbers indicating only a moderate inflation threat, there appeared to be some indication that the Fed could get by with an increase of only 25 basis points in the Federal funds rate, rather than the 50 basis points that had been expected.
Ms. Schaja said the consumer price figures indicated that even though there had been increases in the basic commodity indexes, price increases had not flowed through to the consumer level yet, an indication that producers might be having difficulty passing along price increases at the retail level. That, in turn, may be an indication that the Fed's tightening might not be as severe as expected.
Consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in July, mostly because of coffee prices, which posted a record surge of 22.4 percent, and increases in the prices of energy and automobiles.
The core rate, which excludes food and energy costs, was up two-tenths of 1 percent last month.
During June, both the overall index and the core rate rose three-tenths of 1 percent. So far this year, the index has risen at a rate of 2.7 percent, the same rate as during the first several months of 1993.
One reason for consumers' resistance to price increases might be stalled growth in consumer income. In a separate report, the Labor Department said Americans' weekly earnings, adjusted for inflation, were unchanged in July from June, and up only three-tenths of 1 percent from a year earlier.
Yesterday, the University of Michigan's index of consumer sentiment rose more than expected, to 92.6, in the preliminary August reading, from 89.0 in July.
Analysts said the expectations component rose to 81.4, from 78.5, and the currenct conditions component jumped to 110.1, from 105.4. Business inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent in June, also slightly higher than expected.
The Commerce Department also reported yesterday that business inventories rose more than expected in June, but traders said it was an old number.
Tempering the market's reaction to the inflation numbers, a Federal Reserve governor, John P. LaWare, said he was much less optimistic about the inflation outlook, and sent a strong signal that he thought interest rates should rise again.
An increase may come as early as Tuesday, when the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed panel that sets monetary policy, is to meet.

HEADLINE: Dow Jones Rises 17.81 On Low Inflation News

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks followed bonds higher yesterday, after a smaller-than-expected rise in July consumer prices stirred hopes that the Federal Reserve would be less aggressive in raising interest rates next week.
"I'm not so sure it's a lock the Fed will now raise rates," said Bruce Bittles, market strategist for J. C. Bradford & Company in Nashville. The Federal Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy, will meet on Tuesday and Wednesday. 
 Stocks were also buoyed by a resurgence of takeover speculation in drug and food companies, traders said.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 17.81, to 3,768.71, more than offsetting a drop of 15.86 points on Thursday and finishing the week 21.69 points higher.
 
Exxon Is Bid Up
 Caterpillar and Exxon accounted for more than half of the Dow's gain yesterday. Caterpillar climbed 2 1/8, to 105 1/8, after the maker of construction machinery said its sales of heavy equipment had jumped 20 percent in July, from the comparable month a year ago, an indication that 1994 sales would be stronger than expected.
Exxon rose 2 1/8, to 60 1/4, after a Federal jury awarded damages that were far smaller than had been sought by the Alaskan fishermen who were hurt by the Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1989. The $286.8 million award was less than a third of the $895 million requested, and raised speculation that the final punitive damages would be less than the maximum $15 billion that analysts had estimated.
Broader market indexes also rebounded yesterday from the previous day. The Standard & Poor's 500 index soared 3.07 points, to 461.95. The Nasdaq composite index rose 3.41 points, to 731.61 The American Stock Exchange market value index gained 0.45 point, to 443.70.
Almost three stocks rose for every two that fell on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading was moderate, with 249.3 million shares changing hands on the Big Board.
 
Favorable Inflation News
 Stocks rose after the Labor Department reported that the July consumer price index rose three-tenths of 1 percent. The so-called core rate, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, rose just two-tenths of 1 percent.
The evidence that inflation has not accelerated lifted bond prices, pushing interest rates lower. The yield on the Treasury's new 7 1/2 percent 30 1/4-year bond fell to 7.50 percent, down from 7.65 percent on Thursday.
The C.P.I. negated the higher-than-expected rise in the producer price index, reported on Thursday, analysts said. The P.P.I. rose five-tenths of 1 percent, amid surging coffee and gasoline prices, more than the four-tenths of 1 percent increase that economists had expected.
Investors were watching the two inflation reports for signs of whether the Fed panel would vote to raise interest rates a fifth time this year. Higher rates slow down economic growth and crimp corporate profits.
 
Drug Stocks Are Active
 Drug stocks were active amid renewed takeover speculation. Three drug companies, Syntex, Eli Lilly, and Amgen were among the four most actively traded stocks today.
Syntex fell 1, to 21 5/8. The company denied speculation that Roche Holding A.G.'s $5.8 billion takeover offer for Syntex had unraveled.
Roche's bid for Syntex, coupled with American Home Products' $8.5 billion tender offer for American Cyanamid, has fueled speculation of more drug industry marriages, analysts and traders said.
Lilly shares rose 1/2, to 53, amid unconfirmed speculation of a bid by Britain's Glaxo Holdings.
Food stocks rose on speculation that Sandoz's $3.7 billion offer for Gerber Products in May would not be the last such acquisition. Kellogg rose 1 3/4, to 55 3/8; General Mills gained 1 11/32 , to 53 31/32 , and Quaker Oats rose 1 3/8, to 74 7/8.
In Tokyo yesterday, Japanese stocks slipped. The Nikkei index of 225 issues lost 157.53 points, closing at 20,663.83.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Prices Are Down Sharply For Silver, Cotton and Oil

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Silver prices retreated yesterday, pulled down by economic factors and heavy selling in gold.
On other commodity markets, cotton plunged the daily trading limit and oil prices fell sharply. The Commodity Research Bureau's index dropped 1.90 points, to 229.70. 
 "One of the key factors that hurt silver was the very aggressive producer selling of gold overnight," said William O'Neill, senior futures strategist with Merrill Lynch Futures in New York.
"The producers do not have a long-range constructive view of the market," he said. "So when a little rally developed, they used it as a selling opportunity."
 
Pressure From Economic News
 Silver also had trouble with a combination of economic factors, including a "very tame" Consumer Price Index, a surge in bond prices and a 61-cent drop in crude oil, Mr. O'Neill said. The Government reported yesterday that consumer prices rose three-tenths of a percent in July.
The selling of silver accelerated during the day, turning the decline in silver futures into a full retreat.
Silver for September delivery lost 13.3 cents, to settle at $5.07 an ounce, at the Commodity Exchange in New York, while October gold fell $2.50, to $378.50 an ounce.
Cotton futures prices plummeted in reaction to a huge production estimate released after the close of trading on Thursday. The October cotton contract was down the 2-cent limit, at 69.27 cents a pound, at the New York Cotton Exchange.
The Agriculture Department estimated the 1994-95 American cotton crop at 19.195 million 480-pound bales, more than one million bales higher than what the market was expecting.
 
Move by Short-Sellers
 Crude oil futures dropped below $18 a barrel before bouncing back slightly. September oil settled at $18.05 a barrel, down 61 cents, at the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Traders said the market was under attack by short-sellers who felt the bullish trend in oil prices was ending. Oil prices have surged in the last two months since a strike by Nigerian oil workers disrupted petroleum production and exports.
Other energy futures also declined. September heating oil fell 1.15 cents, to 48.57 cents a gallon, while September gasoline was down 2.08 cents, at 55.22 cents a gallon.
Elsewhere, deterioration of the Australian wheat crop gave wheat futures prices a lift. September wheat gained 5.75 cents, to $3.4175 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Reports from Australia estimated that country's crop at 10 million to 11.5 million tons, compared with the 12.5 million tons projected a day earlier by the United States Agriculture Department.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Trims Early Losses After Bond Prices Move Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the German mark yesterday but ended modestly lower against most other currencies as most American dealers shrugged off an early plunge in European trading and focused instead on bond and stock rallies on Wall Street.
For a second day, European investors fled to the perceived safety of the mark in the wake of Thursday's interest rate increases in Italy and Sweden, which fueled expectations of higher rates across the Continent. 
 A strong recovery in the Treasury bond market on positive inflation data helped offset the dollar's weakness in Europe, where the dollar dropped sharply against the mark and fell at one point below 100 Japanese yen.
"The dollar looked precarious this morning," said Steve Jury, chief dealer in New York for Union Bank of Switzerland. "But we recovered in tandem with the bond market after the C.P.I. data. If it wasn't for the bond market, the dollar would have come off quite a bit."
The Labor Department reported a modest rise of three-tenths of 1 percent in the Consumer Price Index last month. Inflation-wary bond investors reacted by bidding the price of the 30 1/4-year Treasury bond up 20/32 .
 
Unchanged Against Yen
 In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.5515 marks, down from 1.5608 on Thursday. But it ended unchanged at 100.15 yen.
The British pound rose to $1.5473, from $1.5458.
New York dealers adjusted their positions in anticipation of an increase in short-term interest rates after Federal Reserve policy makers meet on Tuesday. The central bank is widely expected to raise its target for the Federal funds rate -- the interest banks charge each other on overnight loans -- one-quarter to one-half percentage point in a preemptive strike against inflation.
A positive reception in the bond market to the expected rate increase would support the dollar, since demand for the currency rises when American securities perform well.
"Demand for dollar assets isn't there right now," said Earl Johnson, a vice president at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. "We need a rally in the bond and stock markets to get some demand. Clearly it depends on how the bond market reacts to the Fed next week."
A rate increase would also benefit the dollar by narrowing the gap between American rates and the higher European rates, a disparity that tends to draw short-term investment funds away from the United States.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

I.R.A. Withdrawals
At age 70 1/2, I must begin withdrawing 6.25 percent annually from my I.R.A., which I am going to do in monthly installments. In future years, will I have to withdraw more than 6.25 percent, and how is the amount calculated?
MARTIN MUCKLER, Flushing, Queens 
 The 6.25 percent minimum withdrawal from an individual retirement account is based on a single life expectancy of 16 years for someone who is age 70 1/2. Each year, this life expectancy will decline under one of two methods: term certain and recalculation.
Under the term certain method, your initial fixed life expectancy is reduced by one each year, so that in the second year your life expectancy is 15 years. Under the recalculation method, life expectancy is recomputed every year because it increases over your lifetime, so that in the second year your life expectancy is 15.3 years. Under both methods, the percentage to be withdrawn will be greater in the second and succeeding years.
"You may want to consider naming an individual as the beneficiary of the I.R.A. to extend the life expectancy," because then a joint life expectancy could be used, said Joel S. Isaacson, president of Joel Isaacson & Company, a New York financial planning firm.

Limits on Pension Rollovers
Will the I.R.S. allow monthly pension checks from the New York City Teachers Retirement System to be rolled over into an individual retirement account if the recipient endorses them to the I.R.A.? WILLIAM RAUSNITZ, Arverne, Queens
To qualify for tax-deferred treatment in an individual retirement account, all the money in the qualifed retirement plan must be rolled over in what is called a lump sum distribution. The full distribution must be received within a single taxable year.
"Since payments in this case will extend over more than one year, it will not be considered a lump sum distribution and therefore not eligible for tax deferral," said Stuart Kessler, senior tax partner of Goldstein Golub Kessler & Company, a certifed public accounting firm, in New York. "This rule affects not only a teacher receiving distributions from a qualified plan, but also all taxpayers who elect or are distributed periodic retirement payments."

When Not to Refinance
If one has a mortgage at 10.5 percent and five years left to go, does it make sense to refinance the mortgage at the lower rates now available?
M. SPEIDEL, Forest Hills, Queens
Your early mortgage payments largely covered interest costs, while your current payments mostly repay the principal. For this reason, many real estate specialists say it probably does not make sense to refinance this particular mortgage.
"With five years remaining, there would be substantial closing costs, which would lessen any immediate cash flow savings between the 10.5 percent mortgage and the current fixed mortgage rates of approximately 8.5 percent," said Robert Mascali of the Gioffre, Gioffre & Mascali law firm in Port Chester, N.Y. "Additionally, since most mortgages are self-amortizing and loaded with interest up-front, the cash flow savings would, in fact, be reduced as well."

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Time to Turn Choosy As Utilities Compete

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty 

 BODY:
THAT old gray mare of investing -- the electric utility -- ain't what she used to be. While people can still get utilities' customary slow, sure amble to high dividends, looming competition in the industry means investors may have a different ride altogether.
True, the nation's 100 electric utilities, hammered by interest rate rises, were off nearly 28 percent in early July from a year ago. And true, bargain hunters have since bid them back up, just a bit. No surprises there. Although safe in many ways, utilities have always had interest-rate risk. 
 But never before have they faced competition, and soon they will. Manufacturers, miffed at high electric bills, have prodded regulators in California and elsewhere to dismantle utilities' longstanding monopolies.
"The speed may vary from state to state, but the momentum can't be stopped," Barry Abramson, an analyst with Prudential Securities, said. So, dowdy utilities are getting into fighting shape -- merging, cutting costs and sealing foreign deals.
And, as utilities adapt, so must investors. "Now, it matters much more which utility you buy," he said.
Regional economics is one factor to consider, Wilbur Simao, an analyst with Sterne, Agee & Leach in Atlanta, said. "The major growth we'll see is in the Southeast," he said, forecasting above-average revenue growth of 4 percent a year for Duke Power in North Carolina and 3.5 percent for Florida Progress.
"If a utility can add 50,000 new customers a year, it blunts the edge of competition," Mr. Abramson said.
But the real growth will be abroad, making overseas activity a big plus. Mr. Abramson likes CMS Energy in Michigan; it has three Argentine joint ventures and is scouting more Latin American prospects, and it is building two power plants in India and two in the Philippines.
And Duke Power, Mr. Simao said, has ventures in Argentina and Australia, plus a land-office business in "exporting its nuclear expertise."
But high dividends -- utilities' star feature, often double or more the 2.8 percent average of general equities -- are losing some shine. Utilities now disburse about 80 percent of their profits in dividends. Under competition, however, this payout ratio is likely to fall, for utilities that retain more profits will be better able to finance new ventures. Mr. Simao very much likes Duke's 67 percent payout.
What about costs? "Cost-cutting is the most important thing," said Douglas Fischer of A. G. Edwards. He likes Wisconsin Energy, which expects its work force -- 5,800 in 1993 -- to be slimmer by 1,000 by December.
But some costs cannot be trimmed, Mr. Abramson cautioned, and investors should heed the distinction. American Electric Power in Columbus, Ohio, is low cost "because it has only one nuclear plant, and it was built 20 years ago when costs were cheaper." But Centerior Energy in Cleveland is high cost because its nuclear units are newer, with bills still to pay.
Utilities cannot do much about another matter sharply affecting their fortunes: regulation. California "forces them to buy expensive solar, wind and geothermal power," Mr. Abramson said, "and under pollution rules they can't use low-cost coal." Both policies mean high expenses. But Florida has "reasonable regulation," said Mr. Fischer, who likes the FPL Group, a utility there.
Mr. Abramson favors utilities with many residential customers because "the fiercest competition will be over the big industrial ones." And Mr. Simao likes those with the safety of several power sources -- coal, oil, hydro or nuclear.
Investors willing to comparison-shop should do so soon. Despite utilities' recent uptick, their long fall this year has depressed prices. Florida Progress -- $28.75 a share, up 12.5 cents, at Friday's close -- is a bargain under $30, Mr. Simao says, as is the Public Service Company of Colorado for anything under $28. It closed at $26.75, up 12.5 cents, on Friday.
Investors must find not just good utilities, but ones suited to their needs. With its foreign ambitions, CMS Energy of Michigan is an aggressive company that growth investors might like. Income seekers, though, may like something less bold.
Is all this too complicated? Then defer to the experts who tend $22.6 billion in 81 utility mutual funds. But the funds are changing, too, as both the electric utilities and the phone companies they hold evolve.
"Phone companies used to be safe, regulated investments, too," said John Teall of Lipper Analytical Services. But with the coming information superhighway, he said, "They may make a lot, or they may be road kill."
So, like utilities, the utility funds are adapting. "Many are buying more foreign stocks and real estate," Natalie Andrus of Morningstar said. Others are more conservative. With the funds, the story, too, is more complication, but more choice.
Eric Ryback, manager of the $12 million Lindner Utility Fund, takes a head-on stance. "We redefined utilities to include cable, oil, gas pipeline and phone equipment," he said, "and 35 percent of our assets are foreign."
The growth-minded may like Lindner -- its diversification can blunt interest-rate risk, too -- but its 4 percent to 5 percent dividend may disappoint income seekers. An alternative is the Franklin Utilities Fund, which is 90 percent invested in electrics and yielding 6.3 percent.
"There will be winners, there will be losers" as utilities compete, Mr. Abramson said. For investors, that means dissecting these fated monopolies carefully to tell which is which.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Baker, Vendor, Scalper, Sigh: Strike Costs City Millions

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
From ticket scalpers to hot dog roll bakers to souvenir vendors who sell Yankee or Met knickknacks, yesterday was the beginning of a midsummer nightmare: no baseball, no customers and no cash.
The bartenders, bookies and concession vendors could only get out their calculators and weep. The City Comptroller's office estimates that each home game adds about $2 million to New York City's economy. 
 The 52 home games that remained on the schedule -- 24 for the Yankees, 28 for the Mets -- would have brought in about $104 million, including ticket sales, hotel rooms for the visiting teams and a host of less direct expenditures.
 
Bleak Echoes of 1981
 For small businesses that get by on small slices of the total, a long strike would be devastating. At the Yankee Tavern in the Bronx, around the corner from where the division-leading Yankees were not playing, the owner, Joe Bastone, figured he would lose 40 percent of what he usually takes in during the summer. Around the corner at Stan's Sports Bar, the owner, Lou Dene, was looking back, thinking ahead and worrying.
"The last time they had a strike, in '81," he said, "it took us three years to get back in the black."
The first day of the strike brought layoffs for about 1,500 concession vendors who work at Yankee Stadium and Shea Stadium. They will not be eligible for unemployment benefits until the walkout has been going on for seven weeks, the same as the players. Never mind that the players take home far bigger paychecks.
 
It Makes No Difference
 "We don't distinguish between people who are striking and people who are indirectly affected," said Frederic Buse, the state director of unemployment insurance.
George Pena, who got his job at a Yankee Stadium souvenir stand only three weeks ago, maintained that he was directly affected, no matter what the state labor laws say. "It's billionaires versus billionaires, and I'm living week to week," he said. "I've been to so many places and there's hardly anything out there. It was hard enough to get this, and now I'm out."
Even his boss was worried about making ends meet. "During the off season I sometimes work in a pharmacy," said John Zale, who owns the stand at Yankee Stadium and another at Shea, "but it's tough to get because they know you're leaving in the spring. Who wants a 48-year-old C.E.O. with souvenir experience?"
Economists said that the strike had the potential for costing the city more than if it had been called, say, last year, when neither the Yankees nor the Mets were playing as well. This year, with the Yankees in first place and the Mets in third, the New York economy loses, as employees who lost their jobs cut back on their own spending, crimping other businesses that had depended on them.
 
A Bonanza Squandered?
 And if the strike is not settled before the scheduled end of the regular season on Oct. 2, the city could miss the bonanza of the Yankees in the playoffs or the World Series.
"In a year when the Rangers showed how much a winning team could do for a city, that's almost incalculable," said Mitchell Moss, a professor at New York University, referring to the Stanley Cup champions. "The playoffs are where the high rollers really spend money. The attendance is so good, it's better to have post-season games because there's more money coming into the city. More people were buying Ranger T-shirts in the spring than ever went to Rangers games."
Post-season games would have meant sold-out hotels, said Jeanine Moss, a spokeswoman for the New York City Convention and Visitors Bureau. But she said that the tourist industry would not be hurt if the strike ends before October because regular-season games draw relatively few out-of-town visitors.
For economists, then, the question becomes how Yankee or Met ticket-holders spend the time, and money, they would have spent at the stadiums.
 
Tracking the Money
 "Some people will probably say, 'I'll go to the city anyway, go to the movies,' " said Prof. Joseph Tracy, an economist at Columbia University. "I have a feeling the money will get spent, but people are fairly specific about what they do. When I got tickets for the Rangers for my 9-year-old, if those games had been called off, I wasn't going to bring him in for something else."
Obviously, it is too soon to say whether baseball fans think that way. John Tepper Marlin, the number-crunching economist at the Comptroller's Office, figures that each home game brings in $2.6 million for the Yankees and $1.5 million for the Mets.
About two-thirds is in direct spending -- tickets, parking, hot dogs and so on. The rest is in indirect expenses, a category that covers what the teams and concessions spend on supplies as well as what the employees spend their paychecks on.
Marlin estimated that each dollar spent on a home game generates $1.52 for the city economy, a figure he said was probably a bit on the low side; the conventional wisdom is that each dollar spent at the much shorter United States Open tennis tournament yields $1.59.
It was not immediately clear how much money the city, which collects rent from the two teams, stood to lose.
 
Does Anyone Win?
 Are there any winners? Cable television customers, if they don't mind missing games. Time Warner Cable, which owns or operates cable systems in four of the city's five boroughs, said it would not charge for SportsChannel until the strike ends or the fall basketball and hockey seasons begin. Time Warner offers the MSG network on its standard tier of programs, and officials said a reduction in the basic rate would depend on how much MSG reduces what it charges Time Warner.
Cablevision, which runs systems in Brooklyn and the Bronx, said it would credit customers who call and cancel their premium sports services, including SportsChannel and MSG, which it offers as a premium service. Cablevision officials said there would be reductions for customers who did not cancel, depending on how much SportsChannel and MSG reduce their charges to Cablevision.
Some companies have tried to win business from fans who suddenly have time on their hands. "Has the baseball strike shut out your group event?" asked an advertisement for a cruise line, Spirit Cruises.
Has the baseball strike meant a surge in bookings?
"If we do feel anything, it won't be for a week," said Steve Cruz, the sales manager at Spirit Cruises. "We're sold out this weekend and into next week."

HEADLINE: In His New Play, a Message for Friel's Critics

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DUBLIN, Aug. 12

 BODY:
Brian Friel's new play, "Molly Sweeney," a tale of blindness, both physical and psychological, and, above all, of self-delusion, opened at the Gate Theater here on Tuesday night.
 The philosophical musing that led many critics to fault his last effort, "Wonderful Tennessee," is muted in "Molly Sweeney." And Mr. Friel, who is directing a play of his own for the first time and who has declined all requests for interviews, seems to admonish his critics explicitly in dialogue at the end of the play.
 
 Critics for all major Dublin newspapers have praised "Molly" enthusiastically, and the Dublin theater establishment has already begun to feel that Mr. Friel, generally considered Ireland's best living playwright, is on the way to more acclaim like that accorded his "Dancing at Lughnasa" three years ago here, in London and on Broadway, where it won a Tony. By contrast, "Wonderful Tennessee" closed on Broadway last fall after only a few performances.
 "Molly" is to run for at least two months in Dublin before moving in November to the Almeida Theater in London. The Gate's director, Michael Colgan, has made it clear he would like to see "Molly" staged in New York City, but no deals have been struck.
 
A More Intimate Setting
 Mr. Friel chose the Gate rather than the Abbey, Ireland's prestigious national theater, which produced both "Lughnasa" and "Tennessee," because, he told Abbey officials, the 330-seat Gate was a more intimate house and better suited to his three-character play. The Abbey is almost twice the size of the Gate.
 "Beautifully wrought and exquisitely written," wrote David Nowlan in The Irish Times, the most influential newspaper among Dublin theatergoers. A "deeply moving and heart-rending piece of theater," wrote Lorcan Roche in The Irish Independent, the country's most widely circulated paper.
 The first notices by London critics were also highly favorable. Michael Coveney said on BBC radio, "This has restored Friel, put him back on course." Claire Armitstead of The Guardian called the play "a searing new piece, stuffed with portent."
 "Molly" has only three actors, each of whom tells the story of a 40-year-old blind woman in Ballybeg, Mr. Friel's usual village, and the results of an operation to restore her sight. The actors do not interact with one another; they narrate intermittently to the audience from a darkly colored set by Joe Vanek that seems to reflect Molly's affliction as well as the motives of two men, her husband, Frank, and her surgeon, Mr. Rice.
 The title role is played by Catherine Byrne, who was in the casts of both "Lughnasa" and "Tennessee." Molly, who as a child was never sent to a therapeutic institution because her father was too cheap, has adjusted to her blindness, held a job in a health center, learned the beauty of flowers by smell and touch and taken sensuous pleasure in swimming. In a reference to an exhilarating dance scene in "Lughnasa," Mr. Friel has Molly recall how she danced wildly, though blindly, around her house.
 
A Follower of Berkeley
 Her husband, Frank, played by Mark Lambert, is a garrulous, unemployed pursuer of failed enterprises, like the breeding of Iranian goats, which, because they are in a permanent state of jet lag, must be fed at odd times. Frank adopts Molly's blindness as a new project for his own ego. He also delivers, quite humorously, the playwright's philosophical musings on physical and spiritual blindness, referring to the thesis of the 18th-century Irish philosopher George Berkeley, that nothing exists unless it is actually perceived. In "Tennessee," some critics thought, the philosophy was nailed awkwardly into the dialogue; in "Molly," the philosophy gets laughs.
 The surgeon, played by T. P. McKenna, has a practice that has shrunk since his wife left him. The retinal operation is to revive his career and sense of self-worth. Molly goes along, more out of curiosity than any deep need to regain her vision.
 The operation works; the two men gloat. But Molly finds the visible world frightening: objects seem to jump up at her; the world moves too fast. Gradually, she slips back into sightlessness, which, the experts say, may be physical or may be her refusal to acknowledge what she can see. The men drift off. At the end of the play, Molly seems to express Mr. Friel's mild scolding of those who disliked his philosophizing in "Wonderful Tennessee."
 Recalling the surgeon's questions, Molly says: "Oh my God, he's asking you profound questions about good and evil and about the source of knowledge and about big mystical issues! Careful! Don't make a fool of yourself! And of course all the poor man wanted to know was how much vision I had."
