HEADLINE: Teaching the Next Generation to Give of Themselves;
Family Foundations Take On the Task of Getting the Young Interested in
Philanthropy

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
As children, generations of Rockefeller offspring were introduced to philanthropy with encouragement to put nickels and dimes from their modest allowances in the collection basket passed at church.
 Thousands of families with much smaller and newer fortunes -- the Rockefellers of Main Street -- are also looking ahead to the next generation, making sure the philanthropic spirit is instilled in their children. 
What is at stake is who will take charge of 24,000 family foundations that gave away $6 billion last year, an amount that accounts for 75 percent of all foundation grants.
 Getting young people interested in philanthropy -- whether to create their own charities, serve on foundation boards or decide where to donate money -- is important for another reason, said Dr. James A. Joseph, president of the Council on Foundations, the trade association for the country's 36,000 corporate and private foundations.
 Young people stand to inherit $6 trillion to $8 trillion in the next 30 years, he said, citing a widely used projection, which is based on Federal surveys of household wealth, devised by a Cornell University economist, Dr. Robert Avery.
 To make sure nothing is left to chance for the next generation, philanthropists are adopting a variety of tactics, including these:
 *Ruth Cummings Sorensen, a granddaughter of the philanthropist Nathan Cummings, is shepherding her 8- and 9-year-old children to Israel, where the three will study Hebrew and teach English to Ethiopian Jews for a year.
 *Katie Nord-Peterson of the Nord Family Foundation has composed and illustrated a book of verse for her 4-year-old son, likening philanthropy to an apple tree that gives shade, fruit and seeds to perpetuate its usefulness.
 *The Frey Foundation of Michigan has created an adjunct board with a small budget so third-generation Freys will learn about making grants.
 *A number of foundation leaders, including Peter C. Goldmark Jr., president of the Rockefeller Foundation, act as informal mentors to young people with inherited wealth.
 
New Patterns
 Most family philanthropies are small, with endowments under $5 million. A few, like the Pews of Philadelphia or the McKnights of Minneapolis, are in the billion-dollar class.
 The young will be less tied to conventional patterns of giving than their parents or grandparents, Dr. Joseph said.
 The Florence V. Burden Foundation, in New York, is a case in point. Mrs. Burden, a member of the Vanderbilt family, created the foundation in 1967 to work in two fields, aging and criminal justice. Today, reflecting the wider interests of its third- and fourth-generations, the philanthropy's $13 million in assets also help people with AIDS, battered women and abused children.
 "We support non-pretty issues like child sexual abuse that others won't touch," said Margaret Burden Childs, who is co-chairwoman of the foundation. "In the old days, we just sat and deferred to our elders, without having input. Now there is no idea we cannot bring to the table and we treat each other's ideas with respect."
 Mrs. Burden, who was in her 40's before she was brought into the foundation, does not want the same thing to happen again. So she is already grooming her grandson, Donald Arthur Macdonald 3d, who is 12. "I'm pummeling, I'm flogging him to come visit interesting community organizations we support," she said.
 
'Least Bureaucratic'
 The Norman Foundation, in Manhattan, is another family philanthropy made up of grandchildren and great-grandchildren of Aaron E. Norman, an early partner in the Sears, Roebuck & Company merchandising empire.
 "We have terrible meetings," his grandson, Frank A. Weil, an investment banker and the foundation's president, said with obvious relish. "We interrupt each other, we don't listen sometimes. We are the least bureaucratic foundation around."
 The Norman Foundation was an early supporter of the civil rights movement and continues to promote voter registration and to finance organizations upholding the legal rights of immigrants, people with disabilities, lesbian mothers seeking custody, battered women and environmental advocates.
 "We help people deal with institutions that control their lives but over which they have little control," Mr. Weil said. "That's our theme."
 The Cummings Foundation's interests range far beyond those of its founder, Nathan Cummings, a Canadian-born merchant who built a small food distribution company into the Sara Lee Corporation. Mr. Cummings was content to be an arts patron and to write checks for medical research and Jewish charities.
 The foundation, which has $300 million in assets, has its headquarters in a 100-year-old loft building overlooking Lincoln Center. The headquarters serves as a handsomely decorated showcase for its current involvement in the contemporary arts, health, the environment and multiculturalism.
 
Bringing Family Together
 After Mr. Cummings's death in 1985, his heirs agreed to build on his interests in Jewish life and to encourage spiritual harmony with other cultures. They sent Jewish scholars to visit the Dalai Lama and brought Tibetan scholars to stay at Jewish summer camps in this country. They help rekindle Jewish culture in the former Soviet Union, assisting congregations and religious schools. They support efforts by black and Jewish academics to tackle anti-Semitism.
 Working together in the foundation has brought the widely scattered relatives closer as a family, said Mrs. Sorenson, who is taking her children to work in Israel.
 "I love this work," she said. "I want my children to understand and share, hoping they will get the bug."
 Young people have a different approach to philanthropy than their parents or grandparents, said Elizabeth J. McCormack, who has been an adviser to several generations of Rockefellers, and is chairman of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation of Chicago.
 Older generations were more interested in creating and supporting institutions in research and the arts, she said. "Younger members want to be engaged directly in the activities they help finance," she said. "They want hands-on experience. They are more committed to causes than to institutions."
 
Building Partnerships
 As a teen-ager, Peggy Dulany accompanied her father, David A. Rockefeller, on his trips abroad as the chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank. "Because I was a wide-eyed kid, I could ask questions of government officials or bankers with impunity."
 Then, fresh out of high school, she spent a summer in Brazil working in a health clinic in Rio de Janeiro and lived with a family in a favela, a squatter settlement. "This was my key formative experience," she said, "discovering how people with few material resources used creative energy to survive." It led eventually to her establishing the Synergos Institute, in Manhattan, to generate economic development by building partnerships in 20 countries between poor, grass-roots groups and donors and policy-makers.
 Steven C. Rockefeller, a professor of religion at Middlebury College in Vermont, remembers laboring over an account book for his father, showing his purchases and charitable spending, a family tradition going back to John D. Rockefeller Sr.
 His children have had other reminders of family philanthropy, including the credo of John D. Rockefeller Jr., which they saw carved into granite at Rockefeller Center's channel gardens. Steven Rockefeller recites his grandfather's words from memory: "I believe that every right implies a responsibility; every opportunity, an obligation. Every possession, a duty . . ."
 
The Rise of Consultants
 The younger Rockefellers have access to a staff of philanthropic advisers, headed by Charles D. Terry. But small family foundations often make do with little professional help. Increasingly, they use consultants to avoid the administrative costs of an office or staff.
 They can reach out, for example, to H. Peter Koroff, who describes himself as a "plain vanilla businessman" who has served on 29 community-organization boards. Based in Boston, he advises foundations, corporations and wealthy individuals through his nonprofit organization, the Philanthropic Initiative.
 The Melville Charitable Trust, one of 25 family philanthropies he serves, is based on a fortune from retailing. The foundation concentrates exclusively on fighting homelessness in Connecticut and the directors spent six months with Mr. Koroff's staff immersing themselves in the subject. They put money into preventive measures like job training and work to overcome neighborhood resistance to low-cost housing. They provided a $1.3 million loan for a shelter in Stamford for women and children that offers counseling and other services.
 "We have supported efforts by the homeless to let the public know they are not 'bums' or 'welfare cheats' but real people in trouble," said Frank Melville, the president of the trust, who is devoting his retirement years to the philanthropy.
 His son, Stephen, joined, and other relatives may do so but only if they demonstrate serious interest, he said."That's not our approach," he said, if they are not serious.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S LIFE WORTH?

BYLINE: By ERIC P. NASH; Eric P. Nash is a researcher for this magazine.

 BODY:
AMERICANS LIKE TO BELIEVE THAT THE BODY is not a commodity and that no price tag can be put on a human life. American law, in fact, forbids the selling of body parts. But at a time when few subjects are sacrosanct, legal scholars and doctors are wrestling with such thorny issues as compensation for families of deceased organ donors and financial incentives to increase the supply of available organs. And this leads to the inevitable question: What is the value of a human life?
If a life were seen as the sum of the salable body parts, then in countries where the sale of human organs is not so much legal as tolerated the value of a human being is upward of $300,000. The value of the hormones alone makes each of us a potential $6 million man or woman. 
 It is, of course, still possible for a woman to create a new life without having to pay anyone a cent. But for women who require heavy-duty medical assistance, the cost of another life can range from $1,800 (for artificial insemination) to $36,000 (for another woman to carry the would-be new life; which comes out to $5.35 an hour, based on a 280-day pregnancy) to $800,000 (for six cycles of in vitro fertilization for a couple in which the woman is over 40 and the man has a low sperm count).
It wasn't that long ago -- 1969, to be precise -- when we were all worth 98 cents. That was the value of the body's chemical components: five pounds of calcium, a pound and a half of phosphorous, some potassium, sulfur and sodium and a pinch of magnesium, iron, copper and iodine. With inflation factored in, the value of these chemicals today is $8.84.
Since everything is relative, the value put on your life should anything untoward happen to you depends on the amount of money you make, whether you have children, whether you show incredible promise and so on. In New York, when it's violent, a life can be worth a bomber jacket ($350), a pair of sneakers ($100) or as little as $2. Last June, the kidnappers of Alfredo Harp Helu, a billionaire Mexican banker, reportedly asked for just under $30 million. In rural China, a man can "buy" a wife by offering her "owner" about $1,000.
An ethicist might say you can put a value on human life but you shouldn't. A theologian would say you can't, although a careful reader of the Bible would find that in Ecclesiastes even the preacher noted: "Money answereth all things."

HEADLINE: If You Film It There, the Tourists Will Surely Come

BYLINE: By ANN HORNADAY 

DATELINE: WINTERSET, Iowa

 BODY:
FILMING OF "THE BRIDGES OF Madison County," starring Clint Eastwood, will not start until the beginning of September, but already the denizens of Madison County, Iowa, have their doors, hearts and tills open. The best-selling novel on which the film is based has been a boon for this quaint and stately region of south central Iowa, which has come to enjoy a cult popularity heretofore reserved for Graceland and the grassy knoll.
But with the arrival of Hollywood, the residents of Winterset (pop. 4,200), the county seat, are looking forward to a further economic boom. Given the experiences of other small towns that have served as locations for movies like "A River Runs Through It" (Bozeman, Mont.) and "Field of Dreams" (Dyersville, Iowa), Winterset can only hope that tourists will come with cameras, maps and money long after the production's last Winnebago has fled down Route 169. 
 But first there is money to be made from the production itself. To accomodate the expected infestation of up to 100 movie stars, dolly grips, makeup artists and other members of the cinematic enterprise, the town is putting its best foot forward. Ten residents have offered their houses for rent (no takers yet). Sherry Ellis, the executive vice president of the Chamber of Commerce, has put together a compendium of services ranging from dry cleaning to wallpaper hanging. She also compiled a guide to more than 230 local flea markets and antique shops, "which should be an asset as far as prop hunting goes," she said.
No doubt such hospitality will be worth Ms. Ellis's while: when a major motion picture is filmed on location outside Hollywood, the surrounding area usually reaps millions. During the filming of "Steel Magnolias," for example, $4 million was spent in Natchitoches, La., according to Roger Riley, a professor of recreation and parks administration at Illinois State University who has made a specialty of studying the economic impact of filming on communities. "Dances With Wolves" infused the state of South Dakota with $12 million in production money, and $10 million was spent in British Columbia during the filming of of "Roxanne."
And Winterset has already reaped income from "Bridges." Robert James Waller's book, on the New York Times best-seller list for two years, has increased local retail business by up to 30 percent, according to Ms. Ellis, thanks to thousands of romantic tourists retracing the ill-fated steps of Robert Kincaid, a rugged yet sensitive National Geographic photographer with a penchant for naming trucks, and Francesca Johnson, the lonely farm wife who falls in love with him and then carries a torch for 30 years. In 1993, 40 tour buses wended their way through Winterset, whose previous claim to fame had been that it was John Wayne's birthplace; this year, more than 150 are booked to come through. Bridge-o-mania includes T-shirts, six books by Mr. Waller, a video called "The Magic of Madison County," and Mr. Waller's CD "The Ballads of Madison County," as well as postcards and books of local poetry, all featuring the county's six covered bridges (one of which sits on dry land in a park in Winterset).
Most locals agree that the Northside Cafe is the model for the cafe in which Robert is sneered at by moralistic locals in the book. At the Northside on a recent summer morning, the regular 9 o'clock kaffeeklatsch of Wayne Griffith, Bernard Wight and Jim Breeding seemed optimistic but blase about the impending arrival of stars and film makers. (The role of Francesca was still uncast as of last week, with the top candidates thought to include Meryl Streep, Isabella Rossellini and Jessica Lange.) " 'Cold Turkey' was a good experience," said Mr. Wight, referring to the last movie filmed in Winterset, in 1970, about a town that tries to stop smoking. He doubts however that many people will want to move out for duration, in order to rent homes to the film makers.
Ms. Ellis of the chamber of commerce predicts that most of the cast and crew will rent in nearby Des Moines. "We only have 47 hotel rooms here," she said. (Lindy's Motel, in which Robert Kincaid is said to have stayed while wooing Francesca, has been shuttered, and along with it the chance for some poetic closure.)
Not surprisingly, Winterset is taking many of its cues from Dyersville, about 200 miles to the northeast, where "Field of Dreams" was filmed in 1988. Although that town of 3,500 didn't profit enormously from the actual production (most goods and services were brought in from Dubuque), the Dyersville Chamber of Commerce was prescient enough to buy the merchandising rights to the movie from Universal. "Now we have a full scale T-shirt silkscreening shop," said Jacque Rahe, executive director of the the Dyersville Chamber of Commerce, "and we started the whole souvenir bit." (According to Ms. Ellis, no merchandising deal with Warner Brothers, which is producing "The Bridges of Madison County," has been agreed to yet.)
Since the release of "Field of Dreams" in 1989, Ms. Rahe estimates that at least $2.5 million has been spent by tourists coming to Dyersville. The most popular attraction is the ball field itself, the subject of some contention after the film wrapped. The film's baseball diamond was built on land belonging to two farmers, Don Lansing and Al Ameskamp. When filming was completed, Mr. Lansing kept the baseball diamond on his half as a tourist attraction; Mr. Ameskamp plowed his part of the field back under to grow corn. "My wife, Rita, wasn't too happy," Mr. Ameskamp says. "But I thought, 'Who the heck comes back to a movie site?' "
True to the movie, however, the film makers built it, and the tourists came. When movie fans flocked to the road on which Mr. Lansing and Mr. Ameskamp live, Mr. Ameskamp got the hint. "In a roundabout way, the public politely asked me to put it back," he said, referring to the rest of the diamond. "I decided I made a mistake. I apologized plenty for it."

THE RESTORED "FIELD of Dreams" movie site has attracted up to 50,000 visitors a year, some of whom -- imagine -- turn up without bat or ball. "Rita said, 'We can fix that, by gosh,' " said Mr. Ameskamp. "So for a buck you can rent a ball and a bat and go have your fun out there. Strangers play together like they've known each other all their lives. About this time of the year, it's a constant ball game, morning 'til night."
The closest counterpart to "The Field of Dreams" baseball diamond in "The Bridges of Madison County" is the Roseman Bridge, the covered bridge where Robert and Francesca conduct their most important trysts. Wyman R. Wilson, a Farm Bureau Insurance representative, has lived next to the Roseman Bridge for 24 years. "I met with the 'Field of Dreams' people in Dyersville, to get an idea of what to expect," Mr. Wilson said. "I'd like to think I have a better handle on it than they did," he said in a reference to Mr. Ameskamp and Mr. Lansing.
Last June, Mr. Wilson opened the Covered Bridge Shop, a tiny tumbledown souvenir shop barely visible through the trees. Inside can be found Roseman Bridge caps, T-shirts, teddy bears, as well as mugs, key chains and cards. A "genuine piece of the Roseman Bridge, when Robert Kincaid and Francesca Johnson were there," sells for $7.50. (The wood was harvested when the bridge was renovated in 1992.) A vial of Roseman Bridge sand costs $1.
Last month, Mr. Wilson got the news that the film's director, Bruce Beresford, had decided against casting the Roseman Bridge as the Roseman Bridge. (This month, Mr. Beresford dropped out of the movie; a Warner Brothers spokesman said no new director had been signed as of last week.) Apparently, the Roseman Bridge cannot hold the heavy equipment necessary for filming; a steel bridge is being shedded over with wood to approximate the old Iowa covered bridge. Will that affect his plans for the shop? "I'll tell you what," he said cagily, "the mere fact that they're doing the movie isn't going to hurt me any." Indeed, the first two weeks after opening his shop, Mr. Wilson's guest book boasted hundreds of names.

 Because the cult popularity of the book is already so high, expectations are that "The Bridges of Madison County" will exceed "Field of Dreams" in local profit. "This is going to be very big," said Dr. Riley, who is undertaking a study of the economic impact of the production of "The Bridges of Madison County" and the resulting tourism on Winterset and its environs.
According to Dr. Riley, after "Deliverance" was released in 1972, the film fostered a flourishing raft and expedition business in Rayburn County, Ga., where it was filmed. (And "Deliverance" was a film about people being attacked on a scenic river.) After "Close Encounters of the Third Kind" was released in 1977, the number of visitors to the Devils Tower National Monument in Wyoming increased by 75 percent. Even more significantly, he added, "When they did a survey 12 years later, more than 20 percent of visitors said their initial source of interest was the movie."
Since "A River Runs Through It" was filmed on the Madison, Gallatin and Jefferson rivers in Montana (standing in for the Blackfoot River), the increase in fly fishers to the area has been palpable. "I get a number of calls from people who say 'Oh, we saw where "A River Runs Through It" was filmed in Bozeman,' " said Racene Friede, the Bozeman, Mont., convention and visitors' bureau coordinator. "And they're interested in seeing the actual Blackfoot River." Loni Stimac, the director of the Montana film office, said, "The new Meryl Streep movie, 'The River Wild,' which is about whitewater rafting, was filmed here. We've spoken with the whitewater rafting companies in the area and told them to expect an increase when the movie comes out" in September.

 So important have movie-induced tourism dollars become that the Great Smoky Mountains Railway in Dillsboro, N.C., has sued Warner Brothers for lost tourist revenue on "The Fugitive." As it turns out, the railroad agreed to let the studio film the train crash scene in Dillsboro on the condition that the Great Smoky Mountains Railway be given a screen credit; the credit did not appear. Orville Coward, the attorney for the railway, estimated that at least $10 million in revenue was lost to the railway, which is a tourist attraction as well as a working railroad. A Warner Brothers spokesman refused to comment on the suit.
Over the next five years, Dr. Riley and Carlton Van Doren, a professor at the department of recreation, parks and tourism sciences at Texas A&M University, will trace economic development Madison County. Dr. Riley predicts that the tourists pulled by "Bridges" "will have a significant impact not only on Winterset and Madison County but also Iowa."
Dr. Riley is also interested in how Winterset residents feel about the coming invasion. "What you usually see is an initial euphoria," he said. "Then, after a while, they start getting ticked off. We'll survey them every two or three years to see if this euphoria changes to tolerance and then if tolerance changes to actual resentment, which has been documented in other tourist destinations like Florida."
But Iowans may be too repressed (or plumb nice) to harbor actual hostility toward tourists. "I suspect that what will happen in Winterset is that euphoria will gradually change to indifference," Dr. Riley predicted.

An article on page 9 in today's Arts and Leisure section about plans to produce a film based on the book "The Bridges of Madison County" reported that, as of last week, a direc tor had not been chosen and one of the major roles had not been cast. SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2412 words

HEADLINE: Reviving a True Classic on West 42d Street

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
ONE DOES NOT SIMPLY VISIT THE NEW Amsterdam Theater. One journeys there. Yes, it can be reached easily enough, through an entrance in the base of a small office building at 214 West 42d Street, just west of Times Square. Yet in the ripe lusciousness of its ornament, the sinuous twining of its floral forms, the generosity of its public rooms and the sheer spectacle of its volume, the 91-year-old Art Nouveau landmark is far removed from the tattered, brazen, razor-edged city outside.
Few people, however, emerge from the long-deserted playhouse without thinking that this distance ought to be bridged, that there must a way to restore the cavernous ruin to the enchanted garden it once was. 
 It may prove to be the theater's salvation that one of those people was Michael D. Eisner, chairman and chief executive of the Walt Disney Company.
His guide was the architect Robert A. M. Stern, who heads the design team for the planned refurbishment of 42d Street, a project in which he had been trying to interest Disney for some time, without success.
On the spur of the moment one Friday evening in April 1993, the Disney chief accepted Mr. Stern's invitation to a tour of the New Amsterdam. The next morning, they trooped through the crumbling interior, where plaster chunks had fallen scabrously amid colonies of wavy-capped white fungi.
"Walking through the New Amsterdam was like going through a dark, damp and musty cavern," Mr. Eisner recalled, while Mr. Stern likened it to a scene from "Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom."
Mr. Eisner said he was "astonished that this once-grand theater could have become so run-down."
"Yet I sensed the grandeur that it once had," he said, "and I thought, 'Wouldn't it be marvelous if this theater, and this whole district, could be brought back to their former glorious stature.' "
Ten months later, Mr. Eisner was back in New York, this time at City Hall, to announce Disney's plan: lease the New Amsterdam from New York State for 49 years, restore and modernize the two-balcony house with the help of a $21 million low-interest government loan, increase seating to 1,810 from 1,600 and stage live productions, either new shows or adaptations like the enormously successful "Beauty and the Beast."
No decision has been made yet on what to do with the devastated shell upstairs that was once a 700-seat rooftop theater called the Aerial Gardens.
And Disney may yet back out of the entire deal if the cost runs much higher than the current $29 million estimate. The Tishman Urban Development Corporation and the architectural firm of Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates are now readying detailed plans that will arm Disney by year's end with enough information to make a decision.
Should Disney go ahead, audiences might assemble under the New Amsterdam's 80-foot-high dome in September 1996 for the first time in 14 years. Until then, The New York Times will revisit the theater from time to time to record the project as it unfolds.

 "It's a great spectacle house and Disney will use it for spectacles," said the architect Hugh Hardy. "In that way, it is a tremendously benign re-use: for big, popular, schmaltzy entertainment. It wasn't built for high art."
But it was built -- every square inch of it -- to dazzle the theatergoer. The architects were Henry Beaumont Herts and Hugh Tallant (designers of the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the Lyceum Theater on West 45th Street, among other landmarks) and the artists were legion.
"When you walk in, you realize why this theater was so prominent," said Laurie Beckelman, chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission. "It was pure fantasy. That's why you went to the theater. This kind of atmosphere no one could create in your daily life. It was like walking through the mirror to Wonderland."
And Disney aims to re-create that sensation. "The experience we would like our guests to have is that the New Amsterdam is beyond their expectations," said David L. Malmuth, vice president for corporate real estate at the Disney Development Company. "Bringing it back to its former beauty will be astonishing in itself."
Who needs mouse ears? After all, the New Amsterdam already has 16 peacock sculptures by St. John Issing, each one 5 feet high, perched in vines around the proscenium arch. Popeyed monkeys, industrious squirrels, bashful pelicans and vigilant owls nestle in the green-glazed terra-cotta balustrades on the grand staircases by Thorbjorn Bassoe. From the newel posts peer the haunting visages of Shakespearean characters.
In the lobby, Siegfried does violent battle with a ratchet-backed, gape-jawed dragon in one of a dozen friezes by Roland Hinton Perry. Other panels show the languorous Titania snuggling with an ass-headed Bottom, Macbeth confronting the witches and Hamlet encountering his father's ghost.
Surprises abound. Over the entrance to the foyer lurks "Progress," an allegorical female figure who cradles a sailing ship in her arms, with stars and sun rays behind her. In the reception room at the back of the auditorium is a fireplace practically large enough to live in. No less ample is the smoking room downstairs, whose elliptical colonnade is linked by intertwined ribbons of stone.
Complementing the abundant details are remarkable spatial qualities. Most theaters have only a narrow passage at the back of the orchestra but the New Amsterdam has a grand promenade with a rounded series of vaults and arched openings through which tantalizing vistas can be glimpsed.
Thanks to the stylistic curves of Art Nouveau and the absence of supporting pillars under the balconies, there is an organic wholeness to the auditorium, a seamlessness in the junction of walls and ceiling.
Above the proscenium is a richly allegorical 45-foot-wide mural by Robert Blum and Albert Beck Wenzell. Nudes, knights and a small menagerie are used to depict Poetry, Truth, Falsehood, Melancholy, Romance, Love and Death. Above the mural, the dome begins.
Up near the dome, at the top of the second balcony, the oxygen seems thinner and the height is dizzying. Yet the stage appears almost close enough to touch. This sensation of intimacy is achieved through the use of overscaled decorations, which tend to make the giant room seem smaller.
Impressive as its design may be, there is even more to the New Amsterdam -- a spirit so strong that it is sensed even by government officials, who are supposed to be unsentimental about such things.
"That's the magic of the place -- that feeling of time," said Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project Inc. Her agency, a subsidiary of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, took over the New Amsterdam in 1992.
"You can't wipe that away," she said. "The ladies in bustles. The fat old men with their gleaming tuxes and cigar smoke. The chorus girls. You've got to be able to feel its ghosts. You should be able to walk in and remember."

 Architectural remembrance cannot be too literal, however. "You have to do a restoration in a way that feels authentic," Mr. Hardy said. For instance, he noted, if lighting levels for the house matched those of 1903, modern audiences would think it far too dim because "our appetite has been so increased."
As another example, if public circulation were authentically re-created, patrons holding the cheaper seats in the second balcony would enter by a small door on 41st Street, avoiding the lobby, foyer and promenade. Such economic segregation will not do today.
Also, there is no way for disabled patrons to reach the balconies. And there are not nearly enough washrooms for women. At the time the New Amsterdam was constructed, the powder room was literally that -- a place to powder one's nose.
"The society in which that theater was built isn't ours," Mr. Hardy said.
True enough, although the review in The New York Times of "A Midsummer Night's Dream," the production that opened the New Amsterdam in October 1903, bears a striking parallel to what contemporary critics said about the abundance of special effects in "Beauty and the Beast," after its April premiere at the Palace Theater.
The Times described "an unceasing showing of the things that mechanical skill could accomplish," which "in many ways charmed and delighted the senses of the listeners, though it sometimes seemed almost as if it overburdened and wearied them."
Florenz Ziegfeld moved his Follies to the New Amsterdam in 1913 and the revue played almost every year until 1927, accompanied by Ziegfeld's Midnight Frolic in the Aerial Gardens upstairs. In those days, the theater's ornamental abundance was easily matched by the talent on or behind the stage. One single edition of the Ziegfeld Follies, in 1918, involved Irving Berlin, Eddie Cantor, W. C. Fields, Marilyn Miller and Will Rogers, with scenic decorations by Joseph Urban.
The New Amsterdam was the last legitimate theater on 42d Street in 1937 when it bowed to motion pictures. The side boxes, which bore designations like heliotrope, violet and buttercup, were removed. (They are to be restored by Disney.) "A Midsummer Night's Dream," this time the Warner Brothers version, inaugurated the theater's 45-year career as a movie house.
The Nederlander Organization, one of three major theater owners in the city, acquired the New Amsterdam in 1982, anticipating the rebirth of 42d Street under a government-sponsored project in which four enormous new office towers would be constructed at the Times Square crossroads, beginning in 1985.
But the theater renovation went seriously awry in 1983, when work was begun in the Aerial Gardens for Peter Brook's production of "La Tragedie de Carmen."
"They discovered that the steel was rotten up there," Mr. Hardy said. "So they opened up the roof to look at the steel. The engineer said, 'You've got to replace the steel.' The Nederlanders said, 'Forget it,' and all work stopped. That's when the rains came in."
"It wasn't benign neglect," Mr. Hardy said. "They walked away from the whole project."
Not at all, said Robert Nederlander, president of the organization. "What we were really waiting for was the city or the state to proceed on 42d Street," he said. "They ran into a whole series of problems. This caused a delay of a substantial period of time. Producers at that time were unwilling to put shows into the New Amsterdam."
Meanwhile, he said, the Nederlander Organization spent "significant amounts of money" to maintain the structure in the years it was empty.
Whether the Nederlanders turned their backs or were paralyzed by the failure of the redevelopment plan to materialize, there is no question that the New Amsterdam deteriorated on their watch.
"The main theater was ready for a production in 1982 and a couple of years later it looked like it was ready to be demolished," Ms. Beckelman said.
Jack L. Goldstein, special assistant to the president of Actors' Equity Association and a theater-preservation advocate, said that "the darkest hour for me was when I walked in there and was shocked to see mushrooms growing."
In August 1992, the state took control of the New Amsterdam and set about to stabilize the building. The roof was patched, the facade was repointed, windows and doors were sealed, rubble was carted out, a net was built to catch plaster falling from the dome and a giant gas-fired heater was installed in the orchestra pit to dry out a decade's worth of dampness. Workers had to shovel snow off the roof last winter after the drains froze.
Mr. Malmuth, of Disney, remembered his first visit. "I was both excited and terrified," he said. "You walk through and think, 'Isn't it fantastic?' It doesn't take much imagination to picture opening night in your mind's eye. But it will take so much work to get there."
One of the biggest changes to the auditorium would be the expansion of orchestra seating into the promenade. This plan was approved by the landmarks commission a dozen years ago when it was proposed by the Nederlanders, said Brian Hogg of the commission staff, who is reviewing the project.

SOME CHALLENGES ARE AS plain as the word "ASBESTOS,"
printed in swirling Art Nouveau letters on the fire curtain. The presence of the fire-retardant material, once a selling point, is now an environmental anathema. But Ms. Robertson said thankfully that "the percentage of asbestos is low."
Far more worrisome is structural integrity. "There's a lot of rotten steel up in the air," Mr. Hardy said, meaning the parapets and main roof trusses overhead. "It's rusted away to the point where it no longer has stability and tensile strength." The replacement cost is already roughly $1 million more than anticipated, he said.
Cost is not the only potential deal-breaker. Disney will not proceed unless there are some substantial new neighbors on 42d Street. The fate of the office towers, construction of which was officially postponed two years ago, "does not affect us one way or the other," Mr. Malmuth said. "But some life on those corners is important to us."
"The judgment we were trying to make was whether this was the right time to make a bold move," he said. "Those are tough calls to make because you could be very wrong."
Ms. Robertson said Disney's timing will be just right. Two weeks ago, the state reached agreement with the office tower developers for an interim refurbishment plan. She said the state is in "serious negotiations" over 42d Street sites with four entertainment companies, including the Tussauds Group of London, the owners and operators of Madame Tussaud's wax exhibition.
The New Victory Theater, opposite the New Amsterdam, is to reopen next year with performances and programs for young audiences. The Warner Music Group is understood to be interested in the Selwyn Theater, several doors west, as a studio. And eight teams, including one composed of Disney and the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, responded to the state's request for developers interested in building a hotel on Eighth Avenue, between 42d and 43d Streets, where pornography now reigns. Disney is also pursuing the idea of a "megastore" nearby, but ultimately it is only one of many players on 42d Street.
"One of the exciting and scary parts of the project," Mr. Malmuth said, "is the recognition that we won't control what we call our guests' experience beyond the theater entrance. It's a new thing for us -- to be part of a real city."

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Black American Artists In Paris and Beyond

 BODY:
Sites in Paris and Nice identified with black American writers and artists will be the focus of a tour offered Sept. 16 to 29. The tour, called Black Paris Plus, will include three walks designed for the group by Dr. Michel Fabre, author of "The Unfinished Work of Richard Wright," who also founded the African-American Studies Center at the Sorbonne. Dr. Fabre has planned walks through Montparnasse and the Latin Quarter in Paris and on the Riviera, visiting sites linked to Wright, other writers, like Langston Hughes, Countee Cullen and James Baldwin, the entertainer Josephine Baker, the jazz saxophonist and clarinetist Sidney Bechet and others. Visits to clubs, museums and the Casino at Monte Carlo are also scheduled.
The tour has been organized by Accent Tours of New York, in conjunction with the Concorde Group, a New York travel consulting company. Denine Rodney, vice president of Accent, who is to accompany the tour, said that Professor Fabre would take part in some part of the visit to Paris. 
 Land arrangements, including deluxe hotels, cost $5,927 a person based on double occupancy; with an economy class round trip on Air France, the price is $6,227. Further information: Accent Travel, (212) 944-2069.

HEADLINE: SNET and Its Union, Tennis and 2,500 Jobs

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
IS a public utility company justified in paying eight tennis players a half million dollars for a three-day exhibition in New Haven when it is in the process of eliminating 2,500 jobs in the state?
No, say officials of the union that represents most of Connecticut's telephone company workers, but, yes, says a spokesperson for the Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation, better known as SNET. 
 The exhibition event, known as the SNET Classic, is scheduled for Aug. 24, 26 and 27 at the Connecticut Tennis Center, near the Yale Bowl. And while Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and New Haven city officials have hailed the event as a boon to the area, others have questioned the wisdom of further enriching a tennis multimillionaire like Steffi Graf when, they say, the money could better be spent to prevent ongoing layoffs.
"Where do they get the half-million dollars to pay the tennis players when they're eliminating so many jobs?" asked Daniel C. Keating, president of the Connecticut Union of Telephone Workers Inc., which represents the vast majority of SNET's employees. "To us, it's strange."
 
The Women's Lineup
 Graf, the world's top-ranked women's player has won more than $1 million in prize money this year and is in a field that includes five other players in the top 20: Lindsay Davenport, Jana Novotna, Gabriela Sabatini, Mary Joe Fernandez and Zina Garrison Jackson.
All eight players -- Brenda Schultz and Chanda Rubin are also appearing -- will receive guarantees, along with bonuses depending on how well they do in the single elimination event, which is not part of the Women's Tennis Association tour. Tournament officials would not say how the $500,000 will be distributed, but Graf is almost certain to receive the largest individual share.
During a 28-player exhibition tournament in Mahwah, N.J., last month, Graf received "appearance money" of nearly $400,000, along with her winner's purse of $40,000, for playing four matches in four days. The 25-year-old German star's overall annual income has been estimated at $10 million, with most of the money coming from commercial endorsements.
SNET is also a sponsor of the Volvo men's tournament, which opens tomorrow at the tennis center. That tournament, which was moved to New Haven from Stratton Mountain, Vt., in 1990, offers more than $1 million in prize money, including $152,000 to the winner. The 56-player Volvo tournament, which runs through next Sunday, includes Andre Agassi, Boris Becker, Ivan Lendl, Michael Stich, Petr Korda and defending champion Andrei Medvedev. SNET is also a sponsor of the annual Greater Hartford Open men's professional golf tournament.
 
Rallying in Protest
 As for the SNET Classic, Mr. Keating said that members of his union would hold rallies outside the tennis center for all three days of the women's tennis event. "We hope to have as many as a few thousand members picketing to let people know how we stand," he said. "We're not trying to hurt the city of New Haven, but we want our position known."
A spokeswoman for SNET, Beverly Levy, said she sees nothing incongruous about sponsoring the SNET Classic while at the same time eliminating jobs. "The tournament is good for our business," Ms. Levy said. "It's an ideal advertising and marketing opportunity for SNET. And over the long term, it can help make our company stronger and create more jobs."
Under a restructuring plan, SNET has eliminated 1,000 jobs over the last year -- including both management and union-covered positions -- and plans to eliminate another 1,500 by January of 1996. "The downsizing is necessary for us to survive because of our competition," Ms. Levy said. "And that competition drives us to be more aggressive in our approach. We've got to win over more customers, and the tennis tournament is one way to do it. It helps give us exposure, and it also enables us to showcase a lot of our products right at the site."
 
Focus of Media Attention
 Whether the Volvo tournament and the SNET Classic do indeed benefit the New Haven economy is arguable. The events do help focus some media attention on the city, but, contrary to predictions by the Volvo promoter, Jewell Productions Ltd. and boosters of the event, interviews with restaurant owners, hotel managers and other business people indicate that few of the spectators venture into the downtown area. In general, the local business people say, residual economic benefits from the Volvo tournament have been nil.
Indeed, the only proven beneficiaries, apart from concessionaires and part-time employes at the tennis center, have been the city of New Haven and the state, which receive a percentage of ticket revenues. On the other hand, the tennis stadium, the second-largest in the United States after the Louis Armstrong Stadium at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadow, Queens, home of the U.S. Open, was built with state bond money at a cost of approximately $15 million. But for more than three years it sat unused, except for the Volvo tournament, which, including the qualifying event, lasts just nine days.
This summer, there were finally some signs of life. Since July 2, five concerts have been held at the center, and three more are scheduled -- with Julio Iglesias on Aug. 28, Alan Jackson on Sept. 1 and James Taylor on Sept. 2. Previously, there had been only one concert at the stadium: Crosby, Stills and Nash in June of 1992.
"We're now on our way to amortizing the cost of the stadium," said Mitch Truwit, the executive director of the Tennis Foundation of Connecticut, the nonprofit organization that operates the center. "It's a beautiful venue for concerts and the sound is great. And we're hoping to have many more concerts."
 
Concern About Concerts
 Some residents of the Westville section of New Haven, a quiet residential neighborhood close to the tennis center, had expressed concern about the staging of concerts, citing potential noise and ancillary problems attendant to outdoor musical events. But Mr. Truwit said that the five concerts held had not evoked any complaints. "We've had no incidents of any kind, and there've been no complaints," he said.
Mr. Truwit, who is also executive director of the Baseball Foundation of Connecticut, which serves as a liaison between Yale University and the New Haven Ravens minor league baseball team that plays at Yale Field across from the tennis center, said the foundation would like to see other events staged at the tennis stadium.
"We'll probably have some events held there during the International Special Olympics next year," he said. "And we've also considered boxing and beach volleyball."
While the foundation plays a role in all events held at the tennis center, the tennis tournaments and exhibitions, along with the concerts, are put on by Jewell Productions. Jewell is headed by Jim Westhall, who has been involved with the Volvo tournament since 1971, and Ben and Beau Segal, the father and son who operate the Oakdale Musical Theater in Wallingford.
Plagued with problems during its first few years in New Haven -- bad weather, a rash of early round upsets of high seeded players and a cracked stadium court -- the Volvo had a relatively smooth run last year.
There will be day and evening sessions starting tomorrow, with the final scheduled for next Sunday.
Ticket prices range from $10 tomorrow to $62 for choice seats at the final. Prices for the women's event also start at $10, but top out at $28 on the final day.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Tighter Credit? London Market Yawns

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
IN London's financial markets, it is now considered a sure thing. Having nursed its economy back to some semblance of health, and with signs of possible inflation flickering on the distant horizon, Britain will undoubtedly begin raising interest rates in the next several months.
With the benchmark base rate brought down over the last two years from 12 percent to its current 5.25 percent -- its lowest level in 20 years -- Britain's imminent about-face on monetary policy is hardly a surprise. The United States, whose economic cycle has been running six months to a year ahead of Britain's, began raising rates in February to head off inflationary pressures. The rate-cutting cycle in continental Europe, which has lagged a year or more behind Britain's, is itself drawing to a close, as last week's rate rises in Italy and Sweden demonstrated. 
 Equity markets generally do not like rising interest rates, which tend to siphon capital off into bonds and other rate-sensitive investments. But in this case, analysts said, the London stock market is likely to shrug off the shift to tighter credit, in part because it has been expected for so long that when it comes it will be yesterday's news.
The Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares closed on Friday at 3,142.3. The index has rallied modestly from just over 2,900 at the beginning of July, after plummeting from a high of 3,520.3 in February, when the Federal Reserve in the United States began nudging rates up.
Analysts said that in addition to having already factored in the effects of a rate rise on the order of half a percentage point before the end of the year, the market has benefited from the solid earnings performance of many British companies.
"Our view has been and remains that in the period from the beginning of February, when the Fed moved, the U.K. equity market has already discounted the interest rate outlook," said Joe Rooney, an equity strategist at Lehman Brothers in London.
"From that point of view, the market won't and shouldn't discount the same event twice over," Mr. Rooney said. "Having made the transition to an earnings driven market, we feel comfortable with the market after this correction."
Indeed, while the London market was jarred somewhat by the unexpected rate rises in Italy and Sweden last week, it remained considerably more calm than its counterparts in continental Europe.
The London market rose four points on Friday, while the DAX index in Frankfurt tumbled 30.6 points, or 1.42 percent, and the CAC-40 index in Paris fell 31.98 points, or 1.57 percent.
Mr. Rooney said the London market could hit 3,250 by the end of the year, and 3,340 12 months from now.
"The U.K. is a very tricky one at the moment, but I'm erring on the optimistic side," said Richard Davidson, an equity strategist at Morgan Stanley in London. "The U.K. is quite clearly going to raise short interest rates before the end of the year, but we have a good earnings, valuation and productivity story."
Mr. Davidson said that the London stock market's price-to-earnings ratio of 15.7 based on projected 1994 earnings still makes it a good buy, as does its dividend yield of 4.4 percent, especially given the low levels of inflation and interest rates. He said retail stocks, such as Storehouse, W. H. Smith and Next, as well as utilities, which have been strong performers, would be attractive plays on the continuing recovery.
Britain has been enjoying a steady if unspectacular recovery. The economy is expected to grow this year by 2.8 percent, and by a similar amount next year. Inflation stood at 2.4 percent in June, with only spotty evidence of any significant upward pressure on prices.
Still, the Bank of England and the Conservative Government seem determined to break Britain's long history of allowing inflation to roar out of control during recoveries. The Government has said it wants to keep inflation below 4 percent.
"The current picture of output growing above trend and inflation continuing to fall remains favorable," the Bank of England said in its August report on inflation. "But if official interest rates were to remain unchanged over the next two years, then it is probable that inflation would gradually rise to a level above the mid-point of the target range."
Those with a positive outlook have history on their side, according to research done by Sushil Wadhwani, an analyst at Goldman Sachs in London.
Mr. Wadhwani looked at the performance of the London market in five previous periods in which rates turned up after hitting a trough. In all five cases -- in 1972, 1975, 1977, 1984 and 1988 -- stocks fell in the month following the upturn in rates. But, in four of the five cases, equities had gained ground a year later. In three of those cases, the gains were substantial, including 22 percent gains in 1984 and 1988.
Merrill Lynch, in a similar study of market performance in 1977, 1984 and 1988, found that equities declined an average of 6.6 percent in the three months following an upturn in rates but rose an average of 25 percent in the first 18 months following the upturns.
"It is not of course the interest-rate rises themselves that cause the equity market to rise," Merrill Lynch said. "Each episode was also associated with strong earnings or dividend growth, which is exactly what we forecast for 1994 and 1995."

HEADLINE: Business Diary

BYLINE: By FRANCIS FLAHERTY 

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Peat Marwick Settles S.& L. Charges, and U.S. Keeps Hunting
 The folks at KPMG Peat Marwick, the nation's fourth-largest accounting firm, got something they understand last week: a number. Dogged like other accountants by uncertain liability for audits of failed savings and loan institutions, the firm settled Federal charges over the crisis for $186.5 million -- a tab of $116,563 for each partner. The payment, mostly covered by insurance, is "an intelligent business decision," said Jon C. Madonna, the firm's chief, and the deal did add up nicely when compared to some other Federal S.& L. settlements by the Big Six. But the Government's figures are pretty nice, too. Federal agencies have collected $2 billion from accountants, lawyers and other professionals from the S.& L. debacle -- half from four big accounting firms. "And the program is still young," a Government spokesman said, with hope. The payments are funneled to institutions made insolvent by the S.& L. crisis.
 
At P.& .G, Profit Follows Flub
 The lesson may be to stick to soap. Tarnished by a $102 million loss in its third quarter from bad derivatives investments, Procter & Gamble regained some shine last week, announcing net earnings of $406 million in its fourth quarter. At 56 cents a share -- up 12 cents from the comparable quarter last year, excluding adjustments -- the results impressed analysts and spurred P.& G.'s chief, Edwin L. Artzt, to write the tale's epitome. "This was a good year," he said, "and if not for the derivatives it would have been a great year." Even more notable: P.& G. achieved its results despite sales not much higher than a year ago.
 
Internet: New Way to Spend!
 Credit card issuers rejoiced last week when some young, intrepid entrepreneurs successfully conducted the first secure retail transaction on the Internet, the global computer network. "Secure" is the key word; without a practical way to keep credit card numbers confidential, businesses will balk at turning the Internet into a major marketplace. Using a scrambling technique known as data encryption, though, tiny Net Market Company of Nashua, N.H., has solved the problem. And what was the pioneering purchase? A compact disk, "Ten Summoners' Tales," by rock musician Sting. Price: $12.48 plus shipping.
 
Disney Turns Interactive
 Built on imagination, the Disney company had nonetheless envisioned little future for itself on the information superhighway. Until last week, that is, when the company announced a venture with three Baby Bells -- Ameritech, BellSouth and Southwestern Bell -- to offer video services to homes. The venture is still vague, with no word on how ownership or profits will be split, but the Bells' reach to 50 million customers in 19 states makes the deal's potential broad. That is, if Michael Eisner, Disney's chairman, has really discarded his well-known disdain for the superhighway and believes, as Tinkerbell would surely hope.
 
Valdez Catch: $287 Million
 About 10,000 Alaskan fishermen reeled in nearly $287 million in damages from Exxon last week, courtesy of a Federal jury deliberating over the Valdez oil spill of 1989. But the compensatory award was much closer to Exxon's damage estimate of $113 million than to the fishermen's $895 million goal -- and that's how the paid parties saw it. "It's not what I wanted," said the plaintiffs' lead lawyer. But it's not over till it's over, and the jury in Anchorage will next consider whether Exxon should pay punitive damages for the mishap. The plaintiffs are asking for a whopper: $15 billion.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Rockwell, Russia in Air Plan
 Faster and safer are an odd mix in the world of transportation, but that's what Rockwell International and Russia's aviation-research agency expect from their plan to modernize the nation's air-traffic control system. Announced in Moscow last week, the project will eventually trim hours from flights between the United States and the Far East, and enhance safety by enabling planes near or over Russia to rely upon both Russian and American navigational satellites. True, it's yet one more story about the cold war's demise, but there's a kicker. Rockwell is getting $4.7 million in financing -- from the Defense Department. For Kenneth A. Medlin, a Rockwell executive vice president, the deal represents "defense conversion at its very best."
 
China Lands a Boeing Deal
 When Boeing announced it would invest $100 million in a Chinese plant to make the tail sections of its most popular plane -- the 737 -- the reasons were several and self-evident. One, China is a big Boeing fan, with 52 of the nation's 79 plane purchases last year coming from the Seattle manufacturer. Two, China is looming ever larger on Boeing's ledgers, with 14 percent of the company's 1994 deliveries destined for that fast-emerging market. And three, Boeing competitors Airbus Industrie and McDonnell Douglas are also energetically investing in China and chatting up the Chinese. Uncounted was Wichita, Kan., where the 737 tail sections are currently made. But to union complaints that last week's deal hurts American workers, Boeing just pointed to reasons 1, 2 and 3.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Greenspan's Secret: Stories
How do Alan Greenspan and his Federal Reserve colleagues divine where inflation is headed? Complex computer models? Reams of statistics? Forecasting formulas? In part, yes, Mr. Greenspan told Congress last week, but there are also . . . stories. The Federal Reserve chairman used a dressed-up phrase, "detailed readings of firm behavior," but he essentially meant stories -- stories from companies, trade groups and others about rising prices. Changes in the American economy and statistics' assumptions about economic relationships makes mere data insufficient for decision making, Mr. Greenspan said.
 
Prices Up, Sales Down, Be Wary
Alan Greenspan's reliance on stories (see above) was vindicated last week, when the Government's July figures for producer prices and retail sales were released -- and at once were labeled misleading. Producer or "finished goods" prices rose half a percentage point, but the rise came mainly from coffee and gasoline prices, not from the prices that make the inflation-wary Federal Reserve snap to. And while retail sales fell one-tenth of a percentage point in July, the drop did not mean consumers wanted to buy less. It just mirrored auto makers' difficulty in restocking car lots that buyers had picked clean last spring. Fittingly, the deceptive data just "adds to the ambiguity" of whether the Fed will raise interest rates, said one economist.
 
Companies Tapped for Wiretaps
 The electronic frontier needs sheriffs like any other, and the F.B.I. says bills introduced in Congress last week will give it the technological draw on cyberspace bandits. Under the proposals, telephone and cable companies must alter their networks to make wiretapping easier, and they will get $500 million in Federal money to pay for the modifications. Company executives were reluctant to be deputies in the deal, however; one testified that $500 million is "severely underestimated." The true costs are "very, very difficult" to come by, agreed the F.B.I. director, Louis J. Freeh. But, he warned, "I certainly know what the cost of not proceeding will be."
 
Info Highway: No Traffic Jam?
 It all depends. That's the answer to the commercially pressing question of how many people ride the Internet, the global computer network. Cyberspace demographers often say 20 million to 30 million, but when Network Wizards, of Menlo Park, Calif., counted 3.2 million computers on the Internet in a survey last week, doubts arose. Not over the machines, but over how many people use each of them. About 10 people per machine is a common assumption; it underpins the 20 million to 30 million estimate. But some revisionists now say 3.5 people per machine, and some say 5 to 10. Riding on it all: how many potential buyers pass by the electronic storefronts that businesses are now scrambling to build.

LENGTH: 1108 words

HEADLINE: The Nation: The Odds on Health Care;
Going From a Good Bet to (Maybe) Even Money

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
HARRIS WOFFORD is a soft-spoken, unabashedly idealistic, professorial sort of man. When he ran for the Senate in Pennsylvania in a special election in 1991, whatever small national reputation he may once have enjoyed had long since faded. He appeared to have little chance against Dick Thornburgh, his Republican rival, a former Governor and United States Attorney General.
But he struck political gold. His television commercials contained one memorable sentence -- "If criminals have the right to a lawyer, I think working Americans should have the right to a doctor" -- and it melted Mr. Thornburgh's lead like butter in August. Mr. Wofford won, and politicians everywhere scrambled to get on the "right" side of the health care issue, whatever that was. 
 Among those who followed the trail blazed by Mr. Wofford was Bill Clinton, the Governor of Arkansas, whose campaign for the Presidency was already under way by the time of the Wofford-Thornburgh race. Health care became a key issue in New Hampshire, hotly debated by Mr. Clinton, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and former Senator Paul E. Tsongas, among others. Words and phrases like "managed care" and "spending caps" and "mandates" soon assumed a prominent place in the political vocabulary. By the time Mr. Clinton took office in January 1993, he was pledging a cheaper, more comprehensive system of health insurance that would cover everyone and could never be taken away.
The public was never united behind Mr. Clinton, but his was a popular initiative at first. Senators of both parties spoke of the need to control health care costs and to extend the safety net -- some with messianic intensity, like Jay Rockefeller, the West Virginia Democrat, other with dutiful bipartisanship, notably including the Senate minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas. At first, no one wanted to be enrolled as an opponent of reform.
As recently as September 1993, 56 percent of the voters in one poll said they approved of the President's health care plan, with only 24 percent disapproving. Critics walked gingerly around the edges of the debate, talking of refinements, not of outright opposition.
 
Getting Perplexed
 But as Americans learned more about what Mr. Clinton planned, as they followed (or ignored) the deliberations of the various panels, study groups and committees, as they listened to the politicians and the experts talk and talk, they got more and more perplexed. In a survey taken by The Washington Post and ABC News late in June, for example, fully 53 percent of the respondents said that they opposed the President's plan; yet more than three-quarters said that they favored a guarantee of universal coverage, which is precisely what Mr. Clinton has been trying for months to wrest from a recalcitrant Congress.
So what happened? How did the President lose his momentum? How did health care legislation -- widely described as the major social innovation of the decade -- turn from a pretty sure bet into a questionable proposition?
Many things have contributed to the change, but one of the most important, surely, is the growing perception that this is a liberal undertaking.
When big businessmen, as epitomized by the Business Roundtable, still seemed interested in backing Mr. Clinton, because they thought he could help them control costs, that gave the measure a centrist coloration. But cost control faded as a central objective, employers were increasingly identified as the source of the needed revenues, and businessmen turned away from the President.
Then, too, the improvement in the economy -- for which voters, curiously enough, seem to give Mr. Clinton little credit -- has caused people to be less fearful about losing their jobs, and with them their health insurance. That, some White House officials believe, has taken some of the urgency out of the debate. Public attention has turned to crime and other urban problems.
Credit or blame for the change goes also to the work of the armies of anti-Administration lobbyists, backed by Harry and Louise on the nation's television screens, and to Mr. Dole's decision to fight the President, and to the sheer complexity of the issue. Detail is always the enemy of public persuasion, and Mr. Clinton was unable to keep the focus on the broader, unifying points.
Then, too, the slide in Mr. Clinton's overall popularity and the growing public impression of him as a beleaguered and accident-prone President must have hurt the backing for his health care plan as well.
For whatever reasons, many voters began talking last winter about their antipathy toward new government bureaucracies and their fears that they would lose their right to choose their physician or that medical care would be rationed. They talked less about the horror stories -- friends and relatives who were unable to buy medical insurance or who had lost what they had.
 
Changing Their Course
 The politicians heard the change of tone and rapidly altered course. No longer do members of Congress fear, as they did a few months ago, that if they do nothing before adjourning this fall, they will be in trouble at the polls. Stop rushing, many of the Republicans said in debates last week; this is too complicated; better to wait and get it right. Even outright opposition no longer seems like a dangerous political course.
When voters were asked last month in a New York Times/CBS News poll what they would do if their Representative voted "no" on health care, there was no clear pattern. About four of 10 said they would be less likely to vote for the Representative, but just as many said it would make no difference, and 16 percent said that they would be more likely to support the Representative.
In the House and in the Senate, the balance is shifting slightly toward the moderates -- people like Senator John Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, and Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee, who would do something, but not everything Mr. Clinton still wants, to change the health care system. Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, introduced legislation whose goal is to cover 95 percent of Americans by the year 2000.
At the moment, with the White House reeling from its unexpected defeat on crime legislation, to say nothing of its Whitewater difficulties, everything is nevertheless still to play for. There is no consensus, no widely accepted conventional political wisdom. But this, from a fence-sitting Senator, comes close: "Passing something is better politics than passing nothing, but not by much, and only if it is something that looks like a modest if honest effort."

HEADLINE: The World: Hands Off;
In Mexico, U.S. Hones Art of Laissez-Faire Diplomacy

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
ONLY last fall, as the United States anguished over the uncertainties of a new economic partnership with Mexico, the cry in Congress was: How can we propose free trade with a neighbor that does not hold free elections?
The Clinton Administration answered emphatically that the North American Free Trade Agreement would enable the United States to push Mexico more quickly and effectively toward a fuller democracy. It prevailed, and Nafta is now a central fact of commerce and investment between the two nations. 
 Yet a week before the Presidential election that will provide a crucial test of Mexico's democratic progress, the role of the United States in this country's politics has at the very least been extremely discreet. A House resolution drafted months ago with a roaring demand for "full-scale international observation" of the vote finally passed on Monday with a watered-down expression of hope that political reforms will be successful.
As the United States gropes to find a proper balance for its sometimes conflicting foreign policy concerns of democracy and trade, it has largely left Mexico to find its way to a more democratic political system by itself. In part, that is a consequence of the many signs that Mexico may indeed be finding its way. In part, critics say, it is the mark of a foreign-policy team that can't seem to see past Haiti.
Yet it is also the product of a growing American understanding that deepening economic ties are a more complicated diplomatic tool than pressure, and that Mexico, for all its underdevelopment, is not El Salvador.
"There is a recognition that you really can't do that much about Mexico," said Peter Hakim, who is President of the Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington-based think tank. "Despite Nafta, there is a big difference between big countries and small countries on this. I think U.S. politicians have come to realize that they can't really influence it, that the changes have to come from within Mexico."
In a broad sense, the United States is unquestionably a bigger part of the Aug. 21 vote than it has been of elections in the past. With Nafta in place, gringo eyes are on Mexican politics as never before. Hundreds of accredited American "visitors" will watch the vote, and American political parties have helped pay for the thousands of Mexicans who will act as formal observers. More important, it is taken for granted that a significant reprise of the blatant fraud that characterized elections here in the past would not only prompt Mexicans to take to the streets but would prompt American investors -- whose money is critical to the Mexican Government's ability to cover its huge trade deficit -- to sell their Mexican stocks.
Some American officials say that what Washington has come to understand is simply that Mexico's stake in the expanding economic relationship with the United States is overwhelming. It would be counter-productive, they say, to bluster about what the Mexican Government should do when a gentle reminder of the two countries' overlapping interests tends to be sufficient. "When I speak publicly," the United States Ambassador to Mexico, James R. Jones, said, referring to his rare applications of public pressure on the Mexican Government, "I put it in terms of the economic consequences of something, because that's more important to them than the reaction of our Government."
As ever, the limits on United States involvement in Mexican political affairs are defined by the deep nationalism of a country that still often views its neighboring superpower more as an enemy than a friend. While many Americans assumed that such feelings would wane with the implementation of the trade accord, they have tended to be surprised this year.
Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat who heads the House Foreign Affairs Committee's Subcommitee on Western Hemisphere Affairs, thought it entirely appropriate when he and the House majority whip, David Bonior of Michigan, proposed a non-binding resolution that criticized past Mexican elections and called for a wide opening to foreign observers.
"Given the new economic partnership between the United States and Mexico, people in Mexico cannot expect everything to be the same," Mr. Torricelli reasoned. "There is some ascending right to be heard. Whether the process is free and fair is a legitimate international question. There is some ascending right to be heard."
But when Mr. Torricelli came to be heard in Mexico, he was almost immediately branded non grata. Newspaper editorials attacked him, politicians across the ideological spectrum shunned him, and the Government all but ignored him.
One State Department official described the threat of such a backlash as "a very real, immutable limit to what we can do in Mexican politics." But critics of that policy tend to see nationalism as a convenient excuse for inaction that effectively supports Mexico's governing party. Like most of its predecessors, they say, the Clinton Administration has put Mexican stability above democracy by accepting the Institutional Revolutionary Party's determination of when the latter threatens the former. Mexico is not El Salvador, by this argument, because the United States wouldn't challenge its new partner on such a basic issue as political change and doesn't have a constituency in the United States demanding that it do so.
American officials protest that Mr. Jones, for example, vigorously pressed President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and his aides to put aside the idea of a military solution to the peasant rebellion that broke out on Jan. 1 in the southern state of Chiapas. Citing another important, albeit benign, intervention, they note that within 24 hours after the assassination of the governing party's presidential candidate on March 23, the Clinton Administration also opened a $6 billion line of credit to Mexico to block a run on the peso.
But as the Mexican Government and political parties have engaged in furious debate over legal reforms to insure a fair election, the United States has been almost invisible. During a visit to Mexico City in May, Secretary of State Warren Christopher openly prodded his hosts to allow foreign election observers. But some American officials described that step as an attempt to guard against instability by diluting the potential for a leftist outcry against perceived fraud.
The Clinton Administration has insisted that it will recognize whoever wins a vote that is widely seen as fair. But with the governing party's replacement candidate, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, well ahead in most opinion polls, the more important test of a commitment to democracy may be how much fraud the United States will tolerate.
"The U.S. Government is quite content to see an election process go forward that it thinks the PRI will win," said Medea Benjamin, the head of a delegation of American "visitors" to the election. "What is important is what the U.S. Government will do after the election if there is evidence of significant fraud. I think it still has to prove to the Mexican people that it is as concerned about Mexican democracy as it is about the Mexican stock market."
