HEADLINE: South Korea Sees North's Move as Helpful

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Long distrustful of its neighbor to the north, South Korea reacted positively but cautiously today to what analysts here called a surprisingly broad agreement reached in Geneva by the United States and North Korea.
Government officials and analysts here said that while the accord could defuse tensions on the Korean peninsula, it might end up being only another in a series of seemingly promising agreements made by North Korea that are never carried out. The South Koreans also said the agreement in Geneva failed to explicitly address one of South Korea's central concerns: that there be inspections of nuclear sites in North Korea in an attempt to determine whether it already has nuclear weapons. 
 Despite some misgivings, South Korea is expected to play a central role in providing North Korea with modern nuclear reactors, costing about $4 billion, as part the accord. The offer is expected to be made on Monday by President Kim Young Sam in a speech to commemorate the 49th anniversary of Korea's liberation from Japanese colonial rule.
In a joint statement issued in Geneva this morning, North Korea agreed to forgo future production and processing of plutonium that could be used in bombs. In return, the United States promised to arrange for North Korea to receive modern light-water reactors, which produce less plutonium than the graphite-moderated reactors now being used. The two nations also agreed to take steps to establish diplomatic and economic relations.
 
Focus Turns to Neighbors
 With North Korea and the United States having resolved some of their differences, attention will now turn to whether North and South Korea can resume their dialogue. They had been planning an initial summit meeting on July 25, but it was postponed after the death of Kim Il Sung, the longtime North Korean leader.
Analysts expect that South Korea's President, in his speech on Monday, will try to restore a more positive atmosphere and will reiterate the South's readiness to engage in dialogue with the North, though he will stop short of calling for the summit meeting to be rescheduled.
But if there is to be any thaw in North-South relations as a result of the Geneva accord, it was not evident here today. North Korea's official news agency continued to issue diatribes against the South. And the South Korean police again clashed with students who wanted to hold a pro-North Korean rally in honor of Korea's liberation from Japan.
Perhaps not to upstage President Kim, and perhaps out of caution, the Government here issued only a brief statement today in which it said it took a "positive view" of the Geneva agreement because it set forth the principles for future negotiations. The statement, issued by the Foreign Ministry, also said Seoul would closely cooperate with Washington to "completely resolve" the North Korean nuclear issue.
"We also consider that North Korea has taken a step in the right direction to insure past, present and future nuclear transparency," it said.
 
Wanted Inspections Missing
 Several analysts and newspaper editorials here expressed disappointment that the agreement did not explicitly call for inspections of two suspected nuclear waste dumps that could hold clues to the question of whether North Korea has reprocessed plutonium and therefore might now have atomic bombs.
Robert L. Gallucci, the chief American negotiator, said in Geneva today that the accord includes language that, while not explicit, commits North Korea to agree to an inspection of those sites, but North Korean officials disputed this.
It was Pyongyang's refusal to allow inspections of those sites that prompted it to threaten to withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty in March 1993, setting off the nuclear crisis. Unless this issue is resolved, commentators said, South Korea will still be troubled by the threat of a nuclear attack.
"It's a positive step forward, but it doesn't really take care of the one fundamental concern that we have," said Kim Kyung Won, president of the Seoul Forum for International Affairs and a former Ambassador to the United States.
 
Distrust Behind Skepticism
 Another cause for skepticism here is the deep distrust of North Korea and a belief that it does not live up to its agreements.
"We've had such bad experiences with North Korea in our long negotiations," said Cha Young Koo, a researcher at the Government-sponsored Korea Institute for Defense Analysis.
About two and a half years ago, North and South signed a broad agreement calling for economic cooperation, cultural exchanges, communications and other measures. The two signed a declaration calling for the denuclearization of the Korean peninsula. But neither agreement amounted to much in practice because the two sides could not agree on detailed adherence.
The Geneva accord also includes some diplomatic risks for Seoul. There is some fear here that a reconciliation between Pyongyang and Washington could result in Seoul's being isolated. That clearly seems to be the intention of North Korea, which has all along insisted on dealing with Washington alone. However, Washington consulted frequently with South Korea during the Geneva negotiations to make sure its ally did not feel left out.
The Pyongyang-Washington agreement to move to normalize relations could also mean that Japan and European countries will also move to recognize North Korea. That would undo some of the leverage South Korea gained by establishing relations with Russia and China, both of which had been North Korea's two main allies.
As for the summit meeting between North and South Korea, Seoul's position is that because North Korea postponed the meeting, North Korea should restart the process. In addition, Seoul wants to see Kim Jong Il, the son and presumed successor of the late Kim Il Sung, officially be given the position as head of state. It is therefore likely that some lower level dialogues will resume first.
Analysts here said that the Geneva agreement shows that Kim Jong Il -- or whoever is running North Korea these days -- is placing a high priority on economic affairs. But others cautioned that it was too early to say how, or whether, Kim Jong Il is departing from the policies of his father, who had set in motion the negotiations that led to today's agreement.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
North Korea's Foreign Policy
 GENEVA, Aug. 13. (Reuters) A senior North Korean official said today that he expected no foreign policy changes under Kim Jong Il.
The statement, by Deputy Foreign Minister Kang Sok Ju, appeared intended to counter speculation of a power struggle or major policy change. He said North Korea remained committed to unifying the Korean peninsula and easing tension over its nuclear program.
Mr. Kang, who concluded the agreement with the United States today over Pyongyang's disputed nuclear program, asserted that Kim Jong Il had overseen all aspects of Government policy for 20 years before the death last month of his father, President Kim Il Sung.
Asked about North Korea's chain of command and how he consulted with Pyongyang, he said all policy was discussed democratically by the officials concerned before being sent to a "higher destination" for approval.
"Our dear leader comrade Kim Jong Il has been overseeing the overall affairs of our country -- political, military, economic and foreign affairs -- for as long as 20 years," Mr. Kang said. "So I think from that perspective you can make your own judgment as to how we got the final approval."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
A Tense Year in Korea Over Nuclear Standoff
 By The Associated Press
 
March 3 -- International Atomic Energy Agency resumes nuclear inspections in North Korea for the first time in more than a year.
 
March 19 -- Talks between Korean rivals collapse.
 
March 21 -- Clinton Administration announces Patriot missiles will be sent to South Korea and begins work on United Nations resolution to apply economic sanctions on North Korea.
 
May 14 -- North Korea's official news agency reports that it has begun replacing fuel rods at an experimental nuclear reactor without international inspectors present to determine whether plutonium has been extracted.
 
May 28 -- U.N. team leaves after its proposals for monitoring the reactor refueling are rejected.
 
June 3 -- The C.I.A. says North Korea has many keys to building a nuclear weapon and probably has already completed one or two; U.S. presses for U.N. sanctions after inspectors find the country erased vital evidence about its nuclear capability.
 
June 13 -- North Korea announces it will withdraw from the I.A.E.A.
 
June 14 -- U.S., Japan and South Korea pledge sanctions against North Korea.
 
June 15 -- U.S. announces it will seek mandatory arms embargo against North Korea.
 
June 16 -- Former President Jimmy Carter, visiting North Korea, says it agrees not to expel international inspectors as long as "good-faith efforts" are made to resolve dispute; China says it will stand by a three-decade-old mutual defense agreement with the North.
 
June 17 -- Mr. Carter says Clinton Administration is ready to give up the effort to persuade the Security Council to impose sanctions. Mr. Clinton later says "nothing has changed" in his policy of pursuing sanctions.
 
June 18 -- North Korea proposes summit meeting and South Korea accepts.
 
June 22 -- Clinton Administration announces North Korea has agreed to freeze its nuclear program and the U.S. will suspend its push for economic sanctions.
 
June 27 -- The White House announces U.S. and North Korea will reopen high-level talks over the North's nuclear program July 8.
 
June 28 -- North and South Korea agree to hold their first summit meeting July 25-27 in Pyongyang.
 
July 8 -- U.S.-North Korean talks begin in Geneva; North Korea's leader, Kim Il Sung, dies of a heart attack at age 82.
 
July 9 -- Mr. Kim's death announced; Geneva talks are suspended and summit meeting canceled.
 
Aug. 5 -- U.S.-North Korean talks resume in Geneva; both sides report no breakthroughs but remain hopeful of progress.
 
Aug. 12 -- South Korea proposes talks with North on reuniting 10 million separated family members on the divided peninsula.
 
Aug. 13 -- U.S., North Korean negotiators reach agreement in Geneva on steps to ease nuclear tensions and establish diplomatic relations. Further talks are scheduled for Sept. 23 in Geneva.

The offer may be made in speech tomorrow to commemorate the 49th anniversary of the end of Japanese colonial rule. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE;
Excerpts From the Debate in the Senate on Health Care Legislation

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from statements made yesterday on the Senate floor in the fifth day of debate over the health care bill, as transcribed by The New York Times from a broadcast on C-Span:
 
 
STATEMENT BY SENATOR COHEN
 In the fall of 1992 Senator Dole, Senator Chafee, myself and several others approached the majority with a list of what we called 11 points of commonality between Republican and Democratic proposals. And we met with the majority leader's task force on more than one occasion to press for these reforms, on which there was broad-based bipartisan agreement. And they were significant steps that we believe could and should immediately slow the growth of health care costs and increase access to quality health care for millions of Americans. And frankly, Mr. President, we were rebuffed. We were told that the reforms were not comprehensive enough and anything short of comprehensive reform would not do. 
 Mr. President, let me say very frankly it was a stall; it was a stonewall. I believe it was a political tactic to delay any reforms until the elections were over in November. That's what happened.
The Democratic majority wanted a perfect issue and not an imperfect solution, a perfect political issue at that time because we had broad-based agreement and we could have passed something.
So here we are, two years later, still talking about the same principles on which we know there's broad-based bipartisan agreement. Portability, no pre-existing condition exclusion, affordable coverage, standard access, emphasis on prevention, cost containment, administrative simplification and stronger efforts to combat fraud and abuse. We all agree on those provisions, and they're part of the Dole-Packwood bill; they're also part of the Mitchell bill.
The problem is that the majority leader's bill goes far beyond those areas of agreement and I believe would drastically alter the delivery of health care in this country.
Now I've listened to the debate and I must tell you, I have been moved by the recitation of the tragic stories that have affected and have afflicted so many thousands and perhaps millions of Americans who lack the kind of health insurance coverage the current system fails to provide. And I can't agree more that we must do something -- everything we can -- to correct the situation for the families who are suffering on a daily basis.
But what's most tragic of all, Mr. President, is that virtually every single situation that has been so poignantly described in this chamber during the past portion of four days would have been helped immediately -- would have been helped immediately by the proposals set forth by Senator Chafee, myself and others. All of those situations would have been covered, virtually all, maybe one exception. . . .
And we're told that the President of the United States is now pursuing a 51-vote strategy. Mr. President, let me suggest that may -- may -- and I'll talk about that at length in a moment -- it may be in the political interests of the President to pursue that strategy. I think it's bad for the country. And let me just suggest why.
 
Questions of Strategy
 If we are to pursue a 51-vote strategy in this chamber, or 52-vote and perhaps one or two more, I can assure you that the very next thing that's going to happen after the elections in the fall, we on the Republican side expect to gain several more votes; it may be one, it may be two, conceivably could be ten, but whatever the number -- I don't want to alarm the chairman of the Finance Committee, just a moment, but let's say anywhere from one to five, let me compromise -- that we expect may come to our side. In any event, what will take place, whatever the margin is of increase, I can almost assure you, from the day we come back into session next January an effort will be made to undo the legislation that passes by a 51-vote strategy.
And the President will sit in the White House, and he will exercise his veto, and depending upon how many members are added to this side of the aisle, he may be successful. He will spend the next two years of his Administration vetoing legislation. . . .
Mr. President, I -- I have a profound sense of -- of apprehension about any strategy that seeks to ram something through on a party-line basis on something this important because there are people of good will on both sides. There are many good things in the Mitchell amendment, and there are many good things in Senator Dole's proposal as well -- in the Dole-Packwood proposal.
The decisions we make in the -- in the coming weeks are going to have a profound consequence for every single American. It's going to control the future direction of one-seventh of our nation's economy. And we shouldn't even begin to contemplate enacting sweeping reforms unless they're broad-based and bipartisan.
 
STATEMENT BY SENATOR MOYNIHAN
 Mr. Mitchell, the majority leader, said today that issues raised by bipartisan moderates such as by Senator John H. Chafee appeared to be negotiable.
And of course they are.
I think we all need to ask ourselves what particular form of ineffectiveness, of almost entropic decline in our capacity to produce results. Whether it's institutional, systemic, I don't know.
Twenty-five years ago, a Republican President -- you can say that now -- proposed a guaranteed income which twice passed the United States House of Representatives and died in the Senate.
There were those who said it was too much and those who said it was too little. And those who made the calculation that -- my goodness! -- if a Republican will do this, think what the next Democrat will do.
That same Republican President proposed universal health care and employer mandates. And I'm standing three feet from the Republican manager of the bill here -- Senator Packwood -- who introduced it. And again the calculation was made: Some thought it too much, but on our side some said it was not enough. We can get more. Think -- if that man would give us this, think how much more we get.
And got nothing.
Now that is the record: We got nothing. A quarter-century of impasse, and I think it's only the spirit in which he speaks that we will move on. Because, you know, we're not -- we are not getting better in some respects. . . .
We've not been looking to our affairs very competently, and we continuously, continually miss these opportunities. There is an element of the neurotic in this: the element of the individual who repeatedly states one desire and behaves in a way that thwarts that desire -- a very common neurotic pattern. I don't have to tell a person of the, of the Senator from Maine's insight with these matters.
I thank him for his address. I yield the floor.
 
STATEMENT BY SENATOR WELLSTONE
 Madame President, let me start off or start out with the obvious, because I think it's been lost in some of the debate. The obvious point is that the Mitchell bill, which represents a lot of hard work on the part of the majority leader, nevertheless, for a very long period of time, leaves out some 14 million Americans. It's not a universal coverage bill.
And most people who were following this debate and who think about their own lives understand that when 14 million people are left out, that could very well be them. . . .
But the fact of the matter is, whereas the President promised affordable health care, the majority leader's bill still leaves all too many families, when we get beyond this care and these services, but other services people need and other health care they need, still paying up to 20 percent of their family income. . . .
The majority leader has really made an effort to bring a bill to the floor, and I applaud him for that. But then I see discussion of some of these other efforts. Yesterday we had the Boren-Nunn-Domenici-Bennett bill introduced and I just would have to say, and maybe later on this is a point of debate, there's no universal coverage -- 90 percent of Americans, still talking about 24 million men, women and children without protection. That's what C.B.O. is going to say. . . .
Madame President, then I read The New York Times today and I get the sense that the majority leader's bill, which is not universal coverage, which is not the same benefits that we have, which is not employers contributing 70-some percent, which is what we have, may yet be even further weakened. We've got all sorts of other discussions about how to water down the bill and weaken the bill while at the same time, over and over and over again, the vast majority of people in the country keep saying they're for universal coverage. The vast majority of the people in the country keep saying they're for employers paying their fair share.
Madame President, these pieces of legislation or alternatives, which further weaken the majority leader's bill, which is quite weak in present form -- I, myself, have made no decision whether I can support this bill in present form, much less if it's weakened. I think then support would be very problematical -- do nothing about the trend. 1980, 24.2 million Americans uninsured. 1992, 38.9 million. We can't be talking about legislation that keeps things as they are or weakens the proposal, given the kind of trends we see within our country. . . .
Today, I sent a letter to the majority leader, actually with my colleagues, Senator Simon, Senator Feingold, Senator Moseley Braun, Senator Metzenbaum and Senator Harkin. And what -- and I will just read from a couple of paragraphs.
"As we continue to support your efforts to achieve portable health care coverage for every American, we want you to know that we are gravely concerned about several aspects of the bill you've introduced. Further movement away from the goals of universal affordable coverage would cause us to question even more seriously our ability to support the bill."
 
Strengthening the Bill
 Mr. President, I want to make it clear that we meant those words, and we'll be meeting with the majority leader at 11 o'clock Monday. I won't read from the rest of this letter but I will tell you, Mr. President, that for myself -- and I think I speak for some of my colleagues, although they have very important amendments as well -- we're ready to come to the floor with amendments to strengthen this bill. . . .
There is no reason why we can't achieve universal coverage for everyone sooner by having an earlier time line for insurance reforms insure getting an employer mandate by 1999 if necessary. We'd like to find a way to get to what was the commitment we made earlier.
Number two, Mr. President, we ought to improve the contributions that employers make. If the United States Congress, if in our case our employer contributes 70 percent of the premium, then we should have an amendment that says that as a matter of fact in this health care reform plan, that should be exactly the way we move to finance it. The same quality plan, as good as what we have. . . .
But I want to say today on the floor of the Senate that we have now reached the point where the majority leader has brought out a bill. It's got some fundamental weaknesses. He believes it's a first step. I hope it will be a first step. Right now, I'm not sure. But what I do know is that some of these alternative efforts just simply weaken it and water it down to the point where I guess all of us can have a fancy name and an acronym and say we've done something great, but certainly it doesn't live up to once we what said -- what we once said, which is: We ought to make sure that each and every citizen, each and every man, woman and child, can afford humane, decent health care for themselves, their loved ones and their children. . . .
If this bill gets further weakened, if this reform effort is hijacked, then there are some of us in the Senate who I think are going to fight as hard as we know how to.
And certainly I view this meeting with the majority leader on Monday as being important. It is quite one thing to present your very best as a reform effort and say it's a step forward. It is quite one thing to say don't make the perfect the enemy of the good. I agree. It's quite another thing to get to the point where you've got a piece of legislation that's so weakened, so watered down, so hijacked, so blocked by all those huge interests that have poured all that money into senators and representatives, with all their power and clout, with the people who need this reform the most left out. It's like the people who need the change don't have the power and the people who have the power don't want the change. When we reach that point -- and I think we're close to it -- I think there are a number of us in the Senate that will draw, quote, the line in the sand on that.

GRAPHIC: Graph/Photos: "THE PLAYERS: Struggling Toward Consensus"
 
William S. Cohen
 Republican of Maine. A moderate, Mr. Cohen is a member of the self-described "mainstream coalition" seeking to find a compromise bill that can attract a bipartisan majority in the Senate. He comes from the same state as the majority leader, Senate. George Mitchell, and the two have a cordial reliationship.
 
Daniel Patrick Moynihan
 Democrat of New York. The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Mr. Moynihan has bipartisan credentials, having served in both Republican and Democratic Administrations before coming to the Senate. His committee steered away from many elements in the Clinton Administration's initial health care proposals, and the legislation it produced, after further modifications, formed the backbone of the proposal under debate in the Senate.
 
Paul Wellstone
 Democrat of Minnesota. A liberal freshman Senator who taught the politics of protest at Carleton College. He favored a health care bill providing universal coverage entirely financed by the Government through a Canadian-style single payer plan, something with little support in the Senate. A member of the Labor Committee, which passed a more liberal health care bill than the Finance Committee's, he wants to strengthen the Mitchell bill.

HEADLINE: Republicans Uneasy About Giuliani Effort on Crime Bill

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's offer to help President Clinton revive the crime bill in Congress showed no immediate results yesterday, even as there were signs of dissatisfaction from the Mayor's fellow Republicans.
On Friday, the Republican Mayor appeared with the Democratic President in Washington and Minneapolis and promised to lobby House members who had scuttled the bill. But yesterday, one of the members closest to the Mayor, Representative Susan Molinari of Staten Island, said no amount of cajoling would change her position on the bill as written. 
 Ms. Molinari, a Republican, said she would support only a tougher bill that included such provisions as an amendment that would allow prior convictions of sexual offenders to be admitted more easily as evidence in court.
And even though Ms. Molinari and her politically established family on Staten Island were vital supporters of Mr. Giuliani in his mayoral campaigns, Ms. Molinari expressed dissatisfaction that the Mayor had sided so visibly with the President.
"It was a little disconcerting to see him on the stage with the President when he gave one of his most partisan speeches yet," she said of the Mayor's appearance beside Mr. Clinton at the National Association of Police Officers in Minneapolis on Friday.
Mr. Giuliani spent the day yesterday visiting friends and family on Long Island. A spokesman, Manuel Papir, said the Mayor did not want to comment on his lobbying, including whom he had called or what he had said. On Friday, aides said the Mayor would call 8 to 10 members of Congress.
Ms. Molinari said the Mayor had not contacted her -- either before flying to Washington or since returning. Asked about the Mayor's offer to lobby, she said, "To be frank, I would have expected a little more communication up to this point."
In light of Ms. Molinari's remarks, it was unclear how much success Mr. Giuliani could have in winning over votes for the bill.
The only other member of the city's 14-member delegation who voted against the bill was Charles B. Rangel, the influential Democrat from Harlem who has differed with Mr. Giuliani on such matters as the location of an economic empowerment zone and the merger of the city's three police forces. Mr. Rangel did not return a telephone call yesterday seeking comment.
 
Risks and Benefits
 For Mr. Giuliani, the first Republican Mayor of New York in a generation, the highly visible appearance with the President and his promise to rally support for a bill he praised as good for the city held both risks and benefits.
In a city where Democrats outnumber Republicans 5 to 1, Mr. Giuliani could reap the rewards of national exposure on a law-and-order issue. One aide said yesterday that the Mayor's office had been pleased with news accounts of Mr. Giuliani's appearance beside -- and even applauding -- Mr. Clinton.
At the same time, Mr. Giuliani could risk offending his Republican colleagues in New York and Washington, who have fought the Democrats over the crime bill.
In Washington, party leaders did not criticize Mr. Giuliani openly. Tony Blankley, a spokesman for Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip in the House, said it was understandable for the Mayor -- or any other elected official -- to support a bill that would have a local benefit.
"We understand he's representing the City of New York," Mr. Blankley said. "There was a lot of money being offered up in the package, and it's perfectly reasonable for the Mayor to do what he needs to do for his constituents."
Still, he said, the Republicans in the House had to worry about "the proper national approach."
 
'An Embarrassing Cousin'
 But other Republican officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said yesterday that some party officials were dismayed by Mr. Giuliani's coziness with Mr. Clinton.
One Republican who would speak for attribution, Jay Severin, a political strategist, said it made sense for Mr. Giuliani to demonstrate over and over for Democratic New Yorkers the fact that "he is not a right-wing Republican."
The difficulty is that the effort could turn him into "an embarrassing cousin" within his own party, Mr. Severin said. "This is a very fine line," he said.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat who was one of the bill's chief sponsors, praised the Mayor yesterday. He said Mr. Giuliani's crime-fighting credentials as a former Federal prosecutor could help sway members of the house in New York and its suburbs, Republicans and Democrats.
"We only need to switch eight votes," Mr. Schumer said. "If the Mayor can switch just one or two, that would be a godsend."

HEADLINE: Canadian Gem Scheme Leaves Americans Holding the Stones

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13

 BODY:
He had bought old coins in the 1970's, when investments in something solid seemed the best hedge against rampant inflation. Dr. Kane Zelle, now a retired gynecologist from Tequeste, Fla., held on to the coins for two decades. But in January 1993 he received what appeared to be a very tempting offer in a letter from a Toronto gemstone trading company.
There was just one hitch: the buyer would purchase the coins only if Dr. Zelle first bought two emeralds. A few days later, Dr. Zelle mailed checks for $6,750 and $5,400 to the gemstone company, Gheko Fox Yamoto. But a week before he was supposed to sell his coins and emeralds, the company disappeared, and an appraiser told him that his new emeralds were worth only $900. 
 "I'm old enough I should never have been suckered into this thing," said Dr. Zelle, who is 77. "I'm really embarrassed by it."
Dr. Zelle was not the only person to be duped. Hundreds of people across the United States were caught up in what the authorities described as the largest telemarketing scam in Canada.
 
$35 Million Fraud
 By early 1993, Canadian officials were already investigating Gheko Fox Yamoto, which operated out of an office building in Markham, Ontario, 10 miles north of Toronto. But it was not until a cluster of complaints from Pennsylvania in March of that year that the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and the Metropolitan Toronto Police fraud squad joined the Federal Trade Commission and the United States Postal Inspection Service in the inquiry.
Last month, a Federal grand jury in Harrisburg, Pa., indicted 25 people and eight corporations, all affiliated with Gheko Fox Yamoto, as well as nine other people and two other corporations on charges they bilked up to 1,000 people out of a total of $35 million. Six defendants have pleaded guilty. Next week, at least three more Canadian gem sellers will be arraigned in Federal District Court in Harrisburg.
What was unusual about the fraud was that Canadian salespeople preyed on American investors who already owned gemstones, or in some cases coins. Consumers thought they were selling their gemstones; instead, they became buyers.
 
'Commitment Trap'
 Officials say the mastermind of the scheme was Robert MacFarlane, whose operation seemed to fit the pattern of what Dr. Anthony R. Pratkanis, an associate professor of psychology at the University of California at Santa Cruz and co-author of "The Age of Propaganda: Everyday Use and Abuse of Persuasion," calls "the commitment trap." As part of the trap, the salesperson establishes himself as an authority figure and then in stages lures the investor into becoming more involved.
Around 1990, Mr. McFarlane obtained lists of coin and gemstone investors from the late 1970's and early 1980's, the authorities said. He hired salespeople who called the investors and insisted that the gemstone owners send in the certificates of authenticity before the exchange would agree to sell the investor's stones. Sometimes, the officials said, the salespeople would warn that an "overseas buyer" would make the deal only within the next 48 hours, so the American investors had to act quickly to buy any additional gemstones needed to complete the portfolio, in Dr. Kane's case emeralds.
In a second round of calls, the salespeople would say that the deal had fallen through, but that they had found another buyer. Except this one did not want emeralds, he wanted rubies. The scenario, officials said, would be replayed time after time.
The Canadian companies actually sent real gems of demonstrably low quality to the American investors, and often insisted that investors call the International Better Business Bureau. But an International Better Business Bureau does not exist, and all calls were forwarded to the same suburban Toronto office in which the salespeople worked.
 
Company After Company
 Sgt. Ronald J. Belanger of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police said that Mr. MacFarlane earned $10 million in two years, then sold his interest for $300,000 in 1991 to three associates, Allen Grossman, Michael Schaumer and Eugene Yermus, trading as Gheko Fox Yamoto Capital Management as well as Equity Control Exchange, International Exchange Board, Capital Exchange Board and Associated Overseas Investor Services. In one year, they made $22 million. A fourth man, Paul Demsky, who was indicted separately along with eight associates, was a MacFarlane salesman who broke off and formed Pan-Asia Asset Management Exchange and gave office space to Pacific Tower Asset Management Exchange. The two exchanges grossed $3.3 million from June 1992 to April 1993.
Involvement by the American authorities in the case began after Robert G. Finkbeiner, the 52-year-old director of Lutheran Social Services in York, Pa., filed a complaint in March 1993 with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. By then he had already paid Associated Overseas Investor Services $1.2 million, most of it borrowed from his employer, banks and several individuals.
He said he was initially contacted by the company in July 1992 and asked whether he wished to sell gemstones bought years before. But to complete the portfolio, a salesman told him, he had to buy another gemstone. Mr. Finkbeiner did, but when it came time to sell the completed portfolio, there was a problem. As it turned out, there would always be a problem: the size of the stones, or the number, or simply that the "purchaser" was getting divorced, went bankrupt or died. Mr. Finkbeiner's debts mounted as the Toronto businessmen threatened that subsequent deals would be lost if he didn't increase his investment. He was "just terrorized by that thought," he told his lawyer, Richard K. Renn of York. He told the banks he was borrowing money to invest in his brother's business, Mr. Renn said.
 
Losing Everything
 Mr. Finkbeiner was indicted in Federal District Court on counts of bank fraud and mail fraud, and also was charged by the state with theft by deception and forgery. He pleaded guilty last May to all the charges and is serving a 15-month sentence at the Allenwood Federal prison camp in Montgomery, Pa., concurrent with an 18- to 36-month state sentence. On May 18, he was removed from the Evangelical Lutheran Church of America's list of ordained ministers on May 18.
After Mr. Finkbeiner complained to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, "we were besieged with complaints from every conceivable state in the union," Sgt. Belanger said.
In March 1993, the Mounted Police seized the computer records of the Canadian company. Although the businessmen thought they had erased all pertinent information, Canadian computer experts were able to retrieve the financial records of the entire operation.
The National Consumers League, a national fraud information center, receives from 250 to 300 consumer calls daily to its consumer telephone line (1-800-876-7060) and encourages potential investors to stand back, think about the purchase, call somebody, talk to an accountant and never invest in something about which they know nothing.
Gemstone fraud, which has been escalating over the past three years, represents 30 percent of the dollar value of complaints in all telemarketing fraud reported to the Federal Trade Commission, said Robert D. Friedman, assistant director of the Bureau of Consumer Protection at the commission. The 10 indicted companies alone account for one-third of the total dollar volume of complaints, Mr. Friedman said.
Richard H. Grove, 68, a Carrollton, Ohio, pipeline foreman, holds out a slim hope that he might see some of the $100,000 he invested from 1991 to 1993. He bought his first stone in 1980 and his last in 1989, all through telephone sales. Then the calls reversed and he was enticed to sell his stones. "Every time they said they had them sold," Mr. Grove said, "but by the time they got around to settling up, they wanted you to buy another stone, or pay the commission up front."
Mr. Grove added: "I have my downer days, when you kind of hate yourself for getting into this mess. I had a guy call from Toronto the other day, and he wanted to sell my stones. I said 'I thought you were in jail!' He never did call me back."

HEADLINE: A Russian Outpost Now Happily Embraces Asia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KHABAROVSK, Russia, Aug. 8

 BODY:
Strange things are happening in this graceful port on Russia's Asian frontier. A popular Korean takeout place has opened at the corner of Leo Tolstoy and Kim Yu Chen Streets. Women are wearing cotton sundresses bought from Chinese salesmen who live across the border, 20 miles away. A visitor from Seattle has set up an espresso bar.
And at the top of the city's Intourist Hotel, part of a chain that in most Russian cities still seems about as innovative as an old Communist Party boss, Japanese businessmen perform karaoke and eat Tokyo-quality sushi (while paying for it with fistfuls of yen.) 
 Built more than 100 years ago on the Amur River as a fortress against the menace from the East, Khabarovsk has seen the future, and it is not in Moscow.
"We belong to the East," said Galina I. Lysenko, the deputy economic director of the Khabarovsk region, which has 1.6 million people but is twice the size of Japan and runs from the Manchurian border to Magadan. "The world, even in Russia, is reforming along new lines, and the only thing that makes sense for us is to integrate ourselves into the economics of Asia."
That has always made sense for what is essentially an Asian city, of course, but until the end of Communism it had never really been possible. Although Khabarovsk is far closer to Seoul and Tokyo than to Moscow, this part of the Russian Far East chafed for decades as bureaucrats sat in the Soviet capital and decided how much housing was needed here, where local officials could buy their textiles, what crops they should plant, and how much heat was required to survive the harsh winter.
 
In a New Orbit
 Now, with official blessings -- and a few misgivings -- from a federal Government that has been struggling hard to reward economic innovation, Khabarovsk has edged steadily into the orbit of the countries it was created to defend against: China, Japan, Korea. Suddenly hotel lobbies are full of American mining executives and Japanese geologists planning their next trip to forage for gold or diamonds. Russian workers who still shop on Lenin Square and stroll down Marx Prospect are struggling to learn Japanese or Korean.
The city's brave new freedom has found it looking East more and toward the center of the country less every month. This has caused some concern among many people here, who do not want to lose their ties to Russia. And it has also worried officials in Moscow who have long relied on this region's cheap, plentiful commodities. But these days, geography, not politics, often determines destiny in Russia
"We can't do it any other way in a free-market economy," said Mrs. Lysenko, who has been leading the move toward integration with Khabarovsk's Asian trading partners. "The transportation costs of shipping materials and receiving consumer goods from central Russia are too much for us to afford."
More than 250 joint ventures are operating here now, dozens having started in the past year. So far most big companies have only a symbolic presence and employ few local workers. But some -- Gold Star for example -- have already hired several hundred residents to make televisions.
South Koreans alone have opened 39 new businesses -- from manufacturing companies to restaurants -- since July 1993. The Japanese, who have the biggest, and in most ways the most visible, presence here, have had trouble keeping up their initial brisk pace because return on investment has been slow. And American companies, particularly Western mineral and timber concerns, have suddenly started showing up as well.
 
Much Wealth Is Undeveloped
 Part of the reason for all the action is that this region oozes with undeveloped wealth. The Khabarovsk territory leads the Russian Far East in logging and lumber production, and its trove of minerals and metals is practically unparalleled in the world. For companies looking to cash in on the next great boom town, this area seems as good a bet as any to be the modern Klondike.
"If you are not here now you don't deserve to be in this business," said Nikolai T. Yakouba, the general director of Russian Far East trade for JK International, an American timber company based in Oregon. "When it all goes, it's all going to go very, very fast."
But when, and whether, "it" will all go remain major and unanswerable questions. Good will and desire can get a company only so far. Economics have to do the rest, and Khabarovsk is in no way immune to the problems that have beset Russia as the country gropes its way toward a new economic structure.
There are more than 100 factories in the region, most of them pitifully out of date. The slump in national production -- official figures put the drop at 25 percent compared with the same period last year -- has been at least as brutal here as anywhere else.
Nearly every enterprise is in debt to somebody -- a business or the Government. Many have already had to close for two or three months this year because there was not enough money to pay fuel bills. Inflation, while lower than it has been, still causes havoc with personal buying power. Many factories are unable to pay full wages and unemployment looms on the horizon.
To help the situation along, the city has taken some of the most aggressive steps in the country to attract foreign investment. Because it needs help getting its great mineral wealth out of the ground, it has rewarded any foreign company that comes in and tries to do it. Registration of foreign companies, so onerous in many parts of Russia, usually takes two days. The first two years after a foreign company declares a profit it remains exempt from local taxes. If its investment of foreign capital is more than $5 million, the exemption lasts three years.
 
Rapidly Changing Rules
 The rules of economic life change so rapidly in Russia it is almost impossible to measure them, particularly in the Far East. Last year, according to local economic data, almost 10 percent of all accumulated investment in the Khabarovsk area was from foreign companies. While this might seem like a low figure, it is twice what it was two years ago. In addition, the region earned $150 million in essential hard-currency exports to Asia last year -- again not much, but more than any other area in Siberia or the Far East.
"They are doing everything they can to help us," said Sekijima Ryoichi, the local representative of Mitsui, the Japanese trading giant. "The government here understands that our profits will be their profits. And that if we can make it, so will they."
But as Mr. Ryoichi sits surrounded by the expensive goods he imports -- Sony stereos, Panasonic televisions, Yamaha outboard motors, Lipton tea -- he concedes that the market in this city of 600,000 has not grown as fast as he had originally hoped. "You have to be committed for a very long time," he said. "But eventually we think it will all pay off."
Not all companies agree with him. The Japanese, first here with their high-quality merchandise, have taken another look and most have decided to slow their pace. Extravagant plans to expand the international airport, which already has flights to Anchorage, Seoul, Harbin, China, and Niigata, Japan, have been put on hold. Japanese backing has not disappeared, but it has slowed considerably.
There are not too many people here buying Walkmans or fancy rice boilers, so Chinese peddlers have become the dominant sales force. They sell cheap clothing, instant noodles and lots of junky toys.
 
Chinese Cause Concern
 People here worry about the Chinese influence, in part because of the low quality of the goods they import and partly because they do not bring much money into the economy. There is also a personal animosity based on years of tension between two poor, but competing, superpowers.
The Russian manager at the fancy new Sapporo Hotel here, where every room has a temperature control panel, Japanese heaters on the toilet seats, and a stereo console next to the bed, admitted in an interview that Chinese guests are not welcome, though not exactly forbidden.
"They don't carry themselves well," said the manager, Anatoly M. Dolinsky. "They are loud and rude and don't take good care of the rooms."
South Koreans meet a different sort of welcome, however. They are among the fastest growing employers in the region, with a new Gold Star television factory north of the city and several other manufacturing plants planned.
"They are here to help us," said Mr. Dolinsky, whose clientele, nonetheless, is virtually all Japanese and whose hotel has a 10-foot-high Japanese flag in the lobby. "And we do need the help."

HEADLINE: With 2 Valdez Trials Down, Big One Is Coming Up

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER 

 BODY:
Now that the jury in the Exxon Valdez trial in Alaska has reached its second verdict, both sides in the exhausting legal contest that has lasted all summer are making preparations for the third and most important stage.
The questions that will be put to the jury are these: Should the world's largest oil company pay punitive damages for soiling Alaskan waters in 1989 with 11 million gallons of oil, and if so, how much? 
 Lawyers for Exxon and for the plaintiffs both said in interviews that they intended to frame their arguments around the same issue: whether Exxon's top executives reacted appropriately in the weeks after the spill. Whatever the outcome, the damages the plaintiffs have gained so far are already the second highest ever in an environmental accident, after the $470 million in damages stemming from the 1984 chemical poisoning in Bhopal, India, legal experts said.
The plaintiffs' trial team, led by Brian O'Neill, a 47-year-old lawyer from Minneapolis, will present Exxon as a callous, calculating industrial bully interested not in cleaning up the spilled oil but in shoring up its image. Mr. O'Neill has said he is seeking $15 billion in punitive damages.
 
Exxon Cites Spending
 Exxon's trial team, led by James Neal of Nashville and Patrick Lynch of Los Angeles, is prepared to argue that the company set an exemplary standard for reacting to an industrial disaster. It said that Exxon had already spent $3.4 billion making amends and that no additional punitive damages were warranted.
For the lawyers and clients on both sides, the Valdez disaster has been an ordeal, the legal equivalent of a journey up the uncharted Amazon. The Federal trial is now in its 15th week. Another trial against Exxon on some of the same issues is taking place simultaneously in state court in Anchorage, where some of the same plaintiffs are seeking $100 million in compensatory damages.
Although the trials are the marquee events, the conflict between thousands of Alaskans and Exxon really began in the days after the spill on March 24, 1989, and it may continue years longer with appeals. Like the grand landscape of the state in which the disaster occurred, everything about the legal aftermath has been off the scale. Legions of lawyers from at least 120 firms flew into Anchorage in 1989 and raced the oil out of Prince William Sound and down the Kenai Peninsula and Kodiak Island, all the way signing up thousands of clients.
From that swarm of lawyers evolved a confederation of 15 firms, which have invested roughly $20 million in direct expenses and twice as much in unpaid time preparing motions, gathering evidence and interviewing witnesses. They represent about 15,000 fishermen and other Alaskans.
Exxon, meanwhile, unleashed its vast resources in an effort to smother the plaintiffs' case before it reached trial. Led by the well-crafted motions filed by John Daum, a Los Angeles lawyer, the company achieved a large measure of success. The case the plaintiffs brought to trial is smaller than their lawyers had wanted. Large groups of clients, like cannery workers and businesses that said they had been harmed from the spill, were barred from the proceedings.
Nevertheless, the plaintiffs' case is still the most important court challenge Exxon has faced since Standard Oil, its predecessor company, was broken up in a Government antitrust action in 1911.
 
One Case, Several Phases
 The volume of evidence and the complexity of the legal and economic issues were so great that Judge H. Russel Holland of Federal District Court divided the case into three phases. A fourth phase, a catchall for plaintiffs not covered by the three other phases, may be tried before a separate jury, possibly as early as the fall.
In the first phase, which ended on June 13, the plaintiffs won a clear victory when the jury of nine women and three men decided that Exxon was reckless for permitting a captain with a known history of alcohol abuse to command a supertanker. The jury's finding of recklessness opened the way for the third phase, which is scheduled to begin on Aug. 22.
In the second phase, which ended on Thursday, the jury decided after 23 days of deliberation that Exxon should pay $286.8 million in compensatory damages, about a third of what commercial fishermen said was due them for harm caused by the spill.
Despite what lawyers for the plaintiffs said was a disappointing result in phase two, they nonetheless have gained in settlements and a jury verdict $404 million in damages from the spill. Before the phase two verdict, Exxon had agreed to settle claims with Alaska natives for $20 million, bringing the total that the plaintiffs have obtained from the oil company to $306 million. In addition, last year the seven oil companies that own and operate the Trans-Alaska Pipeline -- including Exxon -- settled with the plaintiffs for $98 million more.
In an interview, Mr. O'Neill said he was prepared during the third phase of the Exxon case to reprise some of the arguments he introduced at the trial's start three months ago. Then, Mr. O'Neill told the jury that Exxon had repeatedly ignored warnings about the drinking problems of the Exxon Valdez's captain, Joseph J. Hazelwood. He also accused Exxon's senior executives, among them Lawrence G. Rawl, the company's chairman and chief executive at the time of the accident, of lying to the jurors during their trial testimony.
Mr. O'Neill has said he believes it would take a $15 billion punitive damage award to wound a corporate giant and change its behavior. "Somehow, you need to take these institutions and say that just isn't a decent way to act," Mr. O'Neill said last month in an interview in Anchorage. "You need to say, The culture of your company has gone so sour we need to bring it back and do something about it. We need to shock them into some kind of corporate personality change."
 
Exxon Cites Its Response
 Exxon, on the other hand, is preparing to argue that its senior managers were stung by the Valdez spill and that the company's behavior has been exemplary ever since. The most important witness for Exxon during the third phase is expected to be Lee R. Raymond, the company's chairman and chief executive.
An important behind-the-scenes legal adviser for Exxon in Anchorage is Jack Clarke, a former senior vice president of Exxon and a former member of its board. In an interview in Anchorage in June, Mr. Clarke said Exxon had been given little public credit for accepting full responsibility for the spill and then spending $3.4 billion to help Prince William Sound and thousands of Alaskans recover.
Of that amount, $2.1 billion was spent to scrub oil from beaches and take other cleanup measures, a company spokesman said. In 1991, Exxon settled state and Federal claims related to the spill for slightly more than $1 billion. In addition, immediately after the spill, it established a claims settlement program and voluntarily paid $300 million to about 11,000 fishermen and other Alaskans who were harmed, many of whom are now plaintiffs in the Federal trial.
"What are the plaintiffs' lawyers saying about that?" Mr. Clarke said. "They say Exxon's people are liars. They speak out of both sides of their mouths. They ignore all that we've done."
Mr. Clarke added: "When I look at the punitive damage issue, I firmly believe there shouldn't be a punitive damage award. And certainly not one in the multibillions of dollars. Look at how we responded."

HEADLINE: Coffeehouse Slashing Suspect Viewed as Troubled Neighbor

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 13

 BODY:
When Richard and Karen Stimson watched news reports of the wild stabbing spree in a New Haven coffee bar Sunday night in which seven people were injured, the couple knew right away the suspect was most likely their next-door neighbor, the disheveled man they knew only as Louie.
They felt almost certain because the reports had said the man, Daniel Silva, 38, was ponytailed, had his dog with him during the attack, and had fled on a bicycle. 
 Mr. Silva was arrested a short time after the stabbings, and was charged with seven counts of assault in the first degree. He is being held on a $800,000 bond and is undergoing psychiatric evaluation by the State Department of Corrections in Hartford.
The Stimsons and other neighbors described Mr. Silva as a man of limited intellect who was handy and could build bicycles. They said he rode around the Fairhaven section of the city on a bicycle collecting junk, always with one or more of his dogs.
 
Arson Before Stabbings
 Earlier on the day of the stabbings, the Stimsons had watched in horror as Mr. Silva's home went up in flames, and they said they had not seen him since. On Friday, Mr. Silva was charged with first-degree arson in the fire.
Mr. Silva's lawyer, Jerome Rosenblum, suggested that his client was upset because he believed that his mother, who was hospitalized, had died. Whatever the reason behind the stabbings, neighbors said that Mr. Silva had come from a troubled family and appeared to have encountered violence in the past.
"He said there was a lot of mental illness in his family, and he was always babbling about relatives hurting and threatening him," Mr. Stimson recalled. "But there was another side to him, too. He always shoveled our sidewalk during winter without expecting anything in return, and sent us a very warm Christmas card."
Mr. Silva's lawyer, Mr. Rosenblum, said family members had told him that his client, an unemployed junk dealer, had grown up in neighboring West Haven and had attended West Haven High School without graduating. He said they told him that Mr. Silva had lived with their mother in New Haven for the last 20 years.
 
Thought Mother Had Died
 Neighbors said that while Mr. Silva never spoke about his childhood, he often talked of being hurt and threatened and was often overheard in loud arguments with his mother.
"Several weeks prior to all of this he said something about some relatives of his who he was afraid were going to torch his house before he was ready," said Ms. Stimson. She said he refused to explain what he meant by that, but she added that Mr. Silva had told her on numerous occasions about a violent family, though he was never specific. "He showed me what he said was a wound on one of his legs and said it was painful to be stabbed."
On Sunday, the police said, Mr. Silva carried out the stabbings, wounding seven people at the cafe, which is on Audubon Street in the city's arts district, not far from Yale University.
Mr. Rosenblum said that before the stabbings his client had become convinced that his ailing 79-year-old mother, Florence Mary Silva, had died. Mrs. Silva was released to a nursing home on Friday from Yale New Haven Hospital, where she had been treated since July 31 for acute diabetes.
 
Mother's Room Changed
 In an interview on Thursday, Mr. Rosenblum said: "When he went to the hospital last week to see her, his mother had been moved to another room and somewhere along the way he started believing she was dead. I really don't know how or why he came to believe that."
Cathy Zaorski, a hospital spokeswoman, said that Mr. Silva did visit with his mother on Aug. 4 after showing concern about where she was.
"Her room had been changed and he asked where she was," said Ms. Zaorski. "But we never got the impression he thought she was dead."

HEADLINE: Another View on the Yen's Rise

 BODY:
To the Editor:
If a dim possibility of political reform and an increase in trade surplus are the major causes of the recent dramatic appreciation of the yen, it seems to contradict the fact that the Japanese Government had never been more ready to reform than after the fall of the Liberal Democratic Party in 1992, the same period the yen rose 25 percent against the dollar ("Who Controls the Yen? Just Japan," Viewpoints, July 24).
Furthermore, Japan's increasing trade surplus has more to do with the appreciating yen than any underlying policy change in recent years. Japan is not any more of an export-oriented country now than in the 1980's. As recession arrived in Japan, however, companies restructured, slowed the recycling of overseas profit and slowed overseas expansion. There was a decline in overseas investment by Japan, which certainly increased demand for the yen and drove up its price. That may be one of the causes of its recent appreciation. 
 Japan's investment in other countries, mostly the United States, may have been counteracting upward pressure on the yen (mainly because of the trade surplus) for years by decreasing demand for the currency. When this counteraction was temporarily lifted because of the recession, the yen appreciated abnormally.
 
SAMMY LEE
North Bergen, N.J., July 28
 
The writer is a senior consultant with the Japanese practice unit of Deloitte & Touche/Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu.

HEADLINE: Maybe Inflation Is to Blame?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Surely J. E. Lighter is mistaken in "A Word About Money, Cash, Coin . . ." (Viewpoints, July 31), in which he defines a sawbuck as a $20 bill. A sawbuck is a $10 bill; a double-sawbuck, $20. I have always assumed these terms were inspired by the 19th century bills that denominated their value in Roman numerals -- "X" for $10, "XX" for $20 -- because of the designation's resemblance to a sawbuck, a rack used to support wood for sawing.
 
R. H. GREENAN
Winter Park, Fla., Aug. 1

HEADLINE: Employer Mandate? We Already Have One

SERIES: Health Care: Second Opinions-An occasional series

BYLINE: By Michael S. Dukakis; Michael S. Dukakis, Democratic candidate for President in 1988, is professor of political science at Northeastern University.

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
As the nation follows the great debate in Congress over health care reform, one issue stands out: will we require all employers to contribute to the cost of insurance for the company's workers and their families? Listening to the critics of the so-called employer mandate, one would think the nation was facing the issue for the first time.
 In fact, requiring employers to contribute to the cost of maintaining the social welfare of their workers is very much a part of American tradition. It began in Massachusetts and Wisconsin earlier in this century with workers' compensation and unemployment compensation, both of which were subsequently embraced by Congress.
 
 Then came Social Security and Medicare. And virtually all Americans agree that employers should be required to pay a decent minimum wage and observe acceptable standards of occupational safety and health.
 At every stage, when it has been suggested that employers bear some of the responsibility for these costs, the same arguments have been made over and over again. It will be an intolerable burden on small businesses. It will result in a devastating loss of jobs. It will stifle entrepreneurship. Each time the critics have been wrong.
 Now we are told by opponents of the bills submitted by the Democratic leaders of Congress, Representative Richard Gephardt and Senator George Mitchell, that we really don't need to require all employers to contribute to their employees' health insurance because so many of them already do, and that a pastiche of insurance reforms and subsidies for low-income people can get us close to universal coverage. Once again they are wrong.
 Not only will reforms without an employer mandate increase the cost of health insurance for employers who provide coverage and for their employees, failing to require all businesses and workers to contribute to the cost of insurance will continue to saddle responsible employers with a kind of tax on every premium they pay. This hidden tax represents the cost of free care for the employees of businesses who refuse to provide coverage for their workers.
 The Massachusetts experience is a case in point. In April 1988, as Governor I signed a universal health care bill designed to do for Massachusetts what Hawaii has so successfully done since 1974 -- provide health insurance for every Massachusetts worker and his or her family and for people who might be temporarily unemployed or suffer from a serious disability that makes it virtually impossible to buy affordable coverage. (Hawaii, which requires employers to pay at least half their workers' insurance costs, boasts the highest percentage of insured residents of any state: 96 percent.)
 Massachusetts carried out those provisions of the bill that provided for coverage of the disabled, students and the unemployed, and today, thanks to the 1988 law, nearly 100,000 residents have health insurance who didn't have it before.
 Unfortunately, we provided for a phase-in of the employer mandate some four years after the effective date of the law, and Gov. William Weld has done his best to kill or delay its implementation.
 In the meantime, he has continued to impose an 8.5 percent tax on certain hospital charges to pay for the free care that hospitals and community health centers provide to uninsured workers and their families.
 Ultimately, a tax is included in the premiums paid by employers and their employees who do insure. And today that tax amounts to an additional burden on responsible employers and their employees of $355 million a year, up some $20 million in the past two years alone.
 Actually, the tax in Massachusetts is a lot lower than it is in most states. In states with much larger numbers of uninsured workers, the free-care tax on businesses that provide insurance can run as high as 20 to 30 percent.
 Unless all businesses and their employees contribute to the cost of health care, the burden of paying for the uninsured will continue to go up as more and more workers lose their coverage.
 Earlier this year, the Labor Department released figures showing that the number of employers who cover their workers has been dropping steadily since 1988.

In short, we have a hidden employer mandate today. It is forcing responsible businesses to pay for health care for their competitors. It is making it increasingly difficult for small businesses who want to insure their employees to do so. And it is grossly unfair.
 That is why I hope Congress will learn from our mistakes here in Massachusetts. Requiring all employers and their employees to contribute to the cost of health insurance is the fairest and most effective way to achieve a goal everyone can support -- comprehensive health insurance for all Americans that can never be taken away.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed; Series

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.

 BODY:

A Magazine Turns a Corner, Bolstered by the Cafe Boom
 The Java Journal, which styles itself "Manhattan's Cafe Culture Magazine," started up last December with an initial investment of $3,000 each from Paul Millman, the publisher, and Peter Waack, the editor, and they had to underwrite the first four issues. But with the August issue, they say, advertising revenue entirely covered printing and production costs, though they have yet to draw salaries. 
 The partners say their magazine's progress reflects the continuing coffee bar boom. The Java Journal's data base contains 350 New York City cafe listings, Mr. Millman said, adding, "A year ago, there was 25 percent of what there is out there now."
The monthly art and literature magazine based on cafe culture is given away in cafes, coffee shops, restaurants and the lobbies of some New York City hotels.
 
For Low-Income Women, Entrepreneurship Training
An intensive program aimed at giving low-income and unemployed women the skills they need to start a business will be offered starting next month by the American Women's Economic Development Corporation. The classes, financed by the Department of Employment, are free and take place once a week for 26 weeks from 2 to 9 P.M. There is also a compulsory eight-week internship in a business related to the student's interest.
In the most recent program, the corporation said, 26 of the 36 women enrolled were graduated, and about half of them have since started their own businesses, ranging from catering and clothing design to accounting. Marcia Firestone, the vice president for training, said of the students, "Their particular craft or skill can be made into a business, without them having to become an employee of corporate America, and it can enable them to take care of their families."
 
4 Brooklyn Mainstays Join Forces to Sell Themselves
Four of Brooklyn's premier institutions, joined in an effort to sell themselves as a single tourist destination, have brought forth their latest marketing tool, a four-color brochure entitled, "A Day in Brooklyn." The brochure, underwritten by grants from the New York State Urban Development Corporation and the Tourism Grant Program of the New York City Business Assistance Corporation, sets forth the attractions of the four partners, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, Prospect Park, the Prospect Park Wildlife Center and the Brooklyn Museum. It is distributed at hotels and visitor centers and at each of the four institutions.
Signs, banners and subway advertising have also been developed. And a trolley to transport visitors between sites is scheduled to start this fall, running from the skating rink in Prospect Park to the parking lot shared by the Brooklyn Museum and the Botanic Garden.

HEADLINE: At Agency For Drivers, New Chief Has Plans

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG 

 BODY:
COMPLAINTS about the Division of Motor Vehicles are as perennial as tie-ups on the turnpike.
Maybe that should not be surprising. After all, New Jersey is a small state crammed with 4.8 million cars and the 5.4 million people who drive them. The division charged with keeping track of New Jersey motorists and their machines is an administrative behemoth with a yearly budget of $107 million, revenue of $700 million and 2,500 employees around the state. 
 Hundreds of drivers do business with the division every day at agencies, driver testing centers, inspection stations and regional service centers. Everyone knows that such business can mean long waits, sometimes multiple visits and frayed tempers on the parts of the public and clerks alike.
But the winds of political change have swept a new director into the division's Trenton headquarters. On June 27, Richard Heyman, a veteran legislator, began his job as chief executive of an agency that is required to be efficient and easy to use while delivering an increasing number of services in a way that keeps costs in line. He, his managers and employees all have ideas about how to accomplish those goals.
Mr. Heyman has come to his new job in an optimistic frame of mind. "Everyone here understands that this is a service business," he said, adding that clients will see changes within the next 18 months as all the agencies and service centers are upgraded. Plans for a fifth regional service center are on the drawing board, though no site has been selected. A hiring moratorium will probably continue, Mr. Heyman said, but managers at the sites, at Wayne, Deptford, Eatontown and Trenton, are working on ways to deploy counter clerks more efficiently during rush periods.
The new director's plans include the establishment of a telephone line that people can call to find out how long they will have to wait at specific locations. He also hopes to see more transactions by mail.
Division officials say some of the problems and slowdowns arise from lack of public awareness.
"Except for our regular customers, everyone has the problem of not understanding the system," said Martin Casey, who has worked for the division for nine years and is regional coordinator at the Wayne service center.
 
Impact of Changes in Laws
 Mr. Casey also said many motorists appear in person when they could transact their business by mail, and others come without the documentation needed for their transactions. Motorists who arrive with adequate documentation, Mr. Casey added, can still find themselves at the ends of long lines if they visit at lunchtime or at the end of the month.
Both customers and employees are at the mercy of the state and Federal lawmakers and division bureaucrats who enact laws or change regulations causing increases in volume. In July 1992, for example, the division dropped its requirement that driver license applicants show proof of legal United States residency. The same month, budget cuts forced the division to curtail evening and Saturday hours at inspection stations.
Barbara Wells, who is now a Communications Workers of America union representative for the division, was working at the Wayne service center during that period. "The line stretched all the way around the outside of the building," she said, "and met again at the door."
Other sites were similarly crowded. The public outcry was so loud that the residency policy was reversed after a month, reducing applications from resident aliens, and the Legislature restored money for extended hours.
Within the last year, the Parking Offense Adjudication Act made it possible for local governments to turn over the names of motorists with multiple parking violations to local courts. The courts then suspend the offenders' licenses and notify the D.M.V., which sends out suspension notices.
Suspensions are effective immediately, and before an individual driver can take to the roads again, he must report to the local court, pay the fine and then take proof of payment to the D.M.V. Though restoring a license takes only a short time, and the legislation has provided a financial windfall to municipalities, it has also added to customer volume at the division.
Next year, when provisions of the Federal Clean Air Act go into effect, waiting times at inspection stations, which averaged 16 minutes a car for the first five months of 1994, will almost certainly increase.
Mr. Heyman says that to meet the new requirements, New Jersey inspection stations will have to be remodeled, with extra lanes added for new emissions testing. Since these mandates come without Federal funds, increased waiting time will be coupled with increased costs for vehicle registration and other transactions.
 
Effect of Staff Shortages
 Staff shortages continue to cause stress for the work force and the customers. Elizabeth Ferguson, a seven-year division employee, works at the customer service counter at the Springfield agency location. On a busy day, Ms. Ferguson said, her office may handle 1,000 transactions. "We are not overstaffed," she added.
Cheryl Barber, a records technician in the Wayne service center, said her unit's two clerks signed in 600 to 900 customers a day. Many drivers need conferences with records technicians before their suspended licenses can be restored.
According to Ms. Barber, technicians are required to see 25 customers a day. "Most of us do 40 to 50," she said, adding that her unit and the Wayne center in general are "definitely understaffed."
Mr. Casey agrees, noting that a moratorium on hiring imposed during the Florio administration is still in effect. "Even if you promote someone, you have to get permission to replace them," he added.
If conditions were ideal, the regional coordinator said, he would hire 25 percent more employees to work at Wayne, which handles 2,000 transactions a day and is the division's busiest site.
At some locations, an enlarged work force would only aggravate another problem: parking. Between Jan. 1, 1994 and the end of June, the Wayne Police Department was called 13 times to direct motorists away from the overflowing parking lot. The Wayne Police Chief, Donald Pavlack, said this was an improvement over previous years, when calls came in "on a nearly daily basis."
At Wayne, situated on Route 23, frustrated customers of the division have occasionally parked on the shoulders on both sides of the six-lane highway, sometimes attempting to jump over the center divider to get to the building.
Mr. Casey noted that Wayne's parking problem has eased in the years since the division rented a separate parking lot for employees' cars and added an enhanced-hours unit to extend the business day. Other locations, however, as in Moorestown, which has parking spaces for only 10 to 15 cars, have similar troubles.
Division employees like Ms. Barber, Ms. Ferguson and Joann Keenan, receptionists at the Newton location, say management could have a more efficient agency by communicating with the employees. The three women are shop stewards for the Communications Workers, which represents most of the clerical and counter personnel.
They say they and their counterparts work under pressure, sometimes in cramped quarters, in jobs that often have little room for advancement. The division's top managers, Ms. Ferguson said, need to cultivate a more hands-on leadership style, including visits from Trenton to the various agencies and regional service centers.
Ms. Barber said the division's other managers often come from the inspection stations rather than the agencies and have trouble relating to the concerns of the employees they manage. This sentiment is echoed by a union slogan, "We Want to Be Respected, Not Inspected."
 
More Technology Expected
 Employees and customers alike will see more technology at work in the future, Mr. Heyman said. He foresees the day when finger imaging will allow a motorist to insert a finger in a scanner at a division office. The fingerprint scan will not only verify the person'sidentity, but also summon up his entire driving record. Cars registered in the state will be electronically tracked on the anniversary of the day they were first registered.
Mr. Heyman said that in the future the need for economy and efficiency might result in "much greater involvement of the private sector."Such privatization, however, could be opposed by the unions representing the division's employees.
Both Mr. Casey and Mr. Heyman are complimentary toward the division's work force. According to the director, letters containing compliments about employees outnumber complaints by "10 to 1."
"I have to give the employees a lot of credit," Mr. Casey said.
Mr. Heyman said, "Our reputation is improving."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 21, 1994, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last week about plans for service improvements in the Division of Motor Vehicles misstated the surname of the division's director. He is Richard Kamin, not Heyman.
