HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
In Europe, Dollar Dipped, But Rates Still Favorable

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
WHAT a pain: You start planning a European vacation in the winter, when the dollar has one value; you get to Paris or Rome or Madrid in the summer and the dollar is worth something different. True, sometimes it is worth more. Last summer, for example, American visitors were pleasantly surprised. But not this year. It's blues time again for the ol' greenback.
The odd thing is that around two million Americans come to Europe every year no matter what's happening to the dollar. If they're rich, they don't worry about the exchange rate. If they're on a tight budget, they still have to look for bargains. In the end the difference between well-heeled travelers and others is far wider than any swing in the dollar. 
 Still, what tourist doesn't always glance at the dollar rate when strolling past a bureau de change? Who doesn't wonder if tomorrow's rate will be better? It's a hypnotizing world, but also a mysterious one. If the Federal Reserve in Washington doesn't know why the dollar goes up and down, how are we to know?
Only one thing is clear: that the dollar has lost value in recent months. But -- and here's an important but -- it has not lost all the value that it gained in late 1992 when the British pound, the Italian lira, the Spanish peseta and assorted Scandinavian currencies were forced to devalue. So the dollar is still worth 20 to 30 percent more in much of Europe than it was two years ago.
An example or two will suffice. On July 1, 1992, the dollar was worth 1,130 lire and 95 pesetas, while the pound was worth $1.91; on Jan. 1, 1994, the dollar's value had inflated to 1,700 lire and 143 pesetas, while the pound's value had fallen to $1.49. So in relative terms, the dollar's recent slide is not that bad. Last Monday (Aug. 8), the dollar was still worth 1,580 lire and 130 pesetas and the pound cost $1.54.
There is another plus. Western Europe is just beginning to pull out of a protracted recession and, feeling the squeeze, many hotels and restaurants have learned to compete.
In Madrid, for example, some five-star hotels surrendered one of their stars in order to lower their prices by as much as 40 percent. In Paris and Rome, more restaurants now display their fixed-price menus in the hope of enticing passers-by.
Bargains notwithstanding, the dollar now goes considerably farther in Southern Europe and Scandinavia than it did in, say, August 1992. But it still does not walk tall in Switzerland, the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg and France, where currencies are loosely pegged to the German mark. And it is, of course, against the mighty mark -- and the distant Japanese yen -- that the dollar has fared poorly of late.
Put differently, when the Italian lira, the British pound and others slumped in value in late 1992, they were in fact devalued against the German mark. And now that they have found their new levels, they are still measured principally against the mark. So what counts for the dollar is its value against the mark -- and, after that, everything else falls into place. On July 1, 1992, the dollar was worth 1.49 marks; on Jan. 1, 1994, it was worth 1.74 marks; on Aug. 8 this year it was worth 1.54 marks.
But one day it should all become simple. The European Union countries -- 12 now but 16 on Jan. 1 next year when Austria, Finland, Norway and Sweden are expected to join -- are committed to creating a single currency by 1999.
They may not all meet that deadline, but sooner or later it should happen. And at that point, the dollar will have a single rate throughout Western Europe. It won't stop the dollar's value from fluctuating, of course, but at least American travelers won't have to hand over outrageous commissions to a new bunch of exchange houses every time they cross a border.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 4, 1994, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A Correspondent's Report on Aug. 14 about the exchange rate for the dollar in European countries misstated the number of Americans who visit Europe annually. The average from 1990 to 1993 was about 7.2 million, according to the European Travel Commission.

HEADLINE: Advertising's Role in Health Care

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
AS competition for patients among Westchester's hospitals grows, so do those institutions' budgets for advertising. And while some observers of the health-care scene worry that critical dollars are being diverted from patients' bedsides, others argue that aggressive marketing has become an economic necessity in light of the sea changes taking place in medicine and the delivery of health care.
"It's part of an industry shakedown happening all across America, and Westchester is no exception," said Arthur E. Weintraub, president of the Northern Metropolitan Hospitals Association in Newburgh, a nonprofit organization representing 40 hospitals in the Hudson Valley. "Advertising is a valid attempt on the part of hospitals to convey their mission in today's world." 
 Mr. Weintraub said that while the current advertising frenzy was being played out in newspaper, radio and television ads throughout the country, it had taken on an added dimension in Westchester, where hospitals felt the pressure to compete with large institutions in New York City.
"Here the message is about not getting lost in the big city environment, about being close to home and the personal touch," he said.
At the 461-bed New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center, John R. Spicer, president and chief executive officer, called his hospital's $250,000 advertising budget for next year a "necessary evil."
 
Getting Lost in the Shuffle
 "If left to my own devices, I wouldn't move in this direction," Mr. Spicer said, "but we have New York City hospitals to the south and Greenwich Hospital to the north, and we feel the pressure."
At White Plains Hospital, Melissa J. Weisstuch, a spokeswoman, said the concern was about not getting lost in the shuffle. "If you are not out there telling people about the services you have, they may think you don't have them," she said.
White Plains Hospital, a 300-bed institution, has earmarked $200,000 for its advertising campaign next year, twice as much as the amount that some hospitals more than twice its size have budgeted.
At St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains -- which boasts a hyperbaric (or pressurized) chamber, used in the experimental treatment of various diseases, a balance function center for inner ear problems and state-of-the-art laparoscopic surgery (where an instrument is introduced into the abdomen) performed with three-dimensional lenses -- Mary deBarros, a spokeswoman, said: "People think they have to go to New York City for specialized care, but that's not true. It's all right here in their own backyard in their little community hospital."
 
'Perception of Viability'
 In addition to trying to meet the competition from New York City, some hospital administrators said they were also battling an image problem at home.
"Good, bad or indifferent, advertising adds a great perception of viability," said Edward A. Stolzenberg, the county's Hospitals Commissioner, who oversees the 1,000-bed Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla. The medical center has budgeted $100,000 for next year's advertising, and Mr. Stolzenberg said that the money would go toward positive advertising to compensate for some negative press reports. "I would have preferred not to use scarce health-care dollars on advertising, but we had to," he said. "We had no choice."
William Tan, president and chief executive officer of the 184-bed St. Agnes Hospital, also said he was using advertising to overcome a public perception that the hospital was not doing well.
"We have not enjoyed good public relations because of fiscal troubles and the public perception that there might be a cutback in services," he said. "For us, advertising is a necessity." At Sutton & Partners, an advertising firm in Old Greenwich -- which lists St. Agnes Hospital, St. Vincent's Hospital in Harrison and Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville among its clients -- Stephen Katcher, president and creative director, said hospitals were being driven by the need to attract not only prospective patients but doctors as well.
He said that the doctors were the hospitals' chief sources of referrals.
"All in all, it has become very competitive, a quiet kind of war," Mr. Katcher said.
In an attempt to correct the flagging image of St. Agnes Hospital and to tout its affiliation in recent years with New York Medical College, Sutton & Partners uses the headline "University care in a community setting" in its ads.
For St. Vincent's Hospital in Harrison, a psychiatric division of the same hospital in Manhattan, the agency's ads show a picture of a 16-year-old girl with the caption, "It turns out the only one who thought I was a bad person was me."
And for Lawrence Hospital, which is promoting its maternity care, geriatrics department and sports medicine and rehabilitation service, the advertising message is, "The more you know about Lawrence Hospital, the better you'll feel."
 
Need for Reassurance
 At CMA Advertising in White Plains, Gary Blum, president, said that in an uncertain environment, hospitals were intent on "getting the message out about what makes them unique."
He added: "People need to be informed because things in the health-care industry are changing daily. They need to be reassured about services, quality of care and a hospital's reputation." He would not say which hospitals were his clients.
While some Westchester hospitals are taking quarter-, half- and even full-page ads in local magazines and newspapers, others are promoting their services -- a physician referral service, for example -- on printed train schedules. Some are buying radio time. And others are trying to reach the public through what is known as advertorials, an advertisement that looks like a newspaper article and often appears on the editorial pages.
"Whatever way, it's our responsibility to get the message out," said Jon B. Schandler, president of White Plains Hospital Center. "Sometimes it's hard to draw the line between PR and all-out advertising."
 
More Intense Elsewhere
 However strong the competition is in Westchester and the surrounding New York metropolitan area, it is "far more intense, more competitive" in other areas of the country, said Jeannie H. Cross, a spokeswoman for the Healthcare Association of New York State, which represents 400 public and private hospitals, nursing homes and agencies.
She said hospitals in New York had adopted a "more informational tone" in their advertising than hospitals in other areas. "They don't scream at you here," she said. "They just say that this is a service they have to offer."
Sally J. Rogers, a spokeswoman for the United Hospital Fund in Manhattan, observed that advertising had been "slow to come to New York," where occupancy rates for hospital beds remained high, compared with other parts of the country.
In Westchester the occupancy rate averaged 80.3 percent in 1992, the latest year for which figures are available, and in New York City it was 84.7 percent -- much higher than in other parts of the country. In Texas, for example, the occupancy rate in 1992 averaged 56.4 percent, and in Florida, it was 61.3 percent.
 
Blaming the Media
 Ms. Rogers said the high occupancy rates in the New York metropolitan region were the result of poverty and attendant problems like drug and alcohol abuse and low-birth-weight babies. Because the hospitals continued to be busy, she said, they were more likely to purchase low-profile advertising.
Some hospital administrators, angry about the need to pay for advertisements, blamed newspapers, television and radio for not paying more attention to their efforts.
"From my point of view, hospitals are a public service, and the media should provide the space and time to promote our services," said Richard J. Gerber, vice-president for development and public relations at Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in North Tarrytown, an affiliate of Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City.
"Just because our neighboring hospitals are advertising is not a good enough reason for us to do it," he said. The 215-bed hospital spends about $100,000 a year on what Mr. Gerber called pure advertising, which includes a half-page ad in the Yellow Pages.
 
'Too Much Me-Tooism'
 Criticism has also been directed at the Westchester County Medical Center, which is partially supported by taxpayer dollars, for allocating some of its funds for advertising.
"Should a county hospital be in competition in the same arena as a private hospital?" asked Stephen P. Tenore, the Chairman of the County Board of Legislators. As a critical care hospital -- the only one of its kind in the Hudson Valley region -- the Medical Center was not in competition with other local hospitals, he said.
Rhoda Weiss, a national health-care consultant based in Santa Monica, Calif., said she saw "too much me-tooism and panic" in many hospitals' advertising campaigns and added that the dollars would be better spent on community health outreach programs for high-blood-pressure screening and cancer detection, for example.
"What you pay for in a full-page ad could immunize every child in Westchester," Ms. Weiss said. "Doesn't that make more sense to you?"

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX;
The Sad Value of Max's Dime

BYLINE: By WALTER MOSLEY; Walter Mosley is a Manhattan writer whose most recent novel is "Black Betty."

 BODY:
WHEN I was nine years old, I overheard my mother and father talking about a man, a friend of theirs, who had been sentenced to life in prison for murdering another man. This friend, I'll call him Max, shot his victim at the neighborhood barber shop in Los Angeles in a dispute over a dime wager in a back-room craps game.
"Max asked him for his money," I remember my father saying, almost proudly. "And when he didn't get it, he shot him dead." 
 I didn't know Max, and I had no knowledge, outside of TV Westerns, about death by shooting. But I did know something about dimes. With a dime you could buy two Hershey bars or a Superman comic book.
Even at the age of 9 I knew that a dime wasn't worth a man's life. So later on, when my mother wasn't around, I asked my father why Max really killed that man. I knew that there were all kinds of secret reasons why things happened in the world. My father was the only one who was willing to share those secrets with me.
"He killed him because he had to," my father said.
"But why?"
"Because Max never had a thing, and he was afraid that anything he ever got might be the last. When you come up like that, you fight for what's yours. You have to."
"But it was just a dime."
"When you're a poor man, every dime you ever get is your last one. And if you let somebody take that dime from you, you might as well dig your own grave. Because once somebody takes something from you, everybody else will know and then they'll all do it. Even if you're just a little boy and mourners come into your house when your mother dies. They'll steal the pennies right out of your piggy bank and make you sleep in a coal bin."
My father was sad after our little talk, and I didn't press him further. I knew that the story about a mother's wake was his own. I also knew that my father identified with Max and might have committed the same kind of violence, when angered, if it wasn't for his love for me and my mother.
I knew all of this almost unconsciously and with a kind of logic that I couldn't apply to the rest of the world -- at least, not at that time.
But my father's words come back to me when I think about today's world: Kids with guns, teen-age pregnancies, what we call random violence. We all want it to stop, but no one seems to know how.
I certainly don't know.
My father didn't give answers. What he taught were secrets -- why things happened, not how to control them. He taught me there were reasons for everything, that it was up to me to understand their logic so that, hopefully, I could survive.
I understand Max. He lived in a kind of poverty of mind. He had to fight every day of his life and didn't have the shelter of a father's love.
But it's not only Max. I have a friend today who lives in a tough part of Manhattan. When junkies came to her door, time after time mistaking it for a dealer's place, she called the police. After hearing her address, the police officer laughed and, before hanging up, said, "If you want to be safe, you'd better move."
But how can she move? It's twice the rent to be in a better neighborhood -- first, last, and one month for a deposit.
How can she stay? How can she open the door, or approach home at night? That answer is easier at least -- she has no other choice. Poverty makes people do things that seem impossible and unbearable.
When there's no one to protect your interests, you protect yourself or you give up. You arm yourself with courage, love or guns -- or you buy a dream and lose yourself therein.
A child who is threatened every day, who has seen other children murdered, arms himself. A man is willing to risk his life over a small wager. A girl just out of puberty makes a baby. A boy is proud of all the children he can sire.
Sadly, it all makes sense. There is reason. The unloved child, the gun, the white powder -- death. It's not random. And if there is evil, the whole of the society must share the guilt with the perpetrators.
Because this is the world we have settled for. The secret, in this case, is our own complicity. Not a conspiracy against the poor but a fear so great that we begin to deny reason.
Teen-agers having babies are perceived of as welfare frauds, not children seeking love and their human birthright, creation. Youngsters bearing sophisticated automatic weapons are frightening and should be disarmed. But we mustn't let our fear mask the true villains -- the ones who arm them.
Young men and women -- uneducated, unemployed and unloved by an aging society -- live in a world that has metamorphosed true wisdom, civility and grace into profit, object sex and an endless procession of lurid media events.
In short, our world is undone. We have abandoned our poor and even our children. We seek shelter in ignorance. There is definitely evil and danger in the world we live in, but only with clear eyes can we see the extent of the damage and the possibilities for survival. Only if we can comprehend the true value of that dime in Max's eyes can we see the real threat to our world.

HEADLINE: They'll Always Have Auckland

BYLINE: By John Weir; John Weir is the author of the novel "The Irreversible Decline of Eddie Socket."

 BODY:

DANGEROUS DESIRES
By Peter Wells.
220 pp. New York:
Viking. $20.95. 
WITH a screenwriter's gift for knowing how little to include, Peter Wells renders the contemporary urban characters inhabiting this volume of short fiction -- South Pacific islanders roaming New Zealand's coastal cities and seaside resorts -- in achingly spare vignettes. There is the sense of life captured in extremity, in intensely felt moments of longing or pain.
The eight selections, including three novellas, in this first collection evoke a unified mood that stems in part from the geographical isolation of their New Zealand setting and that land's mixed racial history. Like many of Mr. Wells's characters, an out-of-work wanderer named Henry Lawson, taking a stroll in "Encounter," feels displaced because he lacks a strong cultural identity, reflected by the changeable nature of his appearance. "In dubious lighting" he can pass "as a European of around 30, possibly of Italian ancestry." At other times he believes that he resembles nothing so much as "a Polynesian princess." But on a long night walk through an "infinitely tedious village," Henry thinks, in a self-deprecating tone typical of Mr. Wells's New Zealanders, that he is no more than "that discount thing, an islander."
The author's circumspect characters often find themselves wandering alone or sitting in lonely motel rooms or seeking tourist attractions in unfamiliar towns, searching for something they lost. In "Bum to You, Chum," Nick Burns, a refugee from Auckland, arrives at the resort town of Sulphur City with nothing but some faded photographs of the women who raised him. He has just learned that one of them is his real mother. There are clues in this town to his mother's life and to his own identity, but Nick waits a long time before he even leaves his room. When he finally goes out, he returns not with a further clue to his past but with a much younger man he has met in a park. His desire for contact is bruised and tentative, as if he was ultimately more comfortable with strangers than with himself.
Other characters in this collection meet up with long-forgotten lovers whom they barely recognize, or return disillusioned to the places where they were once in love or just briefly, excitingly, in lust. Story titles like "Of Memory and Desire" and "Sweet Nothing" suggest the atmosphere of frustrated yearning and wistful regret that permeates the action. Mr. Wells, co screenwriter and co-director of the film "Desperate Remedies," writes in clean, economical prose that crackles with ironic flourishes. Though he can occasionally sink to overweighted phrases like "He fell into profound blackness," his language is generally concise and expressive.
But despite his skill at short fiction, I can't help thinking that this is a novel trapped in a story collection. Surprisingly, the strongest and most novelistic pieces are not the novellas but three interrelated stories. In the first, "Perrin and the Fallen Angel," Mr. Wells introduces Eric Westmore and Perrin McDougal, whose 17-year-long friendship is at the point of unraveling because Perrin has AIDS. The story opens with Eric in the bar of the soon-to-be-demolished Alexandra Hotel, which he affectionately calls "the Alex," a remnant of Edwardian Auckland that "looked like the tiara, Eric always thought, of a minor Scottish peeress."
With the Alex "being reduced to dust," Eric reminisces about his past with Perrin, going back to the night in 1969 when the friends met on the first occasion either one of them had gone into a gay bar. They were "so spectacularly isolated," Mr. Wells writes, that when "their eyes located each other" it was "like radar -- radar of the dispossessed." Mr. Wells sketches their friendship in a few brief episodes that suggest everything that has passed between them without exhaustively recounting their history together.
The richness of their intimacy is simply and beautifully presented. In the succeeding stories, "Outing" and "Dark and Light," Mr. Wells catches up with Eric and Perrin near the end of Perrin's illness, and after his death. The stories form a chronicle, not of lovers and family members but of friends, and they movingly reflect the central importance friendship occupies in the gay community, especially in the time of AIDS. It is hard not to want an entire volume devoted to scenes like the one at the end of "Outing," in which Eric watches his closest and oldest friend drive away, alone, in Eric's car. "And seeing Perrin move off, odd, slow and cumbersome, trying so hard to control his own fate, Eric watched his dear love, his friend, turn the corner, with as much grace as possible, attempting to execute his own exit."

HEADLINE: Unworthy Causes?

BYLINE: By William C. Taylor; William C. Taylor is a founding editor of the business magazine Fast Company.

 BODY:

UNHEALTHY CHARITIES
Hazardous to Your
Health and Wealth.
By James T. Bennett and
Thomas J. DiLorenzo.
269 pp. New York:
Basic Books.
$25. 
THE time is surely right for a tough-minded look at the country's big medical charities. Health care occupies political center stage, and there are signs that community service is experiencing a new wave of energy. Meanwhile, thanks to lingering fallout from the United Way mismanagement scandal of 1992, the nonprofit establishment has lost the public's once-unimpeachable trust.
All of which makes "Unhealthy Charities" such a missed opportunity. James T. Bennett of George Mason University and Thomas J. DiLorenzo of Loyola College, both professors of economics, focus on what they call the Big Three: the American Cancer Society, the American Heart Association and the American Lung Association. Their indictment -- and that is certainly how their book reads -- is as sweeping as it is unforgiving. They complain that the Big Three devote too much money to public awareness campaigns, which they consider "thinly disguised fund raising"; spend too much time educating doctors and nurses rather than assisting victims; and allocate too many grants to a narrow clique of hospitals and universities.
There may be some merit to these complaints, but the authors routinely overdo it. Take the familiar public service tag line "See your physician for regular checkups." Do we really believe that this slogan amounts to a campaign to "admonish the public to increase their consumption of medical services under the halo of charity"?
The book's more reasonable arguments suffer from the armchair quality of its research. An in-depth investigation of the policies and culture of the three charities should necessarily include tough interviews with individuals inside these organizations. Instead, "Unhealthy Charities" serves up a barrage of bloodless facts and quotations from Congressional hearings, newspaper articles and financial documents.
The result is lots of information, but little insight. Mr. Bennett and Mr. DiLorenzo present a wealth of detail about the 1992 annual meeting of the California chapter of the American Cancer Society, right down to the menus: a marketing team "met in the Hilton's Roosevelt A room and enjoyed coffee, muffins and juice in the morning; dined on the $17.95-per-person California Bistro luncheon selection; and, at 3 in the afternoon, enjoyed soft drinks, mineral water and two dozen cookies -- at $15 per dozen."
AT other times, the authors exhibit an irritating faux naivete. After reviewing financial statements, they report, "we were shocked by what we found: health charities plead for money for programs to aid those in need while at the same time holding millions of dollars in cash, stocks, bonds, real estate and automobiles."
The United Way fiasco underscored the potential for abuses by nonprofit organizations. But
should economics professors be "shocked" that the American Heart Association invests its endowment funds in securities, or that the American Cancer Society owns office buildings?
For all its flaws, "Unhealthy Charities" does leave the reader with the sense that something is amiss with the Big Three. These huge, powerful charities seem uncreative and uninspired, more concerned with perpetuating themselves than with fighting disease. In this, of course, they exhibit the same culture of complacency as so many big organizations that have been around for 70 or 80 years. I.B.M. and General Motors were almost destroyed by decades of success. Should we expect bold innovation from the people who brought you Christmas seals?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Planned Airport Rail Can Use Little-Known East Side Terminal

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The new light rail link planned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for La Guardia and Kennedy International Airports is the most important economic development in the New York metropolitan area in decades. It should not be derailed by a poorly thought out Manhattan terminal on the site of the former Alexander's department store at Third Avenue and 59th Street. 
 The Queensboro Bridge was built in 1909 as a combined rail and highway link between Manhattan and Queens. The trains, called streetcars, ran on the outer lanes of what is now the lower deck. The Manhattan train terminal, still underground at Second Avenue between 59th and 60th Streets, was abandoned in the early 1950's in favor of the Q60 bus, which still runs back and forth across the bridge, but does not use the long-abandoned Manhattan train terminal. This terminal could be remodeled for the new airport-bound train.
The vaults underneath the Queensboro Bridge, now used for storage, could be converted into parking for taxicabs loading and unloading passengers from First Avenue only. Then Second and Third Avenues would be free of the cab traffic feared by protesting East Siders.
But even without this Manhattan terminal, the Port Authority ought to build the train as planned, linking Queens Plaza, La Guardia, Shea Stadium-Willets Point Boulevard, Jamaica Station and Kennedy Airport.
The two airports together are Queens County's largest employers, and airport employees invariably drive to work, crowding the Long Island Expressway, Grand Central Parkway and Van Wyck Expressway. Linking the Long Island Rail Road, IRT No. 7 and IND E subways to La Guardia and Kennedy by rail will allow thousands of airport workers to take the train to work, taking millions of automobile trips a year off these supercongested highways.
New York started in 1624 as a national seaport in lower Manhattan. By the early 20th century, the city was a transcontinental railroad terminal centered in midtown at Pennsylvania Station and Grand Central Terminal. Today they are commuter terminals, mere shadows of their glory days.
New York has grown into a national and international airport terminal centered at La Guardia and Kennedy. To keep New York as the country's central city, it is imperative that international air and local rail be linked.
 
PAUL E. KERSON
Forest Hills, Queens, Aug. 5, 1994
The writer is counsel to the Queens Historical Society.

HEADLINE: Let Us Also Decry the Violence Abortion Does

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The violence that brutally erupted in the fatal shooting of Dr. John Bayard Britton and James H. Barrett at the abortion clinic in Pensacola, Fla., is highly repugnant, reprehensible and has rightly met widespread condemnation. 
 The violence that provoked this tragedy is the antithesis of pro-life movements, which ideally denounce whatever threatens human life or undermines human dignity, not focusing on a single issue like abortion.
The murders have been justly repudiated by religious and civic leaders and groups. Federal agents have properly been deployed to halt violence at abortion clinics.
Violence is not a univocal or one-dimensional reality. The term has been applied to revolutionary and guerrilla movements attempting to transform governments perceived as brutally oppressive.
The word has also been employed in a more extensive but realistic fashion to "institutional or structural violence" by political and religious leaders, sociologists and economists to describe the unjust policies of governments that have doomed many of their people to a dehumanizing existence characterized by widespread disease, malnutrition, illiteracy, inadequate or nonexistent health care and numerous other disabilities.
While we rightly condemn the violent deaths in Pensacola and use all available means to protect life, it is important to recall that many conscientious citizens decry the violence they perceive in abortion on demand.
Women indeed have reproductive rights and a right to privacy. Other inalienable rights to life, liberty, free speech, assembly, to bear arms, are guaranteed by the Constitution, but they are conditioned and limited so as not to violate the rights of others.
A woman's reproductive rights and her right to privacy must be respected and legally protected, but cannot be so absolute as to inflict violence upon the fundamental right to life of the unborn, the most vulnerable of any society, which is judged by its concern for the most defenseless.
 
(Rev.) JOSEPH A. FAHY
Hispanic Apostolate
Archdiocese of Atlanta
Atlanta, Aug. 8, 1994

HEADLINE: Suburban Expansion Fed By an Influx of Minorities

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
After decades in which America's cities worried primarily about white flight, cities are now facing the increasingly rapid departure to the suburbs of middle- and working-class minority members.
No longer the contained, homogenous "Leave it to Beaver" bedroom communities of the 1950's, the suburban destinations of minorities now constitute a broad patchwork that includes inner suburbs, large suburban cities, office parks, retail centers, even rural territory, demographers say. 
 Some experts think the pattern of suburbanization may also be more complex because of the diverse racial and ethnic minority groups involved. And those dynamics may play out in entirely different ways in the sprawling, less dense sections of the South and West.
The minority population has grown substantially in the nation's suburbs, the 1990 Census showed. From 1980 to 1990, the black population in the suburbs grew by 34.4 percent, the Hispanic population by 69.3 percent and the Asian population by 125.9 percent. By contrast, the white population in the suburbs increased by 9.2 percent.
William H. Frey, a demographer at the University of Michigan who specializes in racial distribution patterns, said, "Minority suburbanization took off in the 1980's both as the black middle class came into its own and as more assimilated Latinos and Asians translated their moves up the socioeconomic ladder into a suburban life style."
Though the actual numbers of minorities in the suburbs are small compared with the overall suburban population, policy makers and urban planners say the suburbanization of minorities has important implications for the inner cities, for national urban policy and for the suburbs.
Members of minority groups, like others who choose to flee the cities, move to the suburbs for many reasons: affordable housing, better schools, lower cost of living and amenities like space and greenery. But most often, they say, they move to escape the violence and incivility associated with cities.
Michael and Verna Frazier of Washington, D.C., recently joined the exodus to the suburbs. Black professionals who reveled in living where the population was predominantly black and middle class, they were committed urban dwellers who had expected to raise their two daughters in the city. Then came a predawn burglary last fall.
"I heard them and they heard me, and so they left," said Mr. Frazier, a professor of political science at Howard University here. "But our physical safety had been jeopardized. That did it for us."
Today, the Fraziers live in nearby Temple Hills, Md.
In New Orleans, Mateo Suarez, a fifth-generation resident of the city's Seventh Ward, a working-class, largely Creole area, is thinking about leaving the city for the first time in his life.
Gone are the evenings when neighbors would sit on their porches and talk into the night, he said. Gone, too, is the community where an adult could correct a child -- and the child would obey. Nights are now punctuated with the sounds of gunfire.
"I was born and raised in this neighborhood," said Mr. Suarez, who was a civil rights activist in the 1960's and today runs the Rainbow and Pre-School Academy with his wife, Beverly Veronica. "But it's lost too much for me, primarily because of the youth and the violence."
Some sociologists contend that the departure of more affluent minorities to the suburbs from inner-city neighborhoods is simply adding to urban deterioration.
"It's a major problem for urban America," said Vincent Lane, chairman of the Chicago Housing Authority. "Suburbanization isn't about race now; it's about class. Nobody wants to be around poor people, because of all the problems that go along with poor people: poor schools, unsafe streets, gangs."
Over the last decade, Washington's population declined by nearly 100,000, to 600,000 today. The loss of blacks from the city was nearly three times as great as for whites -- 17,800 black households, as against 6,200 white.
According to a report issued in April by the Greater Washington Research Center, 57 percent of everyone who left the District headed for Northern Virginia and the near suburbs of Maryland. So heavy has the emigration of middle-class blacks been from Washington that Prince George's County, a 52 percent minority suburb, is something of a mecca for demographers.
"I was looking for safety, new brick construction and a price tag under $200,000," said Janet Lane, a native Washingtonian who recently moved to Mitchellville, in Prince George's County.
"What is going on is not so much black suburbanization as black middle-class suburbanization," Mr. Frey said.
Nor is the move limited to the black middle class. People of Hispanic descent as well as Asian-Americans experienced overall higher rates of suburbanization than did blacks during the same period.
 
The Hispanic Population
 In Washington, the heavily Hispanic neighborhoods of Adams-Morgan and Mount Pleasant are the first step to the heavily Hispanic and Asian suburbs of Northern Virginia and Maryland, a move often made within a single generation.
"For Hispanics, suburban life is the good life," said Jose Sueiro, editor of La Nacion, a weekly Spanish-language paper in Washington. "It's the American dream. First you go where you're comfortable, make a little money, get a little English and then head for the suburbs."
Nationally, from 1980 to 1990, the number of Hispanics living in the suburbs rose to 8.7 million from 5.1 million. The number of Hispanic people living in cities grew to 11.5 million in 1990 from 7.8 million in 1980. During the same 1980-90 period, the suburban Asian population grew by 2 million, to 3.5 million.
Nationally, the suburbs remain mostly white, with minorities constituting 41 percent of the city population and less than 18 percent of the suburban population. About 95 million whites lived in the suburbs in 1990, as against 87 million in 1980, a 9.2 percent increase.
Some analysts think this continuing flight to the suburbs will leave the cities more impoverished than ever, with large numbers of the least able.
But Richard P. Nathan, provost of the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State Univeristy of New York at Albany, said the perception that cities are increasingly composed primarily of underclass neighborhoods is incorrect. He noted that of the 24.5 million blacks residing in metropolitan areas in 1990, three-quarters were not living in poverty.
He and a group of scholars are studying minority and ethnic working- and middle-class urban neighborhoods in New York State, including Queens, Brooklyn, Buffalo and Rochester, as well as some suburban neighborhoods in Nassau County. He said they hold "hidden good news for cities." A recent analysis of census data by The New York Times, for example, showed that in middle-class Queens, blacks had passed whites in household income.
For now, however, middle-class blacks continue to follow their white counterparts to the suburbs, particularly in cities like Atlanta, Dallas and Washington, where blacks are prospering.
In Chicago, blacks are leaving the South Side for the nearby south suburbs of Country Club Hill, Chicago Heights, Hazelcrest and Markham. Hispanics are expanding west from the city into Maywood, Hillside, Bellwood. Asians head north to Skokie and Naperville.
In Washington, black middle-class flight to the suburbs has become one of the major issues in the upcoming mayoral race this fall. The city needs a strong middle class for its tax base.
The move by the Fraziers of Temple Hill allowed them not only to find an affordable house in a safe neighborhood but also to send their children to a public magnet school instead of the private school they had attended in Washington.
The move to Maryland, Mr. Frazier said, meant an immediate $1,000-a-month savings on schools.
"Now we have a house that would have cost over $150,000 more in the District," Mr. Frazier said. "When you add up all the plusses versus the minuses, it's worth the 20-minute commute."

HEADLINE: Selling Growth Drug for Children: The Legal and Ethical Questions

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

 BODY:
The companies that make and market a genetically engineered drug face charges that they have crossed legal and ethical lines in promoting their product, in the process tainting trusted relationships between doctors and patients, and parents and school systems.
The drug is Protropin, a genetically engineered version of human growth hormone made by Genentech Inc. that can make some short children grow taller than they otherwise would. A Federal grand jury in Minneapolis this month indicted a doctor, David R. Brown of Minneapolis, on charges that he had received $1.1 million in kickbacks to prescribe the drug. 
 The grand jury also indicted Edmon R. Jennings, the vice president for sales and marketing at Genentech, as well as the company that distributes the drug, Caremark Inc., and three of its officials.
A House subcommittee led by Representative Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, is also investigating marketing practices by Genentech and Caremark, including payments for surveys to find short children in schools. This practice may be funneling children to doctors who would treat them with Protropin, Mr. Wyden said.
The drug, which costs $20,000 to $40,000 a year or more, is approved for the treatment of children whose bodies do not make sufficient quantities of human growth hormone and thus are destined to be very short. But once a drug is on the market, doctors can prescribe it for other conditions at their discretion.
Many medical experts say they have long been concerned that children who have a normal amount of human growth hormone and no medical problems but are simply short are being given the drug despite a lack of convincing evidence that it increases their final adult height. It is not know if Dr. Brown prescribed the drug for any children who had the normal amount of the hormone, but he was one of the most frequent prescribers of the drug in the country with 350 patients receiving the treatment.
Fran Price, the executive director of the Human Growth Foundation, a nonprofit group that works with people with growth problems and is financed mainly by the two companies, said a recently published study concluded that 20,000 children were considered medically eligible for the therapy because they have insufficient human growth hormone.
Genentech says about 15,000 children a year take its drug; thousands of other children take Humantrope, a nearly identical drug made by Eli Lilly & Company.
The 51-count indictment says the payments to Dr. Brown were made by Genentech, of South San Francisco, and by Caremark of Northbrook, Ill.
Joseph Duffy, a Chicago lawyer who is representing Dr. Brown, said that Dr. Brown emphatically denied the accusations against him and that the money he had received was for research and consulting. "There was nothing untoward or illegal about it," Mr. Duffy said.
Jim Weiss, a Genentech spokesman, said the company stood behind Mr. Jennings: "Genentech was not named in this indictment. These are allegations. There is not anything proven."
Caremark, in a prepared statement, said it "absolutely denies any wrongdoing and believes it will be vindicated when the facts are evaluated in an unbiased form."
 
Further Inquiry Under Way
 An official at the Department of Health and Human Services, who insisted on anonymity, and Steve Jennings, a staff member for Representative Wyden, say a Federal investigation is under way to determine whether other doctors around the country received money from the companies and if any did, under what circumstances.
Mr. Wyden, chairman of the House subcommittee on regulation and technology, plans to hold hearings on the marketing of the drug within 60 days.
Almost as soon as Protropin was approved for sale in 1985 it became a critical product for Genentech. The drug has sales of $217 million a year, more than a third of the company's total revenue, Mr. Weiss said.
But as the drug's sales took off, some pediatricians and medical ethicists began asking whether it was being overpromoted as a sort of cosmetic endocrinology in attempts to make normal, but short, children grow. So who were the 15,000 children taking the Genentech drug? And why were so many taking Protropin rather than the Eli Lilly version, Humantrope?
The two drugs have the same wholesale price, but Protropin may cost patients substantially more. Its sole distributor is Caremark, which charges a variety of prices, said Robert Campbell, a senior analyst at the Principal Mutual Life Insurance Company in Des Moines. Mr. Campbell, who reviews charges for the drugs, said Protropin cost on average 30 percent more than Humantrope.
In the indictment, the grand jury charged that there was a conspiracy involving Dr. Brown, Caremark and its officials and Mr. Jennings of Genentech to defraud the Federal Medicaid program through a kickback scheme intended to sell Protropin. Dr. Brown's patients included children on Medicaid.
 
What the Indictment Said
 The indictment gave this account:
The conspiracy began when Mr. Jennings of Genentech wrote Dr. Brown a letter dated Feb. 5, 1986, "agreeing to explore Brown's desire to become involved with Genentech 'in a very significant way.' "
In September 1986, Caremark's predecessor, Caremark Home Health Care of America, executed an agreement giving Dr. Brown a grant. On July 9, 1987, a Caremark employee sent a memo to Mr. Jennings stating that Dr. Brown would receive 5 percent of revenues for the Protropin he prescribed and calculating that he was owed, at that time, $103,551. Dr. Brown wrote a letter to Mr. Jennings dated June 9, 1987, saying he wanted to make sales of $2.3 million for 1987 and $1.35 million for 1986 the "bases for our program."
But in early 1988, lawyers for Baxter International Inc., which owned Caremark at the time, said they were uncomfortable with the agreement with Dr. Brown and wanted to restructure it to make the payments as research grants. This was the start of a complicated series of payments to Dr. Brown, through various entities, including a new company that Dr. Brown started in 1991, Applied Biomedical Consultants.
The research grants were paid by Caremark, with contributions from Genentech. But, the indictment says, though Dr. Brown received $409,000 for research between 1988 and 1992, "he hadn't published any research results and his research was not enlightening." He received various other payments from the companies.
Medical experts say the indictment concerning Protropin may have disturbing reverberations.
When told of the indictment, Dr. Alan Garber, an internist and economist at Stanford University, said that while the accusations against Dr. Brown, Genentech and Caremark, if true, were unethical and criminal, there was a larger issue. "One of the most important aspects of the physician-patient relationship is trust," he said. "Even the appearance of a conflict of interest is devastating."
Dr. John Fletcher, a medical ethicist at the University of Virginia, when told about the accusations concerning the marketing of Protropin, said he was also concerned by the apparent conflict of interest that arose when Genentech and Caremark sponsored studies that had identified short children in schools.
The companies, sometimes indirectly, have sponsored such studies in several states, including Georgia and North Carolina. In the case of North Carolina, Genentech paid $10,000 a year to Susan Parker, the wife of a pediatric endocrinologist, Dr. Mark Parker, in Charlotte, N.C., to do a three-year study that would find short children in the schools and refer them to doctors for evaluation. The Mecklenburg Medical Society said Dr. Parker was the only pediatric endocrinologist in Charlotte.
Mrs. Parker, a nonpracticing pediatric nurse, began the study in 1989. With the Board of Education's permission, she had the school nurses measure young children to detect growth defects that might be signs of serious medical problems, like kidney problems or brain tumors.
David Hains, a spokesman for the Charlotte-Mecklenburg school system, said the schools sent out letters to the parents of children who were found to have possible abnormal growth rates, suggesting that the parents take their children to a pediatrician and asking the parents to return a form filled out by their doctor.
Mr. Hains now says he feels the study was a mistake because he thinks the schools were being used by Genentech.
Mrs. Parker has not yet published her results. Mr. Weiss of Genentech said: "We gave her an unrestricted grant. We have no access to the data until they are published and we aren't in a position to force her to publish." Mrs. Parker said she intended to publish but wants to get "final measurements on the children this fall and do a questionnaire with the families" to learn what had been the result of the letters sent home.
Dr. Parker said he did not know of any children who came to him for growth hormone treatments as a result of his wife's study, but it would not bother him if some had. He said he had 112 children on human growth hormone, adding, "I have never pressured anybody to take growth hormone." But one family that was referred to him disagrees.
John P. Towle said he was so outraged by his experiences with Dr. Parker that he wrote to Jeremy Rifkin, the director of the Foundation on Economic Trends, which monitors the biotechnology industry and has long campaigned against the sale of human growth hormone to children who have no hormonal disorders.
The Towles were referred to Dr. Parker by their pediatrician because their son, Brodie, was short. Dr. Parker, they said, pressured them to give their son human growth hormone.
Terri Towle said in a telephone interview that neither she, her husband, nor Brodie was concerned by the boy's height, but agreed to see Dr. Parker because they wanted to rule out serious medical problems. At 11 years of age, Brodie is 50 inches tall, which is well below average, she said. But, Mrs. Towle said, she is short and her whole family is short. Brodie's projected height is 5 feet 6 inches, the same as Mrs. Towle's father. Mrs. Towle said Dr. Parker had asked her what she would say to Brodie when he grew up and learned that "he could have been five-ten."
Offended and upset, Mrs. Towle said, she left Dr. Parker's office and changed pediatricians as well. The new pediatrician is perfectly happy with Brodie's growth rate, which is a normal rate, she said.

HEADLINE: A Siberian Railroad, From 'Hero' to Disaster

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KOMSOMOLSK-ON-AMUR, Rus sia

 BODY:
It has been exactly two decades since they came here by the thousands, traveling across Siberia by rail, bus and even on foot to help forge the last great link in the proletarian paradise.
Idealistic young Communists rising one final time to a challenge from the Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev, they cast their personal lives aside and dedicated themselves to creating the Baikal-Amur Mainline: the BAM, as it has always been called. 
 "The BAM will cut the primordial taiga," Mr. Brezhnev said in 1971, referring to the permafrost and placing the colossal project's completion among the central goals of Soviet life. "It will bring enormous wealth to the motherland. It will create the biggest industrial region we have ever seen. Cities and towns will grow like flowers."
As a railroad, the BAM would snake through some of the roughest terrain on earth, not only opening the riches of Siberia to a nation that desperately needed its incalculable wealth but also providing a transportation alternative to the Trans-Siberian Railroad that would be far less vulnerable to Chinese attack.
 
A Last Hurrah
 As an idea, what the Soviet leaders called "the Hero Project of the Century," the BAM was an unconscious last hurrah, a grand, idealistic gesture for delivering desperately needed adrenaline to a faltering empire.
"BAM was the world to us," said Aleksandr Y. Manyakin, who was 22 in 1974 when he heard Mr. Brezhnev's plea at that year's conference of the Young Communist League to drop everything and set out for Siberia. Like many of his friends and fellow students, he complied immediately.
"It was all so romantic," Mr. Manyakin, now an unemployed engineer, recalled, his eyes still glistening at the memory. "This was the last great frontier. We were going to build cities for millions and harness the wealth of Russia. It is hard to describe how thrilled we were."
But like the empire itself, the BAM has turned to nothing. There were to be no "cities for millions" on the cruel Siberian soil. The wealth of the region largely remains locked beneath its unforgiving land. The so-called BAM Zone, a total of some 580,000 square miles, or about the size of Alaska, has fewer people living within it now than it did in 1991, when the railroad was officially completed. And in cities like Komsomolsk-on-Amur, where the population has fallen from 350,000 to 305,000 in eight years, people are leaving so fast that city officials have all but stopped planning the future.
Finished at a cost that Western economists say was at least $20 billion, the BAM became one of the century's most expensive public works disasters, in human as well as financial terms.
It was a project conceived on the scale of the Pharaohs. To lay the track, its builders had to blast through seven mountain ranges, erect more than 4,000 bridges and move nearly a billion cubic feet of earth in a climate where metal shatters like glass in the winter and leather falls apart in the summer heat. Far from opening the vastness of Siberia, however, the BAM chewed up the dreams and lives of tens of thousands of dedicated youngsters.
Although it operates on its entire length from Lake Baikal to the Amur River, few train whistles were ever heard along the desolate tracks. In the 1980's, 11 separate ministries pledged money to the project; 130 research institutes studied its engineering problems and its financial and social possibilities. An entire Government agency, Glavbamstroy (the Central BAM Construction Agency) was created to orchestrate the adventure.
Dozens of hastily constructed BAM towns were thrown up along the route, which ran 2,100 miles from Ust-Kut on the Lena River in the West to this Far Eastern city, which was built in the 1930's by an equally devoted and hardy band of Communist pioneers. Most of those towns stand empty now, settlements with half-built railroad stations, a few shoddy homes lacking windows or doors, and almost nothing else.
Fifty miles from here, in a town called DSZ (from the Russian acronym for House Building Factory), where regiments of carpenters were scheduled to live, slabs of concrete lie untouched in the rangy weeds. Water towers stand empty. There are no paved roads, no schools, no stores. The only signs of life are a few wooden shacks that were there long before the railroad.
The most ambitious of the BAM towns -- Tynda, the capital of the BAM Zone and Komsomolsk-on-Amur, its eastern terminus -- are strewn with half-built Soviet apartment blocks and construction cranes that have not moved in nearly a decade.
"Even until last year the Government said they still intended to invest in the BAM," said Aleksandr A. Ivanov, director of the Federal Employment Services office here. "It is clear to me, and to everybody here now, that nobody is going to spend another dollar on it. And that means we have some hard thinking to do."
The entire economy of the region became dependent on the project. And everyone assumed that the BAM, like the Government that created it, would provide for them.
 
Tension and Bitterness
 The tension and disappointment at the results are obvious in Komosmolsk-on-Amur. Bitterness has led to heightened divorce rates, problem drinking even by Russian standards and widespread domestic violence. Desperate to assuage factory workers who have not been paid since March, officials here are struggling to find a way out of their demographic and economic nightmares. For now, they are tripling the average unemployment compensation to workers with families. And they are paying the same amount to those who are working and can show that they need the money.
Most people do. Starting in August, for as long as it will last, many experienced factory workers will receive 300,000 rubles, or about $140. That is a relatively large sum in these parts, where no factory is operating at full power and many are not operating at all. But the alternative, federal officials acknowledge, is an accelerated exodus from a region that can afford no more departures.
"The problem is that the future of the entire area was planned around the BAM," Mr. Ivanov said.
"We have the bricks for a chicken factory sitting five miles away. It was to be a huge supplier of food, to the builders of BAM, and the settlements they were going to create. There was an automobile plant to be constructed. Schools were drawn onto the maps. All that is now forgotten. Our future was tied to the BAM and our past was tied to defense. When a young family comes to me and asks about its prospects, it's hard for me to tell them to stay."
 
Submarine Company in Deep
 The biggest enterprise in the city, the Lenin Shipbuilding Factory, which makes submarines, is in trouble so deep that even its recent shift toward fabricating commercial fishing trawlers cannot begin to help. The city's airplane factory has not finished a plane in a year.
Many people here were angered this year when Yegor T. Gaidar, head of the Russia's Choice political party and a leading advocate of a free market, came to town and said publicly that there simply was not enough work to support the population.
But he was right.
"People here see the future, and it makes them very depressed," said Ina G. Karpovna, a psychologist employed by the city government. "They feel that their Government has forgotten them. They don't see a job that can come in the future, and they live so far from the center of the country that sometimes they feel the don't even belong in it. They don't know what to do."
 
First Arrivals in 1932
 Komsomolsk-on-Amur was founded to connect the ends of the enormous country, not isolate them. Its first settlers arrived in 1932, on a ship called the Columbus, at the order of the leaders of the Central Committee of the Communist Party. They fought their way through frozen rivers, impassable forests and a climate that is loved by no one. Half of the initial delegation of 900 died in the first winter. But those that survived hacked a lovely city out of the woods on the wide banks of the Amur River, and for years Komsomolsk, the City of Youth, had been a leading bulwark in the Soviet eastern defense.
"To me this city is connected to a heroic cause, a great struggle," said Sergei S. Syrnev, 79, one of those who came to build Komsomolsk-on-Amur more than 60 years ago. Mr. Syrnev keeps his BAM Almanacs on a bookcase in his bedroom across from framed pictures of Stalin and Lenin.
"To build this town with my own hands and see the generations of special people come here, it was great," he continued. "I am not one to say we should go back to the old ways, to Communism. We need the future here with us. But the BAM was going to bring us that. And without it I don't know what will."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press;
The Boston Herald, an aggressive tabloid, sets out to prove
that there is life after ownership by Rupert Murdoch.

BYLINE: By William Glaberson 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
PATRICK J. PURCELL has an idea for his newspaper. "If we're a tabloid," he said, "let's be a real tabloid with a personality and a feistiness that will make people more interested."
Mr. Purcell's ideas are quite influential at The Boston Herald, the tabloid in question, because he owns it. He bought it six months ago from Rupert Murdoch, his old boss. Mr. Purcell, 46, had been publisher of The Herald and of The New York Post and was president of Mr. Murdoch's News America Publishing Inc. 
 So, with a bit of tinkering -- and a lift from a recovering New England economy -- The Boston Herald, one of those big-city papers that always seems to be living on borrowed time, is now testing whether there is life after Murdoch.
The new owner likes to say he has a "Three P's" plan for the paper. It should be, he says, Populist, Passionate and Phunny.
Already, Mr. Purcell's team has the Three P's Religion. The new editor he installed in April, Andrew F. Costello Jr., a longtime Herald man, said the paper had to ease up on one of its old obsessions: competition with The Boston Globe, the much larger and more sober broadsheet.
"In some respects," Mr. Costello said last week, "we became too competitive with The Globe. In competing against them, we became too much like them."
The Globe, owned by The New York Times Company, has a daily circulation of 500,337, down from 504,869 a year earlier, while The Herald has a daily circulation of 312,779, down from 337,543, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations report for the six months that ended March 31.
In the new Herald, Mr. Purcell said, readers will see much less "esoteric" investigative journalism, like a series of articles last year on the state pension plan.
What will they see more of? Mr. Purcell is particularly proud of Herald Heroes, a good-news series he started about ordinary people who make a difference.
Some readers worry that the big splash The Herald gave to a single case of flesh-destroying bacteria on Martha's Vineyard this month was another sign of the paper's new brand of journalism.
The Herald's own media critic, Jon Klarfeld, wrote on Friday that the coverage of the bacteria appeared "overwrought."
Some journalists inside Mr. Purcell's newsroom say they are edgy when a former executive of Mr. Murdoch's empire says he wants more tabloid in his tabloid.
In any event, said Mark Jurkowitz, the media critic for The Boston Phoenix, The Herald has been suffering a brain drain of some of its more experienced journalists that will make the changes Mr. Purcell has in mind harder to accomplish. And even in the best of worlds, Mr. Jurkowitz said, Mr. Purcell's Three P's vision will be difficult to realize. "It's hard to make a newspaper passionate and funny," Mr. Jurkowitz said.
And then, of course, there is a fourth "P" that Mr. Purcell doesn't even need to mention. Without Mr. Murdoch's resources, The Herald needs to be profitable.
"Previously," Mr. Purcell said, referring to the days he ran The Herald for Mr. Murdoch, "I didn't have to walk down the hall to the finance department to find out how much money was in the bank."
In recent years, Mr. Purcell said, the paper has had some profitable and some unprofitable years. The fiscal year that ended in June, he said, was the best in years, with profits nearly double the $1.4 million that was the highest annual profit during the Murdoch years. (Mr. Murdoch bought The Herald in 1982 and Mr. Purcell became its publisher in 1984.) The paper's annual revenue, he said, is about $90 million.
Mr. Purcell, a former advertising salesman who climbed through the ranks of Mr. Murdoch's American publishing company, is experienced in the hardball aspects of newspaper publishing. He was one of Mr. Murdoch's frontmen in some particularly tough battles with newspaper competitors and unions.
He has already sent out signals that he is not about to ease up on any of those fights. One of his early actions after he became the owner on Feb. 14 was a demand for substantial savings from the newsroom budget, including layoffs. He is still in a standoff with the union representing editorial and business employees.
Jeffrey Krasner, a reporter who is vice chairman of The Newspaper Guild at The Herald, said Mr. Purcell learned his lessons well from Mr. Murdoch, who cultivates an image of being tough with newspaper unions.
Mr. Purcell says he hopes to make peace with the guild in a few weeks. But what he mostly wants to talk about are plans to use the better economic times to rebuild the paper.
In September, he will introduce what he calls a new Sunday Herald, adding new style, health, education and home sections, expanded coverage of personal finance and sports and a new full-color television guide.
The investment in the Sunday paper is aimed at strengthening one of The Herald's weakest links. On average, just 207,814 copies were sold each Sunday during the six-month period that ended in March, down from 233,507 in the period a year earlier. The Sunday Globe sold 815,265 copies, up from 811,409 in the comparable 1993 period.
There is one last P: Pugnacious. Even if The Herald will imitate The Globe less than it used to, there is little sign that Mr. Purcell's underdog will cease its continuing efforts to annoy its bigger rival.
This summer on Cape Cod, The Herald sliced its 50-cent cover price in half and ran radio advertising all over the Cape. Mr. Purcell said the campaign brought more than 3,000 new readers to The Herald.
Richard Gulla, a spokesman for The Globe, said the move did not affect The Globe's circulation. The ads did not mention The Globe by name, but they did note that the tabloid Herald doesn't block a reader's tan on the beach, "unlike that large, cumbersome Boston newspaper."

The Economy
The proliferation of desktop publishing has brought a new growth industry, the counterfeiting of virtually undetectable fraudulent checks, and banks and law enforcement officials say the cost to the economy could reach $1 billion this year. Those who carry out this check fraud are using the same inexpensive personal computers that transformed the way millions of businesses produce newsletters and advertising. The criminals feed their computers images of good checks drawn on good accounts. [Page A1.] 
 As a consensus grew that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates soon, quite possibly on Tuesday, members of the central bank's interest-rate committee were expressing concern that the economy might be growing faster than sustainable. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Rising Rates: Jarring Truth

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
The unexpected rises in interest rates in Italy and Sweden last week resulted from special factors in those countries, but they still served as a jarring reminder to West European financial markets that a long period of declining rates is drawing to an end.
Italy's decision on Thursday to push its discount rate up half a point, to 7.5 percent, and Sweden's move earlier that day to raise its benchmark lending rate by half a point, to 8 percent, sent European stock and bond markets tumbling on Friday and threw currency markets into turmoil. 
 With investors betting that the rate increases might slow or reverse Germany's policy of cautious rate reductions, the mark jumped against the dollar, despite expectations of a rate increase soon in the United States. The dollar closed in Europe on Friday at 1.550 marks, down from 1.575 late Thursday.
 
Isolated Cases?
 But economists said that the markets probably overreacted and that what happened in Italy and Sweden, while not devoid of influence on economic and monetary policy in the rest of Europe, should not be seen as a harbinger of similar moves in Germany, the Continent's economic engine, or in other nations.
"What happened in Italy and Sweden is a result of problems that are essentially domestic and specific to those countries," David Kern, the chief economist at National Westminster Bank in London, said.
In Italy, analysts said, the central bank was trying to send a message to political leaders that they must deal aggressively and rapidly with the country's huge and growing budget deficit. Italy's fiscal problems have badly undermined the value of the lira at a time of uncertainty about the coalition Government headed by Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi.
In Sweden, there are clear signs of resurgent inflation as the country struggles with a large budget deficit and political instability. Only a month before a general election, the Conservative Government of Prime Minister Carl Bildt is trailing its left-wing Social Democratic rivals.
"What you had was two independent central banks sending loud warning shots to Governments that they have to do something on the fiscal side and do it now," Phyllis Reed, an economist at Barclays de Zoette Wedd in London, said.
 
 
Panic Selling of Stocks
 The Swedish and Italian actions were enough to set off a short, sharp wave of panic selling in thinly traded summertime stock markets that have been fixated on interest rate moves. In Frankfurt, the DAX index was down on Friday by 30.6 points, or 1.42 percent, to close at 2,124.68. In Paris, the CAC-40 index in Paris fell 31.98 points, or 1.57 percent, to 2,006.95. Only the London exchange, where investors have been anticipating a British rate increase for months, shrugged off the news, rising 4.1 points on Friday to close at 3,142.3.
"While the specific triggers were domestic, the moves did touch a raw nerve," Mr. Kern said. "They highlight the uncertainty and the unease in the financial markets, particularly the bond market, that we have been seeing since February."
The Federal Reserve's decision to reverse course and begin raising official interest rates in the United States in February set off a swoon in global bond markets that dragged down most equity markets as well.
Led by Germany, European nations had been cutting rates for two years in an attempt to steer their economies out of a deep recession. Of the leading European nations, only Britain is far enough along the recovery path that it is close to tightening monetary policy.
But Britain is not expected to act for at least another month or two, and most analysts had expected that Germany, followed by other nations on the Continent, would cut rates at least once more in the fall and then not begin raising them until their economies picked up next year.
Mr. Kern said the Italian and Swedish rate increases slightly decreased the likelihood that Germany would cut rates again. But Michael O'Hanlon, chief international economist at Kidder Peabody Securities in London, said he still expected the Bundesbank to cut rates half a point in the fall, probably after the national elections in October. Germany's discount rate now stands at 4.5 percent and its Lombard rate at 6 percent.
"We don't expect the moves in Italy and Sweden to have any effect, with the exception of creating a safe-haven move into the D-mark," Mr. O'Hanlon said. "A stronger D-mark improves the inflation profile in our view and gives them more confidence that they can cut rates."
A stronger currency makes exports more expensive, but makes imports cheaper, thereby reducing inflationary pressures.
Ms. Reed said that if the Bank of Italy's rate increase stimulated the Government to produce a credible deficit-cutting program, the central bank might even turn around and reduce rates again.

HEADLINE: Fed Looks At Growth And Risk

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, is a man in the difficult position of trying to tiptoe as close as possible to a line he cannot see and must not cross.
Mr. Greenspan wants the economy to grow as near as possible at the level that economists call its maximum sustainable capacity -- that is, the greatest growth that does not produce inflationary pressure as factories pile on overtime and bid up the prices of raw material. 
 To prevent the economy from crossing that line, even temporarily, the Federal Reserve now seems certain to raise short-term interest rates soon, quite possibly on Tuesday at a meeting of the central bank's rate-setting committee. Seven members of that group expressed concern in separate interviews over the last two weeks that the economy might be growing too quickly.
While a consensus may be forming within the Fed, there is considerable debate outside it, both about the concept of maximum sustainable output and the central bank's sense of its nearness.
 
A Preference for Growth
 There are many Democrats in Congress who see nothing wrong with unlimited output. To them, the notion that the American economy might grow too fast seems appalling on the face of it.
Others in Congress and a few officials in the Clinton Administration reluctantly accept the concept of maximum sustainable growth, but think that the Federal Reserve underestimates how fast the economy can grow without setting off inflation.
They are alarmed by the prospect that the Fed will raise interest rates again, even though the Labor Department reported last week that the Consumer Price Index and the Producer Price Index both showed only modest increases in July, excluding volatile food and energy prices.
"What's wrong with growth and jobs if it's not being reflected in inflation?" Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, asked.
The answer provided by Mr. Greenspan in testimony last Wednesday, and supported by some of President Clinton's economic advisers, is that Government statistics are so slow to show inflation that by the time the figures clearly show rising prices, it is too late. Once inflation has taken hold, pressure rises on the Federal Reserve to slow the growth of money circulating in the economy by raising interest rates sharply, something than can cause a recession.
"Running over capacity is more like crossing a line than going off a cliff -- nothing abrupt changes," said Alan S. Blinder, the new vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, in an interview a week ago. "The dangers of running over are that you start running into higher rates of inflation."
The problem, as Mr. Greenspan acknowledged on Wednesday is that nobody is able to measure precisely the economy's maximum capacity, or whether the economy is about to cross the line on any given day.
Federal Reserve officials think that the line is very close now. Mr. Blinder said that while the economy might have been three-quarters of a percentage point to one-and-a-half points below full capacity in the spring, most of the gap "has been closed since then, and probably only a little bit remains."
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of the Council of Economic Advisers, said in the spring that the economy was operating at 99 percent of capacity, but is reluctant now to say whether the economy has arrived there.
"We're operating in the range of capacity," she said.
The Council of Economic Advisers tried to estimate the maximum capacity during the 1960's and 1970's, but the Reagan Administration abandoned the effort because officials could not decide how to make forecasts on capacity reflect the supply-side effects they predicted from lower taxes. "I just didn't find it terribly useful for the work we were doing," said Murray L. Weidenbaum, who halted the estimates while serving as Mr. Reagan's first chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.
Some private analysts using big computer models still try to make estimates. Allen Sinai, chief economist at Lehman Brothers, said that the American economy operated at one-tenth of 1 percent above capacity in the second quarter of this year, crossing the line for the first time since autumn 1990.
Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee last month that he had seen some, but not all, of the early signals that he would expect of an economy reaching full capacity. There were shortages of truck drivers and construction workers. More companies were delivering goods late because of backlogs in orders. And manufacturers were paying more for their raw material, he said.
"As yet, these sorts of indications do not seem to be widespread across the economy," Mr. Greenspan said then. "Nonetheless, we shall need to be particularly alert to these emerging signs in considering further adjustments to policy in the period ahead."
Reaching full capacity does not mean that the economy stops growing. It just means that the economy cannot grow any faster than capacity itself increases, which rises as the labor force expands and as companies learn to produce more with the same equipment and number of employees.
Estimates of annual capacity growth range from 2.4 percent to 2.8 percent. Actual output grew at an annual rate of 3.7 percent in the second quarter. The Clinton Administration assumed in its projection last month that economic growth would slow to 2.6 percent in 1996 and 2.5 percent in subsequent years as the economy reached this natural speed limit.
 
Factory Output as a Gauge
 In trying to estimate the economy's potential to produce goods and services, economists look first at the unemployment rate and at the parts of the economy with readily measurable capacity: factories and mines. Manufacturing accounts for only one-fifth of the nation's output, according to the Commerce Department, but is more easily measured than the output of services -- a wide-ranging category that now makes up three-fifths of the economy and covers everything from haircuts to investment banking.
Mr. Greenspan said last week that he thought the Fed's measurements of factory capacity utilization were among the few accurate economic statistics the Federal Government produces.
The nation's factories operated at 82.9 percent of capacity in the second quarter of this year, the highest level since 1989. On Monday, the Fed is scheduled to issue its estimates of capacity utilization and industrial production for July, the last important indicators it will see before the rate meeting on Tuesday.
Edward W. Kelley Jr., a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, said in a recent interview that Fed officials would also review the unemployment rate on Tuesday. Unemployment stood at 6.1 percent of the work force during July, a rate that most Fed officials see as consistent with an economy at full capacity.
If more workers had currently useful skills, or if businesses were more efficient and could produce more with the employees and equipment they have, then the nation's potential capacity to produce goods and services could increase faster. The Administration contends that its worker-training programs and other initiatives will increase the nation's economic potential.
But Wall Street analysts are gloomy about the prospects of this happening, pointing out that the Administration's programs, potentially effective or not, have been drastically scaled back in the Congressional budget process.
Mr. Sinai of Lehman Brothers remarked, "The policy, starting now, is to slow growth and increase potential -- it's the only way to finesse the business cycle."
