HEADLINE: In Boat Races, Dragons Roar and Tradition Lives

 BODY:
Poised at the prow of a Chinese dragon boat, Jack Ribeiro beat the drum yesterday to set the pace for his team. Synchronized by the thundering drumbeats, the 20-member crew paddled furiously in swift, short strokes.
The team members' low grunts were buried by the splashing of foamy white waves on the lake in Flushing Meadows Corona Park in Queens. Three slim teakwood boats -- decorated with dragon heads at the prow and dragon tails at the stern and painted in the traditional colors of gold, green, blue and red -- roared toward the finish line in the Greater New York Championship Race of the Chinese Dragon Boat Festival. 
 Thirty teams competed in the weekend races, an American version of a 2,000 year-old Chinese tradition that takes place in southern China during the Summer Festival, the season's most important holiday. The four winning teams will compete in the national finals in the Hudson River near Battery Park City on Sunday, with the winner to represent the United States in the 1995 international dragon boat races in Hong Kong.
Dragon-boat racing is gaining momentum as a sport in the United States, said Henry Wan, chairman of the race. Four years ago, in the first year of the New York competition, there were only 10 teams, he said, adding that there were now more than 50 teams competing on the West Coast and in Iowa, Virginia, Boston and Philadelphia.
 
Different From Crew
 Dragon-boat racing is different from western crew racing. The person steering the boat is separate from the guide, who beats a drum and does not paddle, said Kevin Mayberry, captain of a team sponsored by Deloitte & Touche. The paddles of a dragon boat are shorter than crew oars, and their blades are smaller and straight, not curved, he said. This slows down the boat, but speed is made up through quicker strokes, up to 100 a minute, instead of the 32 strokes in crew.
Nearly half of the participants in the race are non-Chinese. Companies like AT&T, Debevoise & Plimpton, Deloitte & Touche and Marine Midland Bank promote the sport because it fosters unity and team spirit, Mr. Wan said. Its eclectic participants also include students, police officers, firefighters and construction workers.
"It feels different," said James Lawless, an associate in the law firm of Battle Fowler and the captain of its team, the Battling Barristers. "It's nice to be a part of something that's not American but very much a part of New York."
But for many Chinese-Americans, the sport has a deeper significance. It gives them an opportunity to reaffirm their identity and to renew their emotional ties with ancestral homeland.
"When I was little, the race was part of my life," said Kenny Cheung, 32, a captain of an AT&T team. "When I came to this country from Hong Kong, I missed it terribly."
 
Helping the Community
 Michael Geoghegan, senior executive vice president of Hong Kong Bank, which sponsored the race, said his company became involved because it wanted to give something back to the Chinese community. "We have 33,000 depositors in Chinatown and Flushing area," he said.
In China the boat races are part of the festivities commemorating the death of a court minister, Qu Yuan, who lived in 400 B.C. and was renowned for his righteousness. This year, the holiday fell on June 23. But cold weather and races in other cities delayed the New York race, said Roger Tam, a spokesman for the Hong Kong Economic and Trade Office, which organized the event.
While you do not have to be Chinese to paddle, following Chinese customs can help with winning. Members of The Big Apple team, made up of New York City firefighters and college students, faithfully gorged on tofu stew and buns filled with sweet red bean paste before their race. Michael Levin, a team member who raced in Hong Kong in 1991, went a step further and gobbled down a sweet rice dumpling before the race. His team came in first in its group during the preliminaries, and second overall.

GRAPHIC: Photo: One of the Chinese dragon boats racing on Saturday. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
The Cold War and Its Unanswerable Questions

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG 

 BODY:

The Cold War
A History
By Martin Walker
392 pages. A John Macrae Book/Henry Holt & Company. $30.
The cold war was an ideological war, a weapons war and an economic war. It lasted longer than World War I, World War II and the Korean and Vietnam Wars combined. Now that only one of the adversaries remains a superpower, Western historians are warring over several theoretical questions: When did the cold war actually begin? Was the Soviet Union alone responsible or should some of the blame be shared by the United States? Can any American Administration take credit for "winning" the cold war? Was the cold war avoidable or were the United States and the Soviet Union, in the phrase of the disarmament expert Paul C. Warnke, two apes on a treadmill? 
 In a highly readable book, "The Cold War," Martin Walker grapples with most of these questions without necessarily answering them. He examines almost half a century of confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union. His book smites both sides with long-forgotten details about the distrust that caused Washington and Moscow to destroy their wartime alliance the moment Nazi Germany was defeated. He writes from strength: now the United States bureau chief of the London newspaper The Guardian, he also reported from Moscow and wrote "The Waking Giant: Gorbachev and Perestroika."
Mr. Walker begins his fairly evenhanded survey with the 1945 Yalta conference of the Allied leaders to agree on war strategy against Germany and Japan and settle the broad outlines of the peace. He then covers the effect of the dropping of the atomic bombs and the buildup of terrifying nuclear arsenals, satellites in space, the Cuban missile crisis during the Kennedy Presidency, the American loss in Vietnam, the policy of containment, the demise and revival of detente, Mikhail Gorbachev and the end of the cold war.
Throughout "The Cold War," the author delivers telling scenes of conflict in Washington between statesmen who wanted to trust the Soviet Union and those who were opposed to any postwar aid that might sustain the war-battered Communist regime. In the early days of the Truman Presidency, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson wanted to share the atom bomb's secrets with the Russians as a goodwill gesture. And Under Secretary of State Dean Acheson argued: "The advantage of being ahead in such a race is nothing, compared with not having the race." But neither Stimson nor Acheson prevailed.
Recent revisionist historians have shifted some of the fault for the cold war to American rigidity. Yet nothing in the Stalin record -- as exposed by Kremlin leaders themselves after the dictator's death -- offered hope for a renewal of the wartime alliance or democratization in the Soviet Union and its satellites, which were held in line by Russian tanks.
Mr. Walker's book isn't quite revisionist history, yet at times he seems inclined to see the bright, neo-Orwellian, side of the cold war. What I found most startling was his cool emphasis on the positive economic achievements of the cold war for the world.
Writing about the two major shooting wars in Korea and Vietnam during the cold war era, he makes much of the fact that "America's cold war defense budgets also pumped investment into the now-booming economies of the Pacific Rim. Japan's economic miracle can be dated with some precision to the effect of the Korean War, when Japan became the main base for the U.S. war effort." Again, on the Vietnam War, he says that "Japanese Hondas and stereos and radios packed the PX stores on the American bases.
"The hotel boom of Bangkok followed the Thai capital's designation as a main rest-and-recreation center."
This sanguine interpretation neglects the human side of the equation: the millions of military and civilian casualties in both wars, the waste of resources that might have been used to improve living standards instead of sophisticated armaments and the environmental damage caused by chemical weapons and aerial bombing. Korea and Vietnam were not PX-land.
On the tantalizing question of whether the cold war was inevitable, Mr. Walker writes: "It is just possible, had Roosevelt lived, and had there been no stricken Europe between them, no Western European Allies still festooned in embarrassing colonial entanglements, and in a most prickly pride, that the cold war might not have got under way. But Roosevelt was dead, the Americans had the monopoly of the bomb and Europe sprawled between the victors, to be occupied, rescued or fought over."
There are enough ifs here to render even guesswork futile, but the author's speculation is pleasing to contemplate.
Fiction may be considered inappropriate as valid history by nostalgic cold warriors on both sides who are still claiming credit for the end of the cold war. Nevertheless, there's an admirable human quality and perhaps more than a measure of truth in what John le Carre's exemplary intelligence agent, George Smiley, had to say about the cold war in "The Secret Pilgrim":
"It was man who ended the cold war in case you didn't notice. It wasn't weaponry, or technology, or armies, or campaigns. It was just man. Not even Western man either, as it happened, but our sworn enemy in the East, who went into the streets, faced the bullets and the batons and said: 'We've had enough.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Martin Walker (Henry Holt & Company)

HEADLINE: POP REVIEW;
From India, With Stops On the Way

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

 BODY:
XLNC, which performed on Thursday night at S.O.B.'s with the singer Bindu, is probably the first contemporary Indian bhangra band to perform to an integrated audience in New York. It's surprising that it has taken so long, considering that the hybrid called bhangra, a mix of harvest festival music from Punjab in Northern India and reggae, rap, techno and club music, actually comes from England. Like hip-hop, bhangra has become a way for a minority culture -- in this case, Indians born in Britain -- to find identity and empowerment through its own music.
XLNC (pronounced "excellency") is among bhangra's youngest upstarts. On Thursday, its dance music, powered by the adrenaline tempos of the two-headed dholak drum and the larger, congalike dhol drum, insured that the dance floor remained a sea of waving arms and airborne dollar bills the entire night. Harbajan Singh Talwar and Dave Singh sang mostly in Punjabi, but also in Hindi and English, closing almost every song with rousing chants of "Hey!" Mr. Talwar, in particular, had a resonant voice that soared majestically over the band's good-time grooves. Two keyboardists mixed the traditional and the modern, playing everything from repetitive house-music riffs to spiraling flutelike melodies. 
 Because of the economics of touring, Bindu left her own backing band in England and performed with XLNC. Though Bindu's high, pinched voice is ravishing, its marriage to XLNC sounded forced at times. The band tended to outrun and overpower her more ethereal vocals.
It was still refreshing to hear both acts live. On their most recent albums and singles, available on the Multitone label, XLNC and Bindu sound slicker and more produced than Ace of Base, George Michael and the other pop stars they sometimes emulate. In concert, the alienating sheen was absent, replaced by a party atmosphere where mistakes and rawness were allowed, so long as the slap and thud of the dholak and dahl didn't stop.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Harbajan is a singer with the group XLNC, which is based in England and sings the music of northern India. (Thomas Dallal for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
A First-Place Team Looking for Handout

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MONTREAL

 BODY:
In the humid confines of what is surely the ugliest stadium in North America, Claude Brochu, the president of the Montreal Expos, ponders the essential contradiction of his team: with the second-lowest payroll it is in first place in the National League East with the best record in baseball.
"We're living a miracle now," Brochu said Thursday, molded into a contoured yellow plastic seat inside empty Olympic Stadium. "But we have no margin for error. If we make mistakes, we can't buy ourselves out." 
 The Expos were in Pittsburgh as Brochu spoke, playing their final game before the players strike, which began after games ended Thursday night.
The strike may wreck Manager Felipe Alou's team's best chance for post-season glory since the strike-shortened season in 1981. Right fielder Moises Alou is hitting .339, with 22 home runs. First baseman Larry Walker is at .322, with 19 homers. Pitcher Ken Hill is 16-5. Pedro Martinez, acquired last fall from the Dodgers, is 11-5.
The Expos are 74-40, three and a half games better than the Yankees.
Their payroll is $18.8 million. Only the Pirates' payroll of $13.5 million is leaner, but their record is 53-61, and they are up for sale.
"We spent too much this year," said Brochu, only slightly tongue-in-cheek. "The payroll should have been $14 million."
The question lingers: If the Expos are so adept at winning on the cheap, why does this so-called small-market team require the revenue-sharing/ salary cap plan demanded by owners and rejected by players?
"Revenue sharing and the cap are inseparable; that's what we've decided," said Brochu, in a voice accented with the sound of a native Quebecer. "We need to reduce the spread between team payrolls. The overriding issue is an element of cost control. The cap is a question of survival."
 
The Free Agent Walk
 Spoken just like Richard Ravitch, the owners' gravel-voiced chief negotiator. Ravitch has held up Montreal as an example of a team that has survived on the financial edge, but will have to rid itself, one by one, of players like Walker, Alou and Marquis Grissom as they become free agents, as the Pirates did, with Barry Bonds, Bobby Bonilla and Doug Drabek.
Walker is in the final year of his deal, Grissom has one more year and Alou cannot turn toward free-agent wealth until 1996. The Expos have a small coterie of millionaires on a team paid mostly in the chintzy low six figures. Walker makes $4.02 million, Grissom $3.56 million, Hill $2.5 million, pitcher John Wetteland $2.25 million and Alou, an extraordinary bargain, at $1.4 million.
"If I keep this team together, it will be a $30 million payroll next year," Brochu said.
Yet through deft scouting that has regularly brought up three or four solid minor leaguers each season, and smart, cost-conscious acquisitions, the Expos have wrung a .649 winning percentage out of its low-level revenues.
"You can't live on miracles forever," Brochu said.
But if Brochu's claims are right, he has been doing well hanging on. The team made $1 million (Canadian) in profits in 1992 and 1993, or about $600,000 in United States dollars. This season, the team was projected to lose about $6 million, in part because of the $7 million downdraft in national television revenues this season.
"Maybe if we'd gone to the end, won the World Series, we'd break even," he said. "But now, the losses will be horrendous."
In the owners' proposed revenue-sharing plan, money would shift from cash-rich teams like the Yankees, Mets and Dodgers to revenue-poor clubs like the Expos, Pirates, Milwaukee Brewers and San Diego Padres. A cap would then be set, and teams would be able to spend from 84 percent to 110 percent of it.
Brochu said revenue sharing -- essentially found money from his richer, recalcitrant brethren -- would let him keep his pricier players, and afford low-paid rising stars like first baseman Cliff Floyd ($109,500), shortstop Wil Cordero ($200,000) and pitcher Gil Heredia ($135,000) when their salaries soar.
 
Competitive Figures
 "If we can spend to 84 percent of the cap," Brochu said, "we can compete better than most other clubs at 120 percent."
But Montreal may be lucky if enough revenue is redistributed to allow it to spend to the minimum on the cap.
"From the plans I've heard, no more than $8 million would be redistributed to the small-market clubs," said Andrew Zimbalist, a Smith College economics professor and baseball finance expert.
So, for example, a $35 million cap would force clubs to spend at least $29.4 million. A transfer of $8 million atop Montreal's current $18.8 million payroll would fall short of the required spending level.
Brochu is a former executive vice president of Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Ltd., whose chairman, Charles Bronfman, owned the Expos from their inception in 1969. But Bronfman grew tired of soaring player salaries and put the team up for sale in 1990. When no local buyers appeared, Brochu assembled a group of local companies and the city of Montreal to purchase the team for $80 million.
"I put everything I own into it," said Brochu, who owns a 7.5 percent stake. Asked why, Brochu said jokingly, "Mr. Bronfman was looking for a bigger fool."
From his partners, Brochu received advice that forces him to be a miser: We're giving you $5 million each, now don't come back for more.
Brochu operates the team from a large ground-floor office at Olympic Stadium. On one wall are several caricatures drawn of him. On a credenza sit two bottles of Le Grand Orange wine, a Chardonnay and a Zinfandel, vintage 1992, courtesy of a former Expos deity, Rusty Staub.
Brochu and his parsimonious partners bought into inherently difficult straits: largely French-speaking Montreal has a deeper devotion to the Canadiens and has never supported the Expos with attendance of more than 2.3 million. Only 25 games are broadcast in English (there are 65 in French), and the market for advertising dollars is small.
"Montreal has the most difficult marketing job in all of baseball," said Peter Bavasi, who competed against the Expos when he ran the Blue Jays. "They have a difficult political environment, with the French separatism, and the split between the French and English-speaking constituencies. You have to be very creative to draw from both communities. It was never hard for the Blue Jays to market across Canada where the rest of the language is English."
Unlike the Blue Jays, the Expos are not a cash machine. Each city is in a large market (Toronto's is 3.8 million, Montreal's is 3.1 million) but the Blue Jays sell out the 50,516 Skydome setas every game. The Expos' average attendance this season has been a mere 24,543, barely half the 46,500 capacity.
 
Just Can't Get a Break
 The Expos' deal with Olympic Stadium, which is owned by the province of Quebec, generates about $3 million-a-year in revenues, "the second worst deal in baseball," Brochu said, and nothing from skybox rentals and parking fees. "We try to get a better deal, but they're not giving us a break," he said.
The sliding value of the Canadian dollar, said Brochu, means that by paying all players in United States dollars, the Expos lose at least $3 million annually on the unfavorable exchange rate.
So if Montreal is not a small market strictly by the standards of its population, it is a small-revenue market without a history of pennant success like the Blue Jays. Brochu bristled at criticism that the Expos are doing so well, operating with harsh financial discipline, and don't need help from revenue-sharing and the salary cap. Or that historically meager fan support proves that Montreal doesn't deserve a team and should move, as George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, said Wednesday.
Brochu's response is part standard owners' rhetoric, part hard reality.
"There's an air of contempt that small markets are mismanaged, that we're not marketing as we should, and we should move," Brochu said. "We have to be allowed to compete, and to do it for more than a snapshot of time."
For now, Brochu is playing ostrich, not thinking about the very real possibility that the owners will fail to enact revenue sharing and a salary cap. Without them, he insists that the Expos will become less valuable, and that he cannot sell out to a local buyer without taking a loss.
"I want a respectable return on my investment," Brochu said. "It shouldn't be like life insurance, where you have to die to get paid back."

HEADLINE: A Breakthrough on Korean Arms?

 BODY:
Nuclear diplomacy between the U.S. and North Korea made promising gains in an accord reached Friday in Geneva. The agreement not only assures that a temporary freeze in the North's nuclear program will remain in place until talks resume in September but also sketches a road map to a lasting solution.
It will take more hard work by negotiators to work out the details and leave Korea nuclear-free. But the agreement is an encouraging sign that North Korea is putting the brakes on its nuclear program even under its new leadership. 
 For two years, international inspectors verify, Pyongyang has kept its pledge not to reprocess spent nuclear fuel and extract plutonium for use in bombs. Now it has gone further.
The objects of immediate concern in Washington were the 8,000 spent fuel rods that the North provocatively removed from its reactor in May. The rods are starting to corrode in the cooling ponds where they are stored. The North will now arrange to put them in dry storage under international inspection. That postpones the need to reprocess them and allows more time to consummate an agreement that would prevent them from ever being used for bomb-making.
Such an agreement may well be foreshadowed by Friday's accord. The North pledged not to refuel the reactor for now, preventing more spent fuel from being generated. It will also halt construction of two larger reactors capable of expanding its output of spent fuel and seal its facility for reprocessing that fuel. These steps, the North has agreed, will all be verifiable by international inspection. In return, the U.S. agreed to end the North's diplomatic and economic isolation. The two sides will exchange liaison offices, a first step toward U.S. diplomatic recognition of North Korea. South Korea's President has now confirmed his promise to build light-water reactors, with Japanese financing, to replace the North's graphite models. These reactors are less liable to be used to generate plutonium usable in bombs than are Korea's current reactors. The U.S. will help meet the North's electricity needs while its reactors are being replaced.
The North has not yet agreed to give up the 8,000 spent fuel rods removed from its reactor at Yongbyon or to forgo refueling its reactor forever. Nor has it allowed special inspections to determine how much spent fuel it may have diverted in 1989. But the North did pledge to remain a party to the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and allow full access to all its nuclear sites as part of a final resolution. That is the key to eventually unlocking its nuclear past. In return, the U.S. would offer security assurances, including a pledge not to redeploy nuclear arms to South Korea.
The new Government in North Korea has defied the pessimists by beginning to turn the temporary freeze of its nuclear program into a permanent one. The promising accord is a rebuff to those in Washington and Seoul who were prepared to undermine the new regime in Pyongyang and risk bringing the nuclear crisis to a boil. It brings credit to the Clinton Administration, which had the courage to reject such hawkish counsel and pursue diplomacy.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Why the Rush?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Democrats accuse Republicans of delaying crime and health bills to make President Clinton look bad. But the truth is Democrats are rushing to judgment to avoid having to heed the voice of the people in an election only 12 weeks away.
The crime bill, temporarily stymied by the gun lobby, is far from dead. That is not merely because a President and a majority leadership can use puissant patronage -- and a reprise of last year's "Don't kill my young Presidency" -- to snatch back the votes of enough of the 58 recalcitrant House Democrats to save the party from gridlockjaw. 
 More to the political point, the crime bill has a good chance of passage because it has been presented as a "tough" measure, with prison-building, death-penalty and cop-subsidy elements emphasized, while its "soft" root-casuistry -- multibillion-dollar social spending on midnight basketball -- has been downplayed. The bill exemplifies heavy-spending conservatism, an oxymoron hard to beat.
The health care push, on the contrary, is now seen by voters for what it is: a return to Great Societyism.
Hillary Clinton anointed elite task forces, working in secret, to concoct a Government takeover of a seventh of the American economy, financed by cigarette smoke and mirrors. Eighteen months later, with her grandiose scheme widely derided and the public calling for sober second thought, her gurus have gone underground and not even her husband espouses the misbegotten "Clinton plan."
The ship of Government health care is now frantically jettisoning baggage to stay afloat in Congress. Democrats in the House are waiting to see how many bags of taxes and coercive controls the Senate will toss overboard.
For George Mitchell, the swan-singing Democratic leader in the Senate, timing has become everything. Never mind waiting for the Congressional Budget Office to cost out the latest bills; forget about serious debate of a Republican alternative, the sensible Dole-Packwood insurance reform.
The reason for his urgency: Mitchell believes the Democrats will lose three or four Senate seats in November. He must get that legislation into harbor before the liberal ship sinks, an event scheduled for Election Day. Massive change must be irreversible before the anticipated reverses.
His own bill, with its employer mandate and 1.75 percent tax on everybody's health insurance premium, is not intended to be passed. Despite White House blather about thus-far-no-further, Mitchell's first fallback position was launched as a bill to set up a compromise with a group headed by Republican Senator John Chafee of Rhode Island.
Chafee has been placed at the head of a bipartisan group that has labeled itself "mainstream," not so subtly suggesting that conservative opposition to Government-dominated medicine is extremist.
Ominously, Chafee is using Mitchell's liberal bill as his lodestar; meanwhile, Bob Dole is having fits because the renegade Republicans refuse to consider the conservative alternative. That signals a Mitchell-Chafee setup.
Beware the likely deal: Chafee's rump group comes up with a modified Mitchell bill, giving the Democrats enough votes to invoke cloture on any filibuster. Then the House would pass a Clintonite bill, pulling the House-Senate conferees back to the left, which Clinton would sign in the Return of the Comeback Kid. (Or, if Chafee's fixes are minor enough, the House would pass the liberal Senate bill.)
To prevent this deal, Chafee's Republican colleagues are telling him: "If we can prove how bad this Mitchell bill is in debate and stop it, we will take control of the Senate and offer health insurance reform in the spring."
If Mitchell and Chafee cannot ram their mainstreamliner through the Senate in a week or so, the House may go home to campaign.
Democratic liberals fear that expression of the popular will. That explains their rush to health judgment. Republicans -- even nonconservatives like Chafee -- should want voters to have a chance to influence the outcome of the most far-reaching legislation since the New Deal.
Democrats deny that the hurry is to make the President look leaderly, and thereby help Democrats avert losses in this fall's election. But their real reason for forcing Congressional action on health care is inescapable: to beat the voters to the punch.

HEADLINE: New Breed of Check Forgers Exploits Desktop Publishing

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
The proliferation of desktop publishing has brought a new growth industry, the counterfeiting of virtually undetectable fraudulent checks, and banks and law enforcement officials say the cost to the economy could reach $1 billion this year.
Perpetrators of this fast-growing kind of check fraud are using the same inexpensive personal computers with sophisticated graphics capabilities that transformed the way millions of legitimate businesses produce newsletters and advertising. 
 But the criminals are feeding their computers images of good checks drawn on good accounts. They change the date, the name of the payee and sometimes the check number, and make dozens of copies of the fake on a laser printer loaded with check paper, which can be bought at most stationery stores.
In a particularly brazen case, a Los Angeles-based gang has been roaming the country cashing fake payroll checks at banks, bank and law enforcement officials say. In the next few weeks, 12 members of the gang will be sentenced in Federal District Court in Charlotte, N.C., for their involvement in passing thousands of bad checks in the Southeast, totaling more than $2 million.
"They have hit all over the country," Jessie Wood, an investigator with the Secret Service in Charlotte, said in an interview recently. "They were in Boston last week with exactly the same kind of scheme."
The American Bankers Association says desktop publishing counterfeits are the No. 1 crime problem facing banks. And payroll check scams are only one of the myriad check fraud schemes plaguing not only banks but retailers. Crooks also commonly counterfeit large corporate checks, deposit them in a bank account -- either an existing one or a new account opened by the crook or by an accomplice -- and then draw on them. And around the country, an increasing number of criminals are cashing counterfeit checks in supermarkets, department stores and other retail establishments.
"We'll cash a payroll check if a customer spends 10 percent of it with us," said Angie Spoto, vice president of treasury operations at Ames Department Stores, a discount department store chain based in Rocky Hill, Conn., with 300 stores in 14 Northeast states. "It generates sales for us."
But it also generates losses. Of its $500 million in sales to people who paid by check in 1991, Ames wrote off 1.8 percent because of fraud. This year, it expects to cut that loss rate by half by installing check-reading devices at all of its 3,200 cash registers, which are linked to a national data base of deadbeats maintained by the Deluxe Corporation, a check printing company.
In California, the center of counterfeiting activity, transactions involving fraudulent checks rose fivefold last year at Wells Fargo Bank alone. In New York State, Chemical Bank reports a 50 percent increase so far this year.
Most check counterfeits operate in gangs, but individual entrepreneurship also abounds. John S. Halleron, a self-employed computer programmer who used to work at a payroll-check processing company, has been accused of passing nearly 100 fake checks he made with a software program for businesses called Create-a-Check. He will be tried as early as next week in Franklin County Court in Columbus, Ohio.
"Everything we see is computer-generated, so the items are a little bit better -- actually quite a bit better -- than they used to be," said Ed Lindsey, a detective in the bunco-forgery division of the Los Angeles Police Department. "It started getting out of hand three years ago and now it's gone beyond that -- it's out of control."
The problem is that commonly available computers can merge images seamlessly, creating seemingly official documents, even ones laden with elaborate decoration and "authenticated" with stamps and signatures. And the corner copy shop now has a machine that can make such a realistic color facsimile of a dollar bill that the Government is changing the currency's design.
 
 
Easier Than Copying Cash
 It is far easier to counterfeit checks than cash. For one thing, there is no standard check design. Indeed, more and more businesses are saving bank check fees by printing their own checks on standard office laser printers. These printers, of course, are also available to crooks, as are inexpensive scanners and graphics software to copy corporate logos and check designs. And with Americans writing 60 billion checks a year, it is relatively easy for crooks to steal one as a template. In some cases, they have accomplices that work in stores or banks. Sometimes they steal insurance payments or other checks out of the mail; sometimes they wait outside check cashing stores offering money to people to copy their paychecks.
"The information on your bank account is as available as every check you write," said Mary E. D'Agostino, a vice president and loss prevention manager for Wells Fargo. "Whoever handles that check -- the friend you write it to, the retail cashier, someone at the bank -- has access to that information."
Mr. Halleron in Columbus, for example, created fake checks with real account numbers that he took from the back of one of his own canceled checks, which had been endorsed with an account number, from a refund check issued him for returned merchandise, and from checks processed by the payroll company where he had worked, prosecutors said.
Once a counterfeit check is minted, the crook still has to turn it into cash. The operation of the Los Angeles gang, pieced together from interviews with Federal and local law enforcement officials, and from the indictments this spring of 27 members of the gang, is instructive.
Law enforcement officials say that the gang has an accomplice in a California bank who makes photocopies of checks from large companies as they pass through the bank's check clearing system. "Mules" pass the checks in return for 20 percent of the take.
Typically, cells of six or seven mules travel to a city with one or two controllers, who buy their tickets and provide the checks to forge. In Charlotte, the mules applied to the state motor vehicle department for nondriver photo identification cards. To arm the mules with second pieces of identification, the gang manufactured fake corporate ID's for the companies whose checks were being counterfeited.
Tellers were glad to cash what appeared to be genuine payroll checks -- drawn for about $800, a little less than the limit that most banks set for such transactions -- on good accounts that typically had millions of dollars on deposit. The gang would drive from branch to branch of the same bank cashing copies of the same check dozens of times a day.
 
 
$18,000 in One Day
 According to the Charlotte indictment, the gang cashed 39 checks in one day on the account of Pay Less Drug Stores, for a total of $26,000; 75 checks from Swiss Dairy for $50,000; 9 checks on the Rolm Company for $6,000 and 25 on Hilton Hotels, bringing in a total of $18,000.
After two or three days in one town, the gang typically moved into a different city, investigators said. The 27 indicted in Charlotte, including the 12 who pleaded guilty and are awaiting sentencing this month, were charged with cashing bad checks in 15 cities over four months.
The Charlotte banks noticed the problem when high-speed sorting machines spat out the phony checks because the laser-printed copies did not have the account number coded in magnetic ink, as good checks do.
"The girls that process checks called me up and said look at this: 18 checks that had been rejected all drawn on Pay Less drug store," said Bob Hansen, fraud investigator for Nationsbank in Charlotte.
Mr. Hanson immediately notified the Secret Service, which has jurisdiction over bank fraud. As the Federal investigation began, the banks themselves formed a fax network to share tips.
"It got so good we would send out a description of one guy and they would be locked up as they were walking into Wachovia or First Union," Mr. Hansen said, referring to the other large banks in the city.
The Secret Service was able to track down other check passers when they returned home to California because the checks they passed and the identification they used was in their real names. But the gang's masterminds, who continue to duplicate checks and send cells out across the nation to cash them, remain at large.
 
 
Banks Strike Back
 For years, banks played down their losses to check fraud. But as the costs have multiplied -- losses to all kinds of check fraud are estimated by banking experts to range from $5 billion to $10 billion a year -- the industry is fighting back.
Some banks are trying to make their checks harder to copy, putting small holograms on them and using special inks and printing processes that cannot be duplicated by copy machines or scanners. Features like these, however, help only if the clerk who receives a counterfeit check knows to look for them.
Wells Fargo pays tellers if they catch a fraud and hangs wanted posters with pictures of known forgers in its branches offering rewards for turning them in. (The bank has caught 27 of the 50 people for which it has issued posters.)
 Banks are also using computer technology to improve the age-old process of clearing paper checks. Some companies have started sending their banks an electronic list of the numbers and amounts of checks as they are written so the bank will immediately bounce any check that does not match.
Meanwhile, bank check clearing groups are developing electronic data bases of bad accounts to cut the time it takes to notify a bank that a bad check has been deposited. The New York Clearing House, which handles most checks in the New York metropolitan area, will begin such a system in December.
But in the cat-and-mouse game of catching counterfeiters, the banks have to work to stay ahead. Some banks gave tellers scanners to determine if the account number at the bottom of a check is printed with magnetic ink. But many crooks quickly discovered that laser printers that print with magnetic ink are available, making the counterfeit check undetectable even to machines.
Other efforts have been compromised equally quickly.
"We told the banks to put a certain safety feature on the checks, but someone figured out how to get around it," said Detective Lindsey of the Los Angeles police. "Each time we try something different with the banks, it seems to leak out."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 26, 1994, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Aug. 15 about an increase in counterfeit checks made with personal computers misstated the role of a software program in the case of John S. Halleron, who was charged with passing nearly 100 fake checks. Prosecutors in Franklin County, Ohio, say that the software, Create-a-Check, was found in Mr. Halleron's possession but that they do not know whether he used the software to create any of the counterfeit checks.

HEADLINE: Spinoffs Giving Research Alley Industrial Base

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
Since 1876, when Thomas Edison opened the Menlo Park laboratory where he invented the electric light and the phonograph, the marriage between science and business has found a home in New Jersey.
Color television, the videotape recorder and liquid crystal displays were all invented at RCA's research center, while AT&T Bell Laboratories created everything from the transistor to the laser. Today, what might be called Research Alley -- the Route 1 corridor from New Brunswick to Princeton -- is the core of the nation's greatest concentration of corporate research and development. 
 For all the continuing breakthroughs by the 125,000 scientists and engineers working in the state, though, one question stands out: where are dynamic new enterprises growing up locally to take advantage of the inventions born in New Jersey labs? Experts say they are too few and far between.
More out of necessity than choice, at least one group is at last trying to step into that void. The David Sarnoff Research Center in Princeton -- the former RCA Laboratories -- has recently helped support a handful of new companies in the hope of turning some of the starry-eyed dreams of the institute's 900 employees into money-making ventures. More are on the way.
"We no longer have a single corporate parent, so for us necessity is the mother of invention," said Dr. James E. Carnes, a former RCA executive who is the center's president. "What we realized we needed to do is recreate our own RCA, but the only way to do that today was by building a galaxy of different companies spinning around us. So that's our goal."
Already, one spinoff company, Sensar, is developing a technology that enables computers to recognize moving images almost instantaneously. Another is working on sophisticated chemical and nuclear-energy detection systems. A third, HealthNet, to be unveiled soon, plans to deliver health-care information through an interactive television network.
 
Used in Fiber Optics
 The shift in approach is evident in the experience of Dr. Gregory H. Olsen, who left a secure job at the Sarnoff center, more than a decade ago to start his own business providing a device used in fiber optic systems. (Sarnoff, which became largely self-supporting in 1987 after RCA was sold to General Electric, formally operates as a unit of SRI International, an independent research organization in Palo Alto, Calif.)
"It was pretty much of an academic atmosphere," Dr. Olsen recalled, describing the 9-to-5 life at the center in those days as comfortable, insulated and slow-moving. "I didn't fit in."
But two years ago, after selling his company for $12 million, Dr. Olsen returned to the bucolic 350-acre Sarnoff center campus to give a talk. "I didn't recognize the place," he said. "People were really plugged into the outside world."
Dr. Olsen now runs a new company, Sensors Unlimited, with close ties to the Sarnoff center, named for the longtime RCA chairman. Dr. Olsen markets a special kind of laser developed by scientists and engineers at the Sarnoff center and contracts with the institute to carry out research projects to help him develop new products.
If successful, the Sarnoff effort could provide a road map for scientific centers under intense pressure from their corporate parents to cut back on extraneous research. This could prove particularly important if an expected wave of mergers and acquisitions among communications and pharmaceutical giants makes orphans of other major research centers like Sarnoff.
It might also offer a model to those seeking to cultivate high-tech entrepreneurs in the region instead of seeing some of the extensive scientific know-how in the area left fallow or used mostly to seed new companies elsewhere.
 
Challenging Obstacles
 Entrepreneurs in the research corridor face challenging obstacles. Venture capital has been particularly hard to find. Regulatory impediments, especially for environmental standards, are high. Lately, it is often too expensive to build and operate new manufacturing sites close by.
Of even more importance, perhaps, is that leading industries in the area like communications, chemicals and pharmaceuticals have been dominated by large companies. They have traditions of secrecy and corporate loyalty that long discouraged many employees from leaving the shelter of their companies.
These drawbacks have already proved costly. For example, in biotechnology -- a seemingly natural outgrowth of the convergence of New Jersey's pharmaceutical industry and Manhattan's sophisticated teaching hospitals -- the New York metropolitan region trails well behind California and the Boston area as a company location.
"If you're talking about spinoffs from our research," conceded Robert B. Ford, a spokesman for Bell Labs, "I'd guess you'd have to say that Silicon Valley was invented here. I can't think, though, of too many ones nearby."
One reason is that life was so comfortable inside major industrial research centers like Bell Labs that few researchers were tempted to leave. "They called it the golden womb," said James Hughes, an economist at Rutgers University. "That's why you don't see a whole host of startup companies."
Annalee Saxenian, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley, recently wrote "Regional Advantage" (Harvard University Press, 1994), which examines Silicon Valley's success in bouncing back from the adversity of the early 1980's while many of the computer companies around Route 128 near Boston fared so poorly.
"It's not enough simply to build a science park and expect, like a field of dreams, for high-tech firms to come," she said. "What's important is that there has to be a closely knit regional network where companies not only compete intensely with each other but also learn from each other about changing markets and technologies."
Her research suggests why many costly state government programs around the country aimed at creating university-based technology centers and business "incubators" for nurturing newborn companies have been so disappointing.
 
Marketing Research Ideas
 New Jersey alone devoted a substantial share of a $350 million bond issue for higher education in 1988 to expanding an extensive network of advanced technology centers around the state to enhance industrial competitiveness. But William Ayers, president of Electron Transfer Technologies in Princeton, said: "Most of the money ended up being used by the universities. Very little of it got down to small entrepreneurs like us."
By contrast, the Sarnoff undertaking has the advantage of being run by people with experience in commercializing research ideas. The center was also a pioneer in high-definition television and is a leading member of the consortium that is working to define the standards for the coming generation of digital television. And the Sarnoff orbit is likely to contain many companies working with similar technologies.
"This is not an ivory tower," said James H. Clingham, Sarnoff's vice president for corporate affairs. "We're in the research business as a business in its own right. That drives everything we do."
 
Direct Incentives
 Unlike most other corporate and independent research centers, for instance, Sarnoff now provides direct incentives for researchers by offering them a share of the royalties and profits generated from their ideas. Under RCA, inventors received at most a $400 bonus for a patent.
More unusually, the center no longer discourages its inventors from going out on their own. It will even go so far as to help them start companies from within the center itself.
Chuni Ghosh, for example, recently began a venture, Princeton Electronic Systems, out of his lab at Sarnoff. Based on research into laser spectroscopy, he is developing a sophisticated system for detecting chemicals in the environment. It could be used by everyone from companies trying to locate tiny spills of toxic wastes to Pentagon officials keeping track of other countries that might be working on chemical weapons.
Last year, Dr. Ghosh arranged to work in partnership with the center, devoting some of his time to research and other time to his own company. Once there are profits, the Sarnoff center will receive a share.
Today, Dr. Ghosh has eight employees working out of the crowded lab, with plans to move to a separate site by the end of the year. To keep in close touch with developments at the research frontier, he wants to stay within four miles of the center.
"Sarnoff has never done anything like this before," said Dr. Ghosh, who came to the United States from India in 1979 to do advanced research. "I was amazed that Jim Carnes was so enthusiastic. It was much easier to work out an arrangement than I expected."
For his part, Dr. Carnes, the center's president, responds, "There is very little I will say no to these days."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 10, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Aug. 15 about links between science and business in New Jersey referred incompletely to the history of color television. The first practical demonstration was given in 1928 by John Logie Baird, a Scottish inventor; the version that is now considered the standard in the United States was developed at RCA's research center near Princeton.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The two-earner family is giving way to the three-job marriage, as millions of Americans are pressed to take more than one job. New Labor Department surveys show that seven million Americans work 15 million jobs. Most multiple jobholders are married and, increasingly, nearly as many are women as men. [Page A1.] 
 American industry increased production for the 14th consecutive month in July. Output rose two-tenths of 1 percent. [D1.]
A program to improve the skills of brokers, traders and other professionals was introduced by a group representing the securities industry and the leading stock and commodity exchanges. [D1.]
 
Companies
American Home Products sweetened its takeover bid for American Cyanamid to $9 billion. [D1.]
Bell Atlantic plans to take a $2.3 billion charge to write down old equipment and cut its work force by about 7.7 percent. [D1.]
The boards of Federated Department Stores and Macy approved a merger of the two retailers. The merger will pave the way for Macy to emerge from bankruptcy later this year. [D2.]
 Compaq Computer announced price cuts of 11 to 22 percent. The company, with a huge inventory and high profit margins, can afford a price war in personal computers. [D3.]
A deadline passed for bidders for Madison Square Garden, the arena owned by Viacom, without any indication of a winner. [D3.]
Mo Ostin will step down as head of Warner Brothers Records. Mr. Ostin built the music label into one of the world's biggest. [D3.]
A Canadian court allowed regulators to proceed with the liquidation of Confederation Life Insurance. [D3.]
Humana has been denied accreditation for a health maintenance organization it operates in South Florida. [D4.]
Thinking Machines plans to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The company had been seeking a suitor. [D4.]
Kmart reported a drop in second-quarter earnings. [D4.]
Ruth L. Otte is leaving as head of the Discovery Channel and the Learning Channel to join Knowledge Adventures. [D17.]
The head of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield is quitting. [B1.]
 
International
European weapons makers are increasingly working together as governments seek to save money by pooling arms programs. The move toward collaboration has accelerated a consolidation in the European arms industry, which has lagged behind American military contractors in adjusting to the spending cutbacks of the post-cold-war world. [D1.]
Russia said it would make $2 billion worth of rubles available in credits to help rebuild industry and agriculture. [D2.]
Markets Stock prices were mixed in cautious trading. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 8.42 points. [D6.]
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed as traders awaited a move by the Federal Reserve on interest rates. [D14.]
Coffee prices surged after another report on Brazil's frosts, this one saying that crop damage was worse than expected. [D13.]
There was little movement in the dollar. [D13.]
 
Today's Columns
Paint is hardly an exciting product, but Sherwin-Williams has done very well with it. Now many analysts are recommending its stock as one expected to outpace both a sluggish market and a sluggish building supply sector. Market Place. [D6.]
Are celebrity endorsements worth the money and headaches? A new study shows that such endorsements, at the very least, can slightly improve the stock price of the company spending money to hire a star. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D17.]

HEADLINE: Whitewater Whistle-Blower Is Put on Leave

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
An investigator at the Treasury Department agency who began the inquiry into a failed Arkansas savings and loan that has erupted into the Whitewater investigation was placed on paid leave today while she undergoes an internal review of her conduct, an agency official said.
The employee, L. Jean Lewis, was suspended along with two other investigators at the Resolution Trust Corporation, which, as the Federal agency managing the savings and loan bailouts, examines whether anyone is legally liable for the collapse of failed financial institutions, said Stephen Katsanos, the agency's spokesman. But the reason behind the move was unclear, and Mr. Katsanos, citing a concern for privacy, said he could not describe the accusations. 
 The suspensions were questioned by Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, who has led Republican efforts in the House to investigate Whitewater. "I'm sure the R.T.C. wouldn't take this step lightly, but this would appear to be a blatant effort to discredit the work product of a criminal investigative unit that has embarrassed the powers that be," Mr. Leach said in an interview with The Associated Press, which first reported the suspensions.
Mr. Katsanos said the paid leaves of absence for the three investigators were intended to allow time for "an internal investigation into some matters that were raised concerning internal rules and procedures."
"This is not punitive," he said.
Mr. Katsanos said the suspensions were expected to last about two weeks but could remain in effect indefinitely. "That's going to depend on how long it takes them to complete their investigation," he said.
Ms. Lewis was a leading figure in the decision by the Kansas City office of the trust corporation to forward to the Justice Department two complaints of possible criminal conduct centering on Madison Guaranty, the failed savings and loan owned by James B. McDougal, who was President Clinton's partner in the Whitewater real estate investment.
Ms. Lewis and her associates sent the first referral in the Madison case to the Justice Department in late summer of 1992. They submitted the second referral in the fall of 1993, after learning to their surprise that the Justice Department had declined to prosecute after getting the first referral.
 
Suspicions Raised
 The second referral included accusations that President Clinton may have benefited from Madison's collapse. Investigators said about $12,000 from Madison Guaranty had been deposited in Mr. Clinton's account at another Arkansas bank for the 1984 gubernatorial campaign.
Concern about the referral's mention of Mr. Clinton and the possibility that the matter might become the subject of news reports prompted a series of meetings between Treasury Department officials and White House aides. Those discussions were the focus of hearings in the House and Senate in recent weeks.
The substance of the referrals is still under investigation, but Robert B. Fiske Jr., the former independent counsel in the case, has found no criminal wrongdoing in the White House contacts with Treasury Department officials. Nevertheless, Kenneth W. Starr, who was recently appointed by a three-judge Federal panel to replace Mr. Fiske, is expected to review the contacts again.
Suspended along with Ms. Lewis were Richard Iorio, Ms. Lewis's immediate supervisor, and their superior, Lee Ausen. All three were involved in the criminal referrals in the Madison case.

HEADLINE: Republicans Meet Their Man;
Pataki Delivers His Bare-Bones Message: I'm Not Cuomo

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SYRACUSE, Aug. 12

 BODY:
The Republican clambake was a big success, and the reason was the tall man, somehow both elegant and awkward at once, who shook nearly every hand here. He leaned way over to sign his name, in blue marker, to a woman's T-shirt. "With your help, we're going to win," George E. Pataki, the Republican designee for governor, said again and again.
"So he's our man?" one Republican asked a friend. "Is he a sharp guy?" 
 The questions summed up much about this year's race for governor, as Mr. Pataki takes to the road to define himself as the man who would unseat Mario M. Cuomo. He has risen as Mr. Cuomo's chief rival, as a breathing reminder of what polls say is deep dissatisfaction with the Governor. Yet few people, even at die-hard Republican events like this, know him or what he stands for this early in the campaign.
The challenge, party strategists say, is to win the primary next month against Richard M. Rosenbaum, a former party chairman, and translate the discontent with Mr. Cuomo into votes for Mr. Pataki in the general election. So far, his message on the road, in small fund-raisers and meetings mostly with Republican groups, is heavy on the theme of change. He sticks to the basics: enacting the death penalty, cutting taxes and creating jobs.
But most of all he attacks Mr. Cuomo's record, offering in a dozen stops a day only a sprinkling of his own ideas and back-
ground.
"When Mario Cuomo wants to find out why we lead the nation in job losses, I have a simple suggestion: Governor, take a look in the mirror," Mr. Pataki said today at the opening of his regional office here, using a statistic that, like others he uses in speeches and commercials, is inaccurate, but not far off the mark. [Article, B4.]
"It's not simply about replacing a Democrat with a Republican or Cuomo with Pataki," Mr. Pataki said, his hands bobbing in the air before him. "It's about truly changing the direction of this state government."
His oratory on the stump seems aimed solely at becoming the "anybody" in what is widely called the "ABC vote," for "Anybody but Cuomo." In a twist on President Clinton's campaign slogan, ("It's the economy, stupid"), some people at events like this can be heard calling it the "ABCD vote" ("Anybody but Cuomo, dummy").
So far, Mr. Pataki has released only a handful of details of what he would do if elected. Many of these proposals have circulated for years among Republicans and anti-tax groups. He has advocated cutting the personal income tax to a maximum of 7.5 percent from the current 7.875 percent. (The tax had been scheduled to drop to 7.5 percent this year, but the Governor and Legislature decided to keep it at the current rate.) He also supports abolishing the surcharge on the corporate income tax immediately instead of over the next three years, lowering the capital gains tax and slashing state bureaucracy by not filling 30 percent of all vacant jobs.
But he has yet to adopt much of this into his stump speeches. More typical are passages like this, which he delivered last week before a Jewish group in Brooklyn and uses often, in various forms: "Mario Cuomo is a brilliant speaker and he is great at making excuses. He blamed Ronald Reagan. He blamed the Japanese. He blamed the national recession. He blamed international competition. But the fact of the matter is, it's the failed policies of this administration that are driving jobs and opportunity out of this state."
And that message was enough for many of the Republicans, and some Democrats, interviewed at Mr. Pataki's campaign stops last week, from Brooklyn to the Hudson Valley to Syracuse.
"I am very much against Cuomo," Marie Saunders, a Republican from just outside of Syracuse, said at the clambake at Hinerwadel's Grove in North Syracuse. And Mr. Pataki? "I wouldn't care what he did," she said. "He could dig ditches and I would vote for him. I really don't know too much about him."
Her friend Kermie McGrath added: "I think he's our savior. Mario Cuomo has ruined the state. I pray that the Republican Party can do something. Welfare has gotten out of hand. Crime has gotten out of hand. I'm really discouraged with New York State."
Ms. Saunders and Ms. McGrath, like nearly every Republican interviewed at several stops, said Mr. Pataki seemed to be a strong candidate. They said they were impressed with his resume, which he spins as a tale of a farm boy from Putnam County given all the opportunities a once-great state could offer: scholarships to Yale and Columbia Law School, a job at a big law firm in New York City, a 10-year political career in the Legislature.
 
Warm and Gangly
 They said he seemed decent and warm, if a bit stiff at times, endowed with a sort of gangliness his aides like to compare to Jimmy Stewart or Abraham Lincoln. That gangliness seems to extend to his speeches, which are competent and confident but no match for Mr. Cuomo's.
"It's definitely a detriment to George because he is going against a communicator on the level of Ronald Reagan," said Richard O'Beirne, head of a contractor's union in the Hudson Valley who attended a fund-raiser in Rockland County on Thursday that netted $20,000 for Mr. Pataki.
"George doesn't have that level of ability, but I don't know anybody else who does, either," said Mr. O'Beirne, whose union endorsed Mr. Pataki last week.
 
Wanted: A Platform
 But even as they praised Mr. Pataki, some Republicans said they wanted to hear more about his specific plans for governing. And with Democrats far outnumbering Republicans in the state, they said he would need a strong platform to attract dissatisfied Democrats.
"He's got to talk about the issues -- talk about the economy, talk about a lack of jobs," said Robert Giarrusso, the Onondaga County Republican chairman. "He can't just talk about them. He's got to come up with solutions."
Mr. Giarrusso said, however, that the campaign could wait until the primary next month before releasing the bulk of Mr. Pataki's plans.
"You are going to start hearing more about the size of government," he predicted. "You are going to hear more about privatization."
It is a truism that voters do not pay attention to politics until after Labor Day, and Mr. Pataki seems intent mostly on raising money and getting his name out right now. At the clambake, after about half an hour of shaking hands, people began to cry for him to take the microphone.
"I'm not going to speak long because nobody's going to listen," he said to an aide. "This is a party."

HEADLINE: Industrial Production Rises 0.2%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Despite lower output of motor vehicles and electricity, American industry raised production for the 14th consecutive month in July, Federal Reserve statistics showed today.
Today's report and one due out Tuesday on July housing starts will be the final pieces of national economic data before the Federal Reserve's chief policy-making body, the Federal Open Market Committee, meets to weigh the evidence for further increases in short-term interest rates. 
 Most analysts expect the Fed to increase the Federal funds rate, the overnight rate for loans between banks, by either a quarter-point or a half-point.
 
Little Effect Expected
 The report on industrial production, though a bit stronger than expected, was thought to have made little difference in the Fed's thinking.
"Slack in the economy is limited," said Paul W. Boltz, an economist with T. Rowe Price, the Baltimore investment firm.
Overall production rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month but output at the nation's factories climbed four-tenths of 1 percent, the most since April. Much of the rise was in machinery, industrial instruments, furniture and fixtures.
Declines in motor vehicles and parts have cut into factory gains for five consecutive months, said a report by Laurence H. Meyer & Associates of St. Louis, but "other sectors have taken up the slack."
Output at both mines and utilities fell markedly last month, with electric power and related coal production returning to more normal levels following exceptionally hot June weather, which swelled the use of air-conditioning. Coal is the biggest fuel source for electric plants.
Other restraining forces were a strike at what the Fed described as a leading maker of construction and mining equipment, apparently Caterpillar Inc., and continued weakness in the aircraft industry.
All in all, "production's moving along at a pretty good clip," said Darwin L. Beck, an economist at First Boston and once a Federal Reserve staff member, who said he expected the Fed to raise rates Tuesday for the fifth time this year.
He and others said the size of the increase would apparently depend on the Fed's assessment of the other side of the equation: whether goods would continue to attract buyers, especially consumers already feeling the effects of earlier rounds of rate increases.
Production of construction supplies, for example, has now fallen for two consecutive months because of a decrease in demand for housing. And automotive output fell 1.3 percent in July following even bigger declines in April and May and a negligible uptick in June.
 
Auto Production Drops
 Assembly of cars was at an annual rate of 6 million last month, down from 6.2 million in June, while truck production eased to 5.2 million from 5.3 million, according to the Fed's report.
The nation's industry operated at 83.9 percent of capacity last month, the same as in June. A one-tenth of a point rise in manufacturing -- to the same 83.1 percent level as prevailed in April and May -- was offset by slackened operating rates at mines and utilities.
Utilization in primary processing industries -- the Fed cited textiles, lumber, petroleum products and iron and steel -- remained well above their averages for 1967 to 1993. Industries using advanced processes were generally less stretched.
Categorized by market group, production of consumer goods rose four-tenths of 1 percent despite a 1.3 percent decline in automotive products, with appliances, television sets and other household durables particularly strong. Business equipment rose five-tenths of 1 percent while the decline in construction materials was a minimal one-tenth of 1 percent.
The index of industrial production now stands at 117.2, a level 17.2 percent higher than in 1987 and 5.6 percent higher than in July 1993, the report showed.

HEADLINE: Moonlighting Plus: 3-Job Families on the Rise

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
When Robin Thornburg lost her job as a $25,000-a-year paralegal, she was scared. Her husband, David, an office clerk, made barely enough to cover the groceries and the rent on their $700-a-month apartment in Arlington, Va. So, she is trying to make up the lost income by working two jobs -- as a full-time clerk for a loan company and a part-time bookkeeper for a company that rents out bodyguards.
"It kind of stinks, the two of us having so many jobs," said Mrs. Thornburg, who earns $600 a week, more than matching her former pay, but must work 55 hours to do it. "You argue about money and about hours, and on top of everything, we are both trying to get through college. We go different ways too much." 
 The Thornburgs are not alone. Just as women entered the labor force in huge numbers in the 70's and 80's, giving rise to the two-earner family, in the 90's one of these earners is taking on a second job, giving rise to the three-job marriage.
New Labor Department surveys of multiple jobholders, which this year, for the first time, are being compiled every month, give statistical underpinning to a trend that had been discernible largely through anecdote. Today, seven million Americans, or 6 percent of the work force, occupy 15 million jobs. Most multiple jobholders are married and, increasingly, nearly as many are women as men.
No other industrial nation approaches the United States in multiple jobholders, and the clear implication of such comparative analysis, says Richard Freeman, a Harvard labor economist, is that in other countries, wages from one job are sufficient.
"You would have thought that as women entered the work force, that would have been enough additional income, and dual jobholding would have declined," Mr. Freeman said. "Instead, the opposite has happened. Women going to work have not brought in enough income."
Before this year, the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics had counted multiple jobholders only periodically, with the last survey in 1991 and the one before that, in 1989. Until the 1980's, those soundings showed, most dual jobholders were men with full-time employment who moonlighted part time. Now almost as many women are dual jobholders. They, too, usually combine full-time and part-time work, the new monthly surveys show, although women are more likely than men to hold two part-time jobs.
Some of the three-job couples go this route because one spouse wants to break into a new line of work that is more satisfying or better paying. But the biggest portion, more than 40 percent, take the extra work to pay bills, the Labor Department reports.
The Gittings family combines both these reasons. Philip Gittings, who is 45, resigned in late 1993 as minister of a Presbyterian church in Caldwell, N.J., where he had earned more than $90,000 a year. His wife, Margaret, also held one job, as a retail executive at $50,000 a year.
"The situation in my last ministerial post was not as much fun as I wanted it to be," Mr. Gittings said. But he soon found that he was not earning enough in his new, more satisfying job at Executive Career Resource Group in Berwyn, Pa., a company that helps corporations relocate laid-off workers. With salary and commissions, he is on track to earn $40,000 this year, and has already received $14,000. But with a son entering college, that is not enough, even with his wife's income.
So, while still holding down his job at Executive Career Resource, where he works on average more than 30 hours a week, Mr. Gittings set up a consulting firm this spring. He has made $8,000 so far this year as a self-employed personnel consultant.
 
Losing Ground
 In many cases, wage stagnation has played a big role in pushing married people into so much work, economists say. For three decades after World War II, incomes mostly rose, but in the early 1970's, the progress stopped. Since then 80 percent of the nation's households have failed to gain ground, after their incomes -- mostly in wages -- are adjusted for inflation.
For many people, their "raise" has come from taking second and third jobs. Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said he had run into the phenomenon in numerous conversations during his travels as a member of the Cabinet. "It is symptomatic of the erosion of relatively well-paying employment," said Mr. Reich, who as a teacher and writer at Harvard had devoted a lot of his attention to wage and job issues.
The Thornburgs are fighting this erosion by holding down four jobs, according to the Labor Department's criteria. David Thornburg, a 250-pound ex-Army sergeant, is not only a $22,000-a-year office assistant at a law firm, but also a professional wrestler. "There is excellent money in professional wrestling and semi-fame, if I can catch on," said Mr. Thornburg, who is 25. So far, the big money has escaped him; his 13 matches this year have yielded $150 a match, and some marital stress.
"When he does wrestling, he is gone two or three days at a time," said Robin Thornburg, 24, who married David in 1988, while he was in the Army. "What he is trying to do is to become a promoter of wrestling and not just a wrestler, and I approve of that. Eventually, we have to get our lives down to two jobs if we are to have children."
Like Mr. Thornburg with his wrestling, Mr. Gittings also seeks a more satisfying career. "I did a lot of soul-searching and decided that my best skills were in consulting," not the ministry, Mr. Gittings said. As a consultant, he conducts personnel seminars at corporations and advises companies on matters like how to calm workers after big layoffs.
If one of his jobs gets his income back to his old level as a minister, will he give up the other? "Who knows what tomorrow will bring," he said. "I think my income at Economic Career Resource will grow, but I won't give up the other work. We are always in transition in life and the sooner we recognize that, the more mature we become."
 
Double-Duty Lawyer
 Like the Gittingses, Nathan M. Gundy 3d, who is 29, and his fiance, Dorva Dowdy, 28, sharing a home in Baltimore, are also embarked on a three-job relationship, seeking both money and, in his case, satisfaction. She is a $35,000-a-year computer specialist at a bank, and he is a corporate lawyer by day while at night musicians and performers make up his clientele.
After getting his law degree in 1988, he was a clerk for a judge and then worked for a year at a prestigious Washington law firm, earning $68,000, but finally leaving to open his own practice, negotiating contracts for entertainers and also booking them. "I had gotten some entertainment clients and I wanted to give this a go before I got too far down the line in my career," Mr. Gundy said.
He says his private practice now brings in $40,000 a year. But with marriage approaching, he decided that he needed more. So, Mr. Gundy has joined another Washington law firm, holding a temporary job at $500 a week that he hopes will become permanent. "I decided that I needed to put a couple of more boats in the water," he said, "for a little more security."
For most of the years since World War II, multiple jobholders constituted 5 percent or less of all working Americans, growing from three million people in the late 1950's to 5.7 million in 1985. But then in the late 1980's, as job creation and the economy grew briskly but incomes did not, multiple jobholding shifted upward, reaching 6 percent of the work force in 1989 and 1991.
 
Not All Are Counted
 That 6 percent level has not fallen back. It shows up today in the new monthly surveys. These findings, still tentative, might undercount dual jobholding, says John F. Stinson Jr., a bureau economist. Military personnel are not surveyed, for example, so an Army corporal moonlighting off base as a bartender or store clerk shows up as holding only one job.
And with the economy growing sufficiently to create four million additional jobs in the last 19 months, the opportunity exists to get the extra work. So does the motivation. While jobs have multiplied, wages have not risen; economic growth has been insufficient to make that happen. Among multiple jobholders who are counted, college professors, public school teachers and police officers are well represented. So are single mothers, divorced women and widows -- among them Barbara Holloway, divorced and in her 50's, who has taught elementary grades in Evanston, Ill., for 32 years.
During the last 10 of those years, Mrs. Holloway has also been a sales clerk at Lord & Taylor, working four nights a week and Sundays until her daughter, Kimberley, finished college in 1992. Since then, she has cut back to two nights and Sunday.
"I had hoped to be able to quit the second job when Kimberley was on her own, as she is now," said Mrs. Holloway, whose public school salary is $60,000. "But I can't; my income has not gone up enough to cover my own expenses."
 
The Biggest Category
 Unlike Ms. Holloway, the majority of the multiple jobholders, 56.5 percent, are married men and women, and many are trying to better their lot.
In Alexandria, Mrs. Thornburg says being laid off as the paralegal at a three-member law firm that had fallen on hard times was doubly frustrating. The paralegal job, if she had held it, would have counted toward a B.A. in legal studies at Marymount College, a degree she now hopes to get next year. Meanwhile, the income of her husband, who studies at a community college, is simply not enough.
"His take-home pay is $1,100 a month and the rent alone is $700," Mrs. Thornburg said. "Then there are credit cards, car payments, student loans, clothing."
Mrs. Thornburg signed up quickly with a temporary-help agency, which has sent her mostly to Athena Resources, a Washington firm that buys and sells bad loans. There, she has earned $10.50 an hour as a clerk, working eight-hour days. She also became a bookkeeper for the ICS Corporation, which provides bodyguards and other protection for executives. That job pays $12 an hour for 15 hours a week, done mostly at home.
Unlike Mr. Gittings, the former minister, Mrs. Thornburg talks of escaping dual jobholding. After she gets her Marymount degree, she will go for a master's in physical therapy. "Experienced paralegals can make $40,000," she said, "while a physical therapist starts at $70,000."
