HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
A study shows that celebrity endorsements of products can help a company's stock price. A little.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
IS signing stars as shills for products worth the often considerable cost and the headaches they sometimes cause? A new study comes to the intriguing conclusion that celebrity endorsements offer tangible, measurable benefits, albeit small, in at least one realm.
The study examined 110 instances of companies signing stars to pitch their wares during a 12-year period, from Paula Abdul for Diet Coke, L.A. Gear and Reebok to Bruce Willis for Seagram's wine coolers. It concluded that celebrity endorsements could improve the performance of the stock of a company that was spending money to hire a star. 
 "We started wondering whether all those millions of dollars were worthwhile," said Wagner A. Kamakura, an associate professor at the Joseph M. Katz Graduate School of Business at the University of Pittsburgh. He is the co-author of the study with Jagdish Agrawal, an assistant professor at the School of Business and Economics at California State University in Hayward, Calif. Both men teach marketing.
"Our main objective was to do a validity check on previous research in this area," Mr. Kamakura added, "which had focused on whether celebrity endorsements influence consumer attitudes.
"The consensus is that yes, they usually lead to some impact on the brand being endorsed, because of the transfer of imagery from celebrity to ad and from ad to brand. And there is anecdotal evidence they lead to increasing sales. But we wanted to do a more thorough study."
The interest of the pair was piqued by the recent surge of media interest in "spokes-stars" whose personal problems have embarrassed their sponsors, like O. J. Simpson (Hertz) and Michael Jackson (Pepsi-Cola International).
The lack of control that a marketer has over a celebrity -- even one it has signed to a lucrative long-term contract -- has emerged as a significant threat to the viability of celebrity endorsements. Indeed, Mr. Willis's affiliation with Seagram ended after reports that he had stopped drinking alcohol as a result of efforts to change his life style.
In some studies, consumers play down the influence of celebrities on their product choices, "because they state they don't believe celebrities are endorsing products for anything but the money," Mr. Kamakura said. "But consumers don't necessarily do what they say."
So to tackle the issue from another direction, Mr. Kamakura and Mr. Agrawal decided to examine the impact, if any, on the prices of shares in companies that announced the signings of celebrity endorsers, corrected for any general market trends.
Their idea was that "the investor reaction to what management has done is a more objective assessment," Mr. Kamakura said, because it might indicate "that investors are persuaded that a company is hiring a celebrity because it is confident about its product" or has a long-term strategy to invest in building brand equity -- and therefore its shares should be worth more.
A search of announcements of celebrity contracts yielded 207 examples from January 1980 through December 1992; 110 remained after excluding companies that were privately held or based overseas and made no stock data available.
Among the companies studied, in addition to those endorsed by Ms. Abdul and Mr. Willis, were the American Express Company (Paul Newman), Bristol-Myers Squibb (Joe Montana), the Gillette Company (Marvin Hagler), Nike Inc. (Jim Courier, Deion Sanders) and the Sara Lee Corporation (Michael Jordan, Phylicia Rashad).
In about 58 percent of the 110 instances, "there were positive increases in the prices of the stocks," Mr. Kamakura said, with the rest either negative or no effect. The average increase in the stock price was 0.44 percent.
"It's not much," he acknowledged, "but when you think about the large number of shares in a particular firm, it might represent a substantial sum."
The study concludes that the average increases in share prices "reflect the market's general belief that the expected incremental gain from celebrity endorsements exceeds the incremental costs of advertising due to such contracts."
Mr. Kamakura said he and Mr. Agrawal hoped their next study would focus on the effects on advertisers when celebrities who endorsed them "do something wrong." For instance, after Mr. Simpson's arrest, Hertz was the subject of widespread attention and considerable criticism, even though Mr. Simpson had not appeared in advertising for the car rental company since 1992.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Sherwin-Williams smoothly improves its performance.

BYLINE: By Leslie Wayne 

 BODY:
WATCHING paint dry, of course, is the classic line about the ultimate in boredom. But at the Sherwin-Williams Company, the nation's largest paint producer, drying paint is a precious sight -- and many on Wall Street agree. They are recommending the stock as one expected to outpace both a sluggish market and a sluggish building supply sector.
Just as the company advertises that its paints are impervious, the stock seems to be as well. The company has had 17 steady years of rising earnings, a balance sheet that is almost debt-fee, and a share price that has increased by 14 percent a year for the last decade -- with no signs of slowing. This translates into low risk but solid returns. 
 "It's an undervalued company," said Jeffrey Zekauskas, an analyst with First Manhattan Securities. "The demand for paint is surprisingly strong in both high and low interest rates environments. The stock is like the company -- very solid, very value-minded and very pro-shareholder."
The Cleveland company, founded in 1866, not only produces a broad array of paint brands, but it also has 2,000 company-owned retail stores to sell them. With a 35 percent share of the paint market, it is one of the few national brands in an industry of many small, privately held regional brands.
In addition to its Sherwin-Williams brand -- the one with the famous "Covers the Earth" symbol of paint pouring over a globe -- the company also makes a number of other well-known paints: Dutch Boy, Kem-Tone, and Martin Senour. These are sold through such superstores as Home Depot and Hechingers. The company also makes private label paints for Kmart and Sears, Roebuck.
"Paint is a growth market without much cyclicality," said Robert Curren, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, who rates the stock "above average." "It's driven by the total number of structures being fixed up," he said. "Every increase in the number of homes, and in home sales, is a house where the paint is often replaced." Sherwin-Williams's fate isn't tied to housing starts. Paint is a cheap fix-up in good times and bad.
When current management took over 17 years ago, Sherwin-Williams was almost bankrupt, couldn't pay its dividend and its shareholders were revolting. But under its chief executive, John G. Breen, who was hired in 1978, a turnaround began that hasn't stopped. In recent years, the company's stores have been remodeled, improving per-store profits. Costs have been cut so that the company is now the industry's low-cost producer. And market share has increased through a cap on price rises. Moreover, as the Federal Government increases environmental restrictions on paint makers, many small, inefficient paint makers have been unable to compete, leading to industry consolidation.
"Between store remodelings and cost controls, margins have improved," said Sean D. Love, an analyst at CS First Boston, who rates the stock a buy. Recently, the stock has traded between $32 and $34 a share and closed yesterday at $32.75, up 12.5 cents. Analysts say that caveats are few: Rising titanium dioxide prices, a main paint component, caused the stock to dip to $30 in May. Environmental problems at a Chicago plant remain outstanding. And, the current stock price leaves room for only modest gains.
Last year, the company earned $1.85 a share, and most analysts expect it to earn $2.10 in 1994 and $2.35 in 1995. This translates into a share price of $37 to $49 within the next two years.
Norman F. Klopp, an analyst at the Roulston Research Corporation in Cleveland, has watched the company for more than 20 years and says investors should "buy carefully" and be "precise with their entry and exit level." He is a buyer at $30 a share, but a holder at $32.
And Lawrence J. Horan, an analyst at Prudential Securities, sees the stock at $37 in 12 months. "That's not a lot of upside," he said. "But in a flat market, to have more than 10 percent gain in a low-risk stock looks pretty attractive to me."

HEADLINE: Pataki's Grim Statistics Collide With the Facts

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:
Senator George E. Pataki's campaign against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is based on the premise that, as he often puts it, Mr. Cuomo "has made us No. 1 in all the wrong categories." In virtually every public appearance, and in a television commercial, Mr. Pataki says: "We are No. 1 in tax burden in America. We are No. 1 in spending in the country. And the inevitable result: we are No. 1 in job losses in America."
But government statistics show that none of those claims is true, although Mr. Cuomo may not take much solace from the facts. 
 Mr. Pataki's claim about taxes reflects a recurring debate in state politics about whether it is fairest to judge Mr. Cuomo's record by examining only state taxes or state and local taxes combined. The Governor argues that he cannot be blamed for local tax increases he did not impose. His opponents maintain that the state has shifted costs to local governments and forced them to raise property taxes to preserve services.
In either case, New York is not first. Census Bureau statistics show that in 1992, the last year for which figures are available, New York's state tax burden, measured as a percentage of personal income, ranked 22d. New York's combined state and local tax burden in 1991, the last year available, ranked second to Alaska, which has very low taxes on individuals but high business taxes .
Even that measurement has stayed almost constant during Mr. Cuomo's tenure. Some taxes, like those levied on businesses, cigarettes and petroleum, have been raised by Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature; others, like personal income taxes, have been cut significantly.
Concerning spending, New York ranks 11th in state spending as a percentage of personal income, and third when spending by the state and its local governments is combined, according to the Census Bureau.
The only way Mr. Pataki can argue that New York ranks first in job losses is by examining the period that Federal economists describe as the length of the national recession, from July 1990 to March 1991. During that period, New York lost more jobs, 272,000, than any other state, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. A fairer measurement that takes into account the state's size, however, looks at job losses as a percentage of a state's job base. New York ranked seventh in that category during the nine-month period.
Because New York did not begin to gain jobs consistently until last fall, a more complete measurement examines changes in the state's job picture from July 1990 to the present. During that period, New York ranked second to California in net job losses and second to Connecticut in the percentage of jobs lost.
Mr. Pataki also argues that job growth in New York trailed the national average in each of Mr. Cuomo's 12 years as Governor. Federal statistics show that this, too, is wrong, although not significantly. New York's job growth was higher than the national average by 13 one-hundredths of a percentage point in 1983, Mr. Cuomo's first year, and by one one-hundredth of a percentage point in 1986, according to Bureau of Labor Statistics figures.
Last, Mr. Pataki's oft-repeated claim that New York lost 300,000 jobs since the national recovery began while the rest of the nation has gained three million jobs is also untrue. The truth, however, may be even more damaging to Mr. Cuomo.
Employment figures adjusted for seasonal variations show that New York lost 150,200 jobs during that period, while the rest of the country gained almost 5.1 million jobs.

HEADLINE: Dow Drops 8.42 Amid Uncertainty on Fed

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market closed mixed yesterday amid unusually high levels of uncertainty as to what the Federal Reserve Board's interest-rate setting committee will do today.
A fifth increase in interest rates by the Fed's Open Market Committee would be sure to slow the economy further, perhaps bolstering bonds and strengthening the weak dollar. But it would also weaken corporate profits and thus hurt stocks, at least for the short run. 
 In the last few weeks, traders have interpreted each new piece of economic data as both encouraging and discouraging the Fed from raising rates.
But unless the Fed does something that the market does not expect, such as raising interest rates more than a half-percentage point or not raising them for a prolonged period, the likelihood is that the financial markets will continue to oscillate in wide trading ranges, some analysts say.
For stocks, that trading range may be 3,600 to 3,800 points for the Dow Jones industrial average. For bonds, it may be a yield of 7.62 percent to 7.25 percent on the 30-year Treasury bond.
Yesterday, while rising nearly 18 points shortly before 2 P.M., the Dow glided downward and looked as if it would close unchanged, but dropped abruptly minutes before the 4 P.M. close. The Standard & Poor's 500 followed a similar pattern.
But the Nasdaq composite index, while largely following the other two major indexes, abruptly shot up before the close, buoyed by technology stocks like Lotus Development.
The Dow fell 8.42 points, to 3,760.29, while the broader S.& P. 500 fell 0.72 point, to 461.23. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 1.28 points, to 732.89.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.25 point, to 254.52, with advancing stocks edging past declining stocks, 1,064 to 1,040. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 0.38 point, to 443.32.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 223.6 million shares, below this year's daily average of 280 million shares, but also below the exchange's even more restrained trading average of 260 million shares since June 1.
Blue chips like International Paper and Aluminum Company of America, oil companies like Mobil and retailers like Wal-Mart Stores fell in price.
 
Technology Stocks Advance
 A group of technology stocks, including those of Intel, Cisco Systems, Oracle Systems and Tele-Communications, helped lift the Nasdaq composite index. But it was Lotus, which rose 2 1/2, to 44 1/2, that gave the index its biggest boost.
A Dean Witter Reynolds analyst said an updated version of Lotus's Notes communication software made Lotus more attractive and he repeated his "buy" recommendation. Notes software is designed to let computer users send video images of each other over telephone lines as well as send document images back and forth.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 17 fell, led by International Paper, which dropped 1 1/4, to 72, on no immediate news. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 250 fell, led by Wal-Mart, which fell 1/4, to 23 3/4, on no immediate news.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Little Changed As Move by Fed Is Awaited

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed against other leading currencies yesterday as traders waited to see whether the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates today.
Few traders wanted to make big bets on the direction of the dollar. Though most believe the Fed will push up short-term rates, they are not sure by how much. 
 Trading was also slowed by the Assumption Day holiday, which closed some European markets.
"The market doesn't really want to rally as people wait out tomorrow's rate rise," said Simon Fisher, associate director for foreign exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation.
In New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.5522 German marks, up from 1.5512 on Friday. At 100.15 yen, it was little changed from the late-Friday quote.
 
Committee to Meet
 The Fed's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee is to meet today, and traders believe the central bank will increase the Federal funds rate by at least a quarter of a point and perhaps by as much as a half. After four increases, starting in February, the rate is now 4.25 percent.
A quarter-point rise would probably have little effect on the dollar, because so many traders expect it. "It feels like it's almost a done deal," said Lynn Tierney, a vice president at Shawmut Bank of Boston N.A.
Ian Spence, managing director at Chemical Bank, said the currency market would be "disappointed in the Fed" if it raised rates only a quarter- point. But a half-point move "would be O.K. for the dollar," he said.
If the Fed raises rates by a half-point the dollar may rise against the German mark by as much as 1.5 pfennigs, Mr. Fisher said.
Higher interest rates make investments denominated in dollars more attractive, often increasing demand for the currency and pushing up its value.
Anticipation of a Fed move muted reaction to economic news yesteray. The Fed reported that capacity utilization at American factories was 83.9 percent in July, better than the 83.8 percent analysts had expected. That, coupled with news that industrial output grew for the 14th straight month, if only by two-tenths of 1 percent, suggested that the economy was growing fast enough to warrant higher interest rates.
The dollar was mixed against most other major currencies, finishing little changed at 5.3265 French francs, 1.3030 Swiss francs and 1,594.50 Italian lire. The British pound was lower at $1.5419, compared with $1.5480 late Friday. The Canadian dollar rose to 72.43 United States cents, from 72.36 on Friday.

HEADLINE: Europe Uniting in Building Arms

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Italy, France and Britain, each needing a new destroyer for its navy, set aside tradition for common sense last month and agreed to build the warships together. They awarded contracts that could run as high as $12 billion to a consortium of shipbuilding, electronics and armaments companies from the three nations.
"It will allow all three countries to benefit from better economies of scale as well as from pooling the technologies of three highly industrialized countries," Italy's Defense Minister, Cesare Previti, explained. 
 The Eurofrigate program, as it is known, is just one indication of how European governments and weapons makers are abandoning their go-it-alone approach to arms programs and moving toward greater collaboration. They are being driven partly by the European Union's attempts at greater coordination in foreign and military policy, and are being encouraged by the experience of Airbus, the multinational commercial jetliner project that has made Europe competitive with the United States in civil aviation.
As they do so, they are giving new impetus to a consolidation of the European arms industry, which despite shedding workers, closing some plants and completing a few mergers, has badly lagged behind its counterpart in the United States in adapting to the harsher business climate of the post-cold war world.
Given the immense costs involved, analysts said, European governments can no longer afford to be developing three new fighter planes as the United States concentrates its efforts on one new fighter, the F-22. No longer does it make sense to build three different tanks, or to keep British or Spanish suppliers, for example, from competing for French contracts.
At stake is not just saving money for taxpayers, but the ability of the European industry to remain a strong competitor to the United States in the shrinking but still vibrant global market for military aircraft, missiles, electronic systems and the other hardware of war.
Without the benefits of size, efficiency and pooled technical expertise, Europe may find it difficult to sell arms outside its own borders, a development that would ultimately lead to further shrinkage in the industry and perhaps the failure of some companies, analysts said.
"If they're going to survive, they have to move rapidly," said Paul Cornish, a military industry analyst at the Royal Institute of International Affairs in London. "European industry has realized that if it does not get itself together and pull its socks up, it will lose out to the U.S."
In the United States, military contractors have consolidated with breathtaking speed. Some companies, like the General Dynamics Corporation, are selling themselves chunk by chunk, while others, like the Grumman Corporation, have been sold entirely. And those, like the Lockheed Corporation, that have survived the shakeout have emerged bigger and stronger and more eager than ever to compete for business outside the United States.
 
Tradition of Independence
 For reasons of security, history, pride and jobs, European governments have tended to support national military contracting industries that are as self-contained as possible, even when it might have been cheaper to buy abroad. In many cases, particularly in France, the biggest contractors remain state-owned.
"As far as industry consolidation, it has been much harder for individual companies in Europe than in the U.S.," said Keith Hodgkinson, an analyst at Lehman Brothers in London. "It's hard to merge a government-owned company with a privately owned company. And there are very few governments willing to see elements of their defense industry move into the hands of other nations, even given the trend to a single market."
But with weapons systems becoming more sophisticated and expensive, with budget pressures growing and with international competition for arms sales increasing, neither European arms makers nor their governments can afford to hold themselves apart.
In addition to the Eurofrigate program, two of the biggest collaborative programs are the $50 billion European fighter aircraft project involving Germany, Britain, Italy and Spain, and a proposed military transport plane that would be built in France, Germany, Spain and Britain. France and Germany are to build an armored personnel carrier together, and those two nations plus the Netherlands and Italy are collaborating on developing a military helicopter.
Led by companies like British Aerospace and General Electric of Britain, Aerospatiale and Thomson-CSF of France and Deutsche Aerospace of Germany, the European industry is seeking to cut costs, combine technological strengths and eliminate excess capacity through joint ventures and partnerships, if not outright mergers.
In some cases there has been considerable consolidation within national borders, with the French having pooled much of their shipbuilding business and General Electric of Britain having snapped up a number of other British military electronics companies.
In international efforts, Deutsche Aerospace and Aerospatiale are negotiating joint ventures in missile and satellite development. Matra of France and British Aerospace are negotiating a merger of their missile businesses. The Eurofrigate program has brought together DCN International of France, Finmeccanica/Fincantieri of Italy and a group led by the Marconi Naval Systems division of General Electric of Britain.
For their part, governments are working more closely together and removing many barriers to cross-border deals. France and Germany recently established a joint agency to develop a military transport plane and a satellite observation system, and hope to persuade other Western European countries to join.
Italy and France are moving to privatize state-owned weapons builders. Sweden, Denmark, Norway and Finland are discussing a cooperation pact on military procurement.
 
Common Policy Is Urged
 "There's a developing realization that Europe must get its act together, but it cannot really happen until governments decide on common requirements, common procurement rules and all the circumstances that surround the acquisition of defense materiel," said Mike Evans, the deputy director general of the Defense Manufacturers Association in Britain. "There's a realization that this should happen, even a willingness for it to happen, but the logistics will take some time to develop."
The quandary for Europe is apparent even in some nations' own military purchasing decisions. Britain, for example, plans to decide by the end of the year on a new military transport plane. The choice is between a plane built by Lockheed of the United States and the proposed European transport plane.
The Lockheed plane, the C-130J, is an updated version of an aircraft that has been in production for years and that Lockheed, with its size, financial power and worldwide market, can afford to offer at a discounted price of less than $40 million each.
 
Alternative to Lockheed Jet
 The European plane is supported by British Aerospace, which would build part of it in Britain and which has promised that it would be more advanced than the C-130J. The European plane would be built in collaboration with British Aerospace's partners in Airbus, Deutsche Aerospace and Aerospatiale.
But, lacking Lockheed's long experience in producing military transports and the American company's much larger order book, the European consortium will have to charge more -- an estimated $60 million a plane -- and could well encounter cost overruns and schedule delays.
Britain's Ministry of Defense said it would make a decision by the end of the year.
Even when they win contracts, pan-European contractor groups face difficulties. A previous attempt to develop a common warship for Europe fell apart in 1990 when the nations involved could not agree on their requirements.
And the biggest cooperative program of all in Europe, the European fighter aircraft being built by British Aerospace, Deutsche Aerospace, Alenia of Italy and Construcciones Aeronauticas S.A. of Spain, has been dogged by disagreements among the Governments over the size and speed of the project.
The Eurofighter flew for the first time this spring, more than two years behind schedule. The German National Audit Office estimated recently that the per-plane cost had swollen to $95 million from the original budget of $65 million, and opposition parties in Germany are calling for the project to be canceled. If it is, some European nations might choose to buy their next generation of fighters from the United States.
To succeed, analysts said, Europe and its arms industry will have to put aside old rivalries and domestic political considerations, particularly about jobs. They will also need to improve coordination of military strategies because they will be unable to develop a common weapons-procurement policy unless they are all interested in the same types of programs.
"Cooperation is never an easy thing," the French Defense Minister, Francois Leotard, said at the signing of the Eurofrigate agreement last month. "Of course you are disappointed here and there."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
U.S. Report on Brazil's Frost Lifts Coffee Prices Sharply

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Coffee prices rose sharply yesterday after an Agriculture Department report showing sizable frost damage to Brazil's key crop. The Government estimated that 30 to 40 percent of Brazil's 1995-96 crop, worse than analysts had expected, had been lost.
Coffee for December delivery soared 13.60 cents, to 198.45 cents a pound, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, the first substantial turnaround since prices peaked in mid-July at 245 cents. 
 "Today's price gains reflect the fact that the U.S.D.A., whose views are regarded as authoritative, thinks the frost damage to the Brazilian crop really is bad," a trader said. "But their assessment is not the last word on the subject. It will be impossible to know accurately what is happening until after the trees start flowering next month."
 
30 Percent Drop Predicted
 In a report issued after the market closed on Friday, the Agriculture Department predicted that next year's Brazilian crop would total 17 million to 20 million 132-pound bags, a drop of about 30 percent from the 26 million predicted for this season's crop.
Brazil, which produces nearly a quarter of the world's supply, recently forecast a crop next year of only 15 million bags, down from a pre-frost estimate of 26 million. It also said this year's harvest would reach at most 22 million bags.
On Friday, Brazil's Government contested the Agriculture Department's figure, saying the frost damage was more extensive than the department believed.
On other commodity markets, cotton prices again dropped the daily limit, while energy prices ended mixed. The Commodity Research Bureau's index slipped 0.26, to 229.44.
The cotton market is still reeling from the Agriculture Department's projection last week for a surprisingly large American cotton crop. December cotton lost 2 cents, to 66.55 cents a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange, after falling the 2-cent limit on Friday.
Oil prices ended mixed in what most traders believed was a consolidation after the market's steep drop last week. September crude oil firmed 15 cents, to $18.20 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. September gasoline declined 0.39 cent, to 54.83 cents a gallon, while September heating oil rose 0.53 cent, to 49.10 cents.
Oil prices firmed in late trading following a report that Nigeria's striking oil workers' union would not attend talks tomorrow with the military Government unless political and economic demands were discussed.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
In Strike, Two Sides And Two Sets Of Numbers

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, has used the figure so often during the owners' labor dispute with the players that $1.2 million has become indelibly imprinted on the minds of fans, who would rather hear baseball people talk about 61 and .400.
In his comments about the clubs' quest for cost control, Ravitch has used the average salary of $1.2 million to show how well off the players are and how well off they would continue to be under the limit the owners want to place on salary payrolls. 
 But $1.2 million is just what Ravitch says it is -- the average. Closer examination of salaries for the 1994 season casts a different light on what players earn.
*The median salary is $500,000. Of the 746 players on opening-day rosters or on the disabled list, 363 earn less than $500,000, 361 earn more than $500,000 and 22 make precisely that amount.
*The average salary itself is somewhat misleading because 237 players earn more than $1.2 million and 507 earn less (two are right at that figure).
*Just as they disagree on the economic system baseball should have, the two sides view these figures differently. Ravitch said they strengthen the clubs' position that fewer players are making more of the money. Gene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, said the rising median salary shows precisely the opposite.
They made their comments on the fourth day of the strike, when not much else was happening. For the third successive day, the two sides did not meet and did not speak to each other by telephone. They scheduled no meetings.
"I don't know what's in the immediate future," Ravitch said in response to a question, "but in these matters, things can change within the hour. I'm waiting to hear from the Federal mediators about when they want to meet again."
 
Now Canceled: 46 Games
 There were two strike-related developments yesterday.
The league offices announced that games will be canceled on a day-to-day basis "but should not be considered canceled until the day" the games were originally scheduled to be played. Four games were added to the canceled list yesterday, bringing to 46 the number missed. Fourteen games are on today's schedule.
In the other development, the number of players on strike fell from 763 to 762 when the Chicago Cubs belatedly optioned Steve Trachsel, a rookie starting pitcher, to Iowa of the American Association. With a $112,000 salary, $3,000 above the minimum, Trachsel, who compiled a 9-7 record in 22 starts for the Cubs before the strike, is one of the players below the median. On the other hand, Bobby Bonilla of the Mets and Cal Ripken of Baltimore were scheduled to earn more combined than all of the 22 players earning the median salary.
This season's median is up significantly from the median of $397,500 at the end of last season, but both the median and the average drop from opening day to the end because teams generally wind up with more minimum-salaried players on their rosters as the season progresses and they fill in for players on the disabled list.
Asked about the difference between the average and the median this season, Ravitch said: "I think to contrast the two points out very dramatically what is happening in baseball. With each year, fewer and fewer players get a larger percentage of the take. Each tells a story and together they tell a fuller story."
But Orza used the increase in the median salary to dispute Ravitch.
"He has always said the fact that the median is going down is an illustration of the fact that fewer players are making more money," Orza said. "If it's going up, it's counter to the proposition he's trying to espouse. If it's going up, it means we've ceased to see fewer and fewer players getting more and more money. But I don't know if you can compare the medians until we have the final figures in."
Orza added that the players don't care what the median and the average salaries are so long as a free market establishes them.
"Rather than have Ravitch or Orza or Soupy Sales determine the dispersion of salaries, let the market determine it," he said. "The players are willing to live with it. They always have been."
The owners want to change the current free-market system and implement a salary cap. They have proposed giving the players 50 percent of their revenue for all player costs, a formula that would lead to a maximum payroll amount for each team. The players contend that a cap would artificially lower salaries, impede their mobility as free agents and undermine competitive balance because clubs wouldn't have room under the cap to sign free agents to improve themselves.
Ravitch has said a system featuring a cap would result in better pay for younger players, but early returns from the National Football League's initial experience with a salary cap indicate that some players don't view it that way.
"The salary cap makes the rich get richer, the poor get poorer and takes out the middle class completely," Bryan Cox of the Miami Dolphins was quoted as saying recently. Other players have made similar comments, although the head of their union, Gene Upshaw, stoutly defends the system he negotiated.
Baseball's salary experience in recent years supports the likelihood that the development Cox described would happen in baseball, too.
Clubs take care of their star and other best players first, paying them lucrative salaries. By the time they get to the bottom half of the roster, they would not have enough money left to pay veterans worthwhile salaries to be a platooned player or sit on the bench.
Instead of paying Tim Hulett $550,000 to be a reserve infielder, a team more likely would give his spot to a rookie making the minimum.
 
Lots of Money at the Top
 Richard Moss, a longtime agent, said yesterday that the various salary levels have little meaning.
"The median salary for professional baseball players in the United States is probably about $7,000," he said, including minor league players in his estimate. "What's the significance of it? The point is the people at the top make a lot of money. That's what happens in the entertainment business. Everybody doesn't run around the streets yelling that Bill Cosby makes $80 million a year. The average salary of television stars is something less than that. The median salary of television actors is probably about $12,000."
Most people focus on salaries of major league players, but people like Moss, who represent players, point out that they are the best 700 or so people at what they do. Many others labor in the minor leagues for little pay.
In his first professional contract, a minor league player earns $850 a month for five months, or a total of $4,250. The top draft choices receive hefty bonuses, but they can't earn more than $850 a month in salary.
One player who began his minor league career this season at that salary was Michael Jordan. But because Jordan was playing in a Class AA classification, after 30 days, his salary rose to $1,000 a month.

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Anne-Marie Schiro 

 BODY:

Italian Invasion
For some 500 years, Italians have been discovering and rediscovering America. The latest landing is by three fashion companies eager to expand their global successes to these shores. Marzotto, Maska and Max Mara have had limited distribution in the United States but are now gearing up for major expansion. 
 There are two main reasons for the timing, said Sergio Garretti, the president of the Marzotto (U.S.A.) Corporation.
"The devaluation of the lire gave us an economic reason," he said. "The crisis of traditional European markets caused a major push to find new places for our product. And we are aware of the need to adapt our product to American needs."
Marzotto, a 158-year-old company with annual sales of $1.2 billion, distributes seven men's and three women's wear lines in the United States. The women's lines are Missoni Donna, Studio 000.1 by Gianfranco Ferre and its own Accento. The current emphasis is on adapting the styling and merchandising of Accento and the fit and the delivery schedule of Studio 000.1 so that both lines can be sold in a wider range of stores here.
Maska has been in business since 1967 with a succession of uncredited designers, including Mr. Ferre, Jean-Paul Gaultier and Franco Moschino. The collection has been available in the United States sporadically since 1989, but Adriano Luca Davoli, the vice president and general manager of Maska's United States division, intends to change that. The spring collection is now being shown to store buyers in a new showroom at 650 Fifth Avenue by Travis Winberg, who brought Genny and Byblos to this country a decade ago.
Max Mara, with annual sales of $1 billion, is introducing a new advertising campaign in fashion magazines in September, the same month it is to open its first New York boutique at 813 Madison Avenue (68th Street). There are plans for 15 more boutiques across the country.
Aside from their country of origin, the three companies have other common denominators. Styling is more traditional than high fashion and prices seldom top $1,000 for an outfit.
 
On-Line Fashion
The fashion world is entering the computer age with several on-line services targeted to the industry.
The Fashion Access Network is the Fashion Group International's entry, geared to provide information on jobs, services, events and trends to individuals and to businesses that sign up for membership in the network, as well as to the 6,000 professional women who belong to the group.
"We'd like people in fashion, beauty, home design, retail, manufacturing, real estate, you name it," said Margaret Hayes, the executive director of the Fashion Group.
Renee Palmer, the network's project director, said the service would be updated daily or weekly as required. "It will be menu-driven like a cash machine so it's user friendly," she said.
IPEX Inc. has developed two on-line image databases in cooperation with GE Information Services. One, Ultimate Source, where modeling and advertising agencies can find photographs of aspiring models, will be available in mid-September. The other, Pro Source, where agencies can view portfolios of the work of photographers, illustrators, stylists, models and prop and location providers, will be on line in November.
Fashion On-Line, the brainchild of Ernest Schmatolla, a fashion photographer, is currently available only for PC users with the Windows operating system. Its features include fashion reports, color photographs of runway shows and lists of fashion services.
 
New Bendels Boutique
Henri Bendel has acquired a Latin American accent. Angel Sanchez, 30, a Venezuelan couturier who has been been making periodic visits to the store in the last year to take orders for his glamorous evening dresses, is to get his own boutique on Sept. 19. He will spend two days in the Fifth Avenue store every six weeks for appointments and fittings.
His design trademark, hand-embroidered latticework, often adorned with beads or pearls, gives a distinctive look to his chiffon, silk crepe and velvet dresses with built-in corsets and bras. "I believe in inner construction even if the outside is soft," he said. Prices for the made-to-order dresses are $1,900 to $4,000.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Elusive Truth and a Touchy Subject

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
"Sex, Lies and Harassment" purports to be an investigation into how the famous 1991 Clarence A. Thomas-Anita F. Hill affair changed attitudes and raised perplexities about sexual harassment. But this edition of "American Justice" turns out to be mainly a recapitulation of the front-page charges and denials, not excluding the references to pubic hair on a Coke can, for their own entertaining sake.
If you are willing to settle for that, it's a lively hour. Credit for the peppiness goes to the allies and antagonists of Ms. Hill, who devour the camera. The most voracious is Camille Paglia, scourge of her sister feminists, who calls the treatment of Justice Thomas "obscene," "totalitarian," "a massive injustice." She is seconded by David Brock, author of "The Real Anita Hill," a bible of the pro-Thomas cadre. Catharine MacKinnon, the law professor known for her philosophy that sex is war by other means, and Ellen Bravo of the Association of Working Women maintain that Ms. Hill is a heroine for her time. 
 "Who was telling the truth?" asks the series host, Bill Kurtis. No, he doesn't know. One's answer is likely to depend on where one places the benefit of the doubt. The Thomasites declare that if Ms. Hill was offended by Mr. Thomas, she could have just "got up and walked away from the table." The Hillians reply that a working woman's life is not a liberating one; she can't lightly reject the boss. The Thomasites point out that their man's record regarding harassment was spotless. The Hillians respond that there's always a first time. The Thomasites find inconsistences in Ms. Hill's testimony. The Hillians interpret inconsistency, at least in this instance, as evidence of candor.
You may come away with the feeling that both sides were moved more by ideological preference than by the disputed facts of the case. But, after all, that also seemed to be true of the Senate, which divided pretty much along partisan lines in confirming Mr. Thomas. Whether the question of a person's fitness to sit on the high court should have rested on such an issue remains at least as troubling as what actually passed between accuser and accused.
Tomorrow night's program goes on to note the tendency of the courts in recent years to expand the meaning of sexual harassment. For example, a unanimous Supreme Court (including Justice Thomas) has ruled that psychological injury is not needed for a plaintiff to win damages.
The line, as Mr. Kurtis situates it, "between offensive conduct and romantic misunderstanding" remains ill charted, but business executives are on notice that they had better err on the side of inhibition. The subject, like sex itself, invites both earnest embrace and mere fooling around, but "Sex, Lies and Harassment" settles essentially for old newsreels, an economical way to fill up an hour.
That was true, too, of "Attack at Waco," an episode of "American Justice" shown early this month, which put the clips together effectively but added little new to the much-covered story of the assault on the Branch Davidian compound in Texas. This series is well done as far it goes, but how about going a little further?
 
AMERICAN JUSTICE
Sex, Lies and Harassment
A&E
Tomorrow at 9 P.M.

HEADLINE: Invading Weed Makes a Bid To Become the New Kudzu

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
KUDZU, the Asian vine so fast-growing and invasive that people call it the plant that ate the South, has some saving graces: It controls erosion, for instance, and it provides forage for livestock. Now comes what might be called Son of Kudzu, a nasty and equally aggressive invader from abroad with no apparent redeeming economic or social value.
Known variously as mile-a-minute weed, minute weed and tearthumb (for the backward-bending barbs on its stem), it grows at the rate of perhaps half a foot a day, forms tangled mats 20 to 25 feet high, overwhelms and kills other vegetation in its path and has been spreading rapidly from Pennsylvania into the upper South in the last decade. In some of the parks of Washington, D.C., it has moved into areas where kudzu had been eradicated. 
 Ecologists fear it could eventually spread its noxious carpet all the way to Florida, where the wet, warm climate could turn the weed, an annual known to botanists as Polygonum perfoliatum, into a perennial, making it a major new agent of ecological disaster in a state where exotic species already are creating especially widespread ecological havoc.
The weed poses "a serious threat" to natural ecosystems, cultivated plants and ecological restoration sites, said Dr. J. Douglas Oliver, an ecologist with the Florida Department of Environmental Recreation, who delivered a report on the plant last week at a meeting of the Ecological Society of America in Knoxville, Tenn.
At least 4,500 species of plants and animals from other parts of the world have established free-living populations in the United States, reported a 1993 study by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment. And while some, like soybeans and wheat, are clearly beneficial, the study found that just 79 nonindigenous species caused a total of $97 billionin damage from 1906 to 1991. Kudzu alone accounts for about $50 million annually in lost farm and timber production.
Some confusion could arise between kudzu and the new invader, since kudzu has also sometimes been called mile-a-minute weed. Both plants originated in Asia and both are vines. But there the similarity ends. Kudzu, Pueraria lobata in scientific parlance, is a perennial with large, compound leaves made up of three leaflets. It has deep purple flowers. By sending out runners, it can grow 70 feet in a single summer, or more than a foot a day.
 
Accidental Tourist
 Mile-a-minute weed, on the other hand, is an annual with perfectly triangular leaves, fine and pale green, and iridescent blue fruit. Its elongated stems form dense clusters and it spreads not through runners but by seed dispersal. Birds and rodents eat the fleshy, pendulous fruits in the fall and broadcast the seeds.
And while kudzu was imported and initially planted on purpose in the United States, mile-a-minute weed arrived here by accident. Dr. Oliver's research found that it first appeared in Oregon in a ship's ballast about 1890, but has apparently not been seen in western North America since 1954, where it disappeared for reasons unknown. In the East, Dr. Oliver says, seeds of the plant probably arrived in the rootballs of rhododendrons imported as nursery stock to York County, Pa., from eastern Asia.
As with most weeds, the plant quickly colonizes disturbed ground, like roadsides, edges of woods, nurseries, fallow fields, cleared woodlands and ditches. But it also colonizes undisturbed ecosystems, showing a particular fondness for low, wet ground, stream banks and areas with abundant plant litter like leaves. It prefers sunlight and moist conditions but tolerates shade and dryness, as well.
It outcompetes many native plants, and its dense, tangled thickets and mats climb over shrubbery and small trees, its shade killing grasses and wildflowers. Already, it is becoming an annoyance in parks and gardens, according to Dr. Oliver.
Although mile-a-minute weed appeared in Pennsylvania as early as the 1930's, it apparently did not begin spreading into other states until the last two decades. By 1979, Dr. Oliver reported, it had become established in Maryland; by 1981 in West Virginia; by 1983 in Virginia; by 1986 in the District of Columbia, and by 1992 in southern Delaware.
"In these areas," Dr. Oliver wrote in a recent unpublished paper, "the plant has increased dramatically in a short period of time." For example, he reported, many roadside embankments in Baltimore County are "solid" with the species, possibly because of dispersal by roadside mowers.
 
Threat to Wildlife and Industry
 In any case, he wrote, "this exotic plant has become established and is starting to replace extant vegetation." And although data on the rate of its geographic spread are lacking, he wrote, "the plant is known to be progressing southward quickly, and could soon invade other states."
It might have a particular affinity for his own state, Florida, Dr. Oliver suggested, since in its native Asian range is subtropical to tropical and since it seems to prefer warm habitats.
The weed has no known economic value, Dr. Oliver reported, but it could cause economic damage: It takes over the ground in clear-cut forests, smothering the seedlings of replanted trees and preventing the forest's regeneration. It has appeared in orchards and nurseries, and Dr. Oliver suggested that it could damage the hunting and tourist industries by taking over natural areas and depriving native animals of habitat and food.
Unlike many exotic plants and animals that have natural enemies to keep them under control in their native lands, mile-a-minute weed is reported by some scientists to be a major agricultural pest throughout its large home range, extending around the rim of Asia from Korea to India, where it is common and hard to hold at bay.
There is no known biological control for the weed, Dr. Oliver reported. Although many insects feed on it, they have little apparent effect. Unlike kudzu, it is hard to control through mowing because too many seeds are left behind. Some herbicides, however, including those with the trade names Roundup, Arsenal and Velpar, have been shown to be effective.
If control measures fail, Dr. Oliver says, the plant is expected to continue extending its range southward.
"Whether it will actually take root in Florida is unknown," he said, "but there is a good possibility it will," and perhaps make itself at home in parts of the country outside the South as well.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bill Rates Rise; Trading Dull

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed and little changed yesterday ahead of today's meeting of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee, which will consider another rise in short-term interest rates.
The 30-year bond was unchanged, trading at a price of 9931/32 to yield 7.50 percent, while rates in the shorter bill market were higher as investors moved to the sanctuary of money market funds to await the Fed's next move. Prices and yields move in the opposite direction. 
 Traders and dealers yesterday got a glimpse of another monthly government statistic that the Fed will be studying along with other data issued this month about the state of the economy. The F.O.M.C. meeting begins at 10 A.M.
 
Industrial Output Up
 In July industrial production rose two-tenths of 1 percent, a tad stronger than expected, leaving capacity utilization unchanged at 83.9 percent. Analysts said manufacturing posted a surprisingly solid four-tenths of 1 percent gain for the month, which was only partly offset by the 1.2 percent decline in the utilities output. The stronger data were mildly bearish for the market.
Gerald A. Guild, senior vice president-manager of the taxable-fixed- income department at Advest Inc. said trading on the whole was muted, noting that most of Europe was closed for a religious holiday. He said that yesterday should have been an active session because it was one of those quarterly dates when investors are busy looking to invest cash. "But everything is on hold, as the market waits for the next interest rate hike," he said.
If the Fed raises its discount rate, which is the interest charged on loans to member banks, or the Federal funds rate, which is the rate on overnight loans between banks, or both, most of the selling pressure is likely to be on short-term rates.
But he said that "everyone expects the Fed to act, and for that reason the market has already discounted into prices a 25-to-50-basis-point increase." So, he added, "Now they wait."
If the Fed decides to do nothing today, then long-term rates could spike and cause prices to fall, Mr. Guild said.
Many in the market expect a 50- basis-point increase in the Federal funds rate. And while a tightening announcement could be made early in the morning before the regular intervention time, 11:30 A.M., that does not necessarily mean it will have to happen then, Kim Rupert, an economist with MMS International, said. She noted that at the May 17 F.O.M.C. meeting the Fed did not disclose its intention until 2:30 P.M., when it announced a 50-basis-point increase in the funds and discount rates.
The Fed also announced its 25-basis- point move at the March 22 F.O.M.C. meeting at 2:22 P.M. While the initial rate climb this year on Feb. 4 was announced at 11 A.M., that was on the second day of the the two-day meeting. The only inter-meeting move was on April 18, when the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, announced at 10:02 A.M. a 25-basis-point rise in the funds rate.
In the corporate bond market, where most issuers of corporate debt were absent, Aegon N.V., a large international life insurance and pension management firm with headquarters in the Netherlands, used the opportunity to sell its first public issue in the United States. Underwriters led by Morgan Stanley priced $400 million of 12-year 8 percent subordinated notes at 99.087 to yield 8.12 percent. Rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's, the notes pay interest twice a year.
At the Treasury's weekly bill auction yesterday, average rates rose, with the greatest increase in the three-month bill, up 16 basis points from the previous auction, to 4.59 percent. The average rate for the six-month bills was up 6 basis points, to 4.99 percent yesterday.
The following are the results of the three- and six-month Treasury bill auctions:

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk 

LENGTH: 3146 words

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE LOBBYISTS;
Lobbyists Are the Loudest In the Health Care Debate

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
The telephone callers to Senator John B. Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat and an influential voice in the debate over health care, are stacked up like planes over National Airport. "Senator Breaux's office. Can you hold?"
The Senator's phones are ablaze from dawn until well past dark, with the answering machine collecting at least 200 more messages overnight. Clogged phone lines are one price that Mr. Breaux and some of his fellow legislators pay for staking out an independent position on what many say is the most heavily lobbied issue in the nation's history. 
 The Senator and three members of Congress talked recently about their experiences with the health care lobby, painting a picture of special interests overwhelming the decision-making process.
At least 650 groups spent more than $100 million from January 1993 to last March to influence the outcome of health care legislation, according to a recent study by the Center for Public Integrity, a nonprofit Washington group that examines public issues. The spending has only intensified since then.
"There is no issue of public policy in which the sheer strength of those special interests have so overwhelmed the process as in the health care reform debate," the center said.
Most of the money goes to the brigade of lobbyists who buttonhole members of Congress on behalf of their clients; some of the money goes directly into the campaign coffers of senators and representatives whose votes they hope to influence. Most of the clients, including many hospital and doctors' associations, oppose comprehensive changes in the nation's health care system, but others, like the leaders of some labor unions and the American Association of Retired Persons, are pushing for the Democratic leadership's bills.
"This is the biggest-scale lobbying effort that's ever been mounted on any single piece of legislation, both in terms of dollars spent and people engaged," said Ellen Miller, executive director of the Center for Responsive Politics, another Washington-based nonprofit research group. "It is more fully engaged across the country and at a higher profile inside the Beltway than ever before."
The Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Pennsylvania predicts that by October the amount spent by lobbyists on television advertising alone will exceed $60 million -- more than the $50 million spent on advertising in the 1992 Presidential campaign.
Citizen Action, a consumer group that has examined the campaign contributions made by lobbyists for health and insurance interests over the years, says that in the last 14 years the political action committees representing those interests contributed more than $150 million to Congressional campaigns to "keep health reform off the national agenda."
 
Spending $2 Million a Month
 Citizen Action says these political action committees are spending more than $2 million a month to modify a health care overhaul or kill it outright. They contributed $26.4 million to campaigns from January 1993 to last May, with the biggest donations going to members of committees that produced health care legislation.
For example, Citizen Action said, members of the Ways and Means Committee and the Energy and Commerce Committee received, on average, $27,000 more in this session of Congress than in the previous session, while their colleagues who did not serve on health-related committees received an average increase of $3,000 in the same period.
In the Senate, the report said, members of the Finance Committee, which produced a proposal that George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, drew on for his bill, received the biggest contributions, averaging $600,000 since 1979. Four members of Congress received more than $1 million from the health and insurance industry since that time. They were Senators Phil Gramm of Texas, Bob Packwood of Oregon and Dave Durenberger of Minnesota, all Republicans, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader.
 
'Just Another Trade Association'
 Given the amount of money and the intense competition, "the Oval Office is reduced to just another trade association," said Charles Lewis, executive director of the Center for Public Integrity.
Mr. Breaux said the lobbying "makes it more difficult to find middle ground." Pressure from unions, political parties, hospital groups, doctors and the Chamber of Commerce had already pushed some members of Congress to make commitments, he added.
One of the most effective groups has been the National Federation of Independent Business, which represents 607,000 small-business owners. "The N.F.I.B. has more people on the floor of the House than the White House has," Mr. Lewis said. "They are spending millions because billions are at stake."
Terry Hill, a spokesman for the federation, says the livelihoods of his members are at stake. "This is one of the biggest issues we have ever worked on, and it's the most irate and incensed I've ever seen the membership," he said.
Joshua M. Wiener, a health policy analyst at the Brookings Institution, said the lobbying has been extremely effective. "Back in January 1993, the best that the anti-reform lobbyists might have hoped for is a watered-down Clinton proposal," Mr. Wiener said. "Now there's a good chance we'll end up with nothing at all."
In the bill introduced by Senator Mitchell, the federation has helped stave off any requirement that employers pay their workers' insurance, at least for a few years. On the House side, the small-business lobby has helped rouse opposition to the requirement that employers pay 80 percent of the cost of their workers' insurance, as proposed in the bill offered by Mr. Gephardt.
Big business, which at first applauded President Clinton's efforts to change health care, now generally sees less urgency in change and is pretty much against it.
"With the economy stronger and a temporary slowdown in inflation for health care, many companies believe they don't need a systemwide solution, that they can solve their own problems," Mr. Wiener said.
He added: "This has clearly been startling for the Clinton Administration, which larded up its health care proposal with a lot that was very favorable to big business. But the distrust of government triumphed."
This distrust has undermined efforts by unions lobbying on behalf of health care changes. While union leaders have been pushing for universal coverage and cost controls, Mr. Wiener said, many of their members fear they will suffer if the Government fiddles with the coverage they enjoy now.
The lobbying has become so fierce, fractious and well-financed, said Mr. Lewis of the Center for Public Integrity, that it can "overwhelm the decision-making process." Here are the views of Senator Breaux and three Representatives on health care lobbying:
 
John B. Breaux
A Senator Draws A Lot of Attention
 Senator Breaux says he has been hit on by "everyone from A to Z." This means not just the big, professional interests, but also musical therapists, witch doctors and wart removers, all of whom want their specialties covered.
His office, with its row of colorful football helmets and his case of tennis trophies, is now a must stop on the lobbying circuit. This is partly because Senator Breaux has yet to commit himself to a specific health care plan. It is also because he is one of the mainstream group producing its own set of amendments to the Mitchell bill. Some on Capitol Hill think this bipartisan group may provide the needed heft to get a health care bill through the Senate this session.
"Liberals want to do everything all at once and hope they got it right, and conservatives want to do nothing and take a long time to do it," he said. "I'm trying to take one step at a time and make sure we get it right. When you're in the middle, you get beat up by both sides."
Mr. Breaux, who was elected to the Senate in 1986, is not unfamiliar with the ways of Washington. He came to the House in 1972 as its youngest member -- he was then 28 -- to replace Edwin W. Edwards, on whose staff he had served. (He came from the same small Cajun town as Mr. Edwards, who is now Louisiana's Governor.
At the start of the debate over health care, the Senator said, many of the lobbyists were useful because they provided details on subjects that lawmakers did not have time to delve into on their own. But now things are more intense.
"We've long passed informational lobbying; now we're at break-your-arm lobbying," he said.
Many are callers from orchestrated campaigns who tell him to vote yes or no. "I try to hang up on the ones not from Louisiana," he said. "People will really badger you. People will call up and be really ugly sometimes, and threatening."
"People have been scared," Mr. Breaux continued. "That's a great tactic if you want to get people to be against something. You instill the fear that Congress is going to do something to you rather than for you."
President Clinton's initial proposal "was technically do-able, but politically not do-able," the Senator also said. "It was too much, too soon, too complicated, too bureaucratic, too Washington-oriented."
Reforming health care may be extremely complex, but Senator Breaux has set what may be an even higher goal for himself. "I'm trying to achieve survival," he laughed. "I'll do well if I survive."
 
Bill Brewster
Lone Pharmacist Far From Lonely
 Bill Brewster is the only pharmacist in the House. This makes him particularly sensitive to the pitches of the multifaceted pharmaceutical lobby patrolling Capitol Hill.
But Mr. Brewster, a 52-year-old Democrat who represents a sprawling rural district in southern Oklahoma, is also a small-business owner, a cattleman and a hunter. He is a man of many interests, and many interests have been seeking him out.
"We've heard from more groups than I knew there were in America," he said of the health lobbyists, many of whom represent hospitals, doctors and pharmacists. "There's a lot of different pharmacy groups, and they're all at each other's throats."
The main issue within the pharmaceutical industry, Mr. Brewster said, is drug pricing. "The pharmaceutical manufacturers are on one side, and they've got every lobbyist hired in town," he said. "The ones they haven't hired are working for the National Association of Retail Druggists and pharmaceutical associations."
As a member of Ways and Means, Mr. Brewster said, he was lobbied most heavily from February until late June when the committee passed its proposed bill. "Obviously they worked the members on the committees prior to the committee votes," he said of the lobbyists. Partly because the Gephardt bill has stalled, he said, "I'm having fewer contacts right now."
Mr. Brewster was identified by Citizen Action, the watchdog group, as the ninth top recipient in the House of money from all health and insurance industry political action committees from January 1993 to May 1994. And the Center for Public Integrity identified him as among those who took the most trips sponsored by the health care industry. The top member took 11; Mr. Brewster took 10.
"I figure, anyone who contributes feels like I'm doing a decent job and wants to have good government," he said. "I try to look at an issue first off, how it affects my district."
The economy in his district is based on small businesses, farms and oil and gas interests. He said he was getting "a tremendous amount of pressure" from small-business owners, who oppose any provision to require employers to pay for workers' health insurance. He said he had received numerous letters saying, "I don't have insurance but I do have a job -- please don't mandate insurance coverage that puts my boss out of business and puts me out of a job."
He is unhappy with both the Gephardt bill and a rival plan proposed by Representative Jim Cooper of Tennessee, which has attracted some Republican support, on the grounds that they try to do too much. "If we try to provide a plan that's not intrusive to the 85 percent who have insurance, provide access to preventive care for the 15 percent who don't and went home, the public would be very happy."
Nonetheless, he said, he has it easier than some colleagues. "If you've been on the committee," he said, "you've worked on this for months, you're pretty well cemented in position on whatever issue it may have been because you've already voted on it in committee, you've made speeches for months."
 
Paul McHale
Former Marine Faces New Battles
 Paul McHale of Bethlehem, Pa., has approached the health care debate with the order and determination of the most serious student in the class. A 44-year-old former marine who left the Pennsylvania Legislature to return to active duty for the war in the Persian Gulf, his mission is to conquer every detail and do the right thing.
"To do justice in evaluating any of the pending comprehensive health care plans," said Mr. McHale, a first-term Democrat, "it is absolutely essential for a member of Congress to have done an extensive amount of mind-numbing reading prior to the examination of any individual bill.
"Once you know the basic building blocks, once you know the concepts, you can quickly recognize how they're being fitted together. Now when I'm lobbied -- by ordinary constituents, businessmen and women and professional lobbyists -- when they come in, the dialogue becomes whether or not my position comes close to theirs and whether either of our positions can be found in one of the pending bills."
For the moment, Mr. McHale's cannot. An original backer of the alternative plan discussed by Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee, Mr. McHale said he was disappointed in the plan's final, conservative shape.
He is also unhappy with the Gephardt plan. He opposes making small-business owners pay for their workers' insurance, and he does not like expanding Medicare, which he says would not control costs.
All of which makes him a legislator in search of a bill to support. "The best way to affect my vote is to provide me with information," he said. While all the usual suspects have inundated Mr. McHale with information -- last week alone, he was visited by at least two dozen lobbyists, including representatives of three drug companies, six of the largest businesses in his district, two unions, including the steelworkers, local health care plans, and four hospital associations -- he is still in search of more.
This has left him open to attacks from all sides. "Yesterday a very good friend who is a well-respected leader of organized labor said I was too conservative," he said. "And right after that, the National Federation of Independent Business conducted a press conference back in my district where they criticized my position as too liberal."
"In the final analysis, I'm going to pull back in, find a quiet corner, think about what's good for our country and vote on the issue as if it were a secret ballot," he said.
With that, it is time for a House vote. Mr. McHale checks his watch and steps briskly out the door. "It takes me six minutes and 35 seconds to get there," he said. "I've got this route timed out."
 
Jose E. Serrano
A Caucus Leader Feels the Pressure
 Jose E. Serrano represents the South Bronx, one of the poorest districts in the nation, its striking poverty and vast expanses of rubble made famous by visits by Presidents Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan. A full 60 percent of the district is Hispanic, which helped catapult this 50-year-old, two-term Democrat to the chairmanship of the 19-member Hispanic caucus in Congress.
Thus Mr. Serrano has not only the interests of his district to worry about but also the interests of his caucus. He said they were generally one and the same. But he also has to worry about the interests of New York City, and that can be cause for angst.
The health care industry in New York provides 300,000 jobs, and it has been one of the fastest-growing sectors of the economy. Mr. Serrano has to worry about those jobs -- many hospital workers are Hispanic -- as well as insure that the hospitals will continue to treat poor patients, regardless of their immigration status.
Another big concern is how New York's teaching hospitals, among the nation's most eminent, will fare. The bill offered by Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, proposes a limit on the number of medical residents at such hospitals; Mr. Serrano wants to make sure that Hispanic residents are fairly represented.
Mr. Serrano said the caucus was worried about preventive care and about whether a national health insurance system would require people to carry identification cards and what uses those cards might be put to. But it has supported the most controversial provision of the Gephardt bill, the requirement that employers pay 80 percent of the cost of their workers' health insurance.
Mr. Serrano hears most often not from insurance companies or other giants of the health care debate, but from fellow caucus members and strictly local interests, particularly the teaching hospitals.
Mr. Serrano is sympathetic to some of the hospitals' concerns, but he wants them to admit more local residents into their training programs. "Maybe it's time for me to do a little lobbying," he said, clearing his throat, pinching his collar and straightening his tie.
In his office, which features portraits of Robert F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Mr. Serrano said, "Not all the lobbying is done right here. Anywhere you are, you get lobbied."
He reached for a piece of paper. "This is the White House lobbying," he said. "They ran off a beautiful computer thing that singles out your district. It gives me information I didn't have, that there are people in my district who are not covered by Medicaid and Medicare and who need universal coverage."
The analysis said that 94,000 people, including 36,000 children, in Mr. Serrano's district had no health coverage.
The grass-roots groups, he said, "remind you of what it is they do and their value to society and why we have to be careful not to hurt them."
He said insurance companies were the "toughest" lobbyists "because they're very negative in their approach."
"They say, 'Everything is O.K. Why don't we leave things the way they are?' It's hard to negotiate with someone who believes no change is needed."
 The chart also failed to mention that three of the House members listed -- Mr. Cooper, Michael A. Andrews and Jon Kyl -- are engaged in or were engaged in Senate races; as a result, their contribution totals were inflated. The total listed for Senator Kay Bailey Hutchinson was also inflated because it included gifts from her campaign in a special election in 1993 as well as gifts this year.

 CORRECTION:
A chart on Tuesday about health care lobbying described campaign contributions received by the listed members of Congress incorrectly. In addition to health and insurance industry political action committees, the totals included large gifts from individual donors. One Congressman listed, Representative Jim Cooper, said he does not accept contributions from political action committees.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
TOYS 'R' US INC. (TOY,N)

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Toys "R" Us Inc. said yesterday that its net earnings for the second quarter increased by less than 1 percent, to $38 million, from $35.5 million in the comparable period a year ago.
The company reported earnings of 13 cents a share in the quarter, compared with 12 cents a share for the second quarter of last year. The company's second quarter ended July 30. 
 The chief executive of Toys "R" Us, Michael Goldstein, said the company's international stores had been "adversely impacted by local economic conditions, and therefore had comparable store sales decreases."
A spokesman for the company, Louis Lipschitz, said Toys "R" Us had opened 67 international stores last year, and had expected to lose money on those stores in the first half of the year.
"We warned everyone that the first half of the year would be very tough," Mr. Lipschitz said. "And the economic situation in Europe is also bad."
Mr. Lipschitz said the company expected the international stores to perform better in the latter half of the year, and the company planned to open about 60 stores abroad this year, including its first stores in Denmark, Luxembourg and Sweden.
The company also plans to open 40 more stores in the United States this year.
Net earnings in the first half of the year increased six-hundredths of 1 percent, to $75.6 million, or 26 cents a share, from $70.9 million, or 24 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago.
Toys "R" Us reported an increase of 10 percent in sales, to $1.45 billion, from $1.32 billion last year.
Toys "R" Us, based in Rochelle Park, N.J., is the largest toy specialty retailing chain in the world. It operates 581 toy stores in the United States, 238 international toy stores and 201 Kids "R" Us children's clothing stores.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 18, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A brief report in Business Day on Tuesday about the second-quarter financial results of Toys "R" Us Inc. misstated the percentage increases for the company's earnings and sales for the quarter and the first six months of its fiscal year. For the quarter, sales rose 10.2 percent, while earnings rose 7.1 percent; for the six-month period, sales rose 11.9 percent and earnings rose 6.6 percent.
