HEADLINE: Clinton Wants to Strengthen Global Pact on Air Pollution

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has concluded that the 1992 treaty to reduce the threat of global warming needs to be strengthened and that in any case the United States may already be doing too little to comply with it.
While that first conclusion pleases many environmentalists who are worried about possible changes in the world's climate, both it and its corollary are also likely to put pressure on the Government to take stronger steps to reduce emissions of certain gases, particularly those from gasoline combustion in automobiles. 
 International negotiators will meet next week in Switzerland to re-examine the treaty, which was signed during the Bush Administration and calls for reduction of gases like carbon dioxide and methane that many scientists say act like a global blanket to trap the sun's energy in a greenhouse effect and create global warming.
At the Geneva negotations Clinton Administration officials will support European nations like Germany and the Netherlands in calling for tougher long-term steps to curtail such greenhouse gases in the next century.
"Virtually all nations are in agreement that current efforts are not adequate to the task at hand," Timothy E. Wirth, the Under Secretary of State for global affairs, said at a recent briefing on the negotiations.
But so far there is no sign that the Administration is willing to take a step favored by many environmentalists: raising the Federal requirement for fuel efficiency in automobiles.
And some Administration officials worry that even the current short-term plan to control carbon dioxide, methane and greenhouse gases will not meet the emissions targets set for the year 2000.
 
Troubling Forecasts
 New forecasts, they said, suggested that the United States would be producing more carbon dioxide in the next few years than was assumed when the short-term plan was put together and adopted last October.
Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary said in an interview that lower-than-expected oil prices had encouraged higher consumption, and other officials pointed to the increased use of coal in power plants rather than natural gas and to strong economic growth generally, which has increased industry's energy use.
Mrs. O'Leary said officials from several Federal agencies were already drafting "further steps" to cut emissions of greenhouse gases from their fastest-growing source, automobiles.
"My clear leaning is to put a lot more emphasis on all alternative-fuel vehicles and to get electric vehicles out of the closet," Mrs. O'Leary said.
The Administration's October plan, adopted as a first step toward meeting the United States' treaty commitments, relies heavily on voluntary measures by industry to reduce gases like carbon dioxide from burning fossil fuels. Many scientists believe that the greenhouse effect caused by these gases affects many climatic trends, not just how hot the planet becomes.
Among those praising the Administration's new, tougher stance is Daniel F. Becker, Washington director of the global warming and energy program at the Sierra Club. "We applaud the Administration for recognizing that the problem is terribly serious," Mr. Becker said. "But they need an action plan that has got real action, not just jawboning for industry. They need to do much more about transportation, and the major thing they need to do is raise automobile fuel efficiency standards."
But John Shlaes, executive director of the Global Climate Coalition, a group that represents more than 50 business trade associations and companies, said his group was "disturbed by the implication that the President's voluntary climate action plan, which is just getting under way, will be inadequate and that more stringent measures may be needed domestically."
In a draft report that the State Department circulated among industries and environmentalists early this month, the Administration warned that new controls on emissions of greenhouse gases could become necessary, particularly steps to cut gasoline consumption.
The report cited a previously unpublished Government forecast of United States energy use indicating that "trends of emissions are significantly above the levels used in developing the October 1993 action plan."
"The new data suggest there may be a need to modify the action plan should these trends persist," it said.
The report, which is the Government's official description of American policies to prevent global warming, will be given to other nations under terms of the climate treaty.
The treaty, one of two major environmental pacts drafted in Rio de Janeiro in 1992, calls for the signers, especially the industrialized countries, to move quickly to stabilize atmospheric concentrations of greenhouse gases.
Because the science of climate change is so new, the signers realized that they would have to re-examine the treaty's goals every few years. The first full conference of the signers is scheduled to occur in Berlin next spring, and preliminary negotiations are under way.
On Aug. 22, negotiators will gather in Geneva for two weeks to discuss, among other things, whether it is enough for the industrial nations to return their emissions of greenhouse gases to 1990 levels by the year 2000. The conference in Berlin must decide that issue.
 
'Inevitable Next Steps'
 On Aug. 3 at a State Department meeting of environmentalists, industry groups and other interested parties, Mr. Wirth called on the audience to "prepare together for the inevitable next steps under the climate treaty."
"As a first priority for the future, we need to set an aim that can guide our efforts for the initial period after the year 2000," he said.
During his campaign for the Presidency, Bill Clinton promised to set higher standards for automotive fuel efficiency, but his Administration has instead favored a largely voluntary approach, which has done little to reduce automotive pollution.
Budget cuts are also making it hard for the Administration to meet its goal for reducing greenhouse gases. The House and Senate are negotiating a compromise spending bill that could cut the Energy Department's conservation programs by $150 million to $233 million in 1995, depending on which house's version prevails.
Mrs. O'Leary has testified that a cut of just $120 million would put the target for lower emissions "at substantial risk" and that a greater budget cut would make the target "virtually impossible to meet."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 20, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A chart on Aug. 16 about carbon dioxide emissions in various countries listed its sources incompletely. The figures were calculated and distributed by Population Action International, from data provided by the United Nations and the Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center.

HEADLINE: Experts in U.S. Call Plutonium Not Arms-Level

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
Federal weapon experts say that the plutonium seized in Germany and suspected of coming from Russia is not of the purity found in military stocks and that the Russians may be right in asserting that the security fences around their sprawling military establishment remain unbreached.
However, the experts also say the material, though probably intended as fuel for a nuclear-power reactor, was still potent enough to help make a nuclear bomb, though a crude one by most standards. They view non-weapons establishments in Russia as the most likely source of the leaks, although they say this remains to be proved. 
 And they warn that the large amount of such material appearing on the black market should be seen as a global wake-up call.
German authorities have made another seizure of weapon-grade nuclear materials, a prosecutor in the northern city of Bremen said yesterday. [Page A13.]
"All of us should be worried," said Dr. Terry Hawkins, a senior official in the international security division of the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, the birthplace of the bomb.
"The fact that the Russian military says all the military plutonium is under control should not send us to bed for a rest," he said. "The fact that significant amounts, approaching weapon quantities of plutonium, seem to be showing up in this criminal channel should cause us great concern."
Los Alamos is participating in the Federal effort to analyze the German data and has been working closely with the Russians for several months to help them strengthen their nuclear security and safeguards.
The seized plutonium, according to Dr. Hawkins and many other Federal and private experts, was a mix of plutonium and uranium oxides known as Mox, or mixed-oxide fuel. Mox is made to fuel nuclear reactors that produce electrical power. It has been used or made in such places as Japan, France, Belgium and Germany. In Russia its use is still in the experimental stage.
That exact composition of the seized Mox is being closely studied around the world and is one of a host of potential clues that could help pinpoint the material's origin.
Weapon experts say that in principle it is possible to gather enough evidence to identify positively who made nearly any kind of nuclear-weapon fuel. But in practice, they add, the detective work can be frustrated by information gaps and mix-ups.
 
Fingerprints of a Weapon
 "There's no question that nuclear fuel, whether plutonium or uranium, has characteristic fingerprints," said Dr. Ray E. Ridder, a former weapon designer at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California. "The problem is that we don't always have a complete fingerprint file to match them against, so we may not be able to identify the criminal."
Dr. Hawkins of Los Alamos said positive identifications were also hindered with each passing year because so many nuclear materials, including ones from Russia, are being recycled within producing countries and are being extensively mixed with ones originally made elsewhere.
"In theory," he said in a telephone interview, "you might be able to make a pretty definitive statement. But because these materials are exchanged between all the players in the international market, it's hard to say for sure that it came from a particular country or a particular reactor" used for making weapon-grade plutonium.
The issue is at the heart of a growing dispute between Germany and Russia, which are at odds over Germany's suspicion that plutonium recently seized in Munich was made in Russia. Federal officials in Washington say they are still learning the details of the German-Russian dispute, which they say may take weeks of analysis to resolve.
 
Arrest in Germany
 German authorities recently revealed that they apprehended a suspected smuggler who flew from Moscow to Munich with 300 to 350 grams, or 10.6 to 12.3 ounces, of plutonium 239, one of the main nuclear-weapon fuels. The material was said to be the first part of larger shipment amounting to four kilograms, or 8.8 pounds, apparently close to what it takes to build a bomb.
The German authorities said that the material was still being analyzed, but that it clearly was of military origin, probably Russian, and that in time the analysis would pinpoint the Russian installations that produced it. The Russian Atomic Energy Ministry has repeatedly denied that any weapon-grade material is missing from Russia.
Dr. Hawkins of Los Alamos said the plutonium in the seized Mox had an isotopic composition of 87 percent plutonium 239, the principal isotope used in making bombs. Isotopes are different forms of the same element.
This 87-percent level is short of the 93-percent-or-higher level normally used by nuclear powers for making bombs, and by definition makes the material fuel-grade, or suitable for fueling a nuclear reactor.
 
Origin in Civilian Plant
 The material, said Dr. Hawkins, "was not produced in a reactor for military weapons," adding that it undoubtedly came from one that was part of a civilian power industry, probably in Russia.
"It's probably true that the Russian military material is under control," he said. "But that does not extend to other sectors, to research and civil power. That's where they have the problems."
Some experts noted that Mox usually has far less plutonium 239, raising the suspicion that it had come somewhere close to military sources, perhaps from Russia's emerging efforts to commercialize its huge inventory of weapon-grade materials. But Dr. Hawkins said other countries had also experimented with such higher levels.
The danger in all this is considerable, weapon experts said, since it is widely known that even relatively low concentrations of the plutonium 239 isotope, including the kind in the seized Mox, can be used to make a bomb.
 
U.S. Test in 1962
 In June, Energy Secretary Hazel O'Leary revealed details of how the United States conducted a successful nuclear blast in the Nevada desert in 1962 that used reactor-grade plutonium, rather than weapon grade.
"The test confirmed that reactor-grade plutonium could be used to make a nuclear explosive," the Energy Department said in a statement in June.
Dr. Alexander De Volpi, a physicist at the Argonne National Laboratory in Illinois, said that the clues being searched for in Germany probably fell into three broad categories -- chemical, metallurgical and isotopic. The latter evidence concerns the mix of the different possible forms of a particular element, or its isotopes.
For instance, he said, the main kind of plutonium made in nuclear reactors for weapons is rich in the 239 isotope. But the process can also produce a range of other plutonium isotopes, including plutonium 240, 241 and 242, and the mix of these isotopes can differ radically from one reactor and one country to another.
"The fractions of these isotopes depend on the radiation history and the type of reactor," he said. "These ratios are traceable features."
The problem, he added, is that such tracing "is possible provided one knows enough about the characteristics of a particular country's materials" and that such data is often top-secret.

HEADLINE: Concern Rising On U.S. Shores As Cubans Flee

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KEY WEST, Fla., Aug. 16

 BODY:
By the hundreds, the Cubans stream through the refugee center's doors, some clad only in their underwear and Coast Guard-issue gauze jumpsuits, eager for a shower, a meal and a new life.
Sunburned and gaunt, they have been arriving in United States waters in increasing numbers recently -- 868 since Friday alone, Federal officials say. It is the largest five-day total since the Mariel boat lift in 1980, when 125,000 Cubans arrived in Florida over five months. On Monday, 282 refugees were rescued by the Coast Guard, and by 9 o'clock tonight at least 215 more were picked up. 
 The influx of refugees, about 6,000 so far this year, is a matter of growing concern for state and local officials and for the Clinton Administration, which has signaled President Fidel Castro of Cuba that the United States will not tolerate a replay of Mariel. The Government has also warned people in this country that it would prosecute those who smuggle aliens from Cuba.
The Coast Guard has begun distributing leaflets at marinas from Miami to Key West, warning against bringing aliens into the country. Those who do so will have their boats seized and face Federal smuggling charges. If convicted, they could face prison terms of up to five years and fines of up to $250,000.
With countless small boats in the straits between Florida and Cuba, however, the Coast Guard is also asking boat operators to do all they can to pick up Cubans in sinking vessels or to notify the authorities of those who are in distress, said a Coast Guard spokesman in Key West, Petty Officer Adam Wine.
Mr. Castro has paid particular attention to the mounting number of Cubans trying to flee. On Monday, he visited the village of La Boca in Mariel Harbor, 25 miles west of Havana, where more than 700 Cubans had taken over a docked oil tanker, registered in Malta, according to foreign wire service reports from Cuba. Cuban navy ships blocked the tanker from departing, and by Monday night the Cubans had left the ship.
Under United States immigration policy, nearly all Cubans refugees are admitted because they come from a Communist country. Mr. Castro has said that the policy is encouraging Cubans to flee. Many of the refugees have said, however, that they left their country because of its crippled economy.
Haunted by memories of Mariel, local officials like Emery Major, a Key West City Commissioner, worry that the refugee influx will overwhelm Key West, a resort island that is two miles wide, four miles long and home to 28,000 people.
"It's going to be a boom," Mr. Major said of the growing number of Cubans. The problem, he said, is that few local contingency plans have been made since the flood of refugees in 1980. "It shouldn't have taken 14 years to be caught with our pants down," he said.
Dozens of volunteers are working round the clock at the Transit Home for Cuban Refugees on Stock Island, cooking meals, handing out new clothes, washing linens and calling Miami to track down relatives of the new arrivals.
 
Memorial to the Missing
 In the two years since it opened, the Transit Home has become a kind of privately run Ellis Island. In one room, where new arrivals are interviewed and their paperwork processed, the walls are covered with more than 1,700 squares of note paper bearing names, each representing a boatload of Cubans who left the island but never arrived.
To the Transit Home staff, they are "walls of sorrow for the Cuban Holocaust," for the staff members believe that thousands of men, women and children have died as they attempted the 90-mile crossing.
"You understand the idea of fatherland or death?" asked Arturo Cobo, the Transit Center's founder, referring to Cuba's long-time national motto. "Now it's liberty or death."
Mr. Cobo, who fought Mr. Castro's army in the failed Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961, runs the Transit Home. In two years, about 9,000 Cuban refugees have come through the center, fleeing a economy that has crumbled since the loss of Soviet financial and political support.
Although the scene is always hectic, the 30 or so volunteers and the small paid staff keep things going -- always cooking, always looking for clothes that fit the new arrivals and always trying to make room for the next boatload.
The first stop for the refugees is the Coast Guard base at Key West, where agents of the Immigration and Naturalization Service interview them before turning them over to the Transit Center.
"Our key is buses," Mr. Cobo said. "When we have 100 people we give them food, medical attention, moral support, and we put them on the buses to Miami."
Once in Miami, about 75 percent of the immigrants find family members who take them in, Mr. Cobo said. The others are handed over to Church World Services or to the Catholic Conference, both federally financed private groups that house the new arrivals in Miami motels until they can be resettled in other American cities, Mr. Cobo said.
 
Taste of a New Life
 But it is during the stay at the Transit Home, normally for less than a day, that the refugees get their first taste of a new life. For 17-year-old Dennis Rondon, it meant a meal of rice, beans and a concoction of potatoes and hot dogs that was simmering in a huge skillet.
"I can't remember the last time I had meat," Dennis said, guessing it had been two or three months.
Dennis, who arrived this morning with his mother and 9-year-old brother on a raft made of foam, was covered with a blistering sunburn from four days at sea. "My hope is to have a new life and prosper, to work hard and fight to live well -- and to never go back," said Dennis, who described himself as a New York Yankees fan.
For all the joy of arrival, there is abundant sorrow as well. On Monday an 8-year-old boy arrived after a storm capsized his boat; his parents were believed drowned. The boy, Daniel Bussot, wearing the vessel's only life jacket, clung to a floating plank until another small refugee boat came by and rescued him. "A child has been orphaned searching for liberty," said Mr. Cobo, who called the boy's parents martyrs. "This has to be told to the world."
Mr. Castro heightened fears of another Mariel two weeks ago when, angered by the hijackings of Government boats, he warned that he might allow anyone who wanted to leave the island to do so.
Mr. Cobo said Mr. Castro was beginning to make good on his threat. New arrivals have told him, he said, that while some fleeing Cubans have been detained, others have been pointed north by the crews of Cuban gun boats and wished a good day.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A group of 13 Cubans, picked up at sea on Monday by the Coast Guard, at a transit center in Key West, Fla. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Vote Against Crime Bill Is Lesson on Clout

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Representative Lee H. Hamilton carries the look and the sound of small-town America with him. He uses the phrase "visit with" to mean "talk to," he still wears his hair cut short and he has the same soft Hoosier manner that once made Herb Shriner a popular humorist.
But Mr. Hamilton, an Indiana Democrat, has spent 30 years on the Potomac, and he is now a major player on Capitol Hill as chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. He is invited to the big-time parties in Georgetown and at the White House (he was there for dinner recently with the Emperor and Empress of Japan). He regularly gets approval ratings in the 70's and 80's from most liberal groups and ratings in the 30's from most conservative organizations. 
 Mr. Hamilton is admired for his intellect. President Clinton, it is said, considered him last year for Secretary of State and has thought of him, along with Walter F. Mondale, as a candidate to succeed Warren Christopher in that position. In short, he is someone the Democratic establishment considers one of its own.
So perhaps the most surprising element of last week's surprising defeat of the crime bill on a procedural motion was Lee Hamilton's "no" vote. It is understandable only in terms of the two worlds he inhabits and which one exerts the stronger influence in today's politics.
"It doesn't give me any joy to cast a vote against President Clinton or any other President, for that matter," he said today. "Would I like to see him get a victory when he obviously needs one? Yes. Do I make that my first or my second priority? No.
"The basic nature of American politics has changed. I don't get elected because of what Bill Clinton thinks or what the House leadership thinks. The electorate makes up its own mind. That inevitably means that Presidents have a lot less clout with Congress than they used to have. All Presidents, I mean.
"It's also true, of course, that when a President is riding high his influence goes up, and when a President is in the dumps, the way Clinton is, his influence declines."
Mr. Hamilton lives in Nashville, Brown County, Ind. (population 873), and represents most of southeastern Indiana, an 18-county region whose biggest town is Jeffersonville, across the Ohio River from Louisville, Ky. In the 1980's he came to national attention as the co-chairman of the special Congressional committee investigating the Iran-contra affair.
People in his district tend to be conservative Democrats; many trace their roots back to the "Butternut" Democrats from the South who settled in the area. And they are much more suspicious of government spending and gun control and social engineering than people in Washington or, for that matter, Indianapolis.
"They elect Lee Hamilton," an old friend said, "because they know that deep down, there's a wide streak of Scottish conservatism in there."
Mr. Hamilton certainly sounded conservative as he discussed his vote in an interview this morning. He said he liked some things in the bill, such as the provisions for more police officers and more prisons, but he argued that Congress "can do better" and that no bill was preferable to one he considered deeply flawed.
How? Well, the Congressman said, he found the financing of the new programs "very shaky," in fact "largely phony," because they would be paid for by savings within the Federal bureaucracy that would never be made. There was "a lot of stuff that doesn't belong in a crime bill," he added, like $300 million for economic development, and "another job training program, when we already have about 20 and the Vice President has been running around saying we need to consolidate them."
 
Threat or Security Device?
 But he spoke with special emphasis about the ban on assault weapons, which he voted against when it first passed the House, although he had voted in favor of the Brady law, which requires a five-day waiting period before handguns can be purchased. Such laws are far more popular in cities, he conceded, than in the small towns and rural communities he represents; "in Indianapolis a gun is a threat, but in DuBois or Spencer County it's a security device."
"This is an exceedingly divisive issue," Mr. Hamilton said, "but no one has shown me any evidence that a ban would cut the crime rate."
He pictured his vote as a matter of principle, but at the White House, it was seen as a cave-in to political pressure. Asked why Mr. Hamilton had voted as he did, a senior adviser to Mr. Clinton answered:
"Guns. That's all it is."
In fact, Mr. Hamilton appears to be under no great pressure from anyone. Despite widespread talk of stripping him of his chairmanship as a disciplinary measure, something that would have been almost automatic 20 or 30 years ago, he said he had received no threats from House colleagues and no calls from the White House since the vote. (Beforehand, he was called by Vice President Al Gore, whom he told that he had already publicly pledged to vote "no.")
 
Overwhelming Concern? No
 His hold on his district appears solid. He took 69 percent of the vote in 1992 and 70 in 1994, and his opponent this year, State Senator Jean Leising, is given little chance.
There has been no burst of editorial comment on his vote, and John Gilkey, managing editor of The Evening News in Jeffersonville, said that even the assault-gun ban "is not really an overwhelming concern to people here." The main complaints have come from local police chiefs. Dean Marble, the chief in Clark County, said he was "really disappointed" because additional officers were "desperately needed in the county" and money was not available.
As for Mr. Hamilton, he spent the weekend at church picnics in his district and got "a lot of praise and a lot of criticism." But when he was able to describe the bill in detail, he reported, "most people expressed amazement at what was in there, asked for assurance that we would get some sort of crime bill, which I gave them, then nodded their heads in agreement."
Mr. Hamilton has broken with the President in the past. Although generally supportive of Mr. Clinton's foreign policy -- "I carry a lot of water for him up here," he said -- he has also pungently criticized the Administration for its constant changes of direction. On one occasion, he said of the President: "We don't know what the policy is, but we know what kind of underwear he wears."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
A family-run public relations firm in transition keeps its place near the top of the industry heap.

BYLINE: By Barnaby J. Feder 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
FOR the last year, Edelman Public Relations Worldwide has been trumpeting its ranking as the top public relations firm in the nation by Inside PR, a leading trade publication. But when results of the magazine's 1994 survey of overall performance and reputation were published last week, Edelman had slipped to fourth place, changing places with Porter/Novelli, a unit of the Omnicom Group, which has risen to first place from fourth.
Still, Edelman is enjoying a run of success that most of its competitors can only envy. Though revenue growth slowed last year to 5.9 percent, 1993 was a year in which many other large public relations agencies suffered declines. 
 This year, Edelman's has returned to double-digit growth; the company, which is family owned, expects fees to top $70 million, compared with $63.4 million last year.
"There are three or four firms at the top of the heap right now and Edelman is clearly one of them," Paul A. Holmes, editor of Inside PR in New York, said.
One reason Mr. Holmes cited was Edelman's New York office, which has been headed since 1979 by Richard Edelman, the son of the founder, Daniel J. Edelman, 74. The New York office had 10 employees and $1 million in fees when Richard arrived with a degree from the Harvard Business School and a lifetime of exposure to his father's skills as a creative promoter of consumer products. By the late 1980's, New York had overtaken the company's original office, in Chicago, and now generates about $20 million in fees with 170 employees.
Given that record, no one was surprised when Mr. Edelman promoted Richard, who was president and chief operating officer, to co-chief executive on June 15, his son's 40th birthday. Daniel Edelman, who is co-chairman and chief executive, and his wife, Ruth, still own a majority of the company, and Mr. Edelman senior will continue to focus on his recent passion of expanding the company's Asian business.
Outsiders, though, are watching closely to see whether Richard can broaden the company's image and clout.
"It's going to be a very interesting transition," said John Graham, chief executive of Fleischman-Hillard, the public relations agency in St. Louis that is the only independent agency larger than Edelman. Mr. Graham said that although Edelman had achieved notable success in several specialty sectors, particularly health care, it remained best known for campaigns that draw media attention to consumer products.
Some former employees and industry experts say that Richard Edelman's aggressive emphasis on financial goals and growth has its drawbacks, resulting in employee turnover they deem to be excessive and inadequate servicing of some clients.
As Inside PR put it delicately last year in listing Edelman as the top-ranked firm, it is not the best-loved public relations agency in the country.
If Richard Edelman has his way, the company will become known as a must for those who want to use compact disks, computer networks and the other trappings of the information highway to get their messages out, regardless of whether those messages deal with consumer products.
"I hope that public relations will develop an advantage over advertisers in computers if not in television," Mr. Edelman said. He cited a campaign he has been developing for "a major New York bank" to make its economic analyses of foreign countries and similar reports available to journalists and opinion influencers over the Internet.
In June, Edelman moved to use the Internet as an advertising medium for itself by joining the Digital Equipment Corporation, Ogilvy & Mather Direct and Dun & Bradstreet as a founding supporter of Mecklerweb, a commercial service. Edelman will handle public relations work for Mecklerweb, which will make information about Edelman's services and client list available to millions of computer users around the world. Edelman's office in Mountain View, Calif., developed the arrangement.
"We had a meeting last December in which we told all our office managers to get up to date on the information highway and to get clients involved," Mr. Edelman said. "We're bringing everyone together next month to see what they've accomplished."
Edelman's other focus for future growth is, like its major competitors, overseas expansion. It has hardly been a smooth path.
A bumpy first effort in Hong Kong in the early 1980's has left the company battling with a former partner over who can use the firm's name there. And the London office, opened in 1967, has fallen on hard times. But international revenue has risen from less than 20 percent of total revenue to more than 35 percent in the last five years.
Richard Edelman is also keeping a close watch on the firm's bottom line. He is pushing hard to develop public affairs and financial assignments as accounts for the agency, because they are more profitable than marketing campaigns. Among the most recent: advising Viacom in its takeover wars with Paramount and Blockbuster Entertainment.
"Our pretax earnings were just 3 or 4 percent," he said of his early days with the firm, while declining to be specific. "It's much better than that now."

HEADLINE: U.S., Japan In Accord On Patents

BYLINE: By TERESA RIORDAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
The United States and Japan signed an agreement today that would make major changes in the patent policies in both countries, providing what is being hailed as greater protection for American inventors.
The accord, while covering contentious issues, is just one arena in broader, and essentially stalled, trade negotiations with Tokyo. It is the first accord the two nations have signed in more than a year of often trying talks. 
 "From our point of view it's quite historic," said Assistant Secretary of Commerce Bruce A. Lehman, the Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks. "We're getting provisions we've been seeking a long time. This will have a big market-opening effect."
 
Wide-Ranging Effect Sought
 The accord is not likely to bring about the resolution of disputes involving insurance, automobiles and government procurement, more crucial issues in the broader "framework talks" between Washington and Tokyo, it is expected to have benefits for industries in both countries.
Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown, who signed the agreement with Japan's Ambasador here, Takakazu Kuriyama, expressed pleasure and a degree of hope about its effects. "I'm not sure if it has a direct impact on the rest of the trade framework," Mr. Brown said. "Obviously we're pleased with any success. This certainly was a major success. It moves us closer to the goal of harmonization of intellectual-property laws. It dramatically speeds the ability of American companies to get patents."
And Kiyohiko Nanao, top economics specialist at the Japanese Embassy, said: "Patent policy relates to all fields. It covers everything, not just a single industry like telecommunications or shipping. In that sense, the agreement is important."
 
Shorter Decision Times
 Secretary Brown and Ambassador Kuriyama, in the letters of agreement signed today, committed Japan to reduce the time now required for determination on patent requests, allowing applications to be decided in a maximum of three years. Currently, the average review time is five years.
Japan also said it would do away with a provision that allows patents to be legally challenged before they have been issued, as well as a requirement for compulsory licensing of patents in some instances.
The accord includes an important change that had been announced in an agreement made public in January: Tokyo will allow foreign inventors to file their initial applications in English. Such applications must now be filed in Japanese, and inaccuracies in translation have made it hard for many American companies to defend their patents in court.
The areas covered by the agreement were cited in a report by the General Accounting Office last year as impediments to the granting of patents with "timely exclusivity" to American inventors.
For its part, the United States agreed to substantial policy changes that had been sought by American corporations but challenged by independent inventors and universities.
Some specialists in intellectual property gave the American negotiators high marks. "Lehman gave up nothing to the Japanese that wasn't already in our domestic interests," said Harold C. Wegner, a professor of law at George Washington University and a leading authority on international patent law. "He got something for nothing. It's a brilliant trade."
Among the changes being made by the United States is a provision that patent applications will be published 18 months after they are filed, whether or not the patent has been issued. Unlike most countries, the United States does not now make public a patent application until the patent has been granted.
Another element of the accord, also agreed to in January, speeds a requirement under the new General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that American patents be granted for a period of 20 years after the date of application, rather than 17 years after the date of issuance.
This provision, in conjunction with the 18-month publication rule, is expected to eliminate the ability of inventors to pursue "submarine patents," those that sit for decades at the Patent Office until a technology becomes widely used. As it stands now, companies could potentially infringe on the as-yet unissued patent by developing or using similar technology without knowing about such patents.
 
Disadvantage for Foreigners
 In the past, the most contentious intellectual-property argument between the United States and other countries, including Japan, has been whether Washington should move to a "first-to-file" system, which awards a patent to the first party to log its paperwork. The United States now awards patents to Americans, but not to foreigners, who can document that they were first to think of an invention. Many believe, however, that the recent GATT accord rendered the first-to-invent issue irrelevant. The agreement would eliminate a provision of American law that foreign inventors be awarded patents based on their date of application rather than their date of invention.
Another change agreed to by the United States had been sought by the domestic software industry. It expands the rights of a company to challenge patents once they have been issued. Under Mr. Lehman, the Patent Office has moved to revoke two software patents, one issued to Compton's New Media, a subsidiary of Tribune Publishing, and one issued to the Software Advertising Corporation of Rancho La Costa, Calif.
The Patent Office has acknowledged that in the short term, it is ill equipped to adequately examine software applications, which have doubled in recent years. Mr. Lehman said that the provision, along with 18-month publication, would allow industry to weed out inappropriate patents early and cut down on litigation.
The changes in the accord require legislative action in both countries. Although legislation have been introduced covering each of the proposed American changes, it is by no means certain that Congress will write these provisions into law.
Critics of the agreement include independent inventors, who argue that they will be hurt by the provision for 20-year patents dating from the application, because the Patent Office often takes a long time to grant pioneering patents.
With an 18-month publication rule, these inventors say, they will have to disclose their secrets to competitors without any assurance that they will ultimately be granted a patent -- in essence, a guarantee of the exclusive right to develop an invention.
"Frankly, I'm shocked that a treaty of this nature should be signed without any warning," said Paul C. Heckel, a software designer in the Silicon Valley who heads a loose coalition of independent inventors.
Another group, backed by Jerome H. Lemelson, who holds more patents than any other living inventor, has recently taken out full-page advertisements in The Washington Post objecting to the 20-year term.
Commissioner Lehman, who in the past has been receptive to the concerns of independent inventors, seemed today to have lost patience. "There's been a major campaign by people who have an ax to grind," he said. "They claim they are representing small inventors" But he said the inventors were being misled, as they are "unsophisticated and don't have access to the right information."
Just over two weeks ago, the Clinton Administration had formally accused Japan of discriminating against American companies in awarding government contracts for medical and telecommunications equipment. It set in motion a 60-day timetable for imposing sanctions against the Japanese, taking action a few days after the broader trade talks had reached an impasse. Today's signing, therefore, was a marked change of mood.
Yet even with the progress in the patent agreement, other talks on intellectual property are likely to continue. American officials want an accord protecting copyrights, a provision preventing forced disclosure of trade secrets in Japanese courts, and agreement on the period under which trademarks can be protected.

HEADLINE: A Master Builder for Asia's Future

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Conventional wisdom, and the lucre of those in the business, suggest that the biggest game in town here is property, lots of it, pumping its value to levels beyond even Tokyo's galactic heights, building office and apartment towers with a frenzy. But Gordon Wu, from his office 64 floors above a skyline of mirrored stalagmites, dismisses the way of his fellow tycoons here.
"That's for every Tom, Dick, Harry and Trump," he said. "I want to go into infrastructure." 
 Mr. Wu has been hugely successful in property and buildings, although like many developers he had a nasty scare when the market disintegrated in the early 1980's. But for the last decade he has concentrated on long-term projects, building superhighways and power plants throughout Asia.
"There's no doubt we'll become probably the world's largest independent power producer," Mr. Wu declared, his verbal swagger more off-handed than boastful.
He has four power projects up and running, one in China, and three in the Philippines. Two more are under construction, one in China and another in the Philippines, and negotiations are under way for power projects in China, Indonesia and Pakistan.
Last month, Mr. Wu opened China's first superhighway, a $1.1 billion, six-lane toll road running 77 miles from the border of Hong Kong to Guangzhou, the commercial hub of southern China. Work on a second highway, from the Portuguese colony of Macao to Guangzhou, starts in October, and Mr. Wu hopes to finish a 400-mile highway stretching from Guangzhou to Changsha, the capital of Hunan province in central China, before the end of the century.
"I'll explain the logic of this," Mr. Wu said, unfurling a map of China on the mahogany conference table in his office. "I want Hong Kong to be really successful. If you look at the history of America, you have Boston. You have Philadelphia. You have Baltimore, Savannah. How come all of these ports were not No. 1? How come New York was No. 1? It was because of the Hudson River, the Erie Canal, the Great Lakes. If you want Hong Kong to be on the map, the only way to do it is to put this road into the center of China."
With such plans, Mr. Wu and his main company, Hopewell Holdings, have won a reputation for boldness that sets him apart from many of his fellow hongs, or large conglomerates. "The company," a Credit Lyonnais Securities report put it, "has acquired something of a reputation for becoming involved in visionary and often risky projects in locations where other investors feared to tread."
Mr. Wu, now 58 years old, was born in the Wanchai district here, about half a mile from the glittery central business district where the round, dirty-white Hopewell Office tower sits. His father started as a taxi driver and assembled a fleet of 378 taxis before he turned to building one of Hong Kong's larger property and construction concerns. After a rigorous education provided by Irish Jesuits, the younger Mr. Wu studied engineering at Princeton University. He returned to Hong Kong to earn his certification as an architect.
 
Over the Doorstep to China
 Like many other Hong Kong developers, Mr. Wu flourished during the 1970's as property prices began their steep upward spiral. When China cracked open the door to outside investment in 1979, Mr. Wu was one of the first over the threshold, moving from property developer to a career in Asian infrastructure.
Most analysts of Mr. Wu's empire, a dizzying tangle of companies including hotels, construction, power plant management, engineering, finance and highway concerns, admire his vision but confess to having difficulty figuring it all out. Last December, Hopewell Holdings, which showed profits of $267 million last year, up 25 percent over 1992, spun off a subsidiary, Consolidated Electric Power Asia, as a publicly listed company to manage power projects, while retaining 44.5 percent.
"It's very difficult to value the company because the projects are very complex," said John Pinkel, an analyst at HG Asia. "It is very difficult to get a hold on the complex subsidiaries and the cash flow and the financing situation. But he does have a vision. You have to like the concept of building roads and power plants. The concept is very sound. They need roads, and they need power plants in Asia. But the mechanics of doing it are very, very difficult."
 
American Competitors
 Mr. Wu has no competitors among the major hongs here across the range of his infrastructure projects. It is the big American power development companies active in Asia's booming power sector, like Mission, AES Transpower Inc. and the Enron Power Development Corporation, that jockey with him for power projects. No one else has tried to muscle into highway building in China. In Thailand, where Mr. Wu won his contract for a road, rail and retail system in 1990, his problems lie more with the Thai Government bureaucracy than with rival developers.
When Mr. Wu began talking about his highway to Guangzhou more than a decade ago, not many people in Hong Kong thought he could do it. China was, and remains, a difficult place to do business, but Mr. Wu, like some analysts, is convinced the struggle is paying off.
"I've got no doubt that the road will be exceptionally profitable," said Paul Deayton, an analyst at Lehman Brothers Asia. "Despite problems with toll collection," -- it costs about $13 to drive the highway -- "he's been developing shopping malls under the road. Within three years, the road will be contributing about $1 billion a year," in Hong Kong dollars, or about $131 million in American money, he added.
 
'Right Place at the Right Time'
 Similarly, Mr. Wu's power projects, while slow in gestation, are now seen as prescient. "He's been in the right place at the right time to exploit an industry that is in a massive growth phase," Mr. Deayton said. "The Chinese want to add 17,000 megawatts per year over the next 10 years. Their installed capacity is 175,000 megawatts, so they want to increase 10 percent per year for the next 10 years."
Mr. Wu explained, "We see the opportunity in power generation for the simple fact that in this part of the world they need a lot of power."
Later this month Mr. Wu will take an exploratory trip to India, which has an acute shortage of power. He has already signed a letter of intent to build eight 660-megawatt power plants in Pakistan.
Mr. Wu says he has become accustomed to long delays in projects. "I'm getting now to be very philosophical about bureaucracy," he said.
 
Delays in Thailand
 His project to build a highway, elevated light rail and retail system through downtown Bangkok has been on the books for several years, and some analysts suggest it may have to be written off.
"It really is the Thai Government that is holding things up," Mr. Deayton said. "I don't think the political will is there."
But Mr. Wu, conditioned to skeptics, is pushing on. "The struggle is nearly over," he said. "I was finally able to convince the Thai Cabinet don't go underground. 'For Pete's sake,' I told them, 'we all have to go underground. Why hurry it?' We're on the threshold."
While there have been legions of skeptics, bankers have not been among them. With little effort, Hopewell raised a total of nearly $1 billion during 1991 and 1992.
"In my 36 years of work, I can honestly say I've never had to stop a project for lack of money," Mr. Wu said. "There's lots of bankers out there ready to find me money, for a fee of course."
 
The Chinese Connection
 With China consuming about 60 percent of his companies' time and resources, Mr. Wu protested last month when Prime Minister Li Peng declared a 12 percent cap on profits for foreign-financed power projects in China. That cap was raised to 15 percent, which Mr. Wu finds still too low, but in the end, manageable.
Many analysts admire Mr. Wu's deftness, and connections, in China. Before the Tiananmen massacre in June 1989, Mr. Wu was close to then- Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang, who was deposed for opposing military action against the student protesters. Mr. Wu quickly renewed his relationship with his successor, Li Peng, whom he knew from his first power project in China, and the man many Chinese hold responsible for the bloodshed at Tiananmen.
"Zhao gave me support not because of a personal friendship but rather because what I do is what China needs," Mr. Wu said. "So in a way I get the support of everybody; 1989 is five years ago, and I'm still doing new things."
Similarly, Mr. Wu dismisses as irrelevant a prospect that concerns some investors, the resumption of Chinese sovereignty over Hong Kong in 1997.
"I know exactly what will happen after 1997 -- 1998," he said. "China has tried every possible economic policy since 1949, the Great Leap Forward, central planning, the Cultural Revolution, you name it, private plots, communes, all sorts of things. And finally they tried this little pitch called open door and reform. Now look at the refrigerators and color TV's. I don't think they want to change. And actually, it is that reason I have so much confidence."

HEADLINE: Israel to Tax Stock Gains

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Finance Minister Avraham Shohat, in a reversal of Israeli policy, said today that he wanted to impose a 10 percent capital-gains tax on the Tel Aviv stock market.
Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin quickly embraced the proposal to impose the 10 percent tax, starting Jan. 1, on real profits from stock investments. Officials said it would reduce the burden of other taxes. 
 The announcement came at the close of trading in Israel. Prices of Israeli stocks traded on United States markets finished lower.
The American depository receipts of Teva Pharmaceutical fell $1.44, to $26.50, in heavy Nasdaq trading. Scitex lost 62.5 cents to close at $18.6250, also on the Nasdaq, and Tadiran Ltd. sank $1.625, to $17, on the New York Stock Exchange. The closed-end First Israel Fund was down $1, to $13.125, also on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: FEDERAL RESERVE RAISES KEY RATES TO COOL ECONOMY

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve raised the interest rates it controls today, hoping to prevent the economy's continuing strength from leading to inflation but making it more expensive for Americans to borrow money.
The central bank raised two short-term rates by half a percentage point each, more than most analysts had expected. The moves produced rallies in stock and bond markets, as investors acted on their beliefs that inflation would stay low and long-term rates would not keep rising. 
 The rate increases also prompted banks across the country to raise their prime rate, the rate that determines the cost of home equity loans, small-business loans and credit card balances.
Congressional Democrats and business groups reacted angrily, saying the Federal Reserve action risked a drastic slowdown of the economy. But the public response of the White House was calm, with officials emphasizing the Federal Reserve's independence and predicting continued economic growth.
High White House officials had signaled in recent days that they could accept an increase of a quarter of a percentage point. But a few officials, like Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, who among President Clinton's campaign advisers was most enthusiastic about a Government role to stimulate the economy, said they thought inflation was not a threat.
An official who insisted on anonymity said the Administration began anticipating an increase of half a percentage point this morning, after the Commerce Department reported that builders had started 4.7 percent more houses and apartments in July than they had in June, despite higher mortgage rates.
Today's action makes further rate increases less likely during the autumn Congressional campaign, the official said, a position that the Federal Reserve's announcement early this afternoon appeared to support.
The rate increases today will translate immediately into higher interest rates for small-business loans and home-equity loans. Rates for adjustable-rate mortgages and credit card balances will rise more slowly over the coming months and years, as lenders wait for regularly scheduled reviews of the terms of those loans. Fixed-rate mortgages may actually become a little cheaper, mirroring today's drop in interest rates on 30-year Treasury bonds as lenders worry less that inflation will erode their returns.
Higher rates could hurt Democrat ic efforts to contain the losses the party is widely expected to suffer in the November elections for the House and Senate, and could further depress President Clinton's political standing.
"I think it's bad for the economy, and if it's bad for the economy, then it's bad for elected officials," SenatorPaul S. Sarbanes, a Maryland Democrat up for re-election, said in a telephone interview.
Today's increase was the fifth move this year by the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates. The Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's policy-making body, met this morning and voted to raise the Federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for overnight loans, to 4.75 percent from 4.25 percent. The Federal Reserve Board also voted to lift the discount rate, the rate the Fed charges for its own loans to banks, to 4 percent from 3.5 percent.
The Federal Reserve controls the Federal funds rate by buying and selling government securities.
 
Wall Street Reacts
 In the markets today, the interest rate on 30-year Treasury bonds fell to 7.37 percent from 7.50 percent on Monday, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 24.28 points, to 3,784.57. John Lipsky, an economist at Salomon Brothers in New York, said the Federal Reserve's actions made the economy seem less likely to overheat and inflation less likely to erode the returns on long-term investments. So investors are more willing to invest in stocks and accept lower interest rates on bonds.
"There are a lot of investors who would like to believe the Goldilocks view of the economy -- not too hot, not too cold, but just right," Mr. Lipsky said.
With factories near full use, unemployment low and commodity prices rising, concerns about higher inflation in the months ahead led the Federal Reserve to act today, analysts agreed. The economy grew at an annual rate of 3.7 percent during the second quarter, a level many experts say is greater than the maximum that is sustainable without igniting inflation.
"These measures were taken against the background of evidence of continuing strength in the economic expansion and high levels of resource utilization," the Federal Reserve said in a statement about today's rate increases. "The actions are intended to keep inflationary pressures contained, and thereby foster sustainable economic growth."
Over the last 12 months, consumer prices have risen 2.8 percent, with the July rise put at three-tenths of 1 percent.
In looking for signs of future inflation, Federal Reserve officials try to gauge whether enough resources like unemployed labor, unused factory capacity and commodities are available to allow further economic growth. Unemployment stood at 6.1 percent in July, factories are running at the highest level in five years and commodity prices have been rising.
These signs have convinced a growing number of Federal Reserve officials that the economy is now operating at close to its full potential and may soon exceed that level if factories add overtime and compete for scarce materials. When the economy has operated above full capacity, notably in the late 1970's and to a lesser extent in the late 1980's, inflation has tended to rise.
"The dangers of running over are that you start running into higher rates of inflation," said Alan Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, in an interview at the beginning of last week.
 
Eye on the Elections
 The announcement today also offered a hint that the Federal Reserve may wait before raising rates again, possibly until after the Congressional elections on Nov. 8. "The Federal Reserve will continue to monitor economic and financial developments to gauge the appropriate stance of policy," the Fed's statement said. "But these actions are expected to be sufficient, at least for a time, to meet the objective of sustained, noninflationary growth."
Eugene J. Sherman, director of research at M. A. Schapiro & Company, a New York brokerage firm, said that with today's move, "I would expect the Fed to step aside now, with the next likely move at the November meeting, on Nov. 15."
The other rate increases this year came on Feb. 4, March 22 and April 18, with the Federal Reserve raising the Federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point each time, and on May 17, when the discount and Federal funds rates were raised half a point.
In Congressional testimony in July, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, who is often called the second-most-powerful man in the country and the most powerful when it comes to the economy, said that it would be better to raise rates too much than too little.
"If we fail to recognize emerging inflationary forces, remedying that will be far more difficult and far more of a problem for the long-term stability of the economy in 1995 and beyond," he said.
Only a few Administration officials strongly disagree. Mr. Reich, who has sharply criticized the view that inflation is a risk, without actually criticizing the Federal Reserve by name, said in a recent interview that American workers produce more now in an hour than they did a year ago but their wages have not risen proportionately. So recent wage increases only begin to close that gap and do not threaten inflation, he said.
 
Varied Viewpoints
 But elsewhere in the Administration, notably at the White House and the Treasury Department, there have been much stronger worries that the economy might overheat, feeding inflation and provoking the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates drastically. Much higher rates could produce a recession that would hurt President Clinton's re-election prospects if the downturn lasted through the 1996 election, these officials warn.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of the Council of Economic Advisers, has taken a particularly conciliatory approach to the Federal Reserve. For several weeks, she has said repeatedly that another quarter-point rate increase by the Fed would be consistent with the Administration's forecast in mid-July that the rate on three-month Treasury bills would average 4 percent.
But simple arithmetic shows that given this year's rises in interest rates, any further rate increase by the Fed, including today's, produces a full-year average of more than 4 percent. During an interview on Friday, Ms. Tyson acknowledged that this might be a problem for her forecast. She said that she still expected her forecast of 3 percent growth this year to be accurate but that interest rates might be higher because so much of the economic growth has come early in the year, putting pressure on the Fed to raise rates.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: ECONOMISTS' VIEWS;
The Compromise Plan: A Last Hope, or a Hoax?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Is the Mitchell plan, the Senate Democratic leadership's compromise on health care reform, the last best hope for achieving universal health insurance? Or is it a shell game, an exercise in deception that would waste tens of billions of dollars and discourage work efforts by the poor?
The answer, say health economists -- some with resignation, some with disgust -- is both. 
 "We're into camouflage," concludes Uwe Reinhardt of Princeton University, who nonetheless hopes Congress will seize the moment and pass the legislation. Martin Feldstein of Harvard, who would much prefer to tinker at the edges of the current system than go for broke, argues, "People ought to understand what it's about and what it costs."
In the early stages of the debate, the White House focused on what was then seen as the political imperative driving health care reform: containment of exploding costs. But as business interests began to assess the bottom line and Republicans pounded away at their theme of no new taxes, most eyes turned to the issue of who would pay for broader coverage.
 
Health Insurance Mine Field
 The Clinton Administration's bill put much of the financial burden on employers -- and thus indirectly on their workers, where it already is. But what had initially seemed to be the path of least political resistance proved to be a mine field sewn by small-business lobbies that wanted no part of an insurance mandate.
So Senator George J. Mitchell, the majority leader, expanded on an alternative independently drafted by Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee. His compromise would free employers of the obligation to provide insurance, provided that 19 out of 20 Americans receive it as a fringe from employers or buy it themselves with a little help from Uncle Sam.
The bill, which is now being debated in the Senate, postpones the day of reckoning on employer mandates until the year 2002. And it imposes only very modest new taxes. A tobacco levy would raise $7 billion in 2002, while taxes on insurance premiums would add another $21 billion -- small change on a national health care budget expected to exceed $1.9 trillion just eight years from now.
If that sounds too good to be true, Professor Feldstein would be happy to seat you at the head of the class. The shuffle of cash needed to finance vastly extended coverage, he says, is largely hidden in the fine print.
Mr. Feldstein, who was a member of President Ronald Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, calculates that a big indirect tax is buried in the requirement that insurance companies assume part of the cost of services for poor people now covered by Medicaid.
 
Overbilling the Insured
 Their benefits are more generous than those offered in the bill's standard package, but their premiums would be the same; presumably, the insurance companies would pass the extra cost on to their entire pool of customers. Mr. Feldstein estimates that would add $30 billion to everyone else's premiums, much the way hospitals now overbill the insured to cover the uninsured.
Senator Mitchell is not impressed by this back-of-the-envelope calculation. "They're one person's made-up numbers," he says, and they contradict the conclusions of the Office of Management and Budget, a White House agency. Transferring responsibilities for Medicaid to private businesses will generate substantial savings, he argues, perhaps even obviating the need for more burden-sharing by insurers' paying customers.
Mr. Reinhardt has little patience with this political dance. "One way or another," he says, "universal coverage requires a redistribution of $80 billion from the top to the bottom." The real issue is how to accomplish the transfer with minimal side effects. And here Mr. Feldstein's criticisms ring truer to many economists.
For one thing, the subsidies offered to low- income workers would distort incentives to organize production efficiently. Businesses would "sort" workers, concentrating low-wage workers in companies that did not provide insurance as a fringe to take maximum advantage of the Government's offer to subsidize the insurance of low-income families not otherwise covered.
Arguably most distressing, the sliding scale of subsidies intended to make insurance affordable for the working poor and struggling middle class would be a powerful disincentive to work.
As low-income workers earn more, they gradually lose eligibility to Government benefits ranging from food stamps to income tax credits -- a problem that is already widely blamed for keeping unskilled workers on welfare.
Yet, according to the Congressional Budget Office, the graduated withdrawal of the health insurance subsidies under the Mitchell plan would take another 30 to 55 cents more from an extra dollar in wages. "In the end," the budget office concludes, "some low-wage workers would keep as little as 15 cents of every additional dollar they earned."
These problems are not unique to the Mitchell draft. "Every ambitious reform proposal before Congress has significant economic flaws," says Robert Reischauer, head of the Congressional Budget Office.
Mr. Reinhardt is more pointed, saying, "The approach favored by Senator Dole, who is leading the opposition, is no better than the Mitchell plan."
But as a technical matter, these problems are not intractable. Indeed, there is broad agreement, if not consensus, among economists on the outlines of a simple financing structure that would avoid the pitfalls of employer or individual mandates.
Some basic level of care could be financed from a national sales tax or some other broad-based tax that would have a relatively small impact on incentives to work or save. Everyone, rich or poor, would receive a voucher that could be used to buy insurance through employer-organized groups or directly from the market.
To assure that the voucher bought adequate coverage for people with varying degrees of health risk, its redemption value to a private insurer or umbrella health care provider would be linked to the age, health and other vital statistics of the insured. Those who wanted to buy richer benefits could do so at their own expense.
This is the approach used in many industrialized countries, notably Germany.
But this generic approach to financing health care is about the only one lacking political champions outside the ivory tower. Nor is it likely to win many, since it would create the image -- though not the reality -- of much bigger government.
 
Radical vs. Gradual Change
 Thus, the $64 question in health care finance today is whether any broad reform plan that could clear the political hurdles is worth the trouble. Or, as Barry Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution, sees it, whether it makes sense to pass some variation on the Mitchell bill now and vow to fix it up later, or simply try to patch up the existing system.
Mr. Reinhardt favors radical change, even flawed change. Both Medicaid and Medicare were riddled with perverse economic incentives when they were created, he notes, but have since been whipped into shape. And once several million more low-income Americans have access to health insurance at subsidized rates, he says, the politics will again focus on the core issues of deciding what benefits to deliver and how to deliver them for the least money.
Mr. Feldstein prefers evolutionary change, at least in part because he thinks there is no true health care crisis. "Most people are adequately insured now, and the rest have access to decent care when they are very ill," he says.
Professor Feldstein would abandon the goal of universal coverage and work instead to fix the most pressing problems in the current system: the inability of workers to take their insurance when they change jobs, and the failure of Medicaid to cover all Americans living in poverty.
All this saddens Mr. Bosworth, who, as a trustee of Blue Cross in Maryland, has viewed the growing problems of the health insurance system from the inside. What started as a high-minded quest to curb costs and extend coverage, he says, "is turning into a nightmare."

HEADLINE: Tailhook Accuser Participated in Leg-Shaving, Court Is Told

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 16

 BODY:
Court documents assert that Paula Coughlin, the woman considered the whistle-blower in the Tailhook scandal, participated in a leg-shaving episode on the night before she says she was assaulted by drunken aviators.
Ms. Coughlin has always insisted that she had not participated in raucous partying on the evening before she was assaulted.
In a memorandum filed in Federal District Court here, one defendant, the Las Vegas Hilton, says that Lieut. Rolando Diaz of the Navy testified in a sworn deposition that he shaved Ms. Coughlin's legs on Friday, Sept. 6, 1991, while she was dressed in her Navy uniform. 
 The Hilton memorandum said Lieutenant Diaz testified in a deposition on June 20, 1994, that Ms. Coughlin, at the time a Navy lieutenant, returned to a party later that night wearing a mini skirt and tank top, at which time she was "plastered."
Ms. Coughlin has asserted in depositions that she did not attend the party.
Ms. Coughlin and several other women have filed civil lawsuits against the Hilton and the San Diego-based Tailhook Association, maintaining that they were sexually assaulted at the 1991 gathering of Navy and Marine aviators. Ms. Coughlin's lawsuit is scheduled to go to trial on Sept. 12 in Federal court here.
Lieutenant Diaz said in his deposition that Ms. Coughlin "paid" for his services by signing his "Leg Shave '91" poster on a hotel suite wall. Hotel lawyers want a handwriting expert to determine if the message, "You made me see God. The PA Coughlin." was written by Ms. Coughlin.
A Reno lawyer, Eugene Wait, argued in a memorandum filed on Monday that Lieutenant Diaz's testimony contradicts Ms. Coughlin's statement that she had not felt well and had spent Friday night sleeping in her hotel room.
Ms. Coughlin's lawyer, Nancy Stagg, has said previously that the only event Ms. Coughlin attended was on Saturday night, when she says she was attacked by a group of drunken aviators.
Ms. Stagg was unavailable for comment when a call was placed to her office today.
Ms. Stagg is seeking to reopen depositions of two women, one of whom said that Ms. Coughlin attended Tailhook parties on Friday night. In Defense Department interviews, the woman initially said she knew that Ms. Coughlin was not present but apparently changed her statements when questioned by lawyers.
Ms. Coughlin, 32, was an admiral's aide when she filed claims that she had been sexually harassed while attending the 1991 Tailhook convention at the Hilton. More than 80 women subsequently made similar assertions, with a handful following Ms. Coughlin's lead and filing civil lawsuits. The women said they had been groped and fondled as they were forced down a gantlet of drunken revelers.
The Navy and Marine Corps pursued 140 harassment cases, but none led to a court-martial.
Ms. Coughlin resigned from the Navy in February, saying "covert attacks" had made it impossible for her to serve. She asserts that she is now unemployable because her skills as a helicopter pilot and maintenance officer cannot transfer to the private sector.
