LENGTH: 1509 words

HEADLINE: Many Faces of Harlem's Main Street;
A Day in the Life of 125th: From Bustling to Restless to Cool

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT 

 BODY:
It's 2 A.M. on Saturday and the Uptown Comedy Club at 125th Street and Fifth Avenue is literally shaking with the recorded thunder of rappers Warren G & Nate Dogg, playing a seemingly endless variation on the gangster-chic theme that dominates the street.
Much of 125th Street, Harlem's main commercial thoroughfare, surges with black youth on foot, on bicycles, on motorcycles, in automobiles, Jeeps and even a stretch limousine or two. A summer weekend ritual of see-and-be-seen, set to Harlem's hip-hop rhythms and sensibilities, has evolved on the street of Hughes, Divine, Powell and Malcolm X. 
 It is a place where thousands of the self-described cool, "def" and "dope" hang out while a slightly older set gathers in shadowy hole-in-the-wall bars.
It is also a place in which old tensions can ignite quickly. Earlier this month, the police, after reports of gunfire, clashed with 1,000 young people for almost an hour near the McDonald's restaurant at 125th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard. There were arrests and injuries. "These are good kids, no different than any other kids," said William Morange, the commander of Harlem's 28th Precinct, who stood in front of the Apollo Theater for much of last Friday night and early Saturday. "I don't know what happened."
Nighttime on 125th can be like that: fast, edgy, sometimes inexplicable.
But this is a stretch of Harlem with many guises. In the first hours of sunlight, it takes on the more measured cadence of work and worry, struggle and responsibility, and often pain. Even with its recurring promises of redevelopment, too few jobs and too much crime, violence and drugs, 125th Street is full of enterprise: storefronts, restaurants, churches, vendors' stands, theaters, banks and bars -- many decked in decors that range from the eccentric to the Afro-centric.
From the East River to the Hudson, the restless street only permits itself a fretful nap in the couple of hours just before daybreak. For the remaining 22, it becomes a street theater, offering scenes of the dramatic, comic, tragic, erotic, absurd and inspirational.
Herewith, a day in the life of 125th Street, the artery running through the heart of Harlem.
5:30 A.M., FRIDAY Clarence and Cleo Kenney seem to simply materialize beside their gleaming newsstand near the corner of Malcolm X Boulevard and 125th Street. The retired schoolteachers hurriedly stock and straighten bins of newspapers, magazines and comic books, most with black themes.
A few feet away, a 54-year-old homeless man wearing an eyepatch shuffles behind a shopping cart. For much of the day he will mine the mounds of curbside garbage rich in deposits of redeemable bottles and cans. Across the street men and women, many with signs of slumber clinging to their faces, stop by a coffee-and-doughnut stand before climbing like sleepwalkers into buses and subway cars: workbound.
As the predawn darkness begins its daily retreat, 125th Street begins to pulse with life. As sure as the morning, Joe Knight, a 50-year-old unemployed bookbinder, makes his way to 125th Street.
Once there, Mr. Knight works the street for "any change you can spare," approaching cars and trucks stopped by the traffic light at Malcolm X Boulevard. Police officers usually order him to move along, he says.
"They are trying to make this the new AK-47," Mr. Knight says, comparing the bottle of window spray hanging from his belt to an assault rifle. Mr. Knight, who says he is a Vietnam veteran, says the Giuliani administration's move against quality-of-life nuisances is making his pursuit of an "honest dollar" a crime.
He says he has been out of work for 22 months, his unemployment benefits ran out last year and he supports his three children through welfare benefits. For much of the morning, Mr. Knight, well-groomed in work pants, a light jacket and wide bent-brimmed hat, politely approaches drivers and asks them to help him make ends meet.
For hours he trots along the center line of 125th Street, asking for a handout. "It's my job," he says.
7 A.M. Anna Bates, a 61-year-old clerk at Woolworth's, is waiting patiently for the doors to open. She is respectfully referred to as "Big Moms" by generations of youngsters who have worked and grown up in the old five-and-dime store. She says she has worked there for the last 36 years. Next year, according to her plans, will be her last.
"It's about time to retire," she says with a self-satisfied chuckle.
7:30 A.M. Merchants are beginning to sweep and hose off their sidewalks; the frequency of buses growling along the street starts to increase, forming caravans of people arriving and leaving Harlem.
The first of the metal gates that are pulled down over storefronts at night like corrugated eyelids are unlocked and rattle loudly as they are hoisted.
Woolworth's gates, like many along the street, are painted in a carnival style that depicts black heroes and urban dreamscapes.
Before disappearing inside, Ms. Bates scans her street as it rustles with mounting activities.
"It has changed a lot," she says, remembering the early 1960's, when Jackie Wilson played the Apollo Theater and the street dressed its aspirations in a suit and tie rather than outsized T-shirts and sagging jeans.
NOON The street is fully transformed into its workday incarnation. There are few vacant storefronts. At Sister's African Hair Braiding Center, a score of customers line the walls, two or three deep. The stylists, mostly from West Africa, ply the ancient art of hair braiding from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M., seven days a week.
Many of the hair styles take four to five hours to complete, costing an average of $50, says Aminata Dia, the shop's manager, who is a native of Senegal.
"It's very nice and friendly here," says Bernice Nicks, 57, a woman in a wheelchair whose home attendant suggested getting her hair braided. Finger-length braids frame her face. "It's my first time and I think it looks nice."
2 P.M. Along several blocks on the west side of the street, starting at Malcolm X Boulevard, the sidewalks are crammed with vendors' stands, many stretched end to end. They sell almost anything that can fit on folding tables or hang from chain-link fences, from T-shirts to bean pies to bootleg videotapes of movies as new as "The Mask" and "The Lion King."
Many merchants are West African and much of their wares are from their homelands: beads, wooden jewelry, sandals, art objects, musical instruments, kente and mud cloth by the bolt or fashioned into suits and shirts and dresses. The vendors lend a touch of charm and chaos to 125th Street, though they have been a source of considerable irritation to rent-paying merchants who have been lobbying to get them off the street. Despite all city efforts, they remain.
Even some of the vendors consider the situation out of control.
"I'm not happy," says Jimmy Lee, who has been a street vendor for 35 years in Harlem. He sells handmade pillows on the southeast corner of 125th Street and African Square. "If their country is so great why are they coming here?"
Mr. Lee, 50, who says his father is from Africa, says American-born black vendors are being squeezed off 125th Street by an influx of African vendors who the police have chased away from selling in Brooklyn and the Bronx.
8 P.M. Vendors and merchants begin to leave 125th Street. Some say the absence of a heavy police presence makes it dangerous to do business at night.
9 P.M. The first tides of teen-agers and young adults begin to flood 125th. Now it belongs to entrepreneurs like Antonio Gloss and Rodney Hunter.
Mr. Gloss, 28, equipped with his own air compressor, airbrushes T-shirts to order -- $15 and up -- right on the street like a contemporary Impressionist. In the glow of the Apollo marquee, he creates colorful fantasies of street scenes and characters, each signed with his logo: Harlem 125th Street.
Mr. Hunter, 26, is one of several photographers who for $6 will take a Polaroid picture of anyone who wants to pose against wall-sized paintings of favorite rap artists.
MIDNIGHT Scores of people want to document their night memories of 125th Street with Mr. Hunter and Mr. Gloss.
"People like taking pictures," Mr. Hunter says. "They want it to last forever."
2 A.M., SATURDAY There are polished cars and buffed bodies moving to their own midtempo, bass-heavy sound tracks. It's a virtual block party as far as the eye can see, complete with malt liquor and marijuana, soda and potato chips.
The party is still pounding the old pavement of 125th Street until 3:30 A.M., providing the opportunity for Mychele Boykin, 18, of Jamaica, Queens, and Steven Wright, 19, of the Bronx, to meet and exchange telephone numbers.
"He just came up to me and said, 'What's your name?' " Ms. Boykin said of their not-so-chance meeting on the street.
Dewayne Shelton, a 25-year-old telephone cable splicer, rode his 10-speed mountain bike to 125th Street from the Bronx to observe the street scene. "This is our village," he said.

HEADLINE: On Economics, the Teacher May Need Homework

BYLINE: By SUSAN ANTILLA 

 BODY:
The educational video opens with a scene of high school seniors boasting about graduation gifts from their parents: a trip to Europe for one, a convertible sports car for another. After hearing what her friends received, a student named Jen goes home to get the bad news. Her parents are giving her a mutual fund.
"I don't even know what it does," says Jen, disappointed with such a boring gift. 
 Chances are, neither do her teachers. High school teachers instructing the growing number of business and economics classes are often patching together a curriculum that includes handouts from self-interested corporations and lectures by local business people, who may seize the opportunity to pitch their wares to a captive audience.
High school business teachers have a lot to learn, said Sue Duncan of the Investment Company Institute in Washington, a mutual fund trade group that produced the 11-minute "Mutual Fundamentals" video. Indeed, the video "was produced as much for teachers as it was for students," she said.
In workshops for business and economics teachers in five cities this year, Ms. Duncan found that 22 percent of the teachers had "little or no knowledge" of mutual funds, the nation's most popular investment vehicle. "They were uncomfortable enough with the topic to tell us we would be wasting our time and money if we produced materials for students without giving teacher training," said Ms. Duncan, who directs the institute's education foundation.
William B. Walstad, director of the University of Nebraska's National Center for Research in Economic Education in Lincoln, Neb., acknowledged that "many practicing teachers have never had an economics course, yet they're teaching it."
The reasons are several. Business and economics are frequently taught under the umbrella of a school's social studies department, and many social studies teachers are trained in history, not economics. "A lot of history teachers shied away from economics because it might have been harder than that course in political science," Mr. Walstad said.
Ms. Duncan discovered early that one of the great challenges was finding business and economics teachers in the first place. They are scattered among high school departments of history, social studies, civics, mathematics and consumer education, among others. "It's all over the place," she said. "We couldn't even find a standardized economic text" that might offer clues as to what students were being taught.
In one of the institute's taped sessions with groups of high school economics teachers, one participant admitted that "you get to be a real good scavenger" when you teach business or economics, gathering handouts from banks, insurance companies, brokerage firms and Federal agencies. To keep up the pace -- and to introduce some expertise -- the teachers frequently called in local stockbrokers, insurance salesmen or bankers to teach a class.
But professional participation has its price, said David Earl, the vice president of curriculum at Junior Achievement, a national nonprofit group in Colorado Springs that helps educate students on business and the economy. "Every now and again, you've got to be careful with a volunteer handing out business cards and saying, 'If your folks need insurance, call me.' "
To be sure, progress has been made from the days when business education in high schools consisted of a smattering of lectures squeezed into the accounting course offered to students in vocational education. Only 16 percent of high school students took a course in economics in 1961, Mr. Walstad said. That rose to 29 percent by 1988 and 44 percent by 1990.
But from Mr. Walstad's glass-is-half-empty perspective, the reality is that "a good portion of high school students never get instruction in economics." Those who do, he said, will be shortchanged if their teachers cannot explain the basics.
And many are shortchanged, according to a national survey of 1,005 high school seniors, college seniors and the public, conducted in 1992 by the National Center for Research in Economic Education and the Gallup Organization. The high school seniors who were surveyed answered correctly only 35 percent of the basic questions about the economy. The public did almost as badly, answering 39 percent of the questions correctly -- a result that suggests that virtually everything Americans know about the subject, they learned by 12th grade.
College seniors did somewhat better. They answered correctly 51 percent of the questions about unemployment, profits and supply and demand. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus 3 percentage points for the public's responses and 6 percentage points for the students' responses.
To many educators, the addition of business and the economy as an area of emphasis no doubt sounds like one more luxury that they can ill afford when reading and math scores remain weak.
 
Economics as a Basic
 But Mr. Walstad contends that an understanding of economics is no luxury. "You and I can choose to deal with the world of the arts or music," he said. "But we deal with economics in our careers, as consumers and as voters. You can't escape it, and in that sense I see it as critically important as math, reading and the sciences."
Several institutions are trying to fill this educational void, among them Junior Achievement and the University of Nebraska's National Center for Research in Economics Education. And where new teaching jobs are opening up, more people qualified to teach economics and business are slowly filling them, a response in part to the struggling economy of recent years.
"An increasing number of people with bachelor's degrees in business administration are coming back to school to get a teacher certification," said Janet Treichel, director of the National Business Education Association. "A lot of people went into the business world and were affected by the ups and downs of the economy once they got there."
It is also a "quality of life issue," she said, noting that the prospect of having summers off and shorter work days as teachers appeals to many business people with uncertain futures at large corporations.
Ms. Treichel noted, too, that colleges are trying to strengthen teachers' preparation and expertise in their core subjects, like economics, by mandating that the undergraduate degree be taken in one of those subjects; the teaching certificate is treated like a breed apart. "It used to be without exception that you got your teaching credentials in the course of your four-year degree," Ms. Treichel said. "But now, increasingly, the teaching credential is in a fifth year program."

HEADLINE: Challenger Assails G.O.P. Front-Runner

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEWINGTON, Conn., Aug. 16

 BODY:
Far ahead in the race for Governor, according to polls, John Rowland was attacked by a challenger within his own Republican Party this week for his conduct as a Representative and former Representative.
While representing the Waterbury area for six years during the 80's, Mr. Rowland wrote 108 overdraft checks on his account in the House bank, his challenger, Secretary of the State Pauline Kezer, said in her first radio advertisement, broadcast on Monday, and repeated in their first debate today. 
 After losing the three-way race for Governor in 1990, the advertisement also said, Mr. Rowland then "peddled his influence as a lobbyist, making almost a million dollars in two years from the companies that laid off thousands of Connecticut workers."
The advertisement was immediately protested by Mr. Rowland and by the Republican State Chairman, John A. Mastropietro, who called on Mrs. Kezer to withdraw it. Mr. Mastropietro said Mrs. Kezer, who qualified for a primary by only a three-vote margin at the party's convention, had broken a pledge to delegates and party officials to wage a primary based on the issues.
Personal attacks, Mr. Mastropietro warned, could damage the candidates so much that the party would be unable to unite for the fall campaign, where many Republicans think Mr. Rowland can capture the Governor's office for the party for the first time since 1970.
Mrs. Kezer's attacks on Mr. Rowland are almost certainly a preview of what he would face in the general election. It will again be a three-way race, with Lieut. Gov. Eunice Groark seeking to succeed Lowell P. Weicker Jr. under the banner of A Connecticut Party, and the winner of a Democratic primary between State Senator John Larson and State Comptroller William Curry.
On Monday, Mrs. Groark called a news conference to complain about Mr. Rowland's broadsides on the state government, which he accuses of discouraging businesses while coddling criminals. Mrs. Groark said he was distorting the Weicker administration's record, and she called him childish and "not able to color within the lines."
Mr. Rowland, in the debate today with Mrs. Kezer on radio station WPOP, said: "There are 54 reasons why Pauline has launched this negative, nasty ad. The 54 reasons are that I'm 54 percent ahead in the polls."
He has acknowledged his overdrafts on the House bank, a common practice among many House members that led some to defeat in 1992 after voters learned of the taxpayer-supported courtesy. He noted that he, like other members, always covered the overdrafts with subsequent deposits.
He said Mrs. Kezer had distorted his business record. He was a consultant, he said, not a lobbyist, for large Connecticut military contractors, including United Technologies and Electric Boat. And his total income for 1992 and 1993, he said, was not a million dollars, but $754,149.
But Mr. Rowland's main response to Mrs. Kezer's attacks today was that voters are interested only in positive discussions of the issues facing them now.
 
Not Withdrawing Ad
 "When I'm out talking to people," he said, "people are talking about jobs. They're talking about the economy, they're talking about the income tax, they're talking about people leaving the state, they're talking about spending, they're talking about welfare reform, they're talking about education.
"They're not talking about something that went on five years ago in Washington."
Mrs. Kezer, seated across a table from Mr. Rowland during the debate, said she would not withdraw the advertisement. She was comparing his experience with hers, she said: his was as a lawmaker in Washington and then as a consultant in Washington, while hers was in state government here in Connecticut.
"What I am simply trying to do," she said, "is talk about the last four years and what I have done, and the last four years when John has been in D.C. working for large companies in Connecticut that have unfortunately been laying off a lot of people."
Today's debate featured familiar themes, with Mr. Rowland repeating his pledge to repeal the state's income tax within five years, and Mrs. Kezer saying it could be scaled back but not eliminated.
Mr. Rowland said he wanted to focus the state's economic development efforts on small businesses, while Mrs. Kezer said the efforts should be focused on businesses, large or small, in industries identified as especially promising for the state.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rate Move Buoys Price Of Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose sharply yesterday, after the Federal Reserve announced its fifth interest rate increase of the year.
The price of the 30-year bond climbed 120/32 , to 10118/32 , for a yield of 7.37 percent, down from 7.50 percent on Monday. The yield was the lowest in nearly two weeks. Before the Fed began raising interest rates, starting with an increase in the funds rate on Feb. 4, the yield was 6.35 percent. 
 The drop of 13 basis points in the yield on the 30-year bond nearly matched the drop of 18 basis points on May 17, when the Fed increased short-term rates by half a percentage point. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
A technical analyst with Salomon Brothers, Alex Saitta, said that in the last 25 times the Fed had raised its target for the Federal funds rate, the 30-year bond had rallied 12 times and fallen 13.
The Fed announced the increase in the discount rate to 4 percent, from 3.50 percent, and the increase in its target for the Federal funds rate to 4.75 percent, from 4.25 percent, at an early afternoon news conference. The discount rate is the interest charged on loans to member banks. The Federal funds rate is the interest on overnight loans between banks.
 
Evidence of Expansion
 The Fed said it had made the moves based upon a background of evidence of continuing strength in the economic expansion and high levels of resource utilization.
The increase in the discount rate and Federal funds target rate "are expected to be sufficient, at least for a time, to meet the objective of sustained, noninflationary growth," the Fed said in a release.
But some economists said the statement could be a signal that another rate increase was unlikely when the Fed's policy making Federal Open Market Committee meets again in September. The situation could change, they said, by the next meeting -- after the Congressional elections -- in November.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities, said "that this move clearly demonstrates the Fed's determination to avoid inflationary pressures, and in fact was somewhat stronger than many had expected."
"The economy may be slowing somewhat," he added, "but the Fed thinks current economic growth still exceeds what it believes is the economy's noninflationary long-run growth path."
Mr. Fine said he thought the Fed believed that a growth rate of 2.5 percent was noninflationary, and until that rate was achieved, the Fed would lean toward further tightening. So, if the economy and capacity utilization continue to rise, there could be another move before the end of year.
 
Limiting Risk
 Before the interest rate increase yesterday, many market participants had said that bonds would rally only if the Fed made a move of half a percentage point. Some analysts had said the Fed would only make a quarter-point move, not wanting to risk slowing the economy too much.
The analysts who had leaned toward a half-point increase said that anything less would be regarded as too small to contain the higher inflation that would result if the economy kept growing. The market, they said, may also have interpreted a smaller move to mean that the Fed was not being aggressive enough with inflation, which erodes fixed income investments.
Joseph V. Battipaglia, managing director of Sterling Advisors, said yesterday's move by the Fed was probably the most widely anticipated of the five rate increases this year. And, he said, if the Fed had not acted, it would have raised questions about what it was up to.
"Now, it leaves no doubt," he said. "We're getting the proper response in bonds, with the short end up and long end coming off."
Concern about how much the Fed planned to raise interest rates overshadowed the impact of a report yesterday that showed construction of new houses rose 4.7 percent in July, which was more than expected, to an annualized rate of 1.415 million. The consensus among many analysts was for an increase of 2.1 percent, and an annualized rate of 1.379 million.
Elliott Platt, chief economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said that while housing starts for July were slightly stronger than expected, the increase had not tempered his belief that residential construction activity would no longer be a significant stimulative force for the economy.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
3 Big Retailers Post Strong Earnings

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Three giant retailers -- Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the Dayton Hudson Corporation and the J. C. Penney Company -- reported strong earnings today for the latest quarter, a sign that consumers were still spending freely.
Wal-Mart, the nation's biggest retailer, said its earnings climbed 13.9 percent on record sales. The company, based in Bentonville, Ark., said it earned $564.8 million, or 25 cents a share, in its second quarter ended on July 31, compared with $495.9 million, or 22 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. Sales climbed 23.2 percent, to a record $20.2 billion from $16.4 billion. 
 "We are pleased with our success in the second quarter, particularly in the discount store and Supercenter divisions, said David Glass, the chief executive officer.
"Our sales performance was very good in the food, electronics, basics, and seasonal categories."
He said the company had completed conversion of 35 former Woolco stores in Canada into the retail giant's format during the quarter. The balance of the 122 Woolco stores in Canada are expected to be converted into Wal-Mart stores during the third quarter, Wal-Mart said.
It also opened its first store in Hawaii and announced expansion into Brazil and Argentina.
Dayton Hudson, based in Minneapolis, said its second-quarter earnings soared 104 percent, to $49 million, from $24 million a year ago, because of better-than-expected results at some of its stores.
The company said the earnings were equal to 61 cents a share, up sharply from 28 cents a share a year earlier. Sales totaled $4.8 billion, up 14 percent, compared with $4.3 billion.
The profits exceeded Wall Street estimates.
"It was a strong quarter driven in part by substantial markdown performance improvement in all three divisions," said Bob Ulrich, chairman and chief executive officer of Dayton Hudson, the nation's fourth-largest retailer. The company said operating profits at its Mervyn's stores improved significantly over last year's weak performance.
Mervyn's has been a stubborn problem for the parent company as the unit suffered because of California's weak economy and an inventory control problem.
"Mervyn's is really where you expect them to show operating profit improvement" going forward, said Dean Ramos of Dain Bosworth Inc. in Minneapolis. "This shows how much leverage there is in the company."
Sales at the Target division of Dayton Hudson rose to $3.10 billion in the quarter from $2.61 billion a year ago. Its same-store sales, or sales at stores open at least a year, rose 9 percent.
Mervyn's sales rose to $1.05 billion, from $1.02 billion last year. Same-store sales at Mervyn's dropped 1 percent, the company said.
J. C. Penney, based in Plano, Tex., said earnings for the quarter rose 17.9 percent, to $132 million, from $112 million a year ago. Sales rose 5 percent, to $4.2 billion from $4.0 billion.
The company said its per-share earnings increased 21 percent, to 51 cents, from 42 cents a year ago, when there were more shares outstanding.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Long-term enthusiasm for Sony, despite a dull near-term outlook.

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez 

 BODY:
THE news will not be good for the Sony Corporation when it reports its first-quarter earnings tomorrow. Analysts expect a replay close to the 33 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings it reported in May.
The yen remains near post-World War II highs, and Japan's continuing trade surplus with the United States keeps it there. Moreover, Japan and Europe are only slowly emerging from recession, and that means fewer cash registers jingling for Walkmen, compact disks and tickets to movies from Sony's Columbia Studios. 
 So why does Sony's stock price continue to perform at levels not far below its 52-week high of $62.875 in July? One major reason is spelled "Last Action Hero," Columbia Studios' costly 1993 flop. The absence of a similar box office disaster this year, as well as the prospect of an economic recovery in Japan and Europe, is bound to improve Sony's prospects, analysts say. Buyers of Sony stock foresee a more profitable 1995.
If an American investor had bought $1,000 worth of Sony American depository receipts a year ago, the holding would be worth $1,381 today. In the same period, the Dow Jones industrial average gained only 6 percent, and the Nikkei 225 index was down half a percent.
Sony gained 37.5 cents yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange to close at $59.125 per A.D.R., which represents one ordinary share in Japan.
"We believe the long-term outlook for the company is very good, although the short-term outlook is likely to be dismal," said Barry Dargan, a technology analyst for S. G. Warburg Securities in Tokyo , who recommends the stock.
Zacks Investment's survey of Sony analysts put the median estimate for the June 30 quarter that will be reported tomorrow at 15 cents a share, down from 19 cents a share a year earlier.
But the analysts expect Sony's earnings for the year ending March 31, 1995, to be 94 cents a share, more than double the 41 cents a share of the 1994 fiscal year. That came on profit of $148.5 million on revenue of $36.2 billion.
Mr. Dargan of S. G. Warburg said the absence of a big-budget catastrophe like Arnold Schwarzenegger's "Last Action Hero" was sure to improve profit from its movie business. (Mr. Schwarzenegger's current hit, "True Lies," was made at 20th Century Fox and will not benefit Sony.)
While Sony did not put a figure on its write-off on "Last Action Hero," Takatoshi Yamamoto, an analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company in Tokyo, has estimated the operating loss for Columbia and other studios in Sony's movie group at 15 billion to 20 billion yen, or $150 million to $200 million.
Mr. Dargan says that all Sony has to do is return to historical levels of profit margins, a likely trend, and it will be earning substantially more money. Fiscal year 1994 profit margins for music and movies were only 3.1 percent, he said, less than half the 1993 levels of 7.2 percent.
Sony's hardware -- camcorders and the like as opposed to the "software" of movies and music -- might languish for years at 1994's profit margin of 2.9 percent (up from 2.5 percent in 1993), and Sony can still profit, Mr. Dargan said. But even in hardware, Sony is likely to come out a winner, said Eriko Yatabe, a credit analyst at Moody's Investors Service in New York.
The consumer electronics industry has struggled with few new blockbuster products (the last one was the camcorder years ago), a strong yen and price cutting. A major industry consolidation is likely, Ms. Yatabe says, and Sony is sure to be an unbowed survivor that posts increased sales and earnings. As one of the largest players in consumer electronics, Sony can spend billions of dollars on research and development to create new products that will make it more competitive.
By mid-1995, predicts Jeffrey L. Pittsburg of Goldis-Pittsburg Institutional Services in Garden City, L.I., Sony stock could reach the low 70's from its current below-$60 range. "Sony's not cheap," Mr. Pittsburg said. "But it's quite a reasonable stock that ought to be bought on weakness, and it's weak now."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Crude Oil Prices Plummet On Interest Rate Concerns

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices fell to their lowest point in nearly three months yesterday amid concerns that higher interest rates will slow economic growth and the demand for industrial fuel.
Prices tumbled late in the session, after the Federal Reserve pushed up short-term interest rates by half a percentage point. 
 "As you slow down the economy, it translates into less of a need for energy," said Tom Curtis, director of energy research for Pegasus Econometric Group in New York.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for September delivery fell 47 cents, to $17.73 a barrel, the lowest daily settlement for the near-term futures contract since May 25.
Oil traders ignored developments in Nigeria, despite reports that labor unions were considering expanded strikes to win the release of Moshood K. O. Abiola, who was arrested and jailed by the military Government after apparently winning a June presidential election.
Nigerian oil workers have been on strike since July 4, damaging the nation's most important industry.
"It looks like the market is discounting Nigeria, and there's enough crude to go around, regardless of what happens in Nigeria," said Tom Bentz, director of energy trading for Quantum Financial Services in New York.
The American Petroleum Institute said in a weekly report released after the close of trading that United States crude oil stocks rose by 3.67 million barrels last week. The increase was at the high end of expectations, and could prompt further selling of crude oil futures today, analysts said.
Other energy contracts were mixed. September heating oil fell 0.56 cent, to 48.54 cents a gallon, while September unleaded gasoline rose 0.09 cent, to 54.92 cents a gallon.
On other commodity markets, livestock and coffee futures weakened. The Commodity Research Bureau's index fell 0.27 point, to 229.17.
Cattle futures fell amid signs that meatpackers and retailers had concluded their buying for the Labor Day weekend, which marks the end of backyard barbecuing in much of the country.
Live cattle for August delivery fell 1.13 cents, to 68.87 cents a pound, on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, while August feeder cattle fell 0.33 cent, to 78.37 cents a pound.
Green arabica coffee beans for September delivery fell 2.05 cents on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange on perceptions that a surge of 12.9 cents on Monday was overdone.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances Modestly After Fed's Rate Increases

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended only modestly higher against other leading currencies in volatile trading yesterday, despite strong rallies in the bond and stock markets after the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates.
The dollar plunged in early trading on fears that the widely anticipated increase would not come. It surged when the Fed announced an increase of one-half percentage point at midday, but the currency's strength faded later in the afternoon. 
 The currency market had already priced the Fed's inflation-fighting move into the dollar's value against the Japanese yen and German mark, analysts said. Dealers remain skeptical that rallies in dollar assets will be sustained long enough to increase demand significantly for the currency.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 100.50 yen, from 100.15 yen on Monday. The dollar also gained against the mark, rising to 1.5585 marks, from 1.5522 on Monday.
Yesterday, the Fed increased its target for the Federal funds rate, the interest banks charge each other on overnight loans, to 4.75 percent. It also raised the discount rate, which the central bank charges on its own loans, to 4 percent.
The moves are expected to narrow the gap between interest rates in the United States and rates in Europe, particularly Germany, bolstering the dollar. Higher interest rates also benefit the dollar because they increase returns on dollar-denominated invesments.
Fed officials had hinted at a rate increase following data that suggested the economy was strenghening to the point where inflation could accelerate.
"I do not see it having a lasting impact on the dollar because it was so widely expected," said David Durst, a vice president at Bear, Stearns & Company.
But some market participants were surprised that the surge in Treasury prices after the Fed raised rates failed to lift the dollar further.
"A stronger bond market brings foreign buyers who have to pay for securities in dollars," said Tom Benfer, a director of foreign exchange for the Bank of Montreal in New York. "The capital markets have been driving the dollar all year."
In other currency trading in New York yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.3080 Swiss francs, up from 1.3030; at 5.3450 French francs, up from 5.3265, and at 1,588 Italian lire, down from 1,594.
The British pound fell to $1.5390 from $1.5420. The Canadian dollar rose to 72.55 United States cents from 72.40 cents

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Defining the Choices That Add Up to Identity

BYLINE: By MARGO JEFFERSON 

 BODY:

I'm Not Stiller
 By Max Frisch
 Translated by Michael Bullock. 383 pages. Harcourt Brace. $12.95.
It's been a long time since the earth moved when we read pronouncements like "Man dies; and he is unhappy," or "Hell is other people," or "There are times, alone in my cell, when I have the feeling that I have only dreamed all this; that at any moment I could stand up, take my hands away from my face and look round in freedom, as though the prison were only within me." This is the way serious European writers expressed themselves in the 1940's and 50's: words like freedom, death and self blazed through the novels and plays of Sartre, Camus, Duerrenmatt and Max Frisch as sin and lust blazed through the film epics of Cecil B. DeMille. 
 And yet if you reread some of these works, which are as crucial to making sense of the cold war era as film noir, political witch hunts and rock-and-roll, you can find yourself swept away by the ardor the writers brought to questions of identity and morality, and by the resources they brought to the craft of fiction.
Take "I'm Not Stiller," by the Swiss writer Max Frisch, who died in 1991. First published in an abridged English version in 1958, it was republished in its entirety in Britain 12 years ago and has finally appeared in the United States. It exudes postwar high seriousness; it cannot wait to show off its many layers of meaning. First, "A Note to the Reader" informs us that we are being permitted to study "The strange history of Anatol Ludwig Stiller, sculptor, husband, lover . . . prisoner": the notebooks he wrote while in prison and his prosecutor's postscript. Then come several august lines from Kirkegaard on man's passion for freedom: the need to "choose oneself," rule out every possibility of becoming something else and, in that difficult choice, find happiness. Then comes the voice of Stiller himself: treacherous, evasive and compelling as an Edgar Allan Poe murderer or a Raymond Chandler detective.
"I'm not Stiller! -- Day after day, ever since I was put into this prison, which I shall describe in a minute, I have been saying it, swearing it, asking for whisky and refusing to make any other statement. For experience has taught me that without whisky I'm not myself, I'm open to all sorts of good influences and liable to play the part they want me to play, although it's not me at all." He is a prisoner in Switzerland (a country "so clean one can hardly breathe for hygiene") and the Swiss officers who arrest him are convinced he is a certain Anatol Stiller, who disappeared six years ago, leaving behind a wife, a mistress, a moderately successful career and a few minor political scandals. But he insists he is Jim White, an American with a past that includes Mexican peasants, Texas cowboys, the docks and back alleys of Northern California, and three murders, as yet untraced. What he wants is a life out of B. Traven and Dashiell Hammett, as filmed by John Huston.
And here he is instead, in pallid, prosperous Switzerland with a lawyer who presumes to consider him a sensible, law-abiding citizen. His response is to maintain "an almost insulting silence and stare out of the window at the old chestnut trees with my hands in my pockets, simply because in the long run I can't stand people of his sort -- people who can't imagine committing murder themselves, and therefore can't imagine that I could commit murder either."
Murders are committed, as it turns out, but as Stiller is brought face to face with the woman who says she is his wife and with the prosecutor who says Stiller has had an affair with his wife, it becomes clear that the murders in question are emotional, metaphorical and discreetly bourgeois. What binds Stiller and his strong-willed but long-suffering wife, Julika? A vacuum: the fact that they have never felt happy together or complete apart. What sets his dream of being another man in motion? A failure of nerve while fighting the Fascists in the Spanish Civil War. And his homeland, economically secure, politically neutral Switzerland is "incapable of suffering in any way over a spiritual compromise," he says. "They make things easier for themselves by simply outlawing the need for greatness."
Mr. Frisch is not really a novelist of ideas; he's a dramatist of ideas. We live out our ideas through our daily lives, after all, and he grasps every nuance of those daily habits and compulsions. It is the tension between these details and the larger ambitions -- so grandly imagined, so absurdly lived out -- that makes the novel work. Emily Dickinson wrote:
Our lives are Swiss --
So still -- so Cool
Till some odd afternoon
The Alps neglect their Curtains
And we look farther on!
When the curtain comes down one last time on the life of Anatol Ludwig Stiller, it is truly harrowing: it is a spiritual blackout.

GRAPHIC: Photo of Max Frisch. (Renate von Mangoldt)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TITLE: I'M NOT STILLER (BOOK)

PERSON: JEFFERSON, MARGO; FRISCH, MAX MAX FRISCH (94%); 

LOAD-DATE: August 17, 1994
